titre: Politics Briefing: Ontario Liberals aim to rein in housing prices in election platform
texte: Hello, An Ontario Liberal government would reinstate rent control, create a new tax on vacant homes in urban areas across the province and charge speculators who keep approved housing projects idle – a levy meant to spur them to build. The new policy proposals are contained in Liberal Leader Steven Del Duca’s platform document, released Monday, which includes costing details and also pledges billions in new spending. All of the main political parties competing for votes in Ontario’s June 2 election have made runaway real estate prices a key issue, as many worry most in younger generations will be shut out of home ownership. | Del Duca said the rent control measures would apply to all private rental units, including those built after November 2018, when the previous Liberal government brought in a law that exempted new builds from rent control. The Liberals are also proposing a new tax on vacant homes in urban areas, which they say will help free up housing stock and reduce speculation. The tax would be based on the assessed value of the property and would be collected by municipalities. The party is also proposing a levy on developers who keep approved housing projects idle. The levy would be based on the value of the land and would be collected by the province. The platform also includes a pledge to invest $2.3 billion over 10 years to build 40,000 new affordable housing units and repair existing ones. The party says it will also invest $1.3 billion over 10 years to create a new housing supply action plan. The Liberals are also proposing a new tax credit for first-time homebuyers, which would provide up to $4,000 a year for five years to help with the costs of buying a home. The party is also pledging to invest $2.2 billion over 10 years to build and repair child care spaces, and to create a new tax credit for employers who provide child care benefits to their employees. Del Duca said the platform is focused on making life more affordable for Ontarians, and that the measures will help make housing more accessible and affordable. He said the measures will also help create jobs and stimulate the economy.

titre: Politics Briefing: Senators call for exoneration of 12 Indigenous women who endured ‘systemic inequality’ in Canada’s criminal justice system
texte: Hello, Three senators are calling for the exoneration of 12 Indigenous women they say have endured a pattern of discrimination, inequality and violence within the criminal system. The demand of Senators Dawn Anderson, Yvonne Boyer and Kim Pate, in a report released on Monday, comes as the federal government is working to overhaul its conviction review process and struggling to contain soaring rates of Indigenous incarceration. | The senators’ report, titled “Systemic Inequality: Exoneration of 12 Indigenous Women”, is based on a review of the cases of 12 Indigenous women who were wrongfully convicted or had their charges stayed or withdrawn. The report found that the women had been subjected to systemic discrimination, inequality and violence within the criminal justice system. It also found that the women had been denied access to justice, had their rights violated, and had been subjected to racism and sexism. The senators called for the exoneration of the 12 women, noting that the exoneration process should be “swift and transparent”. They also called for the government to take steps to ensure that Indigenous people are not subjected to systemic discrimination in the criminal justice system. The senators also called for the government to implement a “comprehensive review” of the criminal justice system to identify and address systemic discrimination and inequality. They also called for the government to provide “adequate and appropriate” resources to Indigenous communities to ensure that they have access to justice. The report comes as the federal government is working to overhaul its conviction review process and struggling to contain soaring rates of Indigenous incarceration. The government has committed to implementing the recommendations of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which called for the exoneration of Indigenous people who have been wrongfully convicted. The senators’ report is the latest in a series of calls for the government to take action to address systemic discrimination and inequality in the criminal justice system. In recent years, Indigenous leaders, activists and organizations have called for the government to take steps to address the over-representation of Indigenous people in the criminal justice system. The senators’ report is a reminder that the government must take action to address systemic discrimination and inequality in the criminal justice system. It is also a reminder that the government must take steps to ensure that Indigenous people have access to justice and are not subjected to systemic discrimination.

titre: Politics Briefing: Bank of Canada hikes interest rates by another half percentage point, says it is ready ‘to act more forcefully’
texte: Hello, The Bank of Canada announced another oversized interest rate hike on Wednesday and said that it is “prepared to act more forcefully” if needed to bring inflation back under control. The central bank’s governing council voted to raise the policy rate by half a percentage point – its third interest rate hike this year. That brings the benchmark rate to 1.5 per cent, just a quarter point below the prepandemic level. The bank said that more interest rate hikes will be needed to cool Canada’s overheating economy and to slow the pace of consumer price growth, which hit a three-decade high of 6.8 per cent in April. Economics Reporter Mark Rendell reports here and also offers a Reporter’s Comment on Wednesday’s development: “The Bank of Canada’s 50-basis-point move today was widely expected by analysts and investors. What was striking was the central bank’s hawkish tone. | The Bank of Canada’s decision to raise interest rates by half a percentage point is the latest in a series of moves to rein in the country’s rapidly expanding economy. The central bank has been gradually increasing rates since the start of the year, and the latest move brings the benchmark rate to 1.5 per cent, just a quarter point below the prepandemic level. The Bank of Canada said that the rate hike was necessary to bring inflation back under control and to slow the pace of consumer price growth, which hit a three-decade high of 6.8 per cent in April. The central bank also warned that it is “prepared to act more forcefully” if needed. The Bank of Canada’s decision to raise interest rates has been met with mixed reactions from economists and investors. Some have praised the move as a necessary step to curb inflation, while others have argued that it could have a negative impact on the economy. The Bank of Canada’s decision to raise interest rates could have a significant impact on Canadians. Higher interest rates mean that borrowing costs will increase, making it more expensive for Canadians to take out loans and mortgages. It could also lead to higher costs for businesses, which could in turn lead to higher prices for consumers. The Bank of Canada’s decision to raise interest rates could also have an impact on the housing market. Higher interest rates could make it more difficult for potential homebuyers to qualify for mortgages, which could lead to a slowdown in the housing market. The Bank of Canada’s decision to raise interest rates could also have an impact on the stock market. Higher interest rates could lead to a decrease in stock prices, as investors may be less willing to take on risk in a higher interest rate environment. Overall, the Bank of Canada’s decision to raise interest rates is a sign that the central bank is taking steps to rein in the country’s rapidly expanding economy. While the move could have a negative impact on some sectors of the economy, it could also help to bring inflation back under control and to slow the pace of consumer price growth.

titre: Conservative leadership campaign in quiet phase before stepped-up competition
texte: Campaign organizers in the Conservative Party leadership race say the battle is far from over, but has entered a short lull ahead of the final “persuasion phase” that will launch this summer once they obtain the party’s final membership lists. Sections of candidates’ websites that were once full of scheduled meet-and-greet events across Canada to recruit supporters are now largely empty. Some of the candidates are spending time in their ridings, with relatively short trips to events. “The best way to describe this right now is the lull between the membership cutoff, which was June 3, and when we get the membership lists, which is projected to be in early July,” said Chris Rougier, the national manager for the campaign of former Quebec premier Jean Charest. The six candidates spent weeks roaming Canada to sign up members they hope will support them in the race to replace Erin O’Toole, voted out as leader by caucus members in February. The party has said more than 600,000 people, including current and new members, could be eligible to vote. The plan is to verify and process membership applications in coming weeks, provide a preliminary voter list for leadership campaigns, allow a challenge period, and produce a final list no later than July 29, according to a recent statement from party president Robert Batherson. Meanwhile, Mr. Rougier said in an interview, Mr. Charest is going to events he is invited to, and attending to fundraising matters. “But instead of having an aggressive, proactive, `We need to go here; we need to go here’ [approach], I would think all the campaigns are fairly reactive at this point,” he said. “If there’s events they want to attend, they feel will be of value to them, they attend. Otherwise, they focus on planning and online campaigning.” All of this comes ahead of what he and other campaign officials call the persuasion phase, using membership data to make a final, targeted pitch for support, urging the voters to make their candidate their first or second choice. “There’s a large chunk of new members who signed up during this race that we’re really eager to introduce Jean to, and to communicate with,” Mr. Rougier said. “This is about communication and trying to get messages that resonate with members and then going where they are.” Four of six Conservative leadership candidates call for third debate Conservatives investigating allegations of membership irregularities by Patrick Brown campaign The Conservatives elect leaders based on a ranked ballot and proportional representation. | The six candidates in the Conservative leadership race are now in the midst of a quiet phase before the final “persuasion phase” of the campaign begins. During this time, the candidates are focusing on fundraising and attending events they are invited to, while also planning for the upcoming persuasion phase. The party has said that more than 600,000 people, including current and new members, could be eligible to vote in the leadership race. The plan is to verify and process membership applications in the coming weeks, provide a preliminary voter list for leadership campaigns, allow a challenge period, and produce a final list no later than July 29. The candidates are now preparing for the persuasion phase, which will involve using the membership data to make a final, targeted pitch for support. This will involve introducing the candidates to new members and communicating with them in order to get messages that resonate. Meanwhile, the Conservative Party is also investigating allegations of membership irregularities by Patrick Brown’s campaign. The party has said that it is taking the allegations seriously and is looking into the matter. In addition, four of the six candidates have called for a third debate to be held before the leadership vote. The party has yet to announce whether or not it will hold a third debate. The Conservatives elect leaders based on a ranked ballot and proportional representation. This means that the candidate with the most first-choice votes will not necessarily win the leadership race. Instead, the candidate with the most points based on the ranked ballots will be declared the winner. The Conservative leadership race is far from over, and the candidates are now entering the quiet phase before the final “persuasion phase” begins. The party is currently verifying and processing membership applications, and the candidates are preparing for the upcoming persuasion phase. The outcome of the race will depend on the ranked ballots of the members, and the party is also investigating allegations of membership irregularities by Patrick Brown’s campaign. The Conservative Party has yet to announce whether or not it will hold a third debate, as four of the six candidates have called for one.

titre: Politics Briefing: B.C. Premier John Horgan announces he will be stepping down
texte: Hello, John Horgan has announced his exit as British Columbia premier. At a news conference in Vancouver, one of Canada’s highest-profile New Democrats said Tuesday afternoon that he will be standing down as leader of the British Columbia New Democrats, and has asked the party to organize a leadership convention for the fall. Mr. Horgan, who has been treated for throat cancer and said he is now cancer free after 35 treatments, said his health is good but his energy flags as the days go by. “There has been endless speculation as a result of my recent battle with cancer about what my plans would be. I want to put the speculation to rest so we can get back to what really matters, and that’s the issues before British Columbians,” he said. Mr. Horgan, a Vancouver Island member of the legislature since 2005, has been premier since 2017 after forming a minority government with support from the BC Greens, and ending 16 years of BC Liberal government. | Mr. Horgan said he was proud of the accomplishments of his government, including the introduction of a $10-a-day child-care program, the creation of a $400-a-year renters' rebate, and the implementation of a $400-million COVID-19 relief package. He also noted the province's success in managing the pandemic, with the lowest per capita rate of COVID-19 cases in Canada. “I am proud of the work we have done together,” he said. “We have made life better for people in British Columbia.” The premier said he will remain in office until the party chooses a new leader, and he will continue to serve as an MLA until the next election. He said he will work with the party to ensure a smooth transition. “I am confident that the party will choose a leader who will continue to build on the progress we have made,” he said. The BC NDP will now begin the process of selecting a new leader. The party will hold a leadership convention in the fall, with the date to be determined. The BC Liberals, meanwhile, said they are ready to face the NDP in the next election. “We are ready to take on the NDP and their record of higher taxes, higher debt, and higher unemployment,” said BC Liberal leader Andrew Wilkinson. The BC Greens said they are sad to see Mr. Horgan go, but they are looking forward to the next election. “We are ready to take on the BC Liberals and their record of mismanagement and scandal,” said BC Green leader Sonia Furstenau. The political landscape in British Columbia is now set for a major shift, as the province prepares for a new leader and a new election.

titre: Politics Briefing: Foreign Affairs Minister Mélanie Joly ready to counter disinformation from Russia at G20 meeting, office says
texte: Hello, Foreign Affairs Minister Mélanie Joly is ready to counter Russian commentary at this week’s G20 foreign ministers meeting in Indonesia, her office says. Ms. Joly will be travelling to Bali for the July 7-8 meeting of the countries, which collectively represent 80 per cent of the world’s economic output and two-thirds of the world’s population. Russia is among the members of the G20 whose members include Argentina, Brazil, China, the European Union, France, Germany, and Japan, and its foreign minister Sergey Lavrov is expected at the meeting, which comes amidst Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. “Canada must show up to call out Russia on its lies and, with our like-minded partners, provide solutions to address Russia’s weaponization of food and other challenges such as climate change and the COVID-19 pandemic,” Ms. Joly said in a statement issued by her office. The statement said Ms. Joly would also be looking to “directly counter disinformation from representatives of the Russian regime, which has come to be expected in such multilateral forums. | Ms. Joly's office said she will be looking to “directly counter disinformation from representatives of the Russian regime” and “call out Russia on its lies”. She will also be looking to “provide solutions to address Russia’s weaponization of food and other challenges such as climate change and the COVID-19 pandemic”. The statement also said that Ms. Joly will be looking to “strengthen the rules-based international order” and “promote the values of democracy, human rights, and the rule of law”. Ms. Joly has been vocal in her criticism of Russia’s actions in Ukraine and has been a strong advocate for the rights of the Ukrainian people. She has also been a vocal critic of Russia’s interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Ms. Joly’s office said that she will be looking to “engage in meaningful dialogue” with her counterparts at the G20 meeting and “work together to find solutions to the challenges facing the world today”. The G20 meeting is an important opportunity for Canada to demonstrate its commitment to a rules-based international order and to stand up for the values of democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. Ms. Joly’s presence at the meeting is a strong signal that Canada is ready to take a leadership role in countering Russian disinformation and promoting a rules-based international order.

titre: Politics Briefing: Parliamentary hearings to probe Canada’s decision to repair Russian pipeline turbines despite sanctions
texte: Hello, A senior parliamentary committee has voted to hold hearings on the federal government’s decision to import and repair Russian government-owned turbines for up to two years in circumvention of its own sanctions against Moscow. Members of the House of Commons standing committee on foreign affairs and international development voted unanimously Friday to call Foreign Affairs Minister Mélanie Joly and others to explain the government’s conduct. A committee motion passed Friday seeks to have Ms. Joly and other ministers including Natural Resources Minister Jonathan Wilkinson appear before MPs by July 22. | The decision to repair the Russian turbines has been met with criticism from opposition parties, who have accused the government of undermining its own sanctions against Moscow. The government has defended its decision, saying it was necessary to ensure the safety of Canadians and to protect the environment. The government has said that the turbines were imported and repaired in order to prevent a potential environmental disaster, as the turbines were in danger of failing and releasing hazardous materials into the environment. The government has also said that the turbines were repaired in Canada, and that no Canadian workers were sent to Russia to do the repairs. The government has also said that the repairs were done in accordance with the sanctions imposed by the Canadian government, and that the repairs were done in a way that did not violate the sanctions. The opposition parties have argued that the government should have found an alternative way to repair the turbines, and that the government should have been more transparent about its decision. The opposition parties have also argued that the government should have consulted with the public before making the decision to repair the turbines. The government has said that it consulted with experts and stakeholders before making the decision, and that it was the best decision for the safety of Canadians and the environment. The parliamentary hearings will provide an opportunity for the government to explain its decision and to answer questions from MPs. The hearings will also provide an opportunity for opposition parties to question the government on its decision and to make their case for why the government should have taken a different approach. The hearings will be an important opportunity for the government to explain its decision and to answer questions from MPs. It will also be an important opportunity for the opposition parties to make their case for why the government should have taken a different approach.

titre: Politics Briefing: Ukraine and Russia sign landmark grain export deal, Trudeau says Canada has ‘zero confidence’ in Russia’s reliability
texte: Hello, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says Canada has “zero confidence” in Russia’s reliability but will do what it can to nudge along a deal signed between Russia and Ukraine to reopen Ukrainian Black Sea ports for grain exports. Of Russia, Mr. Trudeau said on Friday that the country has precipitated global crises in energy and food with their invasion of Ukraine. “The reality is we have zero confidence in Russia. I have no confidence in Mr. Putin even when it comes to resolving this issue and the issue, particularly, of food insecurity around the world,” Mr. Trudeau told a news conference in Prince Edward Island. He added, “The G7 is working closely with partners like Turkey and others to ensure that we can get that grain out of Ukraine and to places around the world where it’s needed without putting at risk Ukraine’s sovereignty and protection.” The Prime Minister said Canada has relevant experience to bring to talks on the matter. “On grain, I can tell you that it’s an issue that Canada, with a significant amount of expertise in grain and grain shipping, has been directly engaged in with partners around the world for many, many months now. | The deal, which was signed on Thursday, will allow Ukraine to export grain to Russia and other countries through the Black Sea ports. This is a major breakthrough for Ukraine, which has been struggling to export its grain since the Russian invasion in 2014. The agreement is a positive step forward for Ukraine, but Mr. Trudeau said Canada will remain vigilant in ensuring that Russia does not use the deal to further its own interests. “We will be watching very closely to make sure that Russia does not use this agreement to further its own interests,” he said. The Prime Minister also said that Canada will continue to work with its allies to ensure that Ukraine’s sovereignty is respected. “We will continue to work with our allies to ensure that Ukraine’s sovereignty is respected and that the agreement is implemented in a way that is beneficial to Ukraine,” he said. Mr. Trudeau also noted that Canada is committed to helping Ukraine in its efforts to rebuild its economy and ensure food security. “Canada is committed to helping Ukraine rebuild its economy and ensure food security for its people,” he said. The Prime Minister said that Canada will continue to work with its allies to ensure that the agreement is implemented in a way that is beneficial to Ukraine. He also said that Canada will continue to support Ukraine in its efforts to rebuild its economy and ensure food security.

titre: Politics Briefing: Russian aggression and climate change are changing Arctic dynamics, PM and NATO Secretary General say
texte: Hello, Climate change and recent Russian aggression have fundamentally changed the nexus of security in the Arctic, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg emphasized during a press conference Friday at a Royal Canadian Air Force base about 300 kilometres northeast of Edmonton. The stop at 4 Wing Cold Lake comes on the final day of Mr. Stoltenberg’s three-day tour to Canada, which has largely focused on Arctic security. In his remarks Friday, Mr. Stoltenberg said that Russia has set up a new Arctic command, opening hundreds of new and former Soviet-era military sites, including airfields and deepwater ports, and is using the region as a “test-bed” for new weapon systems. The NATO Secretary General also said that with climate change, the importance of the high north is increasing – as melting Arctic ice leads to greater military and economic accessibility of the region. “Our response is a strong and predictable Allied presence in the region,” he said. The two leaders highlighted recent announcements about Canada’s defence efforts in the North, but no major new initiatives were announced at the press conference. | Mr. Trudeau said that Canada is committed to defending its sovereignty in the Arctic, and that the country is “working with our allies to ensure that the Arctic remains a region of peace, stability, and cooperation.” He noted that Canada has increased its presence in the region, including the deployment of a new Arctic and Offshore Patrol Ship, and the establishment of a new Canadian Armed Forces Arctic Training Centre. Mr. Stoltenberg praised Canada’s efforts, saying that “NATO is grateful for Canada’s leadership in the Arctic.” He also noted that NATO is working to strengthen its presence in the region, and that the alliance is “working to ensure that the Arctic remains a region of peace, stability, and cooperation.” The two leaders also discussed the importance of addressing climate change in the Arctic. Mr. Trudeau said that Canada is “committed to taking action on climate change,” and that the country is “working with our allies to ensure that the Arctic remains a region of peace, stability, and cooperation.” Mr. Stoltenberg echoed this sentiment, saying that “NATO is committed to addressing the effects of climate change in the Arctic, and to ensuring that the region remains a region of peace, stability, and cooperation.” The two leaders concluded their remarks by emphasizing the importance of working together to ensure the security of the Arctic region. Mr. Trudeau said that “Canada is committed to working with our allies to ensure that the Arctic remains a region of peace, stability, and cooperation,” while Mr. Stoltenberg said that “NATO is committed to working with Canada and our other allies to ensure that the Arctic remains a region of peace, stability, and cooperation.”

titre: Politics Briefing: Trudeau had ‘epic battle’ with former finance minister over budget spending, new book says
texte: Hello, A new book reveals that former finance minister Bill Morneau wanted to break a 2015 Liberal campaign promise to keep Old Age Security eligibility at 65, rather than raising it to 67, out of concern for the huge cost the policy would have on federal finances. Former Prime Minister Stephen Harper first announced at the World Economic Forum in January 2012 that his government intended to raise the eligibility age for OAS. His government’s budget of that year announced that this would be implemented gradually between 2023 and 2029. The 2012 Conservative budget said the change was necessary because OAS is the federal government’s single, largest program and it needed to be adjusted to account for the fact that Canadians are living longer and healthier lives. | The Liberal Party, led by Justin Trudeau, campaigned on a promise to keep the eligibility age for Old Age Security at 65, and Trudeau was determined to keep that promise. According to the new book, Trudeau and Morneau had an “epic battle” over the issue, with Trudeau insisting that the promise be kept and Morneau arguing that the cost of doing so would be too high. The book claims that Trudeau was adamant that the promise be kept, and that he was willing to make cuts elsewhere in the budget to make up for the cost of keeping the eligibility age at 65. Morneau, however, argued that the cost would be too high and that the government should consider raising the eligibility age to 67. Ultimately, Trudeau won the battle and the Liberal government kept its promise to keep the eligibility age at 65. The book claims that Trudeau’s victory was a testament to his determination and his commitment to keeping his campaign promises. The book also claims that Trudeau’s victory was a victory for Canadians, as it ensured that seniors would not have to wait two extra years to receive their Old Age Security benefits. It also ensured that the government would not have to make cuts to other programs in order to pay for the cost of keeping the eligibility age at 65.

titre: Politics Briefing: PM and new Conservative leader spar in separate speeches
texte: Hello, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Pierre Poilievre, the newly elected leader of the federal Conservative party, sparred from afar on Monday, positioning themselves for the battle ahead to win the support of Canadians. In Ottawa, Mr. Polievre used his first speech to the national caucus of the Conservative party - a mix of MPs and senators - to call for a freeze on tax hikes affecting workers and seniors. “I am issuing a challenge to Justin Trudeau today. If you really understand the suffering of Canadians, Mr. Prime Minister. If you understand that people can’t gas their cars, feed their families or afford homes for themselves; if you really care, commit today that there will be no new tax increases on workers and on seniors. None,” Mr. Poilievre told caucus members. The Ottawa-area MP said the Conservatives will work with any party on advancing the interests of Canadians, but said the Official Opposition would not support any new tax increases. “And we will fight tooth and nail to stop the coalition from introducing any,” he said, referring to the New Democratic Party and Liberals. The NDP is supporting the Liberals in Parliament in return for action by the government on NDP priorities such as pharmacare and a dental program. However, the agreement is not a coalition. At a federal Liberal retreat in St. Andrews, N.B., Mr. Trudeau congratulated Mr. Poilievre on winning the leadership, but made it clear he will challenge his rival’s political positions. “We’ve been making every effort to work with all parliamentarians and we will continue to do so, but this doesn’t mean that we’re not going to be calling out highly questionable reckless, economic ideas,” Mr. Trudeau said. | The Prime Minister went on to criticize the Conservative leader's proposed tax freeze, saying it would be irresponsible and would not help Canadians in the long run. He argued that the government's current fiscal policies are helping to create jobs and stimulate the economy. "We have to make sure that we are investing in Canadians and in our economy, not just cutting taxes," he said. "We need to make sure that we are creating jobs and growing the economy, not just cutting taxes." Mr. Trudeau also took aim at the Conservative leader's stance on climate change, saying that the party's policies are out of step with the majority of Canadians. "We need to make sure that we are taking action on climate change, not just talking about it," he said. "We need to make sure that we are investing in renewable energy and green technology, not just cutting taxes." The Prime Minister also highlighted the government's record on helping Canadians, pointing to the Canada Child Benefit, the Canada Pension Plan, and the new Canada Emergency Response Benefit as examples of how the government is helping Canadians during the pandemic. "We are doing everything we can to help Canadians during this difficult time," he said. "We are investing in Canadians and in our economy, not just cutting taxes." The Prime Minister's comments come as the Conservative party is preparing to launch its election campaign, and as the government is preparing to introduce its 2021 budget. It is expected that the budget will include measures to help Canadians recover from the economic impacts of the pandemic. The sparring between the Prime Minister and the Conservative leader is likely to continue in the coming weeks and months as the two parties prepare for the next federal election.

titre: Politics Briefing: Advancing use of French in Quebec will be a key priority in second term, Legault says
texte: Hello, François Legault, who has led his Coalition Avenir Québec to a second term governing Quebec, says one of his key priorities going forward is to continue defending and advancing the use of French in the province. On Tuesday, the afternoon after the election, Mr. Legault said he had already made his case on the priority to his national counterpart. “Justin Trudeau called me to congratulate me so I took advantage of the occasion to say that my priority in my discussions with him will be to see how we can protect and promote French and stop the decline of French in Quebec and he seemed open to working on that,” Mr. Legault said during a news conference in the Quebec City-area Island of Orleans. The Quebec government has faced criticism from the province’s English-speaking community for Bill 96, which bolsters the use of French in the public service, education and business in the service of Mr. Legault’s view that French is on the decline in the province. | Mr. Legault has long been a proponent of protecting and promoting the French language in Quebec, and has made it a priority of his government since taking office in 2018. He has also been vocal about the need to ensure that French is the language of work in the province, and has proposed legislation to that effect. The CAQ government has also taken steps to ensure that French is the language of instruction in Quebec schools. The government has implemented a policy that requires all students to take French classes from kindergarten to Grade 11, and has also introduced a new French-language curriculum for elementary and secondary schools. The CAQ government has also proposed legislation that would require businesses in Quebec to use French in their signage and advertising. The legislation, which is currently being debated in the National Assembly, would also require businesses to provide services in French. Mr. Legault has also proposed a new law that would require all immigrants to Quebec to pass a French-language test before they can become permanent residents. The proposed law has been met with criticism from some immigrant groups, who argue that it would make it more difficult for immigrants to integrate into Quebec society. Mr. Legault has also promised to increase funding for French-language services in the province, including for French-language health care and education. He has also promised to increase funding for French-language cultural organizations, such as museums and theatres. Mr. Legault has also promised to increase the number of French-language radio and television stations in the province, and to create a new French-language television network. He has also promised to create a new French-language university in Quebec.

titre: Politics Briefing: Ontario acts with legislation in attempt to avert strike by education workers
texte: Hello, The Ontario government introduced back-to-work legislation on Monday to avert a strike by the province’s 55,000 education workers. Education Minister Stephen Lecce said the government had “no other choice” because it didn’t want classes shuttered and the union had not withdrawn its intent to strike, which would start Friday. “If we do not act today with legislation, schools will close on Friday,” Mr. Lecce told a news conference. “To us, the choice is clear. We are acting decisively in the defence of students so these kids can finally maintain stability and learn and grow after the last difficult years. “The goverment has been left with no choice, but to take immediate action today.” The government would impose a contract on the union. The Canadian Union of Public Employees said Monday its approximately 55,000 education workers will stage a provincewide protest Friday, meaning they will be off the job despite the government’s legislation. titre: Politics Briefing: BoC’s Tiff Macklem says unemployment needs to rise in order to slow inflation
texte: Hello, Bank of Canada Governor Tiff Macklem says unemployment needs to rise in order to slow down inflation, although elevated levels of job vacancies could soften the blow. In a speech in Toronto hosted by the Public Policy Forum, Mr. Macklem said on Thursday that Canada’s labour market is overheating. This is feeding through into inflation, as companies bid up wages to compete for employees. “We need to rebalance the labour market,” Mr. Macklem said. “This will be a difficult adjustment. | He noted that the Bank of Canada’s (BoC) latest projections show that the economy is expected to grow faster than potential in the second half of 2021, and that the unemployment rate is expected to remain below its pre-pandemic level. Mr. Macklem said that the BoC is prepared to take action if needed to ensure that inflation remains in check. He noted that the BoC’s monetary policy framework is designed to keep inflation at the 2% target over the medium term. “We will be prepared to adjust our policy stance if needed to ensure that inflation remains on target,” he said. Mr. Macklem said that the BoC is monitoring the labour market closely and that it is prepared to adjust its policy stance if needed. He noted that the BoC is also monitoring the impact of the pandemic on the labour market, and that it is prepared to take action if needed to ensure that the labour market remains healthy. He added that the BoC is also monitoring the impact of the pandemic on the housing market, and that it is prepared to take action if needed to ensure that the housing market remains stable. Mr. Macklem said that the BoC is committed to ensuring that the Canadian economy remains resilient and that it is prepared to take action if needed to ensure that the economy remains on track. He noted that the BoC is also committed to ensuring that the Canadian economy remains competitive and that it is prepared to take action if needed to ensure that the economy remains competitive.

titre: Politics Briefing: Jim Carr, former Liberal cabinet minister and Winnipeg MP, has died
texte: Hello, Former federal cabinet minister Jim Carr, the Liberal MP for Winnipeg South since 2015, has died a week after he saw the passage of a private members’ bill he had advanced. There were gasps of surprise in the House of Commons at news of Mr. Carr’s passing, announced on Monday afternoon by Kevin Lamoureux, the Liberal MP for Winnipeg North. That was followed by a moment of silence for 71-year-old Mr. Carr, who served as natural resources minister and international trade diversification minister until stepping down from that post in 2019 after a diagnosis of multiple myeloma. And then, by unanimous consent, and in Mr. Carr’s memory, the Speaker adjourned the House until Tuesday at 10 a.m. Following the diagnosis of his illness the day after being re-elected in 2019, Mr. Carr accepted a role as the Prime Minister’s special representative for the Prairies. For much of that time he was also a minister without portfolio. Mr. Carr’s family issued a statement on Monday afternoon, saying he had died at home, surrounded by his family and loved ones They said he had been battling multiple myeloma and kidney failure since 2019, which included receiving dialysis treatments, chemotherapy and a bone marrow transplant. Mr. Carr’s family also said he was pleased that his private member’s Bill C-235 - Building a Green Prairie Economy had passed in the House of Commons on Dec. | Mr. Carr was a passionate advocate for the environment and was a strong supporter of the green economy. He was a vocal proponent of the need to transition to a low-carbon economy and was a leader in the development of green energy initiatives. He was also a strong advocate for Indigenous rights and was a key figure in the development of the Indigenous-led clean energy projects. Mr. Carr was a beloved figure in his home province of Manitoba and was a tireless advocate for the people of Winnipeg South. He was a passionate advocate for the city and was a strong supporter of local businesses and initiatives. He was also a strong advocate for the arts and culture in the city and was a key figure in the development of the Winnipeg Art Gallery. Mr. Carr was a respected figure in the Liberal Party and was a key figure in the development of the party's platform. He was a strong advocate for the party's progressive policies and was a key figure in the development of the party's environmental policies. He was also a strong advocate for the party's commitment to diversity and inclusion and was a key figure in the development of the party's policies on Indigenous rights. Mr. Carr was a beloved figure in the House of Commons and was a respected figure among his colleagues. He was a passionate advocate for the people of Canada and was a strong supporter of the country's democratic institutions. He was also a strong advocate for the rights of all Canadians and was a key figure in the development of the country's human rights policies. Mr. Carr will be remembered as a passionate advocate for the people of Canada and a tireless champion of the environment. He was a beloved figure in his home province of Manitoba and a respected figure in the House of Commons. He will be remembered as a strong advocate for the rights of all Canadians and a key figure in the development of the country's progressive policies.

titre: Politics Briefing: ‘Significant progress’ in funding talks raises Health Minister’s hopes
texte: Hello, Federal Health Minister Jean-Yves Duclos says Ottawa and the provinces and territories have made “significant progress” on a multi-billion-dollar health care funding deal and he’s optimistic an agreement can be unveiled at the first ministers meeting within weeks. “We are confident we are going to get to a good place. I am personally very optimistic and I am looking forward to significant and positive developments in the weeks ahead,” Mr. Duclos told a news conference on Friday. Mr. Duclos was responding to a report in The Globe and Mail that Ottawa and the provinces and territories are inching closer toward a 10-year funding deal that would provide a hefty increase in federal health transfers, along with bilateral financial agreements in areas such as long-term care. | The federal government has been in talks with the provinces and territories for months to reach a new health care funding agreement. The current agreement, which was signed in 2004, is set to expire in 2024. The new agreement is expected to provide a significant increase in federal health transfers, as well as bilateral financial agreements in areas such as long-term care. The Globe and Mail reported that the deal could be worth between $15 billion and $25 billion over 10 years. Mr. Duclos said the two sides have made “significant progress” in the negotiations and he is optimistic that an agreement can be reached in time for the first ministers meeting in the coming weeks. The federal government has been pushing for a new agreement that would provide more money for home care and mental health services, as well as a new funding formula that would take into account the needs of each province and territory. The provinces and territories, meanwhile, have been pushing for more money for long-term care and a greater say in how the money is spent. The two sides have yet to reach an agreement on the details of the deal, but Mr. Duclos said he is hopeful that a deal can be reached soon. “We are confident we are going to get to a good place. I am personally very optimistic and I am looking forward to significant and positive developments in the weeks ahead,” he said.

titre: Politics Briefing: Canada’s anti-Islamophobia representative apologizes for comments about Quebec
texte: Hello, Canada’s new representative for combating Islamophobia has apologized for comments that have caused controversy in Quebec. “I understand that the words and the way that I have said them have hurt people,” Amira Elghawaby, speaking in English, told journalists ahead of a meeting with Bloc Québécois Leader Yves-François Blanchet on Wednesday. “I am listening very carefully. I have heard you. And I know what you are feeling and I am sorry.” Multiple politicians in Quebec have called for Ms. Elghawaby’s appointment by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to be rescinded because of comments she made in 2019 opinion piece she co-authored. The column cited polling data to say that “a majority of Quebecers” who supported Bill 21 also held anti-Muslim views. Earlier this week, Quebec Premier François Legault said Mr. Trudeau is endorsing the contempt she has shown for Quebec by keeping Ms. Elghawaby in her position. Members of the Quebec National Assembly also adopted a motion calling on Ottawa to put an end to her contract immediately. Story here from The Montreal Gazette. | Ms. Elghawaby, who is also the communications director for the National Council of Canadian Muslims, said she was “deeply sorry” for the comments she made in the opinion piece. She said she was “truly sorry” for the hurt she had caused and that she was “committed to learning from this experience.” Ms. Elghawaby said she was “committed to working with all Canadians, including Quebecers, to combat Islamophobia and all forms of racism and discrimination.” She said she was “committed to listening to the concerns of all Canadians and to working together to build a more inclusive and equitable society.” Mr. Blanchet said he accepted Ms. Elghawaby’s apology and that he was “pleased to have had the opportunity to discuss the issue with her.” He said he was “committed to working with her to combat Islamophobia and all forms of racism and discrimination.” The controversy over Ms. Elghawaby’s comments has sparked a debate about the role of the federal government in Quebec. Some have argued that the federal government should not be interfering in Quebec’s affairs, while others have argued that the federal government has a responsibility to combat racism and discrimination in all parts of the country. The Prime Minister’s Office has said that Ms. Elghawaby’s appointment was made in consultation with the Quebec government and that she is “well-suited to the role.” The office has also said that the government is “committed to working with all Canadians, including Quebecers, to combat Islamophobia and all forms of racism and discrimination.” The controversy over Ms. Elghawaby’s comments has highlighted the need for a national conversation about racism and discrimination in Canada. It has also highlighted the need for a better understanding of the issues facing Muslim Canadians and other minority groups in Canada.

titre: Politics Briefing: Prime Minister Trudeau welcomes news that Pope Francis will visit Canada
texte: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau welcomed news that Pope Francis will visit Canada in July. The visit will be the first papal visit to Canada since Pope John Paul II visited in 1984. The visit will be a historic occasion for Canada, and Trudeau expressed his excitement in a statement. “We are honoured to welcome Pope Francis to Canada this summer,” he said. “His visit will be an opportunity to celebrate the values that Canadians hold dear, and to reflect on how we can work together to build a better world.” The Pope’s visit will include stops in Toronto, Montreal, and Quebec City. He will meet with Indigenous leaders, visit a refugee centre, and celebrate Mass in each city. Trudeau said he looks forward to the Pope’s message of peace and inclusion. The Pope’s visit comes at a time when Canada is facing a number of challenges, including the ongoing opioid crisis, the rise of hate crimes, and the need to address climate change. Trudeau said he hopes the Pope’s visit will help to bring attention to these issues and inspire Canadians to work together to find solutions. The Pope’s visit will also be an opportunity to celebrate the diversity of Canada’s population. Trudeau said he looks forward to welcoming the Pope to Canada and to hearing his message of inclusion and understanding. The Pope’s visit will be a significant event for Canada, and Trudeau said he is looking forward to the visit. “I am confident that Pope Francis’ visit will be a source of inspiration and hope for all Canadians,” he said. “We look forward to welcoming him to Canada and to hearing his message of peace and understanding.”

titre: Virtual work reportedly the cause of tinnitus and other health problems for parliamentary interpreters
texte: Parliamentary interpreters in Canada are facing a growing health crisis due to the increased use of virtual work. The interpreters, who are responsible for translating parliamentary proceedings into both official languages, are reporting an increase in tinnitus and other health problems due to the long hours of virtual work. The interpreters, who are employed by the House of Commons, have been working virtually since the pandemic began in March 2020. The interpreters are required to wear headphones for long periods of time, which can cause hearing damage and tinnitus. The interpreters also report feeling fatigued and stressed due to the long hours of virtual work. The interpreters are calling on the House of Commons to take action to protect their health. They are asking for better ergonomic equipment, such as adjustable chairs and headsets, as well as more breaks during virtual sessions. They are also asking for more support from the House of Commons in terms of mental health services and access to medical professionals. The interpreters are also calling for more flexibility in their work schedules. They are asking for more flexibility in terms of when they can work, as well as the ability to take breaks during virtual sessions. They are also asking for more support from the House of Commons in terms of mental health services and access to medical professionals. The interpreters are also asking for better compensation for their work. They are asking for a raise in their salaries, as well as better benefits and vacation time. The House of Commons has yet to respond to the interpreters’ demands. However, the House of Commons has recently announced that it is looking into the issue and is working on a plan to address the health concerns of the interpreters. The interpreters’ plight is a reminder of the importance of taking care of the health and safety of workers in the virtual workplace. As more and more people are working virtually, it is essential that employers take steps to ensure that their employees are safe and healthy. The interpreters’ demands are a reminder that virtual work can have serious health consequences if not properly managed.

titre: Politics Briefing: Conservative Party says it has 678,708 members, record for Canadian political party
texte: The Conservative Party of Canada has announced that it has reached a record-breaking 678,708 members, making it the largest political party in the country. titre: Politics Briefing: Ottawa to use regulation to ban handgun imports in two weeks
texte: The federal government is set to introduce new regulations to ban the importation of handguns into Canada in two weeks. The move comes as part of the government's efforts to tackle gun violence in the country. The regulations will be introduced in the coming weeks and will be in effect immediately. The regulations will apply to all handguns imported into Canada, including those imported for recreational use. The government is also looking at ways to restrict the sale of handguns within Canada. The move is part of a broader effort by the government to address gun violence in Canada. The government has already taken steps to strengthen background checks for gun purchases, and has introduced legislation to ban certain types of military-style assault weapons. The government has also announced plans to invest $214 million over five years to support community-based initiatives to reduce gun violence. This includes funding for programs to help young people stay away from guns, as well as initiatives to help victims of gun violence. The government has also announced plans to create a new firearms advisory committee, which will provide advice on how to reduce gun violence in Canada. The committee will be made up of experts from a variety of backgrounds, including law enforcement, public health, and community organizations. The government's move to ban the importation of handguns is seen as a positive step in the fight against gun violence. However, some critics have argued that the regulations will not be effective in reducing gun violence, as criminals will still be able to access guns through the black market. The government has also faced criticism for not doing enough to address the root causes of gun violence, such as poverty and mental health issues. Critics have argued that the government should focus on addressing these issues, rather than simply banning handguns. The government's move to ban the importation of handguns is seen as a positive step in the fight against gun violence. titre: Politics Briefing: Indigenous teen and water activist Autumn Peltier says Trudeau must do more toward reconciliation
texte: Autumn Peltier, a 15-year-old Indigenous water activist from Wikwemikong First Nation, is calling on Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to do more to advance reconciliation with Indigenous peoples. Peltier, who has been advocating for clean water since she was 8 years old, has been a vocal critic of the Trudeau government’s approach to Indigenous issues. She has spoken out against the government’s failure to implement the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP) and its lack of action on the 94 Calls to Action of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. At a recent press conference, Peltier said that Trudeau’s government has not done enough to address the issues facing Indigenous peoples. “We need to see real action,” she said. “We need to see the government taking concrete steps to address the systemic racism and discrimination that Indigenous peoples face.” Peltier has been a vocal advocate for Indigenous rights and has been a frequent presence at protests and rallies. She has also been a vocal critic of the Trudeau government’s handling of the Trans Mountain Pipeline expansion project, which she says will have a devastating impact on Indigenous communities. Peltier has also been a vocal advocate for the protection of Indigenous lands and waters. She has spoken out against the government’s failure to protect the rights of Indigenous peoples to their traditional lands and waters. Peltier has been a frequent presence at the United Nations, where she has spoken out against the government’s failure to implement UNDRIP. She has also been a vocal critic of the government’s failure to implement the recommendations of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Peltier’s activism has earned her recognition from around the world. She was recently named one of the BBC’s 100 Women of 2018 and was also named one of Canada’s Top 25 Environmentalists Under 25. Peltier’s message to Trudeau is clear: “We need to see real action. We need to see the government taking concrete steps to address the systemic racism and discrimination that Indigenous peoples face. We need to see the government implementing the recommendations of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission and the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.” Peltier’s message is resonating with many Canadians, who are calling on the Trudeau government to do more to advance reconciliation with Indigenous peoples. The Trudeau government has taken some steps to address the issues facing Indigenous peoples, such as the creation of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls and the introduction of the Indigenous Languages Act. However, many Indigenous activists and leaders say that much more needs to be done. The Trudeau government has also committed to implementing UNDRIP, but has yet to take concrete steps to do so. As Peltier and other Indigenous activists continue to call on the Trudeau government to do more to advance reconciliation, it remains to be seen whether the government will take meaningful action.

titre: Politics Briefing: Alberta to take control of prosecutions for banned firearms from Ottawa, provincial justice minister says
texte: Alberta's Justice Minister, Kaycee Madu, announced on Tuesday that the province will take control of prosecutions for banned firearms from the federal government. titre: Politics Briefing: Trudeau calls ArriveCan subcontracts through two-person firm ‘illogical,’ asks Privy Council Clerk to review
texte: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has called the awarding of contracts to a two-person firm for the ArriveCan app “illogical” and has asked the Privy Council Clerk to review the situation. The ArriveCan app was created to help streamline the process of entering Canada for international travelers. The app was developed by a two-person firm, which was awarded the contract to manage the app. The awarding of the contract to the two-person firm has raised eyebrows in Ottawa, with some questioning the decision. Trudeau has now weighed in on the issue, calling the awarding of the contract “illogical” and asking the Privy Council Clerk to review the situation. The Prime Minister’s Office has said that Trudeau is “concerned” about the awarding of the contract and wants to ensure that the process was “fair and transparent.” The Privy Council Clerk is the head of the federal public service and is responsible for providing advice to the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The Clerk is also responsible for ensuring that the government’s procurement processes are fair and transparent. The awarding of the contract to the two-person firm has been criticized by some, who argue that the government should have gone through a competitive bidding process. The government has defended the decision, saying that the two-person firm was the most qualified to manage the app. The government has also said that the contract was awarded in accordance with the government’s procurement policies. The Privy Council Clerk is expected to review the awarding of the contract and provide advice to the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It is unclear how long the review will take, but it is expected to be completed in the coming weeks. The awarding of the contract to the two-person firm has raised questions about the government’s procurement process and has sparked a debate about how the government should award contracts. The Prime Minister’s Office has said that Trudeau is “committed to ensuring that the government’s procurement processes are fair and transparent.” The review by the Privy Council Clerk is expected to provide clarity on the issue and help ensure that the government’s procurement processes are fair and transparent.

titre: Politics Briefing: Advance look at health care proposal would have been helpful, Manitoba Premier says
texte: Manitoba Premier Brian Pallister says he wishes he had been given an advance look at the federal government's health care proposal before it was released. The proposal, which was unveiled last week, includes a commitment to increase health care funding by $6 billion over the next five years. It also includes a plan to create a national pharmacare program and a national home care program. Pallister said he was disappointed that he wasn't given an advance look at the proposal, as he believes it would have been helpful in preparing his government for the changes. "We were not consulted on the proposal, and I think that's a mistake," Pallister said. "We should have been given an opportunity to provide input and feedback on the proposal before it was released." Pallister said he is concerned that the proposal does not address the needs of Manitobans, and that it could lead to a decrease in health care services in the province. "We need to make sure that the federal government is providing adequate funding to ensure that Manitobans have access to the health care services they need," Pallister said. Pallister said he is also concerned that the proposal does not address the issue of mental health care, which is an issue that is particularly important in Manitoba. "We need to make sure that the federal government is providing adequate funding to ensure that Manitobans have access to the mental health care services they need," Pallister said. Pallister said he is hopeful that the federal government will take his concerns into consideration and make changes to the proposal that will better meet the needs of Manitobans. "We need to make sure that the federal government is providing adequate funding to ensure that Manitobans have access to the health care services they need," Pallister said. "We need to make sure that the federal government is taking into account the unique needs of Manitobans when it comes to health care."

titre: Politics Briefing: Departing Ethics Commissioner says PM’s ethics issues have probably complicated efforts to encourage MPs to stick to the rules
texte: The departure of Canada’s Ethics Commissioner, Mario Dion, has left many wondering what the future of ethics in Canadian politics will look like. Dion, who served as the Commissioner since 2017, was responsible for overseeing the ethical conduct of public office holders, including the Prime Minister. During his tenure, Dion found Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to have violated the Conflict of Interest Act on two separate occasions. The first violation occurred in 2018 when Trudeau accepted a vacation from the Aga Khan, a registered lobbyist. The second violation occurred in 2019 when Trudeau attempted to influence the former Attorney General in the SNC-Lavalin affair. In his final report, Dion said that Trudeau’s ethical issues have likely complicated efforts to encourage MPs to stick to the rules. He noted that the Prime Minister’s actions have “undermined public confidence in the integrity of the office of the Prime Minister” and “created a perception that the rules do not apply to the Prime Minister.” Dion’s departure has raised questions about the future of ethics in Canadian politics. The Trudeau government has yet to name a replacement for Dion, and it is unclear who will take on the role. The government has also yet to address the issues raised by Dion in his final report. Trudeau has said that he takes “full responsibility” for his actions, but has not provided any concrete steps to address the issues. The lack of action has been met with criticism from opposition parties, who have accused the government of not taking ethics seriously. NDP leader Jagmeet Singh has called on the government to “take real action to restore public trust in our democracy.” The Trudeau government has also been criticized for its handling of the SNC-Lavalin affair. The scandal has raised questions about the government’s commitment to transparency and accountability. The departure of Dion has also raised questions about the future of ethics in Canadian politics. It remains to be seen who will take on the role of Ethics Commissioner and how the government will address the issues raised by Dion in his final report. In the meantime, the Trudeau government must take steps to restore public trust in the office of the Prime Minister and ensure that all public office holders are held to the highest ethical standards. Without action, the government risks further eroding public confidence in the integrity of the office of the Prime Minister and the ethical conduct of public office holders.

titre: Analysts’ forecast returns and ratings for all stocks in the S&P/TSX Composite Index
texte: After a rough start to the year, the first quarter is ending off on a positive note with strength across most sectors. Month-to-date, the S&P/TSX Composite Index is up 4.2 per cent with nine of the 11 sectors seeing gains. Leading the rally are the Materials, Energy, Health Care, Industrials and Consumer Staples sectors. Each have returns of 7 per cent or more. Given the strength in the back half of the quarter, the S&P/TSX Composite Index is now in positive territory for the year with a price return of 3.7 per cent. Year-to-date, 62 per cent of the stocks in the TSX Index have positive price returns and 34 per cent of stocks in the Index have double-digit gains. Ahead of the first quarter earnings season, which kicks off in a few weeks, here is a list of analysts’ target prices, recommendations and forecast returns for all securities in the S&P/TSX Composite Index grouped by sector and ranked according to their expected price returns (excluding dividend and distribution income). The posted target price for each security is an average of all available target prices from analysts. A target price typically reflect an expected share or unit price 12 months from now based on an analyst’s financial modelling such as a discounted cash flow model or sum-of-the-parts model. All data is as of the close on Fri. March 25. Once all companies have reported their financial results in the weeks ahead, earnings expectations, multiples and targets could be adjusted meaningfully depending on the reported earnings and management’s outlook, if provided. It’s important to note that high target prices which imply stellar returns that seem unbelievable may be just that - unrealistic. At times, when a stock price falls, analysts may maintain their bullish expectations, inflating the forecast return. In addition, an outlier (extreme target price) can skew the average target price to the upside or downside, particularly when the number of analysts covering a stock is low. Don’t let a huge projected gain lure you into a position – it is critical to look at the company and industry fundamentals.

Once all companies have reported their financial results in the weeks ahead, earnings expectations, multiples, and target prices could be adjusted meaningfully depending on the reported earnings and management’s outlook, if provided. titre: Analysts’ forecast returns and recommendations for all stocks in the S&P/TSX Composite Index
texte: The S&P/TSX Composite Index has staged an impressive comeback in the fourth-quarter, rallying 9.75 per cent as of the close on Dec. 5 with strong breadth in the market. In fact, nine of the 11 sectors have gains of 10 per cent or more quarter-to-date, led by the technology, health care, industrials, and the consumer discretionary sector with price returns of 20.3 per cent, 18.3 per cent, 13.3 per cent and 12.7 per cent, respectively. Just one sector is in negative territory – utilities- with a loss of 3.9 per cent. Give this rapid recovery in the stock market, the TSX Index is now down less than 5 per cent in 2022. According to Bloomberg, the S&P/TSX composite index is trading at a forward price-to-earnings (P/E) multiple of 12.5 times the 2023 consensus estimate – bouncing off of its 10-year low of just under 11 times set back in Oct. The Index is still trading below its 10-year historical average of 14.3 times. With the Bank of Canada hiking interest rates six times since March, the multiple compressed rapidly in 2022. At the start of the year, the S&P/TSX Composite Index was trading at nearly 15 times forward earnings. Anemic but positive earnings growth is forecast for the S&P/TSX composite index. The Street is currently expecting 2.5 per cent earnings growth in 2023. To help investors navigate this challenging market, this report includes a link to a list of analysts’ target prices, recommendations, and forecast returns for all securities in the S&P/TSX Composite Index grouped by sector and ranked according to their expected price returns (excluding dividend and distribution income). The posted target price for each security is an average of all available target prices from analysts. A target price typically reflects an expected share or unit price 12 months from now based on an analyst’s financial modelling, such as a discounted cash flow or sum-of-the-parts model. For the yield provided, Bloomberg calculates this figure by annualizing the most recent announced dividend or distribution value. It’s important to note that high target prices, which imply stellar returns that seem unbelievable may be just that - unrealistic. At times, when a stock price falls analysts may maintain their bullish expectations, inflating the forecast return. In addition, an outlier (extreme target price) can skew the average target price, to the upside or downside, particularly when the number of analysts covering a stock is low. Don’t let a huge projected gain lure you into a position – it is critical to look at the company and industry fundamentals. All data is as of the close on Monday Dec. 5, 2022.

titre: Wednesday’s TSX breakouts: A spiking cybersecurity stock to put on your radar as its share price retreats
texte: On today’s Breakouts report, there are 33 stocks on the positive breakouts list (stocks with positive price momentum), and 50 stocks are on the negative breakouts list (stocks with negative price momentum). Featured today is a newly listed stock that has more than doubled in value in just a few months – Magnet Forensics Inc. (MAGT-T). As of Sept. 14, the share price is up 183 per cent from its initial public offering price of $17. Two weeks ago, the stock appeared on the positive breakouts list when the share price closed at a record high of $64.90 on Aug. 31. Since then, however, the share price has tumbled 26 per cent (closed at $48.06 on Sept. 14). Despite this move lower, the share price remains above the target prices from all four analysts. As such, this is a stock to watch. A buying opportunity may emerge if the stock price continues to fall. A brief outline on Magnet Forensics is provided below that may serve as a springboard for further fundamental research when conducting your own due diligence. The company Waterloo, Ont.-based Magnet Forensics’ cloud-based investigation software platform analyzes data from digital sources including computers, cell phones, and servers, gathering evidence in crimes and cybercrimes. The company has a diversified customer base. As at Dec. 31, the company had more than 4,000 customers in over 90 countries, of which 65 per cent were from the public sector and 35 per cent were from the private sector. By geography, 60 per cent of the company’s clients stemmed from North America, 25 per cent from Europe, Middle East and Africa, 12 per cent in Asia-Pacific, and 3 per cent stemmed from Latin America. In 2020, the top 20 customers accounted for roughly 22 per cent of its total revenue and its largest customer represented approximately 6 per cent of total revenue. Customers include IBM, Allstate, GlaxoSmithKline, Chevron, Bank of America, the World Health Organization, Amazon, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and London’s Metropolitan Police Service (the Met). There is seasonality in the company’s operations with higher revenue generated in the second half of the year compared to the first half. Investment thesis Quarterly earnings reported Before the market opened on Aug. 10, the company reported its second-quarter financial results. Revenue was US$16.5-million, up 42 per cent year-over-year. Recurring revenue was US$13.3-million, up 72 per cent year-over-year, and represented 81 per cent of total revenue. Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) stood at US$4.4-million, unchanged from the same period last year. ARR was US$49.6-million, up 48 per cent year-over-year. That day, the share price rallied 11 per cent, and jumped a further 14 per cent the following day on high volume with over 350,000 shares traded each day. The three-month historical daily average trading volume is approximately 117,000 shares. | The company’s software platform is used to investigate a wide range of crimes, including fraud, terrorism, and child exploitation. It also provides digital forensics services to law enforcement, government agencies, and corporations. The company’s products are sold through a direct sales force, as well as through resellers and distributors. Magnet Forensics has a strong balance sheet with US$90.3-million in cash and cash equivalents as at June 30. The company has no debt. The company’s management team is led by CEO and co-founder Jad Saliba. He has been with the company since its inception in 2011. The company’s stock has been volatile since its IPO in June. The share price has been on a roller coaster ride, with the stock hitting a high of $64.90 on Aug. 31 and a low of $37.50 on Sept. 8. Analysts have a bullish outlook on the stock. The average target price is $60.50, which is 25 per cent above the current share price. The company also has a strong dividend policy, which has seen it increase its dividend for the past five consecutive years. The company's dividend yield currently stands at 4.7%, which is higher than the average dividend yield of the S&P/TSX Composite Index. The recent purchases by the directors of Algonquin Power & Utilities Corp. are a sign of confidence in the company and its future prospects. The company has a strong balance sheet, a diversified portfolio of assets, and is investing in new projects. titre: Thursday’s Insider Report: CEO invests over $3-million in this auto-parts company
texte: The auto-parts industry is a competitive one, and it takes a lot of money to stay ahead of the competition. That’s why it’s no surprise that the CEO of a major auto-parts company has recently invested over $3-million in the company. The CEO, who has been with the company for over a decade, has been a major driving force behind the company’s success. He has been instrumental in developing new products and services, as well as expanding the company’s reach into new markets. The CEO’s investment is a sign of his commitment to the company’s future. It’s also a sign of his confidence in the company’s ability to continue to grow and succeed. The investment is a major boost for the company, as it will help to fund new product development and marketing efforts. It will also help to ensure that the company remains competitive in the auto-parts industry. The CEO’s investment is also a sign of his faith in the company’s management team. He believes that the team is capable of taking the company to the next level and achieving even greater success. The CEO’s investment is a major vote of confidence in the company’s future. It’s a sign that the company is on the right track and that the CEO is willing to put his money where his mouth is. titre: Review: Megan Leavey goes beyond cheap sensationalism but meandering scenes muddle its point
texte: The real Megan Leavey won a Purple Heart for nearly being blown to smithereens with Rex, her bomb-sniffing German shepherd, during their second tour in Iraq and fought to adopt him when he could no longer serve. The movie version works best when it shows us what putting the words "woman" and "marine" together really looks like. There's no towel-snapping camaraderie for Leavey (Kate Mara); she's a loner even in the midst of her fellow soldiers. The film – the feature directorial debut for Gabriela Cowperthwaite, whose orcas-in-peril documentary, Blackfish, struck a nerve – treats the handler/dog relationship with respect, not cheap sensationalism. (Although, if a small lump doesn't rise in your throat when Rex jumps out of a moving Humvee to save Leavey, there may be something wrong with you.) Unfortunately, the film also wants to show us what happens to veterans, both human and canine, when they return home and here it loses its way. The stateside scenes meander so much, you'll find yourself in the unlikely position of wishing we were back in Iraq.

titre: A Star Is Born, Roma and the problems with thrusting non-professional actors into the spotlight
texte: I need to say up front, I admire the films I’m about to discuss. I think the filmmakers made the right casting choices, and those choices enriched their movies in the ways they’d hoped. But I’m reading a lot of praise at the moment for the brilliance of non-professional actors. Something about the breathlessness of said praise is making me question when non-professional actors are employed, and how we laud them. Every year or so, a non-professional actor catches fire. In 2013, it was Barkhad Abdi, who went from being a chauffeur with no acting aspirations to barking, “I’m the captain now,” to Tom Hanks in Captain Phillips, to being nominated for an Oscar for best supporting actor. Before reading for Precious (2009), Gabourey Sidibe was studying psychology in Brooklyn; she wound up a best-actress nominee. The same swept-off-their-feet heat happened to Keisha Castle-Hughes for Whale Rider, Quvenzhane Wallis for Beasts of the Southern Wild and the casts of American Honey and The Florida Project. This noise this year is especially loud, thanks to two performances from two very different new actors: Lady Gaga in A Star Is Born, and Yalitza Aparicio in Roma. Both are being showered with plaudits and award nominations; both are favourites to walk the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences’s red carpet in February. For Gaga, the leap isn’t so big. Like Madonna in Desperately Seeking Susan, she may be new to feature films, but she’s no stranger to performing. Aparicio is a different story. A teacher in rural Tlaxiaco, Oaxaca, Mexico, she was so unfamiliar with moviemaking that when she was auditioning, she had no idea who her director, the international superstar Alphonso Cuaron (Gravity), was; for a minute she feared the whole thing might be a human-trafficking scam. Cuaron cast her as his lead, Cleo – the devoted nanny to a posh Mexico City family – who is based on his own childhood caregiver. Now critics and audiences are going crazy for her unforced naturalism. But here are the things that give me pause. First, why do we naturally assume that a non-professional actor is going to be more “authentic” than a trained or experienced one? Isn’t all that training and experience designed to get the actor out of their own head, so they can inhabit the character? Aren’t the screenplay, the director’s notes and the actor’s own research valuable? There’s something condescending here, both to trained actors (we assume they can’t be this real) and to untrained ones (we assume their realness can’t be acting). The film business has a split personality: It’s both a liberal, inclusive place where everyone tries to do the right thing and anyone can be the next big star; and a grasping soul-suck where innocents are snapped up, drained dry and tossed aside. Again, I’m not saying that people such as Aparicio, Abdi and Sidibe shouldn’t be cast in films – on the contrary. But I do wonder if there isn’t a bit of a disconnect between these new actors and the hard, shiny world they’re suddenly pulled into. I think directors like Jonah Hill or Gus Van Sant have only good intentions when they cast real skateboarders or high-school students in their films (respectively, Mid90s and Elephant). There’s no question that the performers’ stories, dialogue and unfiltered behaviours add to the films. But I do wonder what happens to those kids after the circus moves on. Have they been given a valuable break? Have they been used? Both?
