titre: Detainee drama in China, 1960s-style: A former Globe correspondent looks back at a tense time in Beijing
texte: In the 1960s, the political climate in Beijing was tense. As a former Globe correspondent, I remember the drama that unfolded when a Canadian detainee was arrested in the Chinese capital. The detainee was a Canadian diplomat, who had been in Beijing for several months. He had been working on a project to improve relations between Canada and China. But his mission was cut short when he was arrested by Chinese authorities. The Canadian government was outraged by the arrest and demanded the detainee's immediate release. But the Chinese government refused to budge, insisting that the detainee had violated Chinese law. The Canadian government then took the extraordinary step of sending a delegation to Beijing to negotiate the detainee's release. The delegation included the Canadian ambassador to China, as well as representatives from the Canadian embassy in Beijing. The negotiations were tense and difficult. The Chinese government was adamant that the detainee had violated Chinese law and refused to budge. The Canadian delegation, however, was equally adamant that the detainee had done nothing wrong and should be released immediately. After several days of negotiations, the Chinese government finally agreed to release the detainee. He was released on the condition that he leave China immediately and never return. The detainee was eventually released and returned to Canada. But the incident left a lasting impression on me. It was a reminder of the power of the Chinese government and the lengths it was willing to go to protect its interests. It was also a reminder of the importance of diplomacy and negotiation in international relations. The Canadian government was able to secure the detainee's release through diplomatic means, rather than resorting to military force. The incident also highlighted the importance of Canada's relationship with China. Despite the tensions between the two countries, the Canadian government was able to negotiate a peaceful resolution to the incident. The incident also serves as a reminder of the importance of human rights. The Canadian government was willing to stand up for the rights of the detainee, even in the face of Chinese opposition. The incident in Beijing in the 1960s was a dramatic reminder of the power of diplomacy and negotiation in international relations. It was also a reminder of the importance of Canada's relationship with China and the importance of human rights.

titre: Guidelines to protect Quebec’s acute-care system during first wave were misunderstood, LTC inquest hears
texte: The Quebec government's guidelines to protect the province's acute-care system during the first wave of the COVID-19 pandemic were misunderstood and not followed, a long-term care (LTC) inquest heard on Tuesday. The inquest, which is looking into the deaths of 31 residents of the CHSLD Herron long-term care home in Dorval, heard from Dr. Horacio Arruda, Quebec's director of public health, who said the government's guidelines were not followed by some LTC homes. "We had guidelines that were not followed," Arruda said. "We had guidelines that were misunderstood." The guidelines, which were issued in March 2020, were meant to protect the acute-care system from being overwhelmed by COVID-19 cases. They included measures such as limiting visitors, screening staff and residents, and ensuring that staff and residents wore masks. However, the inquest heard that some LTC homes did not follow the guidelines, leading to outbreaks of the virus in the homes. "We had some homes that were not following the guidelines," Arruda said. "We had some homes that were not doing the screening, not doing the testing, not doing the isolation." The inquest also heard from Dr. Mylène Drouin, the regional director of public health for Montreal, who said that the guidelines were not always followed in the LTC homes in the region. "We had some homes that were not following the guidelines," Drouin said. "We had some homes that were not doing the screening, not doing the testing, not doing the isolation." Drouin said that the lack of compliance with the guidelines was due to a lack of resources and a lack of understanding of the guidelines. "We had some homes that were not following the guidelines because they didn't have the resources to do it," Drouin said. "We had some homes that were not following the guidelines because they didn't understand them." The inquest also heard from Dr. Richard Massé, the president of the Quebec College of Physicians, who said that the guidelines were not always followed by physicians in LTC homes. "We had some physicians who were not following the guidelines," Massé said. "We had some physicians who were not doing the screening, not doing the testing, not doing the isolation." Massé said that the lack of compliance with the guidelines was due to a lack of understanding of the guidelines and a lack of resources. "We had some physicians who were not following the guidelines because they didn't understand them," Massé said. "We had some physicians who were not following the guidelines because they didn't have the resources to do it." The inquest is expected to continue for several more weeks, and will hear from more witnesses, including family members of the victims of the CHSLD Herron outbreak. The inquest is expected to make recommendations on how to improve the safety of LTC homes in Quebec.

titre: Quebec cardinal Marc Ouellet accused of sexual assault in class-action lawsuit
texte: Cardinal Marc Ouellet, the Archbishop of Quebec City, is facing a class-action lawsuit alleging sexual assault. The lawsuit was filed in Quebec Superior Court on behalf of three anonymous plaintiffs, who allege that Ouellet sexually assaulted them when they were minors. The allegations date back to the 1970s and 1980s, when Ouellet was a priest in the Diocese of Amos, Quebec. The plaintiffs allege that Ouellet sexually assaulted them on multiple occasions, and that the abuse was enabled by the Diocese of Amos, which failed to take action against Ouellet despite knowing of the allegations. The lawsuit seeks damages for the plaintiffs, as well as a public apology from Ouellet and the Diocese of Amos. The plaintiffs are also seeking a court order requiring the Diocese of Amos to implement policies and procedures to protect children from sexual abuse. The allegations against Ouellet have sparked outrage in Quebec, with many calling for him to resign from his position as Archbishop of Quebec City. Ouellet has denied the allegations, and has refused to step down. The allegations against Ouellet come at a time when the Catholic Church in Quebec is already facing scrutiny over its handling of sexual abuse allegations. In recent years, the Church has been accused of covering up allegations of sexual abuse by priests, and of failing to take action against perpetrators. The class-action lawsuit against Ouellet is the latest in a series of legal actions taken against the Catholic Church in Quebec. In 2018, a class-action lawsuit was filed against the Archdiocese of Montreal, alleging that the Church had failed to protect children from sexual abuse. The allegations against Ouellet have also sparked a debate about the role of the Catholic Church in Quebec. Many have argued that the Church should be held accountable for its handling of sexual abuse allegations, and that it should be more transparent in its dealings with victims. The class-action lawsuit against Ouellet is ongoing, and it remains to be seen how it will be resolved. In the meantime, the allegations against Ouellet have sparked a much-needed conversation about the Catholic Church in Quebec, and the need for greater accountability and transparency.

titre: Les moments clés de l’arrestation de Mamadi Camara
texte: In an attempt to shed light on the arrest of Mamadi III Fara Camara, Le Devoir went back to the heart of that evening of January 28 by combing through the official communications of the SPVM, analyzing the comments collected by our reporter in the field on the evening of the event, as well as rereading the judicial file. Here is an overview. 16:50 Mamadi III Fara Camara is intercepted in front of 900 Cremazie West by officer Sanjay Vig for a violation of the Highway Safety Code. During the stop, Mr. Camara remained in his vehicle. 4:58-5:00 p.m. Officer Vig was assaulted. 5:00-5:05 p.m. Mamadi III Fara Camara calls 911 after witnessing the assault on Officer Vig. At the same time, Officer Vig requests backup. Within minutes, Mr. Camara encounters the first police officer to arrive on the scene. They exchanged words briefly. According to Mr. Camara's version, the officer told him that he could leave the scene. Read also SPVM blinded by tunnel vision in Camara case 5:17 p.m. Mr. Camara left the scene in his vehicle to go to his residence, which is near the crime scene. He noticed the large security perimeter. He is intercepted by police officers, arrested and handcuffed. 5:23 p.m. The SPVM reports that a police officer was shot, a version that is later revised to state that the officer has "serious injuries" to his head. 5:35 p.m. Mr. Camara is taken to the police station. Camara is taken to the police station, where he will be questioned for 4 hours. 17:53 On Twitter, "the #SPVM confirms that one of its officers was seriously injured during an intervention in the Parc-Extension sector. A police operation is underway. Further details will follow. 6:00 p.m. At the microphone of Patrick Lagacé, journalist Daniel Renaud indicates that "an individual would have been arrested in the minutes or moments that followed in the sector, but it would not be the right suspect and in any case, officially at the time we speak, the suspect and the weapon of the police officer would not have been located". 6:34 p.m. In an interview with Le Devoir, the SPVM spokesperson said: "For the moment, the information we have, around 3:50 p.m., the police officer intercepted a vehicle in front of 900 Crémazie Boulevard West. During the intervention, there was a physical altercation with the driver. During the altercation, the officer was injured, so as I speak, we are trying to determine if the officer was shot or injured during the intervention, it is to be determined. What I can tell you, though, is that the officer is currently in the hospital, he is conscious and doing well. We are still looking for the individual who was involved in the altercation with the officer in question, but at this time, it is to be determined if the officer was shot or injured during the intervention or if he fell or hit his head somewhere" "There is a report [that] he was disarmed. We're going to try to confirm [that one]." "We are looking for someone involved, there is talk of a male, but at this time there is no direction of escape or information on the vehicle in question or the person in question. Our investigators are on the scene." 6:38 p.m. On Twitter, the SPVM wrote: "MAJ injured officer on duty: this one stopped a driver in connection with a CSR violation. There was an altercation during which the officer was reportedly disarmed and injured. The #SPVM proceeded to arrest the suspect and the officer is now out of danger." In a second tweet, the SPVM wrote, "The investigation is ongoing and Major Crimes is taking charge of this one." 10 p.m. On the 10 p.m. newscast on TVA Nouvelles, reporter Félix Séguin reports that a suspect has been arrested. "He is a man in his thirties. There were contradictory versions during the evening. One believed he had been arrested, at other times, not. Finally, yes, he was intercepted by the police officers of the SPVM and I would say to you by leaving you that during all the night, in the sector of Parc-Extension, you will see police officers here ", he says.

titre: Controverse autour d’une arrestation musclée
texte: A forceful arrest that took place on Saturday in Parc Jeanne-Mance is causing controversy. Witnesses of the intervention deplore its brutality, while the Service de police de la Ville de Montréal (SPVM) justifies the punches inflicted on the suspect because he would have bitten one of the officers who tried to restrain him on the ground. A video widely shared on social networks shows five police officers trying to arrest a man, whose face can be seen a few times. Three other officers form a bubble around them. "Why are they choking him," can be heard in the footage, seconds before an officer punches him in the face. "Stop biting, stop biting," can be heard in the distance. "It was a horrible scene, I never thought I'd see that in a park in Montreal," said Leigh O'Brien, who filmed part of the intervention that took place before her eyes. The American student, who has been living in Montreal for a few months, was enjoying the beautiful weather with friends at the foot of Mount Royal when she saw the police surround the man. "I'm from the United States and, with everything that has happened in the last year, especially the death of George Floyd, it was instinctive to film because I can not explain what can justify such a use of force, "she said. Her friend, Agnes Bebon, who also witnessed the intervention, is still in shock. "What we saw shows us that police brutality is a problem here too, and I find it frightening," she says. The police were in the park to ensure that sanitary rules were respected last Saturday. In an interview with Le Devoir, the SPVM explains that the use of force was necessary after they stopped a man who was violating the municipal bylaw prohibiting the consumption of alcohol on public property. " The man refused to cooperate with police officers and adopted a fighting stance during the stop," said David Shane, spokesperson and advisor to the SPVM director's office. To avoid a bite, one of the officers used what is known in police jargon as a diversionary technique, in this case, punches. After the intervention, the man was taken to the detention center and was released on a promise to appear. He could face charges of assault and obstructing police work. He was issued a $100 ticket for violating the public consumption of alcohol by-law. Since he has not yet been formally charged, his identity has not been confirmed. On Instagram, the man thanked people who sent him messages of support and promised to provide more details about what happened soon. The man has since appeared to take part in the curfew protest on Sunday night. At the time of writing, he had not given an interview to Le Devoir. "Retired supervisor at the SPVM, Stéphane Wall analyzed the images broadcast throughout the weekend. "The use of force is never pretty," says Wall, who devoted part of his career to training on the judicious use of force. "It's important to distinguish between perception and reality. The technique used by the officers in the video occurs when there is active resistance from a suspect. The goal is to create discomfort so that he or she will allow themselves to be handcuffed," says Wall. "You don't get that far if there was no resistance," he emphasizes. This recent video proves that there is an urgent need to rethink public safety, says Marlihan Lopez, spokesperson for the Coalition to Define Police. "What concerns me is to imagine the violence they can use when there are no witnesses, if they have allowed themselves to use excessive force in front of a crowd," she notes.

titre: Mascouche: Benoît Cardinal est accusé de meurtre non prémédité
texte: It was a family "without history", at least until last Friday, when the father resigned from his position as a specialized educator at the Centre jeunesse de Laval following an "inappropriate behavior" that led to an internal investigation. A situation that would have created tensions within his couple and that would have led the man to commit the irreparable on Thursday night, killing his spouse in the presence of their six children. Arriving in the dock in a wheelchair, Benoît Cardinal was formally charged with the unpremeditated murder of his wife Jaël Cantin late Friday morning. With a blank look, the man hid his face under his long hair. During the brief hearing, he seemed to be looking for relatives, scanning the room with his eyes. The accused allegedly murdered the mother of his children in the middle of the night in their home on Chemin des Anglais. Mr. Cardinal, who was found wounded when the police arrived, would have tried to cover up his crime. He would have mentioned a break-in that went wrong. It was only at the end of the day that the theory of a marital tragedy was retained, after the police had met the six children of the couple, aged from 1 to 12 years old. The six young orphans were taken in by relatives of the family. The court prohibited the defendant from contacting nine people. "The ban on contact concerns the six children of [Mr. Cardinal], of course, as well as three witnesses in the case," said the Crown prosecutor, Valérie Michaud. Mr. Cardinal remains in custody, but could apply for release. The next hearing is scheduled for February 26 at the Joliette courthouse. Suspension and resignation Friends and neighbors are still struggling to understand what could have happened to change the life of the couple, who had been together since CEGEP, in a tragic way. "Jael was a smiling person, an active woman, she ran marathons, she was a cheerful person, and Benoît was like a big teddy bear. Since yesterday, I can't believe that they are mentioned in the news," said a family friend who came to the family home to bring flowers. In the last few days, psychological support had been offered to the accused, who found himself at the heart of an investigation, confirmed the Centre intégré de santé et de services sociaux (CISSS), to which the youth center where he worked belongs. According to TVA Nouvelles, it was a father who made a report after discovering explicit text message exchanges between the educator and his young daughter. "At the end of December, it was brought to our attention that [Mr. Cardinal] might have engaged in inappropriate behavior," the Laval CISSS limited itself to commenting. The man was suspended from his duties and finally resigned last Friday. A support unit was set up for employees and users of the Centre jeunesse de Laval following the tragedy. Support and listening services were also offered by the Commission scolaire de Laval (CSDL), where the victim, a special education technician, worked. "It is with regret and great sadness that the CSDL learned of Jaël's tragic death. The entire school community is shaken," commented Louise Lortie, CSDL President. Ms. Cantin's parents' business, located next door to the residence, displayed a sad note to explain its closure for the next few days. "We are going through a period of mourning, our counter will be closed," it read. "I can't believe it. I never heard anything inappropriate and I never witnessed any bickering or anything. On the contrary, it really seemed like a close-knit family. We never saw the police come in here," said the couple's immediate neighbor, Nathalie Labonté.

titre: Le meurtre de Sainte-Foy était-il évitable?
texte: The Parole Board of Canada (PBC) is in the spotlight for allowing a man who killed his wife in 2004 to meet with women, "but only to meet his sexual needs. As a tragic consequence of this decision, the murderer reoffended and killed a sex worker in a hotel in Sainte-Foy, Quebec on Thursday. "When a man has a history of domestic violence, he should be considered a risk to all women. How can we allow him to have contact, but only with sex workers? How can there be women who are willing to be put at risk?" asks Simon Lapierre, a professor at the University of Ottawa's School of Social Work. Eustachio Gallese was charged Thursday with the unpremeditated murder of Marylene Levesque. The 51-year-old man gave himself up to police, confessing to the crime and identifying the location of the victim's body. The woman was a sex worker working in an erotic massage parlor. According to several sources, Gallese was expelled from the parlour after being violent towards other masseuses. The victim had agreed to see him outside of his place of work. The accused was on day parole and was allowed to see women, but only to satisfy his sexual needs, according to the most recent PBCC decision issued last September. He was serving a penitentiary sentence after being convicted of the murder of his wife in 2004, to which he also admitted by calling the police himself. He also had a history of domestic violence with a previous spouse in 1997. "Although you say you are not ready to enter into a serious relationship with a woman...your parole officer has pointed out that a strategy has been developed for you to meet women, but only to meet your sexual needs," the commissioners wrote. However, the murderer was required to be "transparent". One of the conditions imposed on him was to declare all his "intimate relationships", which makes the executive director of Chez Stella, an organization that helps sex workers, jump. "Sex is not a right. There is no charter in Canada that says sex is a right," said Wesley. She said the commissioners were aware that this was an unusual condition. "The Commission expects that the analytical framework that culminated in this approach will be re-examined," the PTAB decision states. For Geneviève Quinty, director of the Projet intervention prostitution Québec, sex workers feel that they have been considered as less valuable women. She also points out the subtlety of the commissioners in never explicitly suggesting that they are sex workers. "They had to be aware that they couldn't put it in black and white about buying sex," says Quinty. Accounts demanded Quebec has also held Ottawa to account. Justice Minister Sonia LeBel has indicated her intention to question federal Public Safety Minister Bill Blair about the circumstances surrounding the day parole since the PBC is responsible for the file. She believes that one of the questions that should be asked is whether the commissioners are "adequately equipped to do the risk assessment". Minister Blair's office reiterated that the protection of the public is the overriding criterion in all CLCC decisions. "The PBC makes these decisions independently, based on long-established criteria to promote safe and effective offender reintegration," it said. Asked if it is common for an offender's sexual needs to be considered, the PBC referred Le Devoir to the Correctional Service of Canada. At the end of the day, a spokesperson indicated that the circumstances of this decision are being reviewed. "We take this tragic event very seriously...As there is an ongoing criminal investigation, it would be inappropriate to provide further details on this case," said Patricia Jean of the Correctional Service of Canada. With Hélène Buzzetti and The Canadian Press

titre: Frédéric Bastien se lance dans la course à la chefferie du PQ
texte: The professor and historian Frédéric Bastien became this weekend the third candidate to confirm that he will enter the race for the leadership of the Parti Québécois (PQ), which will start Saturday. "My reflection has come to an end, and it is with pleasure that I announce that I will be a candidate for the leadership of the Parti Québécois," he wrote in a Facebook post online Saturday at 11 p.m. Contacted the next morning, the future candidate explained that he made his decision not only for a matter of procedure, but also to have peace of mind. "I knew I was going skiing [Sunday] and I closed my computer. My decision was made and I wanted to 'focus' on my day on the ski slopes with my children," he told Le Devoir in an interview. His campaign will be officially launched on February 9 at the Ninkasi Simple Malt in Montreal. Frédéric Bastien came to prominence this fall after filing a complaint against the Chief Justice of the Quebec Court of Appeal, Nicole Duval Hesler. He accused her of failing in her duty to act in a reserved manner in the appeal of the challenge to the Quebec Secularism Act. More recently, he "threatened" two Supreme Court of Canada justices with legal action if they gave a lecture to raise funds for Lord Reading, a legal organization that has taken a stand against Bill 21. The two judges' participation has since been cancelled. "The future candidate is counting on this desire to fight with the federal authorities to convince PQ militants to elect him to head the political party. "Our party must show an assertive nationalism that challenges the federal system, especially the constitutional law of 1982, which, without our consent, has given federal judges the power to invalidate our laws. This is what I did as a historian, this is what I do as an activist, this is what I will propose to the members of the Parti Québécois during this race," he explained on social networks. So far, two other candidates have officially announced their intentions. MNA and former interim leader Sylvain Gaudreault was the first to enter the leadership race in November. His parliamentary responsibilities have been lightened so that he can devote more time to them. Paul St-Pierre Plamondon, lawyer and author of the report "Dare to Rethink the PQ", will present his program on Tuesday at the Lion d'Or in Montreal. I've said it before, I don't believe that the question of a referendum on independence should be done in a first mandate. I want to force constitutional negotiations. - Frédéric Bastien Frédéric Bastien believes he is in a position to distinguish himself from his opponents. "They are not people who have attacked the federal system and who have really challenged it. I think I put my finger on the boo-boo [with Judge Duval Hesler and the cancellation of the conference]. I think activists are hungry for action," says the Dawson College professor in Montreal. He emphasizes that if he is elected leader of the party and wins the next election, he will focus on the issue of the Constitution. "As I said before, I don't believe that the question of a referendum on independence should be dealt with in a first mandate. I want to force constitutional negotiations," he said. Candidates under consideration With one week to go before the launch of the PQ leadership race, other interested candidates are still under consideration. Comedian Guy Nantel and immigration lawyer Stéphane Handfield have confirmed their interest, but their decision is still pending. Both are waiting to know the rules of the race which will be set on February 1st. La Presse had reported on January 9 that the national executive of the party will propose to open the vote to supporters without them being members in good standing of the formation. This information was confirmed to Le Devoir. The name of Jean-François Lisée's successor will be known on June 19.

titre: La police de Repentigny se veut plus inclusive
texte: The Repentigny police are cautious about using the term "racial profiling" as they begin a process of "inclusion" while awaiting the findings of a report on police stops based on ethnic origin on their territory. "It is certain that there is a problem, otherwise the population would not ask us to reflect on our practices," says Hélène Dion, director of the Service de police de la Ville de Repentigny (SPVR), in an interview with Le Devoir. In recent years, the SPVR has been singled out by black citizens who have testified to the numerous arrests they have been subjected to without cause. While the Service de police de la Ville de Montréal acknowledged the existence of racial profiling among its troops last year, the SPVR has not yet reached that stage. "This is part of the reflection that will allow us to see if our practices are free of discrimination," says Ms. Dion. As humans, we can't say we don't have prejudices," she adds. However, once we recognize that we have them, we must ensure that our practices are not guided by them. So we want to identify them, understand them, and work to always make sure they don't guide our decisions in the field." So why not acknowledge the existence of racial profiling? "There have been several allegations of profiling and, to date, not all cases before the police ethics board have been proven," says Dion. "However, the public is asking us to reflect because our practices can no longer be like they were 15 or 20 years ago. We have to adjust and that's what we're going to respond to." Reflection The North Shore police force in Montreal will announce on Monday that it is partnering with the Uena agency, which specializes in "inclusive governance", to take a step back from its ways of doing things. The process will take nearly a year and will include five major steps, the first of which is to raise awareness of the issue of equity among police officers. Dafina Savic, co-founder of the Uena agency, says an organization doesn't have to acknowledge that profiling exists within its ranks to address the issue. "We're not here to judge whether they've done it or not. However, they have been made aware that it exists and they want to take action," notes Savic. There have been several allegations of profiling and, so far, not all cases before the police ethics board have been proven - Hélène Dion Last August, a car protest was organized to denounce racial profiling within the province's police force. The group of motorists made stops in Montreal, Repentigny, Terrebonne and Mascouche, and ended the demonstration in front of Premier François Legault's constituency office in L'Assomption. The VPD was roundly criticized this summer after a group of nine black youths received a total of $11,500 in tickets for playing basketball, while other white youths received only a warning the same night. The police force maintains that they have corrected the facts. They maintain that the intervention was in no way related to skin color, but to the fact that several of these youth had already been stopped and warned in previous weeks about following public health guidelines. In Montreal, an independent panel's report revealed in October 2019 that Blacks and Aboriginals are four and five times more likely to be stopped by police officers than Whites, respectively. In the wake of this, Repentigny police decided to commission their own report on police interventions as well. "There is a bond of trust to rebuild, that's clear, and notwithstanding the conclusions of the report that is expected, the SPVR wants to take action to break these perceptions," says Dafina Savic, of the Uena agency.

titre: Robert Lafrenière assure ne pas avoir quitté l’UPAC à cause de Guy Ouellette
texte: The former commissioner of the Unité permanente anticorruption (UPAC), Robert Lafrenière, says his surprise resignation in the middle of an election day two years ago is not related to the case of Laval MP Guy Ouellette. The arrest of Ouellette, who is suspected of leaking information to journalists, has so far not led to any charges. "I was 65 years old, I had been working for 46 years, I was tired and I had decided, that summer, that I would resign [at some point]," he said Monday, in his first public appearance since leaving the UPAC. Lafrenière was the first witness in the civil trial of his former right-hand man, Marcel Forget, who is suing the Quebec government for $2 million for "constructive dismissal. The former UPAC boss himself turned to reporters for an update on his time in court as he left the courtroom at the Montreal courthouse. However, he remained unmoved when asked about the allegations against him in Qu'on accuse ou qu'on s'excuse, the recently published book by Guy Ouellette, in which he is described as "the Edgar Hoover of Quebec". "I will not comment on Mr. Ouellette's book. There may be investigations in court on subjects that are in the book and I do not want to comment," he limited himself to saying, while his lawyer was at his side. The resignation of Mr. Lafrenière had been announced on the morning of October 1, 2018, as Quebecers were preparing to go to the polls, electing late in the evening the Caquist government of François Legault. A few days earlier, the Director of Criminal and Penal Prosecutions (DPCP) had announced that UPAC would not be able to finally search the documents seized from the residence and car of Liberal MP Guy Ouellette during his arrest in October 2017. The investigative unit suspected him of being behind the leaks of sensitive police information to the media. Trial On the first day of the hearing of the trial of Marcel Forget against Quebec, the lawyer of the former number two of the UPAC, tried to question Mr. Lafrenière on the involvement of the politician in the appointments within the UPAC. Me Daniel Rochefort met with numerous objections from his colleagues who represent the government and Mr. Lafrenière. "There is a context that I want to demonstrate," he pleaded. "When Mr. Lafrenière's mandate was renewed, he became untouchable, so we targeted the number two." He wanted to know the former commissioner's version of the searches at the Quebec Liberal Party (QLP), the arrests of Marc-Yvan Côté, a former QLP moneyman, and Nathalie Normandeau, a former Liberal minister, as well as his relationship with MP Guy Ouellette. However, the judge did not allow him to go any further in his questioning on these subjects. Forget found himself in trouble in November 2017 after Le Journal de Montréal reported that he had sold shares without a broker's license in the 1990s and 2000s. Police officers and ex-police officers told the Montreal daily that thanks to him they had invested in the firm Newtech, which was fined in the wake of an investigation by the Autorité des marchés financiers (AMF). According to Mr. Lafrenière, his former right-hand man was never pushed out the door. "I remember telling him [that] it was going to end eventually, not to worry," he testified. Yet Mr. Forget reportedly ultimately decided to leave the organization on November 30, 2017. According to court documents, Forget claims he was forced to resign after being threatened by André Fortier, associate secretary general for senior jobs, in the wake of the reports. Former Public Security Minister Martin Coiteux is expected to testify on Tuesday.

titre: Quatorzième féminicide de l’année au Québec
texte: A woman would have been killed by her husband Monday evening in Montreal while their two children were at the scene. This is the 14th feminicide committed this year in Quebec. Rajinder Prabhneed Kaur had recently changed the lock on her apartment in the Parc-Extension neighbourhood after filing a complaint with the police. "She didn't want [her spouse] to be able to come in anymore and she paid for a new lock. But two days later, she phoned me to inform me that she had started up again with him and that she was going to give him a key", testifies Joseph Fernando, the concierge of the building where the couple had been living for several years. According to our information, the suspect is Navdeep Ghotra. The 30-year-old man is already facing criminal harassment charges: on May 19, he allegedly made serious threats to the victim. He was released on conditions, including not possessing any weapons. The man fled before authorities arrived and, at the time of writing, had still not been found. "Last month, the police came in the middle of the night because he was intoxicated," says Fernando. After being escorted out by the police, the man returned the next day. The last time the janitor spoke with the couple was last week: their refrigerator had stopped working and he went to their apartment to replace it. "He was very courteous to me, but I don't know what happened after the door was closed," he says. Children present Police received a call about an unconscious woman in an apartment on Birnam Street at St. Roch Street shortly before 5 p.m. Monday. First responders were unable to save the mother, who had a serious upper body injury; Rajinder Prabhneed Kaur was pronounced dead at the scene. "She was on her balcony a few minutes earlier and was talking on the phone, she didn't look panicked or in danger," mentions Noureen Gilani, who lives in the building next door. "I suddenly heard the children crying, but I didn't see her partner," she adds. The couple's two children, a girl and a boy, were reportedly present at the time. "The policemen knocked on all the doors because the little girl, in panic, would have run away. They looked everywhere, in our yards and under the balconies," said Gina Di Frushia, who lives in a nearby house. The girl would have been found in a nearby park later in the evening. They have two young children... It's terrible: they just lost their mother and father. - Renu Zani In the 14-unit apartment building where the family had resided for more than three years, neighbors described a quiet couple, some even had the impression that they had just moved in. "The man gave off something aggressive. When I greeted him, he didn't respond. So I never really had a conversation with them," says Sharif Mahmudul Hasan, who lives on the same floor as the couple. Tariq Chaudrey, a neighbor who lives in the apartment below the couple's, says he didn't hear anything unusual. "I've seen them several times. I don't know how this could have happened. We feel terrible. If I had heard anything, I would have called the police," he says. On her way home from work, Renu Zani, whose husband is close to the suspect, was shocked when she saw the security perimeter in front of her house. "They have two young children... It's terrible: they just lost their mother and father," she said. Do you need help? If you are a victim of domestic violence, you can contact SOS Violence conjugale at 1 800 363-9010. Our feminicide watch since 2020 in Quebec

titre: Meurtre de Daphné Huard-Boudreault: les policiers blanchis par le commissaire à la déontologie
texte: The police interventions that occurred a few hours before the murder of Daphne Huard-Boudreault by her ex-spouse in March 2017 do not reveal any breach, concluded the Police Ethics Commissioner. A decision that, according to her father, shows the insensitivity of the authorities to domestic violence when it is not physical. "It is revolting. On the police cars, it is written 'Protect and Serve', but my daughter, nobody protected her that day", deplores Éric Boudreault. He had filed a complaint in police ethics against the five officers of the Régie intermunicipale de police Richelieu Saint-Laurent involved in the two interventions on the day of his daughter's murder. He accused them of having failed to protect the young woman "despite various signals that should have been detected by them". His daughter was 18 years old when her ex, Anthony Pratte-Lops, killed her with 15 stab wounds. The man, 22 years old at the time, had led her to believe that he had left the apartment they shared and that she could come by and pick up his belongings. Instead, he hid there and killed her. In the hours preceding the murder, police officers Ralph Dallaire, Louis Deschamps, Édith Fafard and Olivier St-Cyr-Lanoie went to the convenience store where Daphne worked because Anthony Pratte-Lops had followed her and refused to leave the premises. In a decision rendered on February 28, Commissioner Marc-André Dowd concluded that, "despite the tragic conclusion", the police officers did their job well. None of the five officers cooperated with the investigation, as permitted by the Police Act, so the Commissioner relied on their reports. Officers Dallaire and St-Cyr-Lanoie, who arrived at the convenience store at approximately 5:39 a.m., wrote that Daphne "mentions to them that [Anthony] has reacted badly to their recent break-up and does not want them to separate. She states that he has not threatened or abused her. She does, however, find him pushy. "Relatively calm" The reports from the four police officers present note that Daphne "was relatively calm, although she appeared to have been crying." According to the quartet, the internal domestic violence guideline did not apply to her case. "Rather, it applies when there is an assault or threat or when a person fears for their life, whether or not they make a complaint, which was not the case in this situation," the commissioner said. According to reports, Anthony Pratte-Lops was not perceived as a threat. "To them, there was no criminal offense and no apprehended danger," writes Commissioner Dowd. A finding that surprised Boudreault, since the decision reveals that during the police intervention, Anthony Pratte-Lops entered the convenience store and appeared to be angry with Daphne. "He talks about infidelity and insults her," it reads. "There is a man who follows his ex, refuses to leave his place of work and calls her a whore in front of police officers, isn't that enough?" it questions. The decision states that the police asked Daphne to keep all messages from her ex in case she decides to file a harassment complaint. They also asked her if she wanted to report her cell phone stolen when she realized her ex probably took it. "Isn't stealing an illegal act?" asked Boudreault. According to the ruling, Anthony Pratte-Lops was known to police for being "impulsive." The officers even told Daphne that it "would be wise" for her to contact them to retrieve her belongings, "to avoid any outbursts." "It's absurd to read that," says Boudreault. Boudreault, who points out that a Domestic Violence Death Review Committee was formed in the wake of Daphne's murder. Boudreault is scheduled to testify on Thursday before the Expert Panel on Supporting Victims of Sexual Assault and Domestic Violence. He hopes that police training will be reviewed and that from now on social workers will be present with the police during an intervention. This is the second time that the police officers involved in the two interventions on the day of Daphne's murder have been cleared. A report by the Independent Investigation Bureau concluded that the officers acted appropriately. Officer Brigitte Légaré, who followed Daphne when she went to retrieve her belongings, was also the subject of the ethics complaint.

titre: Ugo Fredette se compare à Guy Turcotte
texte: The sentencing hearings for murderer Ugo Fredette began Monday with some disturbing statements as the trial continues, in part, virtually due to the pandemic. While waiting for the hearing to resume, the accused compared himself to Guy Turcotte, saying that "when you go through this, you understand [his actions]. "It can happen to anyone," said the 44-year-old man who was convicted last October of the murders of his ex-wife, Véronique Barbe, and a passing motorist, Yvon Lacasse. The murders had occurred on September 14, 2017, and had resulted in the longest Amber Alert ever issued in Quebec. Ugo Fredette had fled with a six-year-old child and was eventually intercepted in Ontario. With the gradual resumption of courthouse activities, Ugo Fredette's trial can be followed by videoconference. However, on two occasions on Monday, the camera and microphone in the room from which the murderer was appearing remained open. While he was waiting for the judge and lawyers to arrive, Ugo Fredette was probably talking to a guard. He told him several anecdotes about prison life and even confided in him. "When it happened to [Guy] Turcotte, I said to myself, "How did he do that? It does not make sense, his two children [...] It's sure that it played in my head, but when you go through it, you understand, "he said. The man even speculated on the motivations of the ex-cardiologist convicted of the unpremeditated murders of his two children. "It's because in his head, I imagine he must have said to himself, I'm going to punish [my ex-wife] severely, and the worst punishment is the children," he said. The killer also spoke of his friendship with the murderer Guillaume Gélinas, who was also convicted of a double murder. "He is a friend of mine. He's a really sharp guy. I didn't even know what he had done," he says. "It was when he went to court, I saw his name come up in the media, I thought, my God, he doesn't look like a guy who did this," he continued. Ugo Fredette had just briefly mentioned Veronique Barbe, whom he described as "the one who died", as well as another ex-wife, when the conversation was interrupted to resume the hearing. A few minutes earlier, Ugo Fredette was impassive before the testimony of Dr. Gilles Chamberland, who was mandated by the prosecution to evaluate the dangerousness of the murderer. The expert described Ugo Fredette as a person with a narcissistic personality disorder. The accused presents himself as a victim, has little empathy and feels he is in the middle of unfair situations. "The rehabilitation potential of [Ugo Fredette], according to the information available, allows us to see that it is almost nil in the short term," said Dr. Chamberland. During the lunch break, the lawyers heard what Ugo Fredette had said after an article was published in La Presse. The newspaper reported on another conversation held in the morning, before the virtual hearing began. Among other things, Ugo Fredette recounted his meeting with the murderer Eustachio Gallese, who pleaded guilty last February to the premeditated murder of Marylène Lévesque. He recounted how he was able to prevent her from being beaten by suggesting that she press the panic button. The defense has heard from psychiatrist Louis Morissette, who believes that, although Ugo Fredette has narcissistic traits, he is not suffering from a disorder. "It is true that empathy is not the first quality of this man, but the narcissistic trait is not present in all areas of his life," analyzed Dr. Morissette. Judge Myriam Lachance will have to determine the period of incarceration that Ugo Fredette will have to serve before being eligible for parole. The defense is asking for 25 years, while the prosecution is asking for a cumulative sentence of 50 years. Since 2011, the Criminal Code has allowed judges to take into account each murder conviction in their sentences. At the time, the provision was added to further punish multiple murderers. Sentencing submissions continue Tuesday at the St. Jerome courthouse.

titre: Les dépanneurs au front
texte: Pieces of wood, plastic wrap and lots of tape: makeshift signs were constructed by several convenience store owners who used their resourcefulness and creativity to stay on the front lines, while protecting themselves from COVID-19. "It's not perfect, but I think it's better than nothing," says Suquin Cao, owner of the 7 Days convenience store at the corner of St. Zotique and La Roche in Montreal's Rosemont district. "Our goal is to stay open as long as possible, because you know, we help people out," says Ms. Cao, who has been in the neighborhood for 16 years. Photo: Valérian Mazataud Le Devoir Cautious convenience store owners refuse to accept returnable containers to limit the risk of spreading the coronavirus. For the past two weeks, the owner has been trying to leave the door of the convenience store open most of the time, in order to prevent customers from putting their hands on it. The cash counter of her business is now covered by a huge plastic curtain that shows a silhouette, but is too thick to put a face on the person behind it. "It's difficult for a small convenience store to build protection, it's expensive and we don't have the same means as a grocery store," says the woman who also wears a mask and gloves. "The masks were sent to me by my family in China, because we can't find them here anymore," she says. Unlike grocery stores, which will be closed every Sunday in April, convenience stores will be able to stay open. This is why many have revised their opening hours in order to stay on the front line without getting exhausted. Photo: Marie-France Coallier Le Devoir With a piece of Plexiglas and some piping, the owner of the convenience store L'Épicerie Casse-Croûte du coin in Hochelaga built himself a makeshift window. "We have to clean everything several times a day, the Interac machine, the floor, the displays. Since there are fewer customers than usual, we decided to open a little later and close earlier," says Thanh Nguyen, who works at the Grignoterie convenience store. "Customers mostly come to buy the newspaper and get a little cake or chocolate," he says. When he saw that the situation was getting worse, he, too, went looking for something to protect himself. "I found this piece of plastic that Loto-Quebec had given us a few years ago for the lottery display. It was new, so I tied it to two pieces of wood," says Nguyen. He says he also has masks and gloves, but has decided not to wear them anymore. "The other day, I was wearing a mask and my customers were scared. They thought I was sick," he says. Photo: Marie-France Coallier Le Devoir The payment terminals are disinfected after each use. Working seven days a week, "helping out" those who forgot to buy their pint of milk or breaking the isolation of the most vulnerable who come to buy beers and cigarettes, the owners confide that they find this period of pandemic particularly difficult financially. "There are fewer people than usual. I haven't done the math yet, but our revenues are down for sure," says William Meng, owner of Rosie's Convenience Store. With the required lockdown, beer sales have dropped significantly and Loto-Quebec has also suspended in-store lottery sales. "The economic pressure is strong. We have to think about rent, electricity costs and being able to sell our products so we don't make too many losses," says Mr. Meng, who has decided to finally close his store on Sundays. The rest of the week, he plans to be there for the neighborhood. "People are very kind and grateful that we are there for them. The other day, a firefighter from the fire station came by to buy for $30 and he left us a $10 tip to thank us for being there, that touched me a lot," says Mr. Meng, who confided to Le Devoir that his whole family works in an essential service: his wife is a pharmacist, his daughter is a nutritionist and his son is studying medicine. Photo: Valérian Mazataud Le Devoir William Meng built a protective panel to keep his clients safe.

titre: Inquiétudes face à un tueur qui écope d’au moins 13 ans de pénitencier
texte: A murderer was sentenced Thursday to at least 13 years in prison for stabbing his ex-wife 62 times. A hearing that also raised the court's limitations in being able to frame his new relationship with an intellectually disabled woman he met on the Internet using an illegally obtained cell phone. "I know this may be incomprehensible to family and friends [...] but I want to remind you that the sentence is one of life. If the Max Aubin of today is the Max Aubin of ten years from now, it would be surprising if he could obtain parole," said Judge Hélène Di Salvo, in rendering her decision. With tears in their eyes, the relatives of Mylène Laliberté could not hide their disappointment. The 24-year-old woman was killed by Max Aubin, who did not accept their breakup. On January 13, 2017, he went to her home in Saint-Lin-Laurentides with the intention of having a discussion. Seeing that he was under the influence of cocaine, Mylène Laliberté refused to let him enter her apartment, but the man broke down her door. Once inside, he stabbed her 62 times with two knives before leaving with a friend who was waiting in his car. "The crime is horrific, marked by unprecedented violence. Violent, gratuitous and odious acts were committed by the accused who could not accept the break-up [...] this is another sad case of conjugal violence and the legislator is making it an aggravating factor. Too many women are murdered by an abusive spouse who is unable to accept the breakup," noted Judge Di Salvo. The 25-year-old man remains a high risk to reoffend, according to a pre-sentence report. Although he is showing signs of introspection, the judge noted that this is "the beginning of regret" and that Max Aubin is most concerned about the length of his sentence, which he hopes will be as short as possible. According to him, "a man can improve when he gets help" and believes that the court should give him that "chance". "I had many companions before Mylène, I didn't kill them all," he said. The man, who was 21 years old at the time of the crime, pleaded guilty last December to a reduced charge of non-premeditated murder. Emphasizing the seriousness of the crime, Justice Di Salvo accepted the joint recommendation of the Crown and the defence that the man serve at least 13 years in prison before being eligible for parole. The judge also expressed her concerns about Max Aubin's new romantic relationship. Even though he has been behind bars for three years, the man was able to meet a young woman on the Internet, who has an intellectual disability, with whom he says he is in a relationship. Last January, TVA Nouvelles revealed that he illegally possessed a cell phone in prison, which allowed him to communicate with her. "This new affair seems to expose a repetition of the same addiction problem [...] His emotional dependence, control and jealousy are central to the relationship with his current partner. If we cannot speak of direct actions, we believe that the tangent that the relationship tends to take involves a risk for the safety of the girl that is of concern," the magistrate mentioned, quoting the report. Also according to the document, Max Aubin wants prison authorities to give him prompt access to direct contact with her. "Despite his concerns and worries, the Tribunal unfortunately cannot protect her during the sentencing process. The young woman's entourage and the prison authorities will have to adequately and effectively supervise this relationship," the judge emphasized.

titre: Service Correctionnel Canada visé par une demande d’action collective
texte: An inmate who contracted HIV from behind bars wants to file a class action suit against Correctional Service Canada (CSC) for having "acted too little, too late", thus contributing to the outbreak of the virus in Quebec penitentiaries. "In addition to promoting the transmission of COVID-19 to incarcerated persons, the faults committed by CSC have the effect of making the current conditions of incarceration of inmates in its custody inhumane," reads the motion filed Monday at the Montreal courthouse by the Larochelle Law Firm. The inmate Joëlle Beaulieu explains that she suffered from the negligence of prison authorities, who did not take her health condition seriously, even though she had several symptoms of COVID-19. The woman of Aboriginal origin is incarcerated at the Joliette Penitentiary. This is the prison where the most positive cases of COVID-19 have been reported. As of April 18, 51 inmates had the virus. The inmate has decided to turn to the courts to obtain compensation of $100 per day of detention since March 13, until CSC ensures security inside Quebec penitentiaries. She is also seeking a lump sum of $500 for the physical and emotional harm she suffered as a result of the anguish she experienced as a result of CSC's mismanagement after contracting the virus. Ms. Beaulieu wishes to act as the representative of all persons who were detained in a federal correctional facility in Quebec on or after March 13, whether or not they contracted COVID-19. Lack of preparedness by prison authorities for the pandemic caused the inmate to fear for her safety. "[CSC] was grossly negligent...as prompt and consistent measures could have been quickly put in place to prevent the current spread and effectively protect inmates." Ms. Beaulieu suspects that she was infected by staff members. The inmate works as a cleaner, which meant that she had to clean the administration area of the institution. From the beginning of the pandemic, she asked for masks and gloves, but was refused. "She was constantly refused. She was only able to get gloves, which she could wear while cleaning, but no masks were provided, even though her duties meant she was in the presence of administration members, during business hours, exposing her to contamination," the document states. The first symptoms associated with COVID-19 were felt by Beaulieu around March 21. She went to the infirmary on March 26, but was told that since she had not traveled, it could not be COVID-19. "Yet she had been in contact with many people on the outside due to her work as a cleaner at the administration," the petition notes. Two other inmates are told the same thing. They were provided with a mask and two Tylenols before being returned to their unit, where they would come into contact with several other women. "The prison authorities were putting everyone at risk by letting these three women go back to the unit and be in contact with everyone else," it is argued. It was not until the next day that the three inmates were transferred to a separate unit. Ms. Beaulieu's health condition deteriorated, her temperature would have reached 43°C according to the petition. Ms. Beaulieu was transferred back to a unit that would be used to isolate inmates waiting for COVID-19 results. On April 1, the inmate tested positive for COVID-19. Ms. Beaulieu was confined to a cell for 14 days. While suffering from gastric symptoms, she had to relieve herself in a container since she could only leave to go to the bathroom during the officers' rounds, every 50 minutes. "Ms. Beaulieu felt diminished and discredited. She felt that she was ignored by prison authorities and that her life had little value in their eyes," the petition states.

titre: Jean Charest poursuit Québec pour violation de sa vie privée
texte: Former Premier Jean Charest is accusing Quebec of violating his privacy following leaks from the Mâchurer investigation conducted by the Unité permanente anticorruption (UPAC). The former politician filed a lawsuit on Friday for more than a million dollars. "It is with great reluctance that I am filing a lawsuit today against the Quebec government," said Charest in a written statement. The man who was leader of the Quebec Liberal Party until 2012 is one of the main targets of the Mâchurer investigation. He is claiming a total of $1,050,000 in punitive and moral damages from Quebec. Launched more than six years ago, this investigation, which is still ongoing, is looking into an illegal financing system in the Quebec Liberal Party. These police suspicions have never been validated by the courts and have not yet led to any charges. According to Mr. Charest, the choice of the name of this investigation was already a sign of UPAC's intention to damage its image. "The UPAC commissioner [Robert Lafrenière] and his staff called this investigation Mâchurer, a term that is defined as 'smearing someone with black', 'slandering someone', i.e. blackening their reputation' or 'saying bad things about someone in order to sully their reputation'," he says. Leaks in the media The former deputy of Sherbrooke believes that Quebec and UPAC have failed in their duty to protect the information collected in their investigation. He accuses them of having violated his privacy, while several elements of the investigation have been leaked. "Over the past few years, confidential information about my personal life, as well as my family, has been leaked to the media. These leaks are illegal and, moreover, constitute an obstruction of justice," Mr. Charest argues. In April 2017, Le Journal de Montréal revealed, among other things, that Mr. Charest was under police surveillance until 2016. "It is clear that the publication of the investigation file relating to [Mr. Charest] is the direct result of a leak by a member of the [UPAC] staff, which constitutes an abuse of power marked by bad faith and recklessness on his part," his motion reads. Frustration Mr. Charest maintains that he had hoped not to litigate the case. He allegedly tried to negotiate with the government for a public apology in exchange for not suing the state. "My offer was refused," he said, adding that he had offered to mediate to reach an "honourable settlement. Faced with the state's refusal, Mr. Charest says he had no choice but to go to court. "The Mâchurer investigation, through the faults of [Quebec City and UPAC], had the effect, if not the purpose, of seriously infringing on the applicant's fundamental right to the preservation of his private life," he wrote. Last January, when Mr. Charest was being considered for the leadership of the Conservative Party of Canada, his lawyer called for an end to the Mâchurer investigation in an interview with Radio-Canada. The leaks of this investigation have had important repercussions in the last two years. Laval MP Guy Ouellette is also suing the government for damage to his reputation, claiming just over half a million dollars. The leaks were also cited in the stay of proceedings of the files of former ministers Nathalie Normandeau and Marc-Yvan Côté in September. Former UPAC commissioner Robert Lafrenière had launched Project A, an investigation into information leaks that is now in the hands of the Office of Independent Investigations under the name Project Oath, in October 2017.

titre: Mamadi Camara s'avoue déçu par les deux enquêtes annoncées
texte: Mamadi III Fara Camara says he is disappointed by the investigations announced Tuesday to shed light on his arrest and false accusation of attempted murder of a police officer. The Montrealer and his family would have preferred that they take the form of a public inquiry rather than being conducted under the Police Act. "Mr. Camara could have only a very secondary role in these two investigations," said one of his lawyers, Alain Arsenault. "The announced investigations are in the form of an internal inquiry, but they are not independent investigations as when a commission of inquiry is launched," he explains. On Tuesday, Quebec City announced that the work of the Montreal Police Service (SPVM) that led to Camara's arrest and prosecution will be scrutinized in detail by Judge Louis Dionne. The investigation, which will begin on February 22, will last up to five months and will lead to the filing of a report. However, the report may not be made public in its entirety, said Public Safety Minister Geneviève Guilbault. It will be released "to the extent that it is possible to do so without prejudicing a police investigation or potential legal proceedings," she said. "The current form of this investigation does not give any minimum guarantee that we will be able to really shed light on the events, because we will not even know who will be met and who the witnesses will be. It is an inquiry that will be held behind closed doors," said Arsenault. Racial profiling? In Quebec City, Premier François Legault assured that the inquiry will provide answers to Quebecers "who don't like what they've been hearing for a week. "I can understand that people want answers," he said on the sidelines of a press conference on the pandemic. One of the things he said this investigation will determine is whether or not there was racial profiling, a possibility he did not want to address head on. "We don't have enough information to know if this is a case of racism," Legault said, insisting on the need to "get to the bottom of things" before seeing a link between racism or profiling in the intervention of the SPVM. "Judge Dionne will be able to answer this question, as to the motivations and reasons why it happened the way it did and whether it would have been the same if it had been a white person," he noted, refraining from using the term "systemic racism. For its part, the SPVM said in an email that it "respects" the decision made by Quebec City. "We will be collaborative and transparent throughout the process," the police force said. The Director of Criminal and Penal Prosecutions (DPCP) also announced that an investigation into the judicial handling of Mr. Camara's case will be conducted and hopes to give the mandate to Judge Dionne. Plante satisfied On the political scene, the investigation into the SPVM was well received. "The announced investigation meets the desired objectives, namely a neutral investigation of the entire process leading to the confirmation of Mr. Camara's innocence," wrote Montreal Mayor Valérie Plante on Twitter. Mr. Camara spent six days in jail because of a mistaken identity. He was falsely identified as the main suspect in the violent assault on police officer Sanjay Vig on January 28. The 31-year-old man accepted the apology offered in person Monday by the head of the SPVM, Sylvain Caron. His lawyer, however, specified that the page is not turned, since he is still studying the possibility of filing a civil suit. As for the real aggressor, he has still not been found.

titre: Le processus judiciaire a été «réparateur» pour Léa Clermont-Dion
texte: Although she describes it as imperfect and maladaptive, the legal process has been restorative for author Léa Clermont-Dion, who is revealing her identity four years after filing a complaint in order to bear witness to her journey through the justice system and to help improve it. "I want to talk about it, to be able to share with other women, to do something useful. With hindsight, I am no longer ashamed to have done it," testifies Léa Clermont-Dion in an interview with Le Devoir the day before the verdict. In October 2017, in the wake of the #MoiAussi movement, she filed a complaint for sexual assault against former journalist and founder of the Institut du Nouveau-Monde, Michel Venne. The man was found guilty Wednesday of sexual assault and sexual exploitation. "Regardless of what the judgment was about, I am at peace," she assured. "The process has been like a hike for me. Today, I'm at the top of the mountain and I see the scenery, but there were bits where I ran out of breath." Just before the verdict was handed down, Léa Clermont-Dion therefore asked Judge Stéphane Poulin that the publication ban on her identity be lifted. The 30-year-old has documented the behind-the-scenes of her trial in her documentary T'as juste à porter plainte, which will be broadcast at the end of the summer on Noovo. "The documentary helped me make amends. The fact that I talked to about 30 victims helped me because I realized that I'm not alone, that it wasn't personal to me, that it's way beyond me, and it made me put things into perspective and it [motivated me] to help change them," she explains. The lack of knowledge about the judicial process was particularly significant. "It took me two years [to] understand how the system works. At the beginning, I was all mixed up, I didn't know what a preliminary inquiry was, what it entailed," she says, stressing that she was "lucky" to find a dedicated prosecutor who listened. This lack of understanding, she says, contributes to a roller coaster of emotions for the complainants. "A victim has no control over the process, so could we at least give her the knowledge to feel informed? That will help make it less anxiety-provoking," she says. She also points to the disproportionate means between the accused and the alleged victim. "The system is ill-adapted. It wasn't my lawsuit, it was the Queen's. It's not my lawyer, it's the Crown Attorney. What's missing in the process is an independent lawyer who can advise the victim, because the accused has advice," she notes. After being cross-examined for two and a half days, Clermont-Dion says she felt overwhelmed by shame and frustration. "The anger subsided, I don't take it personally anymore and today I am really serene. Looking back, I understand that the defence lawyers are doing their job and they are very well paid for it, but I don't agree with their methods, which I find inappropriate in sexual assault cases. No victim should have to feel guilty or ashamed for coming forward," she says. She is also concerned about the treatment of victims from different social, cultural and economic backgrounds, for whom the process is an obstacle course. "I think of women in precarious situations, for whom French is not their first language, and for whom their time in court will be one of the most painful moments of their lives, and I ask myself why, why are we putting them through this? At 30 years old, despite the ups and downs, through the moments when she felt confident and those when she felt like she was in pieces, Léa Clermont-Dion does not regret having embarked on the judicial process. However, her experience confirms that she would never have been able to do it at 17 years old, when the alleged events would have occurred. "It's a great paradox. The 17-year-old Lea would have gone through the wringer and it could have been a very destructive process. Today, I have been well supervised and surrounded and it has been a restorative process," she concludes.

titre: Un pas de plus vers la protection des victimes de violence conjugale
texte: A mother who was a victim of domestic violence has obtained court protection in her separation, a rarely used measure that Juripop says could change the lives of many women. "Domestic violence doesn't always mean hitting. It is often at the time of separation that it becomes explosive, especially when it is necessary to negotiate the custody of the children or the alimony", underlines Sylvie Lévesque, general director of the Federation of the associations of single-parent families and recomposed of Quebec. Although violence is subtle and difficult to prove, women's fears are real, notes Me Justine Fortin, a lawyer at the Juripop legal clinic. It is in this context that the organization recently succeeded in obtaining a protection order for a mother whose separation with the father of her children turned into a nightmare. "It is a case of psychological and economic violence, which took place over a period of ten years, but where no criminal act was committed," explains Me Fortin. "The mother did not have the possibility of filing a complaint with the police, but she still had reason to fear for her safety because of her experience in recent years. In Quebec, there is a little-known procedure that allows you to be protected against someone even if they have not committed a criminal act. It is the civil equivalent of the criminal no-contact order, called an "810" in legal jargon. To date, this civil procedure has been used mostly in cases of neighbor disputes, for example. The man was ordered by a judge to cease all harassing and intimidating behaviour towards the mother of his children, to stay away from areas frequented by his ex-wife, and to surrender all weapons in his possession to law enforcement. The protection order is valid for a maximum of three years. If the order is breached, the court may order the individual to pay a fine, perform community service or serve a jail sentence. According to Juripop, this would be one of the first civil protection orders in a domestic violence context. "The issue we're going to experience in family law courts is that domestic violence is often brushed aside and so it becomes even more difficult to demonstrate the relevance of protecting the mother," Fortin points out. A study published in November 2019, conducted by the Federation of Women's Shelters, revealed that domestic violence was often replaced by more nuanced terms in decisions rendered by family courts, which speak more of "parental conflict", or "stormy relationship". The judge's decision is another step towards justice adapted to the needs of victims of domestic violence," says Sophie Gagnon, Executive Director of Juripop. "Victims have different backgrounds and the system must be able to respond to them. The civil protection order fills a void, but it is not a measure that should replace the possibility of filing a complaint," she emphasizes. Women who are victims of domestic violence can use the family law hotline that was launched this spring, says Gagnon. Since its launch, the organization has been receiving 8 to 10 calls a day on issues such as child custody or access to the family home. The legal hotline is available at 1-844-312-9009.

titre: Les opposants au port du masque veulent contester les constats d’infraction
texte: At the same time that Quebec City announced hefty fines for public health violators, organizers of a demonstration of mask-wearing opponents urged them to contest any ticket they might receive. "The authorities are playing on the fear of tickets, not the fear of disease," said Steeve "L'artiss" Charland, a former leader of the identity group La Meute, now a spokesperson for the anti-mask movement. The hundreds of protesters gathered at La Fontaine Park, located in the Plateau-Mont-Royal borough of Montreal, were invited by Mr. Charland to continue their fight for their freedom not to wear face coverings as well as to continue to be able to meet in peace. Follow the evolution of COVID-19 in Quebec. "They want to give us tickets for huge amounts of money because we want to live a normal life, it makes no sense, we will not accept that," he said to the applause of the crowd. A few minutes earlier, Quebec City announced that police officers will now be able to obtain a "telewarrant" from a judge on the spot to enter private residences where they suspect an illegal gathering. They will then be able to issue a portable ticket with a $1,000 fine to anyone flouting health regulations. "It's not the COVID cases that are going to go up, it's the bankruptcies, the distress cases and the domestic violence cases," Charland said. I'm not going to purposely enter someone's bubble, I respect physical distance, but I'd like to breathe and the mask prevents me from doing so - A protester Other speakers encouraged protesters to continue to educate their families on the importance of opposing the measures imposed by Public Health. Some suggested that Quebec City is tightening the screws because of their growing numbers. Festive evening Unmasked protesters hugged, kissed and danced together just hours before the start of the 28-day lockdown announced earlier this week by Premier François Legault. Karine, who preferred not to give her last name, drove from Mont-Saint-Hilaire to be there. "It's a matter of respecting everyone's freedom of choice. I'm not going to enter someone's bubble on purpose, I respect the physical distance, but I would like to breathe and the mask prevents me from doing so," said the mother, who came with her 11-year-old son. On two occasions, police officers from the Service de police de la Ville de Montréal (SPVM) intervened with the organizers. "We ask you to respect the physical distance, the space allows us to do so, but we remind you that it remains an individual choice," warned an organizer, who also reminded the demonstrators that "a ticket can always be contested. They want to give us tickets for huge sums of money because we want to live a normal life, it makes no sense, we will not accept that - Steeve Charland Officers on bicycles rode through the crowd at times demanding that the two-meter limit be respected. A dispersal notice was also issued, suggesting that the authorities would intervene, but in the end the protesters left the site at 7:00 p.m., as planned. No fines were issued. One man was arrested for mischief during the demonstration. In conjunction with this rally, organizers of the rally scheduled for October 11 at Jarry Park in Montreal finally announced the cancellation of the event in a video posted on Facebook. "Due to the red zone and the restrictions surrounding it, the "Action for Freedom" event is cancelled," said Jean-Francois Denis, one of the organizers, while calling the situation a "pseudo pandemic.

titre: Les besoins des femmes violentées restent immenses
texte: The cry from the heart launched in recent months for funding for resources for victims of domestic violence is beginning to be heard, according to aid organizations. Although "historic", the sums released by Quebec in its 2020 budget will still not meet all the needs. "There was an urgent need to act. The recent feminicides and deaths related to domestic violence since this fall have created a shock wave. The government is under the spotlight," says Louise Riendeau, spokesperson for the Regroupement des maisons pour femmes victimes de violence conjugale. Also read Marie-Andrée Chouinard's editorial - "Huge delay, small catch-up" Investments of $181 million over five years were announced on Tuesday to improve the government's plan to fight domestic violence and the services offered by shelters. Of this amount, a budget of 120 million is reserved for these shelters over the next five years, so that they ensure the "sustainability" of their services and adapt them to women in vulnerable situations. "This is historic," Minister Isabelle Charest said proudly, recalling that the action plan was previously accompanied by $86 million in funding. "I think that yes, current events have brought this issue to light even more and the importance of taking action," she added. "It is indeed a major investment that will allow us to perpetuate the financing of shelters, but it is obvious that we did not get what we wanted," said Manon Monastesse, of the Federation of Women's Shelters. Her group, which includes 36 shelters, would need $32 million. "Quebec has announced $24 million per year that will have to be divided among not only the first-stage emergency shelters, but also the second-stage shelters," notes Ms. Monastesse. There was an urgency to act. The recent feminicides and deaths related to domestic violence that have occurred since this fall have created a shock wave. - Louise Riendeau Development In the short term, it is difficult to imagine opening new houses. "If we want to open new spaces in emergency shelters and open new second-stage apartments that would allow women to leave their homes, it would take twice the amount of money announced," says Ms. Riendeau. The Provincial Alliance of Women and Children's Shelters for Victims of Domestic Violence, which has been waiting for months for the green light to open 98 new second-stage apartments, stresses the importance of making them a reality. Second-stage housing is for women who, after staying in a first-stage shelter, are at the highest risk of being murdered. "The development of new spaces is a huge issue because, unlike first stage housing, our funding is unfortunately not recurring," says Fedida. A good start She also believes that the announced investments are only "catching up" at this point. "It's a good start, even if it doesn't meet our expectations," says Gaëlle Fedida of the Alliance. She is particularly pleased that Quebec has earmarked $5 million to consolidate the eight existing rapid intervention cells and to set them up in new regions. "Concretely, it aims to prevent spousal homicide and it works very well, so it is good news to want to implement it in other regions. This investment is a recognition of the government's public safety mandate to protect women," said Fedida.

titre: Un policier acquitté dans l’affaire Bony Jean-Pierre
texte: The acquittal of police officer Christian Gilbert, who caused the death of Bony Jean-Pierre in March 2016 during a drug bust in Montreal North, was greeted with relief by the Service de police de la Ville de Montréal (SPVM). "Our police officers do not get up in the morning wanting to take this type of action," commented SPVM police chief Sylvain Caron, who said he was relieved by the decision handed down Thursday by Judge Yvan Poulin.
