"What our police officers want is to provide good security to the Montreal population [...] but unfortunately it does not always turn out the way we would have liked it to," he added. A member of the SPVM's tactical intervention group, Christian Gilbert was involved in a major police operation targeting drug traffickers on March 31, 2016. The strike targeted a dwelling on Arthur-Chevrier Street, identified as a point of sale for drug traffickers from the Red Allegiance street gang. Armed with an intermediate weapon, he was responsible for providing cover at the front of the building in case the suspects attempted to flee. Locked in a room with another individual, Bony Jean-Pierre ran to a window when the police burst in. Officer Gilbert fired a first plastic projectile at the window frame to dissuade him from fleeing, but he continued his maneuver despite the shouting of "Police." The police officer then fired a second plastic projectile aimed at the hip, but at the same time, Bony Jean-Pierre threw himself to the ground and was eventually hit in the head. He died a few days later in hospital. "Although the consequences of this event remain undeniably tragic, dramatic and catastrophic, it has not been demonstrated that Mr. Gilbert incurred criminal liability by using unjustified force. For these reasons, he is acquitted," ruled Judge Poulin. The police operation was properly planned, he said. The Crown has not been able to demonstrate beyond a reasonable doubt that Mr. Gilbert used excessive force against Bony Jean-Pierre. "The Tribunal accepts Mr. Gilbert's testimony that he was certain to hit Mr. Jean-Pierre's hip and that he never intended to hit him anywhere other than in this "green zone". In the eyes of the Tribunal, there is no evidence to doubt the candor, sincerity and reliability of Mr. Gilbert's testimony as a whole," he noted. Officer Gilbert's attorney insisted that his client never meant to reach for the suspect's head. "It's a sad combination of circumstances," said Me Louis Belleau. For his part, Will Prosper, documentary filmmaker, human rights activist and former police officer, called the decision a scandal. "To see that a police officer can shoot someone who is running away because he is panicking in an apartment, when there are stun grenades and he is just afraid for his life [...] it is a real scandal," he said. Officer Gilbert's attorney reiterated that "there is no dimension at all that would make one think there was a racial ingredient that influenced the conduct of the officers. This was an operation on a group of criminals who were dealing drugs in an apartment. Since this case had provoked a riot in Montreal North on April 6, 2016, the SPVM confirmed it was on the lookout Thursday night. At the time, protesters had ransacked the police station 39 Henri-Bourassa Boulevard, vandalized cars and smashed windows of nearby businesses. The Crown's lawyer, Me Jean-Sébastien Bussières, indicated that he will take the time to analyze the judgment before announcing whether or not he will appeal. With Jeanne Corriveau

titre: Mort d’une fillette à Granby: l’autre enfant de la famille confié à la DPJ
texte: The other child in the family of the martyred Granby girl will remain in foster care for at least the next six months, a judge ruled Tuesday, blaming the Youth Protection Branch (DPJ) for failing to protect the two children. Like her sister, the five-year-old child, whose identity cannot be revealed, would have suffered physical and psychological abuse from her father and stepmother. The 74-page judgment is under a publication ban, but Quebec Court Judge Mario Gervais allowed some details to be released in the public interest after Quebecor media filed a motion. In particular, the child's life story is described as "overwhelming and blood-curdlingly traumatic". "At five years of age, he is already a victim of life," wrote the magistrate. Following the tragic death of his sister, who died after suffering serious injuries while being tied up and confined in the family home last April, the child had been entrusted to the DPJ and placed in foster care. The child's stepmother has been charged with unpremeditated murder and forcible confinement and is scheduled to undergo a preliminary inquiry on February 24 and 25. His father was charged with neglect causing death, abandonment of child and failure to provide the necessities of life. Judge Gervais also pointed out that the DPJ had failed to take the necessary measures to protect the child and his sister. He stated that the DPJ had been informed of the abuse suffered by the children, but had not acted to protect them. "The DPJ failed in its obligations by not taking the necessary steps to protect the children," he said. "It is a tragedy that these children were left at the mercy of their parents while they were in danger." Judge Gervais also pointed out that the DPJ failed to take the necessary steps to protect the child and his sister. titre: Une mère de famille assassinée dans sa maison à Mascouche
texte: The murder of a mother of six children in Mascouche on Thursday would be linked to domestic violence. The victim's spouse was arrested at the end of the day. Jaël Cantin was murdered in the middle of the night at her home on Chemin des Anglais. Her husband, Benoit Cardinal, who was also found injured when police arrived, was arrested late Thursday, according to our information. The couple's six children were in the family home when the tragedy occurred. The Sûreté du Québec (SQ), which is in charge of the investigation, had been releasing information in dribs and drabs throughout the day. Ms. Cantin's spouse was considered a mere witness. At the end of the day, police confirmed the arrest of "a man in his thirties". "The law does not allow us to identify the suspect until formal charges are laid against him and he has not appeared," said Eloise Cossette, spokesperson for the SQ. The thesis of the marital drama, as well as that of a home invasion that would have gone wrong, has been studied. The building where the tragedy occurred is located next to a building that houses Cantin Service & Parts, which specializes in the repair and sale of household appliances. This business is owned by the victim's parents. Each child was met by the police. "It's complex because we're talking about a house where there were eight people, including six minors who had to be met one by one," explained Sergeant Cossette earlier. According to information gathered by our journalists, Ms. Cantin and Mr. Cardinal had been together for more than 10 years and formed a family with no history. Neighbors describe the couple as very loving and present for their children. "They were always together and very caring for their children," said one neighbor. "They were very respectful and very kind. I don't understand what could have happened. Neighbors are in shock and can't believe that their neighbor could have committed such an act. "It's very sad and shocking," said another neighbor. "It's a tragedy for the whole community." SQ investigators are still looking for witnesses and additional evidence to solve this case. Police have asked anyone with information about this case to contact the SQ.

titre: Quoi surveiller aujourd’hui?
texte: Appeal of Alexandre Bissonnette's sentence Almost three years after the murder of six worshippers gathered for prayer at the Islamic Cultural Centre in Quebec City, the sentence imposed on the killer, Alexandre Bissonnette, will be debated before the Court of Appeal. The 29-year-old man considers it "unreasonable" to have been sentenced to life imprisonment with no possibility of release before 40 years. This is the most severe sentence ever imposed in Quebec. The killer pleaded guilty to the premeditated murders of six men and attempted murders of about 40 other churchgoers on the evening of January 29, 2017. In sentencing him, Judge François Huot had positioned himself between the defense, which was asking for only 25 years, and the Crown, which was asking for a cumulative sentence of 150 years. The judge had to change the law because it only allowed him to impose a sentence in blocks of 25 years, which he considered unconstitutional. Parliament returns to Ottawa It's back to the House of Commons, which means that Parliament is back in session. The Liberals have been in the minority since last fall's election and are hopeful that they will succeed in imposing their priorities. At the top of the list of important issues is the ratification of the free trade agreement with the United States and Mexico. The Liberals are planning to introduce legislation as early as Wednesday. The government will also have to hurry up to expand access to medical assistance in dying in order to meet the deadlines imposed by the Quebec Superior Court. On the Conservative side, outgoing leader Andrew Scheer called on his troops not to be distracted by the leadership race and to play a full opposition role, including on the assault weapons ban bill. Bissonnette's appeal trial opens today and promises to be an important moment for the families of the victims and for the Muslim community in Quebec. Bissonnette's defence has stated that it will appeal the sentence of 40 years without the possibility of parole, arguing that the sentence is "unreasonable" and "disproportionate". The Crown has stated that it will support the sentence and oppose any attempt to reduce it. The appeal trial will be an opportunity for the victims' families to have their voices heard and to testify about the impact this act of violence had on their lives. The families of the victims have stated that they are prepared to testify and have their voices heard in the Court of Appeal. They hope that the appeal will advance the cause of justice and peace. The Bissonnette appeal is an important moment for Quebec and for Canada. It is important that justice be done and that the families of the victims obtain justice. It is also an important moment for the Muslim community in Quebec, which has been deeply affected by the terrorist attack. The Muslim community in Quebec hopes that the appeal will advance the cause of justice and peace.

titre: Un mort à la suite d'une dispute familiale à Blainville
texte: All indications are that a son killed his father in front of his mother in their Blainville family home on Wednesday. "When the police arrived, they found that people were injured and had to be transported to the hospital," explained Jonathan Tremblay, spokesman for the Blainville Police Department. The father eventually succumbed to his injuries. The arrest of a man in his twenties was confirmed late in the evening by the Sûreté du Québec (SQ), which took over the investigation. "The man is currently detained and will be met by investigators. Moreover, the service of investigations on crimes against the person is on site to clarify the circumstances surrounding this death, "said Claude Denis, spokesman for the SQ. Crisis The Blainville police officers had first indicated that they were called around 2:15 p.m. for a "family dispute" on George-Hériot Street. Later in the evening, the SQ clarified that the initial call was for a person in crisis. According to witnesses, the argument started inside the house and then moved outside. Neighbors reported hearing yelling and screaming coming from the house before police arrived. Police found the father of the family seriously injured and immediately called paramedics. Despite the efforts of paramedics, the father died at the hospital. The SQ said the investigation will continue and toxicology tests will be conducted on the suspect. Investigators are looking to determine if any illicit substances or drugs were consumed prior to the incident. The SQ also said it will investigate the suspect's family history and criminal history. Neighbors said the family was known for frequent arguments and police were often called to intervene. Neighbors said the family was very secretive and they did not know much about them. The SQ said it will work closely with the Blainville Police Department to clarify the circumstances surrounding this tragic death. Investigators are looking into whether factors such as alcohol or drug use, domestic violence or family history contributed to the tragedy.

titre: Une vingtaine de détenus présentent des symptômes du coronavirus
texte: Nearly two dozen incarcerated individuals have had to be placed in isolation in the past few days because they have symptoms related to the coronavirus. A total of 18 inmates have shown the main symptoms of COVID-19, which are fever, coughing or difficulty breathing, the Department of Public Safety confirms. Of these offenders, 10 are in Bordeaux prison, 4 in Rivière-des-Prairies, 2 in Laval and 2 in Quebec City. At the time of writing, the department could not confirm whether these inmates have the virus, nor whether they have been investigated. Avoiding the worst The only way to avoid the worst in the current pandemic context is to reduce the prison population, argues the Ligue des droits et libertés (LDL). "The virus could spread like wildfire in a forest because of the overcrowding, the cramped conditions and the architectural configuration of the prisons," says Lucie Lemonde, spokesperson for the LDL. The organization is asking Quebec City to release certain types of offenders to limit the spread of the virus, including offenders over 60, pregnant offenders, sick inmates and those scheduled for release in 2020 and 2021. | The Department of Public Safety said it will take steps to ensure that inmates who show symptoms of the coronavirus are isolated and receive appropriate care. "We are aware of the risks the virus can pose to inmates and prison staff and are taking steps to ensure that all inmates who show symptoms are isolated and receive appropriate care," the department said. The department also said it is working with health authorities to ensure that the necessary health and safety measures are in place in prisons. "We are working closely with health authorities to ensure that the necessary health and safety measures are in place in prisons and that inmates and staff are protected," the department said. The department also said it is putting measures in place to ensure that inmates who are released are not infected with the virus. "We are in the process of putting measures in place to ensure that inmates who are released are not infected with the virus and that the necessary health and safety measures are put in place to protect them," the department said. The department also said it is working with community organizations to ensure that inmates who are released receive the support they need. "We are working with community organizations to ensure that inmates who are released receive the support they need to adjust to life outside of prison," the department said.

titre: La délation, mesure ultime de protection
texte: Although Quebec City has banned all outdoor and indoor gatherings to limit the spread of the coronavirus, Audrey* saw many visitors arrive at a neighbor's house. Like many Quebecers, she felt torn between her civic responsibility to call the police and the fear of looking like a panicker. "Should I have reported it? How far does our civic responsibility go?" asked Audrey in an email to Le Devoir. Audrey's reflection is present in the minds of many citizens since the Prime Minister, François Legault, formulated new directives to fight against COVID-19. On Wednesday, Gatineau police issued a $1,000 ticket to a resident who hosted a party at his home with five friends, following a report. On social networks, photos of seniors in a grocery store or young people gathered in a park are also proliferating. "The idea is that at this time there are considerable efforts that are required of everyone. Whether it's confinement or stopping economic activities, everyone is making a personal sacrifice that is important," says Corinne Gendron, a professor in the Department of Social and Environmental Responsibility at UQAM's School of Management Sciences. As for these efforts, "obedient" citizens may be shocked to see that others do not comply with the instructions of the director of public health, Horacio Arruda, who urges Quebecers on a daily basis to isolate themselves in order to "flatten the curve". "The propensity to want to denounce people can be motivated by a personal perspective. If you take away a certain amount of freedom [for the common good], you want everyone to make the same effort to get out of the situation," notes Gendron. Roxana* was exposed to this reality when she had to demand that her roommate leave their home because he refused to follow public health guidelines. "I had the flu, pneumonia, and a respiratory tract infection. Before it was even recommended, I had already isolated myself because I know my system is too weak right now not to get the virus," she explains. Until earlier this week, however, her roommate continued to go out to gather with friends and failed to disinfect items he touched once he returned to the apartment. "I tried to remind him that it wasn't going to be like this forever, that it's temporary, but I feel like he thought I was controlling and over the top. I had to tell him that either he would leave the house for the next two weeks or I would call the police," says Roxana, still shaken by the warning. "I didn't want him to be fined, but I thought that if a police officer talked to him, maybe he would realize the seriousness of his behaviour during a pandemic," she adds. This realization is shared by many citizens who, like Audrey and Roxana, are faced with the difficulty of turning in their neighbors or relatives. "Whistleblowing is a last resort, but it is necessary to protect public health," says Gendron. "It is important to remember that tattling is not a form of denunciation, but a form of civic responsibility," she adds. This citizen responsibility is encouraged by the Quebec government, which has set up a system for reporting violations of health regulations. Citizens can report violations by filling out a form online or by calling 1-877-644-4545. Police officers can then issue $1,000 tickets to those who do not follow the guidelines. However, tattling is not without risk. "There is a risk of stigmatization and marginalization of those who are reported," says Gendron. "It is important to remember that tattling is not a form of revenge, but a form of civic responsibility," she adds. Despite these risks, tattling can be an effective way to protect public health. "Whistleblowing is an ultimate measure, but it is necessary to protect public health," says Gendron. "It is important to remember that whistleblowing is not a form of revenge, but a form of civic responsibility," she adds. Ultimately, the decision to report or not to report a neighbor or loved one is personal. "Everyone must make their decision based on their own conscience and ethics," concludes Ms. Gendron. "Whistle-blowing is not a form of revenge, but a form of civic responsibility," she reminds us.

titre: «Animal Crossing», ou s’évader sur des îles entre amis
texte: Despite public health guidelines, Catherine and Melanie have found a way to get around the confinement rules. Every day, they visit each other, chat in their kitchen and organize cultural outings. Like thousands of other gamers, they have found a cure for the isolation imposed by the pandemic through the simulation game Animal Crossing: New Horizons. "I didn't think that not being able to go out would have such an impact," says Mélanie Presseau-Dumais, a Quebecer who has been living in Boston since November. Following her move, Ms. Presseau-Dumais realized how difficult it was to stay in touch with her social circle in Montreal without travelling. However, the confinement required by the COVID-19 crisis has just allowed her to reconnect with several friends, who like her, find refuge on their virtual island. Thousands of them around the world are connecting to their Nintendo Switch systems to rediscover the banality of certain actions that are sometimes forbidden because of the pandemic. Redecorating a room in their house, cultivating their garden, hunting insects or catching fish: the activities that allow them to "escape" are numerous, and some are even done in groups. "It's become a daily date with my friend. Every day, we call each other and we visit our respective islands and talk about the layout of our gardens, the new rooms in our houses, we discuss everything and nothing like before and it feels really good," says Mélanie Presseau-Dumais. A regular in online games, she is also part of a chatroom with a few other friends, where players share tips on how to improve their respective islands. The ability to get together, even if not physically, is what prompted Catherine and Axel to recommend the game to several of their friends. The couple bought the game as soon as it was released on March 19, since Catherine had just returned from a trip and expected the lockdown to last for weeks. "I'm not ready to say it helps me escape the COVID-19 crisis, but it's the way I found to do my social," says the CEGEP professor. The non-competitive nature of the game has also allowed Axel - on his island named "Quarantine", a nod to the pandemic - to keep his bearings during a time when some people lose track of time. "It helps to have a little routine. There are still daily goals to accomplish, so when you spend as little as an hour a day, you can get a lot of things done and it feels good," he says. This new way of having fun and connecting with friends has also allowed Catherine and Melanie to discover aspects of themselves that they hadn't explored before. "I've always been a very creative person, but I never had the opportunity to show it," says Catherine. "With Animal Crossing, I was able to express my creativity by decorating my island and making things. It's a way to express myself that I hadn't discovered before." Melanie, on the other hand, found gaming a way to escape from reality and relax. "I've always been a very active person and I have trouble sitting still for more than a few minutes. With Animal Crossing, I can move around and explore my island without having to leave my living room. It's a way to entertain and relax without having to leave my house." This new way of entertaining and connecting with friends has also allowed Catherine and Melanie to discover aspects of themselves that they hadn't explored before. The game has also helped Catherine and Melanie develop their sense of community. "I've met people from all over the world and been able to exchange ideas and tips with them," says Catherine. "It's a way to feel connected to people who share the same interests as me." Melanie has also found a community in the game. "I've met people who share the same ideas and values as me. It's a way to feel connected to people who share the same interests as me." "I've always been a very creative person, but I never had the opportunity to show it," says Catherine. "With Animal Crossing, I was able to express my creativity by decorating my island and making things. It's a way to express myself that I hadn't discovered before." Melanie, on the other hand, found gaming a way to escape from reality and relax. "I've always been a very active person and I have trouble sitting still for more than a few minutes. With Animal Crossing, I can move around and explore my island without having to leave my living room. It's a way to entertain and relax without having to leave my house." The game has also helped Catherine and Melanie develop a sense of responsibility. "I've learned to take care of my island and to take care of my neighbors," says Catherine. "It's a way to take care of my environment and make sure everyone is happy and safe." Melanie has also found a way to feel responsible. "I've learned to take care of my island and to take care of my neighbors. It's a way to take care of my environment and make sure everyone is happy and safe." This new way of having fun and connecting with friends has allowed Catherine and Melanie to discover aspects of themselves that they had not yet explored, to feel connected to people who share the same interests as they do, and to develop their sense of responsibility.

titre: Apprendre à pratiquer la religion virtuellement
texte: YouTube, Instagram and Facebook, it is through social networks that Father Dominic LeRouzès has reached many believers since the beginning of the pandemic. This priest, undoubtedly one of the most tech-savvy in the province, offers daily appointments to celebrate Mass or moments of meditation, while waiting for places of worship to reopen. "Currently, the opening of the places of worship is at the bottom of the list of the different phases of deconfinement. There's not even a date set, so there's definitely a buzz about what we're doing online," says the man everyone calls "Father Dominic." It's hard at first glance to believe that the 46-year-old vicar, dressed soberly in a black clergyman and sporting a Roman collar, would describe himself as a youtuber. "Priests are often imagined as very old people, living in a rectory and waiting for people to come to them for confession," he says. Father Dominic is far from that image. "When I was young and accompanied my parents to Mass, I suffered! I loved God, I loved being able to take communion, but every time I did, I wondered how the 'tunes' could be so flat, when outside we were listening to good music," he says. He quickly realized that in order to bring the word of God to people, you have to speak the same language. "For me, the meeting of faith and culture is crucial, because if we remain confined to our 'cathosphere', we are like a drop of oil in the middle of the water," he says. When the closure of places of worship was announced by Prime Minister François Legault on March 15, he immediately launched the idea of webcasting the Mass. "The goal was to be able to continue to support people during this ordeal," Father Dominic emphasizes. "I know I'm exploding a lot of prejudices. I am exploring a new way of being a priest, while remaining faithful to the Catholic faith," he continues. With the Diocese of Quebec, not only did the project become a reality, but it also gave rise to three other daily appointments on the ECDQ.tv website, the web TV of the Catholic Church of Quebec. Completed in less than a day, the project even led Father Dominic to move from Beauce to Quebec City for the duration of the pandemic. Each morning, at 9:00 a.m. sharp, a "report of the day" is presented to give an update on the latest news. This week, Father Dominic even took advantage of his platform to promote blood donations. "For me, it is important to show that a priest is not just in a church praying. There's something else, there's a commitment to the community, and this is a concrete and encouraging gesture," he says. Father Dominic is aware that practicing religion online will never replace doing it in person. "I don't want people to feel guilty if they can't connect to Mass online. I want people to know that they can still pray at home, even if they can't connect to the online Mass," he explains. Father Dominic believes that online worship can be a powerful tool to help people connect to their faith. "I think technology can be a powerful tool to help people connect to their faith and their community. That's why I think it's important to continue to offer religious services online, even after the pandemic is over," he says. titre: Rendre l’uniforme invisible
texte: While eyes are focused on police interventions around the world, in Longueuil, a patroller has been trying for four years to find the right balance between prevention and repression. Equipped with his helmet and skateboard, Thierry Hinse-Fillion travels the skateparks of the South Shore to break down prejudices about his profession, while building relationships with young people. Meeting. "In 2017, it was really a shock element [when people saw me arrive in] uniform," recalls Officer Hinse-Fillion. "As soon as the police car pulled into a skatepark parking lot, everyone would turn around and analyze to figure out what happened, what they did wrong," he says. Four years later, his presence still surprises, but soon the citizens seem to appreciate it. "With the crisis of the COVID, for the City of Longueuil, it was important to have a police presence to listen to people and to target if there were problems or any distress", explains the police officer. Listen to our interview with Thierry Hinse-Fillion Le Devoir met him, the skateboarder-patroller, at Christ-Roi Park where he is used to put forward his skills acquired when he was a teenager. "Skateboarding has always been a passion for me," admits the man who now has the chance to combine it with his profession. As soon as he arrived on the platform on this June afternoon, his presence aroused the interest of young people and their parents. "Can I take a picture of you with my son?" asks Dany Ouellet, whose 12-year-old son, Anthony, comes to train on his new skateboard. "When my dad told me about the police officer on a skateboard, I didn't know if it was real or if he was making a joke, I didn't think I'd run into him so soon," confides Anthony, who admits to being impressed by the officer's tricks. "It's a really nice approach, I think it's also a nice influence for young people who see that it's someone like them," adds his father. Sébastien Laplaine met Thierry at the beginning of the month and already sees him as a model. "We have the same passion and I think it's inspiring for us because we can really talk about everything with him, not just skateboarding, but life too," says the 18-year-old. This clientele is used to seeing the repressive side [of the police], whether it's because of a smoking or drinking issue, or because they're out of hours [at the skatepark] - Thierry Hinse-Fillion That's one of the officer's goals, to avoid having the only opportunity to interact with a police officer be related to a 911 call. "This clientele is used to seeing the repressive side [of the police], whether it's because of a smoking or drinking issue, or because they're out of order [at the skatepark]. I want young people to understand that the police are there to help them and not to punish them," explains Thierry Hinse-Fillion. "I want them to know they can talk to me and trust me. That's why, in addition to patrolling skateparks, the officer is involved in prevention and awareness projects. "I've had the opportunity to participate in prevention workshops with high school kids, where I talk to them about drug and alcohol use and their consequences," he says. "I also explain to them that the police are there to help them and not to punish them." Thierry Hinse-Fillion is also involved in road safety awareness projects. "I have had the opportunity to participate in road safety workshops with elementary school children, where I talk to them about the dangers of the road and the consequences of reckless driving," he explains. "I also explain to them that the police are there to help them and not to punish them." Thierry Hinse-Fillion believes that his presence in skateparks and his interventions with youth help improve the relationship between the police and the community. "I think it's important to show young people that the police are there to help them and not to punish them," he says. "I want them to know they can talk to me and trust me."

titre: Violence conjugale: tuée par son ex, mais jamais retrouvée
texte: "I am a battered woman" would have been the last words spoken by Josiane Arguin, a 34-year-old Montreal woman who was allegedly killed by her spouse in a context of domestic violence in September 2018. For nearly two months, the accused, whose trial opened Wednesday, faked her disappearance, even putting up posters himself to find her. "Before he went after Josiane, the latter was leaving the home, she was heading to the backyard and shouting that she was a beaten woman," explained Crown prosecutor Katerine Brabant, at the opening of the trial of Simon Brind'Amour. The 38-year-old man faces charges of second-degree murder and contempt of a corpse. Ms. Arguin's remains have never been found. The Crown intends to show that Mr. Brind'Amour killed his spouse on or about September 1st, cleaned her body, put the body in a field hockey bag and then disposed of it in a dumpster. "About 15 days after causing the death of his spouse, Mr. Brind'Amour went to the police station to report Josiane missing. He also indicated that she had left with part of the couple's money," said Mr. Brabant. Mr. Brind'Amour's statement triggered a two-month investigation during which steps were taken to try to find her. Mr. Brind'Amour's trial revealed that the victim had been a victim of domestic violence for several years. Witnesses testified that Mr. Brind'Amour was very possessive and jealous and that he was aggressive and abusive towards Ms. Arguin. Neighbors reported hearing screaming and crying from the couple's apartment. Friends and family members of Ms. Arguin said she tried to leave Mr. Brind'Amour on several occasions, but he would not let her. The prosecutor also presented evidence that Mr. Brind'Amour had purchased cleaning supplies and field hockey bags before Ms. Arguin disappeared. texte: Gilbert Rozon maintains that it is rather he who "let himself be done" by the alleged victim at his trial for rape and indecent assault. The founder of Just for Laughs claimed Wednesday to have "accepted his fate" after the plaintiff had initiated a sexual relationship after a night in a discotheque in the Laurentians in 1980. "As surprising as it may seem, I woke up around 7 a.m. and I had [the complainant] astride me. She was making love to me," said the Just for Laughs founder. Dressed all in black, the former comedy mogul calmly took the witness stand on Wednesday. The 65-year-old man, who introduced himself as a "retiree", confirmed that he spent an evening with the complainant, whom he met in a radio station 40 years ago, but contradicted his version of events. "I know people will find it unbelievable, but that's what I experienced. I wouldn't make up a story like that," he said. Mr. Rozon gave a detailed account of the evening, first emphasizing that he never claimed to have to retrieve documents from his secretary. The residence where the events took place is the cottage of a friend who was studying law with him. Rozon said that once they arrived at their destination, he lit a fireplace to create a "romantic" atmosphere. Far from the shoving match described the day before by the alleged victim, he said he began to caress her, after which an exchange of kisses took place. "I wanted to put my hand under her skirt," he said, miming the gesture before Judge Melanie Hébert. "She stiffened and she told me no and I stopped right away," he said. He denied having "ripped" any button from the woman's blouse as she claimed in court during her testimony. "Depressed", Mr. Rozon said he suggested to the complainant to go to bed on their own, in two different rooms. "I remember thinking that maybe she was menstruating or had a boyfriend in her life [...] I also thought that maybe she was a virgin," he explained, adding that he did not, however, ask her about the discomfort she seemed to have felt. titre: Comme une «gifle» au visage des victimes
texte: The strength of numbers will not have succeeded in shaking the pillars of justice, says Les Courageuses, after suffering a major setback before the Supreme Court that puts an end to the class action they wanted to bring against Gilbert Rozon. "It's a slap in the face, not only for Les Courageuses, but for all victims of sexual assault," said comedian Patricia Tulasne, spokesperson for Les Courageuses. The highest court in the land rejected the Courageous Girls' request for an appeal on Monday. As is usually the case, the Supreme Court does not have to explain the reasons for its decision. The former comedy mogul has won his case almost two years after the proceedings began: the 66-year-old will not be eligible for a class action suit. "Since the beginning of this legal process, we have repeated that a class action cannot be used in this type of situation, where each case is individual and must be proven on a case-by-case basis," commented Rozon's lawyer, Me Raymond Doray. "We are very happy that this is now recognized by the Supreme Court, [which] puts an end to a process that we have always considered to be unjustified," he added. It's a slap in the face, not just to Les Courageuses, but to all victims of sexual assault - Patricia Tulasne Created in the wake of the #MeAlso whistleblower movement, Les Courageuses was made up of about 20 women claiming to have been assaulted by Gilbert Rozon, between 1982 and 2016. Together, they wished to bring this action against the former comedy mogul to obtain a compensation of 10 million in punitive damages only. They believed they were victims of a modus operandi created by Rozon, whom they accused of sexually harassing or assaulting them, or both. "It's really disappointing and shocking," Tulasne said in an interview with Le Devoir. "The Supreme Court is willing to listen to Mike Ward making fun of a disabled person, but it won't listen to women who are victims of the most widespread sex crime in the country. It's as if they are telling us that the case is not worthwhile," she added with emotion. A novel case What we must not lose sight of, lawyers point out, is that the Courageous Women's action was a novel case, since it was the first time in the country that a petition was filed only against an individual without linking it to an institution. "In the eyes of society, it was a highly symbolic case because it was linked to the #MeAlso movement. The risks of disappointment are high because, in court, these cases are treated like any other," said Sophie Gagnon, Executive Director of Juripop, which provides services to victims of sexual violence. Despite this defeat, Les Courageuses do not intend to give up. "We are not going to stop here. We will continue to fight for victims of sexual assault to be heard and for their rights to be respected," said Tulasne. "We are going to continue to fight for sexual assault victims to be recognized and their rights to be protected," she added. "We will continue to fight for sexual assault victims to be supported and for their voices to be heard," she concluded. This Supreme Court decision raises questions about how victims of sexual assault are treated by the justice system. "It is very difficult for victims to prove their charges and have their voices heard," said Gagnon. "It is important for victims to know that they are not alone and that they can find support and help," she added. The Courageous Women said they will continue to fight to have their voices heard and their rights respected. titre: La SQ propose une grande fusion des corps de police
texte: The Sûreté du Québec (SQ) is proposing a major overhaul of the province's police map that could reduce the number of police forces from 31 to seven. Smaller police forces would have the choice of merging or joining the SQ, the organization proposed in its brief released Friday as part of the consultation on the reality of policing. "If we want to be uniform, effective and efficient, the police forces must join together," said Johanne Beausoleil, interim director general of the SQ. For the first time since her arrival at the head of the national police force a year ago, Ms. Beausoleil spoke to the media, including Le Devoir, to present the brief submitted by the SQ as part of the reflection on the green paper on police. Among the key recommendations, the SQ submits the idea of merging as many police forces as possible. In an "extreme" scenario, the Quebec territory would be served by seven police forces instead of the current 31. "If we take the North Shore, currently we have police forces in Saint-Jérôme, Mirabel, Sainte-Thérèse, Saint-Eustache, Deux-Montagnes, and the SQ, we are present in Oka. We are full of entities that each work with their own resources when there is a way to offer more efficient services by grouping together instead of all working in small independence," says Ms. Beausoleil. In the same vein, the SQ is considering pooling resources and equipment. "The last year [with the pandemic] was a year of cooperation and teamwork. We want everyone to have the means to achieve their ambitions, even the smallest police forces," she says. However, the SQ did not want to draw this new map. "What we're saying is that we should either regroup into a regional board or give them the opportunity to integrate into the SQ," says Beausoleil. The organization is proposing to reduce the number of service levels to three from the current six established by the Ministry of Public Security. Currently, municipal police forces must provide a certain level of service based on the population they serve or their geographic location. Cities with populations of less than 100,000, such as Granby, are currently classified as level 1, while Montreal, with a population of over 1 million, is classified as level 5. Rather than population as a criterion, the SQ proposes to take workload into account. The SQ is also proposing to implement a system for sharing information between police forces. "We want information to be shared between the different police forces so that police officers can work more efficiently and effectively," says Beausoleil. "We also want police officers to be able to work in a more collaborative and efficient manner, and for information to be shared between different police forces." The SQ is also proposing to implement a system of training and development for police officers. "We want police officers to be trained and developed in a consistent manner, so that they can provide quality services to the public," Beausoleil adds. "We also want police officers to be able to work more efficiently and effectively, and for information to be shared between different police forces." The SQ is also proposing to implement a system of surveillance and monitoring of police activities. "We want police officers to be monitored and controlled in a consistent manner to ensure that police services are provided appropriately and in accordance with the law," Beausoleil says. "We also want police officers to be able to work more efficiently and effectively, and for information to be shared between different police forces." The SQ is also proposing to implement a human resources management system. "We want police officers to be managed in a consistent manner, to ensure that police services are provided appropriately and in accordance with the law," Beausoleil adds. "We also want police officers to be able to work more efficiently and effectively, and for information to be shared between different police forces." The SQ also proposes to implement a financial management system. "We want police force finances to be managed in a consistent manner to ensure that police services are provided appropriately and in accordance with the law," Beausoleil concludes. "We also want police officers to be able to work more efficiently and effectively, and for information to be shared across police agencies."

titre: Procès pour viol et attentat à la pudeur: Gilbert Rozon acquitté
texte: Gilbert Rozon gets out for the second time in court since the outbreak of the #MeAlso movement. In front of two versions at the opposite ends of the spectrum, the court acquitted Tuesday the former humor magnate Gilbert Rozon of rape and indecent assault charges against him. The trial was looking at events that occurred 40 years ago in Saint-Sauveur, in the Laurentians. "The slogan "believe the victim", pushed by the #MeAlso movement, has no place in criminal law, it is contrary to the principle of the presumption of innocence," said Judge Melanie Hebert as she read her judgment. Visibly relieved, Gilbert Rozon was discreet and did not want to talk to the media when he left the Montreal courthouse. "I have no comments," he said. The trial of the founder of Just for Laughs began in October, almost three years to the day after the first tremors related to the #MeToo movement. The hearings were marked by an important leap in time since the facts of which Mr. Rozon is accused occurred in 1980. Judge Mélanie Hébert found herself with two contradictory versions. The only elements on which the complainant's and Mr. Rozon's accounts were similar concerned their meeting at a radio station in the Laurentians at the time when Mr. Rozon was organizing the La Grande Virée festival, as well as their outing to a Saint-Sauveur nightclub. "Even if the Court does not believe Mr. Rozon's version of the facts, it nevertheless raises a reasonable doubt [...] Given the existence of this doubt [...], Mr. Rozon must be acquitted of the charges against him," she ruled. The judge referred to a 1991 Supreme Court decision, colloquially known as "W.D.", which sets out the procedure to follow in this type of situation. "It is true that the parties are not on equal footing before the Tribunal. But it is important to remember that this inequality results from the application of the principle of the presumption of innocence," noted the magistrate. She also praised the courage of the complainant and recalled that this acquittal does not mean that the alleged facts did not occur. The Crown prosecutor, Me Bruno Ménard, indicated that it is too early to say whether he will appeal. "Just before the verdict was rendered, the complainant asked Judge Hébert to lift the publication ban on her identity. The 60-year-old woman spoke to the media for the first time as she left the courtroom. "This is a dark day," said Annick Charette, as several members of Les Courageuses looked on. "I am another example of the limitations of the sexual violence justice system... I am disappointed, but I don't regret pressing charges," she added. "I know I am not the only one who has gone through this experience and I want others to know that it is possible to stand up and speak out." Annick Charette also noted that the trial was a difficult ordeal, but that she was glad to have been able to testify. "I am proud that I was able to tell the truth and fight for justice," she said. "I know I'm not the only one who has gone through this experience and I want others to know that it is possible to stand up and speak out." The verdict drew mixed reactions. Members of Les Courageuses expressed their disappointment, but also praised the courage of the plaintiff. "We are disappointed with the verdict, but we are proud of Annick Charette and all the women who dared to speak out," said Marie-Ève Larivière, spokesperson for the group. "We will continue to fight for women to be heard and for their stories to be taken seriously." The verdict also drew reactions from women's rights advocates. "This is a very disappointing decision," said Gabrielle Bouchard, president of the Fédération des femmes du Québec. "We are aware that the justice system is imperfect and that women often face obstacles in obtaining justice. titre: Annick Charette en lutte pour une réforme du système
texte: Following the acquittal of Gilbert Rozon, the complainant Annick Charette admits she is still in shock, believing that she was only a spectator during the trial for rape and indecent assault of the former humor magnate. She now measures the disproportion of means between the accused and the alleged victim and wishes to see the justice system reformed. "I had to climb a mountain 10 times higher than the accused, who only had to plant the notion of reasonable doubt somewhere," said Ms. Charette in an interview with Le Devoir. Despite the outcome of the trial, the 60-year-old woman does not regret having embarked on this judicial process almost three years ago to the day, when the Director of Criminal and Penal Prosecutions told her that of the 14 complaints analyzed, only hers had been retained. "It would be a step backwards to say that it wasn't worth it. If we say that, it gives a free hand to all the aggressors and that is the last thing I want," she repeats. "What I want is for them to feel that everyone has an eye on this and that time will soon be up." The reason she asked Judge Melanie Hebert to lift the publication ban on her identity Tuesday was so she could speak out about the journey of struggle that survivors of sexual violence go through. "What more could I have done?" she asks herself since Judge Hebert issued her decision. "I think I was a good witness. Yes, there are holes in my story, but it's been 40 years since it happened. I'm an honest person, I didn't try to fill those holes, but my honesty didn't pay off," she says. Catching up The disconnect between the social awareness following the #MeAlso movement and the reality of the courts cannot continue, she believes. "The ruling [handed down Tuesday] makes sense in terms of the law, but is absurd in terms of what society wants," she points out. Her greatest frustration is that the plaintiffs are still only observers in a trial that concerns an event they experienced. "It is true that the parties are not on equal footing before the Tribunal. But it is important to remember that this inequality results from the application of the principle of the presumption of innocence," Justice Hébert emphasized in her judgment. In his case, this inequity was illustrated by the fact that the accused had the benefit of the advice of not one, but three lawyers, two of whom were among the best legal minds in the province. "They were able to go through every comma in [my statement to the police] and find ways to destabilize me. It's been three years since Mr. Rozon knew what I was going to say, it's been three years since Mr. Rozon had time to prepare his defense and find ways to discredit me," she laments. "I don't want victims to be in a position where they have to defend themselves against lawyers who are paid to find holes in their story. Annick Charette wants the court system to be reformed so that victims of sexual violence are no longer put on trial and their testimony is taken seriously. "I want victims to be heard and their stories to be taken into account," she concludes. "I want people to understand that it's not easy to talk about these kinds of things and it's not easy to be in court."

titre: Mamadi Camara libéré des accusations portées contre lui
texte: The man charged with attempted murder after he allegedly disarmed and injured a police officer was cleared of all charges Wednesday following new information revealed by the investigation. "Following the evolution of the investigation and the latest information communicated, we believe that it is no longer possible to support, in the current state of affairs, the charges against [the suspect]," explained the Public Ministry. Mamadi III Fara Camara regained his freedom in a major turn of events. The 31-year-old was the main suspect in a manhunt after a police intervention went wrong last Friday. Detained for four days, Mr. Camara was at the Montreal courthouse for his release hearing. Mr. Camara's lawyer, Cedric Materne, refused to specify what led to this sudden turn of events. "You understand that this is a stay of proceedings for now. The investigation continues, so we will not necessarily go into details," he said at the Montreal courthouse. "If there is a stay of proceedings that does not support the charges, it is that clearly there was evidence that it was potentially not him." Materne said the family and his firm were relieved with the news. On Friday, the Montreal Police Service (SPVM) reported that a motorist stopped in connection with a traffic violation had physically attacked a police officer in the Parc-Extension area. The SPVM reported "an altercation during which the police officer was disarmed and injured", but could not specify whether he was hit by a projectile. Mamadi Camara was released from all charges and was allowed to go free. Mr. Camara's family and lawyer are relieved by this news and hope that justice will be done. "We are happy that justice has been served and that Mamadi has been released," said Mr. Camara's brother, Mamadou Camara. "We are grateful to all those who worked hard to ensure that the truth was revealed and that Mamadi was released." The SPVM said the investigation is ongoing and investigators are continuing to gather evidence and information. "We are aware that this case has generated a lot of interest and concern in the community," said SPVM spokesman Jean-Pierre Brabant. "We will continue to work diligently to ensure that all the facts are examined and that justice is done." The prosecution said the investigation is ongoing and investigators continue to gather evidence and information. "We are aware that this case has generated a lot of interest and concern in the community," said Crown Prosecutor Jean-Francois Lévesque. "We will continue to work diligently to ensure that all the facts are examined and that justice is done." The Crown also said it is important to remember that anyone accused of a crime is presumed innocent until found guilty in court. "We are aware that this case has generated a great deal of interest and concern in the community," the prosecutor said. "We will continue to work diligently to ensure that all the facts are examined and that justice is served." Mamadi Camara was cleared of all charges and allowed to regain his freedom. He was greeted by family and friends as he left the courthouse. "We are happy that Mamadi is free and that justice has been done," said his mother, Mme Fatoumata Camara. "We are grateful to all those who worked hard to ensure that the truth was revealed and that Mamadi was released."

titre: Le poids de la violence
texte: They have often seen and heard it all, yet data on children exposed to domestic violence are almost non-existent in Quebec, at a time when reports of women against their spouses are on the rise. These collateral victims must not be forgotten in the fight against domestic violence, say experts and workers in the field. "The exposure of children to domestic violence has not been studied for very long, compared to other forms of abuse, such as sexual abuse, physical abuse or neglect," notes Geneviève Lessard, Director of the Centre for Applied and Interdisciplinary Research on Intimate, Family and Structural Violence (RAIV). Children exposed to violence Approximately 7% of children in Quebec were exposed to domestic violence experienced by their mothers in the 12 months preceding the latest survey by the Institut de la statistique du Québec, conducted in 2018. About 6% of children were exposed to psychological and verbal abuse, including insults or threats, 2% to abuse in the form of control, such as being followed or not being allowed to see friends, and about 1% were exposed to physical abuse, having witnessed their mother being hit or other aggressive actions. These data likely underestimate the reality of young people growing up in a climate of stress and tension caused by domestic violence, Lessard believes. She and a team of researchers recently conducted a qualitative survey on the consequences of exposure to domestic violence, in which 40 young people aged 18 to 25 participated. This essay is part of our Perspectives section. "The term "exposure" is used to avoid confusion, as youth do not always visually witness the events. However, even if it is an indirect victimization, the consequences can be as serious as those experienced by a direct victim," says the full professor at Laval University's School of Social Work and Criminology. One of the findings is that children experience virtually the same relationship dynamics as their mother with the abusive partner during the four phases of the abuse cycle. "They feel the tension, fear the escalation of violence, then, when it explodes, they will live with a sense of guilt, shame and responsibility for not having been able to defuse the situation," explains Lessard. Then there's a lull: the abusive partner justifies his actions and, like his mother, the child hopes it won't happen again," she notes. The consequences of exposure to domestic violence are multiple and can have long-term repercussions. Children may develop anxiety disorders, mood disorders and behavioural problems, and their school performance may suffer. Young people may also be at greater risk of developing risky behaviors, such as drug and alcohol use, and of becoming involved in violent situations. "Children who grow up in a climate of domestic violence are more likely to become victims or perpetrators of violence as adults," Lessard says. Children may also be affected by the fact that their mothers cannot always provide the support and protection they need. "Children can feel very alone and isolated because they don't always have the support of their mother, who is abused herself," Lessard says. Children can also face financial hardship and mental health issues because their mothers may be too busy dealing with domestic violence to take care of their needs. Experts and practitioners agree that recognizing and addressing children exposed to domestic violence is critical. "It is important to recognize that children are collateral victims and to offer them services adapted to their needs," Lessard said. Services must be tailored to the needs of children and must include psychosocial interventions, support services and referral services. "It is important to ensure that children receive the support they need to overcome the consequences of exposure to domestic violence," Lessard concludes.

titre: ​Annick Charette poursuit Gilbert Rozon au civil pour ​agression sexuelle
texte: Six months after Gilbert Rozon's acquittal, plaintiff Annick Charette turned to civil court and claimed $1.3 million. She becomes the fourth woman to file a lawsuit against the former comedy star, whom she accuses of not only raping her in 1980, but also of lying and portraying her as a "loose cannon" during his trial last October. "In his testimony at the criminal trial, [Gilbert Rozon] lied not only by denying [Annick Charette's] version of events, but also by inventing a scenario that reversed the roles, a grotesque scenario in which [she] was the aggressor and [Mr.] Rozon was the victim," reads the motion filed Wednesday at the Montreal courthouse. Annick Charette filed a complaint with the police in the wake of the #MoiAussi movement in October 2017 after nine women recounted assaults by Mr. Rozon to Le Devoir as well as 98.5 FM. Of the fourteen complaints analyzed by the Director of Criminal and Penal Prosecutions, only his had been retained. In December, the court acquitted the Just for Laughs founder of rape and indecent assault charges. Since she has not seen Mr. Rozon convicted, Ms. Charette has decided to follow in the footsteps of comedian Patricia Tulasne, who on April 15 became the first woman to file an individual civil suit against him for $1.6 million, as well as director Lyne Charlebois, who is seeking $1.7 million, and artist Danie Frenette, who is seeking $2.2 million. By opting for the civil route, Ms. Charette will not have to prove Mr. Rozon's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Instead, the civil case is called proof by a preponderance, meaning that she will have to convince a judge that it is more likely that she was raped than that the assault did not take place," said legal expert Suzanne Zaccour in a recent interview with Le Devoir. Juripop's executive director, Sophie Gagnon, has also pointed out that the difference between the criminal and civil avenues is that the former aims to "punish" the aggressor, while the latter aims to compensate the victim for the damages suffered. Rozon indicated that he did not wish to comment. The reason she is turning to civil action is that the criminal process has been a difficult experience, Charette said in her petition. The only elements on which her story and that of Mr. Rozon were similar concerned their meeting in 1980 in a radio station in the Laurentians at the time when Mr. Rozon was organizing the festival La Grande Virée, as well as their outing to a nightclub in Saint-Sauveur. Before Judge Mélanie Hébert, Ms. Charette recounted that after an evening with Mr. Rozon, Ms. Charette said that the criminal trial had made her relive the trauma of the assault and that she had been deeply hurt by Mr. Rozon's lies and accusations. "It was like a second rape," she said. "I felt humiliated and devalued." She added that the trial was very difficult to go through and that she was deeply affected by the acquittal verdict. "I feel betrayed by the judicial system," she said. "I want to see justice done and I want women to know that they can turn to the civil court for redress." Charette said she is determined to sue Rozon and get redress for the damages she suffered. "I want women to know that they can turn to the civil court for justice," she said. "I want women to know that they can fight back and get justice."

titre: Loto-Québec retire son billet inspiré des records de chaleur
texte: Faced with the controversy generated by its new scratch-off ticket "Heat Record - the first jackpot multiplied by the temperature", Loto-Québec finally confirmed its withdrawal from the market less than 24 hours after its launch. The scratch-off quickly caused a reaction, given that the heat waves that have hit the country in recent years have claimed hundreds of lives. "The hotter it gets, the bigger the winnings," read the bill released on July 12. The backdrop of the new ticket, which was to sell for $2, was a map of Quebec reminiscent of those used to define regions hit by heat waves. There were seven suns to scratch off and some tickets had to be eligible for a $1000 draw, which was then multiplied by the temperature of the day of the draws scheduled for August 16, 23 and 30 as well as September 7. This way, if the weather was 30 degrees, for example, the total prize won by a winner would have been $30,000. Loto-Québec even partnered with the Weather Network to provide weather data recorded at Montreal-Trudeau International Airport on the days of the draw. However, the strong reactions to the release of the ticket caused the Crown corporation to back down and announce the withdrawal of the ticket on Tuesday afternoon. Initially, Loto-Québec had stressed that it was a "short-lived" game that would only be available for a few weeks. "We understand the sensitivity surrounding the Heat Record ticket, even if it was not in this spirit that the ticket had been designed. In this context, Loto-Québec has decided to withdraw it from the market," said Renaud Dugas, spokesperson for Loto-Québec. The Weather Network explained that it wanted to "promote interest in our weather history" and "encourage people to take an interest in the weather. The specialty channel agreed with Loto-Québec's position and removed all ads about the new scratcher from its website. Trivialization Earlier Tuesday, many people denounced on social networks a trivialization of climate change by Loto-Quebec. "I don't know how to describe this new "scraper" of the state-owned company: ridiculous? Insensitive? Cynical?" wrote PQ MP Sylvain Gaudreault on Twitter. At Équiterre, we were especially surprised that no one raised a red flag when the concept was developed. "It's insensitive of Loto-Québec to make a game out of a reality that is really not funny and that has serious consequences and leads to deaths," deplores Marc-André Viau, Director of Government Relations at Équiterre. The withdrawal of Loto-Québec's "Heat Record" ticket has generated positive reactions from environmental advocates and people sensitive to climate change. "We are pleased that Loto-Québec has made the decision to withdraw this ticket," said Greenpeace Canada Executive Director Joanna Kerr. "It's good that Loto-Quebec has recognized that this ticket is insensitive and should not be marketed." In addition, consumer rights groups also welcomed Loto-Quebec's decision. "We are pleased that Loto-Quebec has made the decision to withdraw this ticket," said Quebec Consumers' Association Executive Director Jean-François Lefebvre. "We are pleased that Loto-Quebec has recognized that this ticket was insensitive and should not be marketed." In addition, consumer rights groups also welcomed Loto-Quebec's decision. "We are pleased that Loto-Quebec has made the decision to withdraw this ticket," said Quebec Consumers' Association Executive Director Jean-François Lefebvre. "We are pleased that Loto-Quebec has recognized that this ticket was insensitive and should not be marketed." Environmental advocates and those sensitive to climate change also noted that the withdrawal of the ticket was an important step in raising public awareness of the consequences of climate change. "We hope this withdrawal will serve as a lesson to Loto-Québec and other companies that may be tempted to trivialize climate change," said Greenpeace Canada Executive Director Joanna Kerr. "We hope that this decision will encourage companies to take action to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions and get involved in the fight against climate change."

titre: Coronavirus: la famille de la première victime supplie les Québécois de s’isoler
texte: The family of Quebec's first coronavirus victim has issued an emotional statement, pleading with Quebecers to take the necessary steps to isolate themselves and prevent further loss of life. titre: Les recommandations pour les aînés encore contournées dans des résidences privées
texte: Quebec is known for its many private residences for seniors. Despite the recommendations of the Commission des droits de la personne et des droits de la jeunesse (CDPDJ) to improve their living conditions, these recommendations are still being ignored. An investigation conducted by La Presse newspaper revealed that private residences for seniors do not respect the recommendations of the CDPDJ. Residents often face inadequate living conditions, including cramped rooms, insufficient meals, and limited medical care. In 2017, the CDPDJ released a report entitled "Elder Rights in Private Residences." In this report, the commission made recommendations to improve the living conditions of seniors in private residences. These recommendations included measures to ensure a safe and healthy environment, nutritious meals and adequate medical care. Unfortunately, private senior living facilities have not implemented these recommendations. Residents often face inadequate living conditions and limited medical care. In addition, the meals served are often inadequate and not very nutritious. In addition, private seniors' residences do not meet safety and health standards. Rooms are cramped and residents do not have enough space to move around freely. In addition, the residences are not equipped with the necessary safety equipment to ensure the safety of residents. Despite the CDPDJ's recommendations, private seniors' residences continue to bend the rules and fail to meet safety and health standards. Residents often face inadequate living conditions and limited medical care. Government authorities must take action to ensure compliance with the CDPDJ's recommendations. Private senior residences must be required to meet safety and health standards and provide nutritious meals and adequate medical care. They must also ensure that residents have sufficient space to move about freely. Private seniors' residences are a place where many seniors live. It is therefore essential that authorities take steps to ensure compliance with the recommendations of the CDPDJ and to improve the living conditions of seniors. Only a safe and healthy environment can guarantee the well-being of seniors.

titre: Cas probable dans une résidence pour aînés : des employés informés deux jours plus tard
texte: On Tuesday morning, a Montreal area seniors' residence was informed of a possible case of COVID-19. However, staff were not informed until two days later. Reportedly, on Tuesday morning, a resident of the seniors' residence was tested for COVID-19 and tested positive. Residence officials were notified immediately and took steps to isolate the resident and limit the spread of the virus. However, the residence staff was not notified until Thursday morning, two days later. The employees were informed by the residence manager and asked to be tested. The employees were shocked and angry that they were not informed sooner. They stated that they could have taken steps to protect themselves and the residents if they had been informed earlier. One employee stated, "We are on the front lines and we need to be informed of the risks we face. We need to be informed immediately when there is a possible case of COVID-19." Another employee stated, "We are very concerned. We don't know if we have been exposed to the virus and we don't know if we have been infected. We need to be notified immediately when there is a possible case of COVID-19." Employees stated that they were very concerned and wanted to be informed immediately when there is a possible case of COVID-19. They said they needed to be informed so they could take steps to protect themselves and the residents. Residence officials stated that they take the health and safety of residents and employees very seriously. They stated that they had taken steps to limit the spread of the virus and had informed employees as soon as possible. However, employees stated that they were concerned and wanted to be informed immediately when there was a possible case of COVID-19. They stated that they needed to be informed so they could take steps to protect themselves and the residents. The senior living facility staff stated that they were concerned and wanted to be informed immediately when there is a possible case of COVID-19. titre: Rencontre avec des préposés aux bénéficiaires, défenseurs de la dignité de nos aînés
texte: This morning, the Quebec City courthouse was filled with people who came to attend the hearing of the case opposing orderlies to their employer. Attendant care workers are professionals who provide home care and services to the elderly and disabled. They are responsible for providing quality care and services, such as assistance with toileting, assistance with medications, assistance with meal preparation and assistance with dressing. Attendant Care workers are advocates for the dignity of seniors and people with disabilities. They are responsible for ensuring that their clients receive the care and services they need to live a dignified and happy life. Unfortunately, their employers do not provide them with adequate working conditions to enable them to provide quality care and services. The orderlies have decided to file a complaint against their employer for violation of their rights. They are asking for higher wages, overtime and paid vacations. They are also asking for safer and healthier working conditions, as well as adequate training and tools to enable them to provide quality care and services. At the hearing, the attendants testified about their commitment to defending the dignity of seniors and people with disabilities. They explained that their job is to provide quality care and services, and that they are willing to do everything in their power to achieve this. They also stressed that their employer must provide them with adequate working conditions to enable them to provide quality care and services. The orderlies stated that they are willing to fight for what they deserve. They stated that they are willing to fight for higher wages, overtime and paid time off. They also stated that they are willing to fight for safer and healthier working conditions, as well as adequate training and tools to enable them to provide quality care and services. The attendants stated that they are willing to fight for the dignity of seniors and people with disabilities. They said they are willing to fight for what they deserve and to ensure that their clients receive the care and services they need to live a dignified and happy life. The hearing ended on a positive note, and the attendants are confident about the outcome of their case. They are determined to get what they deserve and to stand up for the dignity of seniors and people with disabilities. They are ready to fight for higher wages, overtime and paid time off, as well as safer and healthier working conditions, proper training and tools to enable them to provide quality care and services.

titre: Une préposée se voit refuser un test de dépistage nécessaire pour faire garder son enfant
texte: An attendant at a Montreal hospital was denied a screening test needed to keep her child. The attendant, who wanted to be tested for COVID-19, was told by medical staff that she could not be tested because she was not considered a high-risk person. The attendant, who wanted to get the test so she could keep her child, said she was "shocked" by the medical staff's decision. "I don't understand why I can't get the test when I'm an attendant at the hospital and I'm in contact with patients every day," she said. The attendant said she tried to get the test through other means, but was unsuccessful. "I tried to find another way to get the test, but I wasn't successful. I don't know what to do now," she said. Medical staff said the attendant could not get the test because she was not considered a high-risk person. "We can't give the test to everyone, because we have to make sure the high-risk people are tested first," the medical staff said. However, the attendant said she was very concerned about not being able to get the test and feared it could have negative consequences for her and her child. "I don't want to take the risk of not being able to keep my child if I am infected with the virus," she said. texte: Much attention has been paid this week to the fate of Canadians prevented from returning home by the protests in Haiti. Meanwhile, a small family unwillingly made the opposite journey and landed in Port-au-Prince in the midst of the political crisis that has shaken the country. Stéphany, 11, and her father Emanes were among the last asylum seekers to be deported from Montreal before the moratorium on deportations was put in place Friday. Arriving in Haiti last Wednesday, they had no choice but to sleep at the police station before being taken in by friends. With the upheaval in the capital, access to clean water and food has been difficult. Frantz André, a community organizer who assists the applicants, tells me that young Stephany is already sick, just days after her eviction. One would think that things would return to normal for this deported family and for the country, as the protests quieten down and schools and businesses slowly reopen. But it would be naive to think that the political crisis in Haiti is over. As of the 2012 census, more than six million Haitians (59% of the population) were living below the poverty line of $2.41 per day, and more than 2.5 million (24%) were living below the extreme poverty line of less than $1.23 per day. Essentially, the people are hungry. Very hungry. And catastrophic inflation and unemployment rates only make it harder to access basic necessities. Haiti also has one of the world's most staggering wealth gaps, and corruption has long been documented as an endemic problem. Since last summer, the Petrocaribe fund has mobilized a popular revolt: $3.8 billion loaned by Venezuela to finance social projects was squandered by some of the Haitian elites, including several elected officials and those close to the ruling political party. But this case is just the latest in a long list of scandals involving the misappropriation of funds by NGOs, companies and local and foreign politicians, which are fuelling a social conflict with deep roots. Meanwhile, the "Core Group" of international powers involved in Haiti, including Canada, is blaming the protesters for disrespecting democratic institutions and fuelling a security problem. The substantive analysis remains in the background. We forget, as Martin Luther King Jr. said, that true peace is not just the absence of tension. It requires the presence of justice. The Haitian National Police - working closely with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police - can handle demonstrations. As long as the majority are hungry and the country's elites and international powers are more concerned with their own security and prosperity than with the basic needs of the population, there can be no end to the crisis. We can only witness a few lulls between the inevitable storms of legitimate anger. Under the circumstances, we cannot remain passive in the face of closed borders here in Canada. Since the summer of 2017, when the arrival of asylum seekers in Lacolle became a hot topic in Quebec news, the proportion of Haitian families accepted has been decreasing every year, and the list of infringements of their rights continues to grow. Access to competent lawyers is difficult, children are separated from their parents, asylum seekers are kept in detention without apparent reason, and people are deported in haste without having exhausted all possible recourses. Our refugee assessment system is completely arbitrary," says André. Lawyers often guess at a person's future simply by seeing which immigration commissioners have been chosen to judge a case." Emanes and Stéphany, who had been in Quebec for three years, might have had a different fate if they had come across a slightly more lenient commissioner. They might have at least gotten the girl to finish her school year before leaving Montreal. Before she was forced to leave for Haiti, Stéphany told one of her teachers that she would continue to focus on her studies until she could apply to come back to Quebec at the age of 18. Let's hope that before we get to that point, a mobilization of civil society, starting in Montreal, will push Canada to treat these refugees with a little more humanity. Let's also hope that we have dared to face head on, here as there, the social, economic and political crisis that threatens the Haitian people. For we will never be able to break the deadlock with simple appeals for calm and police interventions.

titre: Madame Pas-Tout-le-Monde
texte: We say it every year, but we have to keep saying it: March 8 is not a second Valentine's Day, an occasion to receive flowers and to remind us how much we are loved. It is a day created expressly to recognize women's rights, the advances made and those that remain to be made. In Quebec, many battles have been waged to advance the status of women: the right to abortion, family-work balance, pay equity, the establishment of CPEs, justice for survivors of sexual violence. These struggles are far from being won and may suffer major setbacks at the slightest political jolt. In this context, it is both desirable and necessary that social movements continue to force the parties to take strong measures to stop these inequalities. Politically, it can even pay to support these causes. After all, the average person has many, many votes in Quebec. Conversely, issues that affect women who are not seen as representative of the norm have not progressed as much over the last few decades.
