The Quebec feminist movement has coalesced around the leadership of middle-class francophones, and it is often only these women that the parties are interested in. The others are somehow not part of the "electorate" or the "people". These "other" women are, for example, the 25,000 domestic workers in Quebec, a shocking proportion of whom must survive psychological and sexual harassment, racism, violence, rape, threats and exploitation. Most of these women are from the Philippines and enter the country through an immigration program that, despite reforms, is still rooted in old colonial traditions. Their work permits are tied to their employers: if they want to leave an abusive home, they may have to wait several months before they are allowed to join a new family. If they have not worked enough within the prescribed time, they are no longer eligible for permanent residence. In this context, threats of deportation by bosses who seek absolute obedience are not exceptional, according to Evelyn Caluguy of the Pinay Centre. Many Quebec laws still exclude domestic work from the definition of "work". It is therefore still uncommon for these women with precarious status to benefit from CNESST coverage. They cannot unionize either. And when the Quebec selection certificate is not forthcoming, some work for months without even having access to health insurance. "It is not uncommon, in 2019, for some domestic workers in Quebec to be treated as true slaves," denounces Ms. Caluguy. Why?" Directly because of the laws and programs that frame them, or rather exclude them." By whom? Often by career women, so that they can free themselves from part of the education of children and household tasks. If social and economic inequalities have increased everywhere in the West over the last few decades, it is not surprising that the gaps between Quebec women are also greater than before. Today, some are breaking through glass ceilings and expect others to meekly sweep the floor. So-so-so, solidarity. Of course, domestic work is not the only dimension of the status of women in Quebec that is left in the shadows. For the past few years, a coalition of organizations has been trying to get Quebec to react to the unsanitary conditions, the illegal strip searches, the use of solitary confinement, and even the lack of access to drinking water for women inmates at the Leclerc prison. We know that here, as elsewhere in the country, racial profiling plays an important role in the imposition of sentences, and that the vast majority of incarcerated women also have a history of physical and sexual assault, and struggle with mental health and substance abuse issues. However, it remains very difficult to bring the rights of these women to public attention. In addition, the services available to survivors of sexual violence are for the most part poorly adapted to the specific needs of immigrant, racialized, Aboriginal, disabled and trans women. And this lack of resources plays directly into the risks of homelessness, criminalization, deportation, increased exploitation and marginalization. Certainly, the wave of the #MeToo movement has forced an examination of rape culture for women in general. But even the political, labor, and community left is still often reluctant to invest time and energy in advocating for victims who don't fit the "mainstream" narrative. By focusing all our efforts on the "unifying" realities of the Everyman, the emergencies of the Not-All-Woman are still waiting. March 8, International Women's Rights Day, did you say? "Women", that is to say also women who do not fit into our political imagination?

titre: Ce qu’on n’ose pas dire
texte: In the aftermath of the terrorist attack in Christchurch, New Zealand, several right-wing identity-based tribunes have called for censorship of analyses that make clear links between the toxicity of public discourse and the rise of right-wing violence in the West. These defences of free speech and hateful expression are having an effect on Canadian political leaders, who fear that they will disown part of their base if they clearly denounce Islamophobia. This is the case with Andrew Scheer, who, in response to the murder of 50 New Zealanders, initially expressed general sympathy and condemned "this kind of hatred" without any reference to the particular identity of the victims. After sharp criticism on social media, and even within his own caucus, he finally agreed to describe the killing as a "cowardly and heinous attack on the Muslim community. Is this initial hesitation an anecdote? Of course not. Mr. Scheer is well aware of the importance of words, those that are said and those that are not. His initial choice is best understood when you consider that the Conservative leader has named Hamish Marshall as a close advisor and chair of his upcoming election campaign. Marshall is a former head of the far-right platform Rebel Media, a company often compared to Steve Bannon's Breitbart News in the United States. Rebel Media lost its thin veneer of respectability in 2017 when its reporter Faith Goldy, well known for her advocacy of a return to European-only immigration for Canada, offered sympathetic coverage of the white supremacist rally that left one person dead and several injured in Charlottesville, Virginia. Since then, conservatives have been dancing an uncomfortable tango. Forced to publicly distance themselves from the platform, they know that its subscribers are part of their electoral base. The same game could be observed last month during the United We Roll mobilization. The convoy of truckers crossed Canada to demand the construction of pipelines and, at the same time, to denounce the United Nations International Compact for Safe Migration. The presence of several right-wing elements in the movement was well known, but this did not prevent Mr. Scheer from speaking at his Ottawa rally, just after... the same Faith Goldy. There was no official support for the movement, but not to the point of turning our backs on it completely. These strategic choices make sense in the context of Maxime Bernier's dissent and the creation of his People's Party. Bernier, who declined to comment on Christchurch, seems to be openly inspired by Donald Trump in the style of many of his inflammatory statements on Twitter - capital letters included. This forces Scheer to pay even more attention to his right wing. Jason Kenney's United Conservative Party, which is currently leading the Alberta provincial election, is also home to some of these same ideologies. It has just been revealed that its candidate for Calgary-Mountain View is concerned about "white replacement. Is it any wonder that a man who ran his last federal campaign on a platform of "barbaric cultural practices" would attract such agitators? Like Kenney, Doug Ford has supported the Canadian Yellow Vests movement, which, unlike the French movement, has been linked to far-right organizations from its inception. And he was strongly criticized last fall for refusing to dissociate himself from... Faith Goldy - yes, her again! -with whom he had been photographed while she was running for mayor of Toronto. Here, the Parti Québécois had to let candidates go during the last campaign for their Islamophobic statements on social networks. While La Meute expressed admiration for the CAQ, François Legault had to distance himself from them, saying the group was "on the verge of racism. One of the group's leaders retorted that Legault must be as well, since La Meute had been inspired by the CAQ platform to draft its own manifesto. Was Legault thinking of this segment of the electorate when he argued - before being forced to retract his statement - just after the second anniversary of the Sainte-Foy massacre, that there was no islamophobia in Quebec? There is something disturbing happening in Canada. It is increasingly difficult for right-wing political parties to ignore right-wing sensitivities in the political calculations that determine their programs, strategies, statements and silences. On this March 21, International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, it is important as always to denounce racism in all its forms, which of course includes Islamophobia. Above all, it seems urgent to uncover the reasons why some leaders do not do so, or comply as quietly as possible. There is a significant threat to the health of our democracies.

titre: Chère grand-maman
texte: You were 92 years old. I can never really know what it was like for you to grow up in the 1920s, 1930s, 1940s in the parish of Saint-Romuald-d'Etchemin, near Quebec City. But I know that as a wife, mother and grandmother, you became one of those who give, give and give again. I will always remember the thousand gestures of affection, tenderness, generosity and empathy that you lavished on me, as well as on your children and your other grandchildren. We can never thank you enough. I can never truly understand your upbringing as a young girl in the convent, where you were taught to keep house and to respect the etiquette of the rural French-Canadian petty bourgeoisie, whose men became priests, notaries, lawyers, doctors... and also, often, grown children who could not feed or care for themselves. I remember conversations on the eve of elections where you talked about not "cancelling your husband's vote" with your own choice. I remember your anxiety about breaking the rules of decency. I remember the absolute taboo on sexuality. I also know that when you asked yourself what you would have liked to do for a living, if it had been possible, you would take the time to preface your hesitant answer with an important reminder: "You know, in the old days, we didn't think about that stuff." I know that by being attentive to the whims of others, you often sacrificed part of your own happiness, and part of your health. As a woman, you were among those who sacrifice, who fade away, and then even forget themselves. Over time, I met other women your age who told me about their careers, their studies, their travels, in short, their lives. But growing up, like you, in Levis, the freest elders I met were the nuns who taught me. By withdrawing from men, they were able to live differently than through them. It must be said that our region of origin is among the last faithful of the Union nationale, the first supporters of the ADQ, and the strongest bastions of the PCC in Quebec - that it is therefore inhabited by a social conservatism with particularly deep roots. Did you know that there is even a local guy, a guy named Maxime Bernier, who has just founded his own party? He said, just last week, that women have other priorities than politics. He also wants us to "think", as in the United States, about the control women have over their own bodies, which they won with great difficulty not so long ago. Grandma, there are people who want to rebuild the old cage in which you were locked, to see if my generation can't be thrown in. Just imagine. There are many who are surprised by the rise of certain currents, and who thought that Quebec had become a place where all women could now breathe quite freely. But your granddaughter is a black woman, the daughter of a Haitian father, and queer to boot. I have had my own reasons for running out of oxygen at times, two generations later, in the face of the populist right and the conformist pressure of our corner of the world. You had to live with the injunctions from church stoops, and I had to live with private radio stations and their emulators. Things have changed, but maybe not enough. Even though I left the region a while ago, I am infinitely grateful for the love and knowledge of the territory that was passed on to me, growing up in the area where your family has been rooted for generations. My childhood is also all the afternoons spent between women picking and preparing fruits and vegetables from the yard or the fields of the surrounding villages, whose farmlands - and architectural heritage - are among the best preserved in Quebec. It is the walks on the shore, or even on the frozen St. Lawrence River in the coves of Bellechasse. It is also the summer evenings, in the street with the neighborhood to admire the fireworks over the Montmorency Falls, in front of the tip of Orleans Island, with the echoes of music carried by the wind to our shore of the river. Grandma, unless people decide to aspire to something better than transforming all the fertile, beautiful and historic corners of Quebec into highways, suburban dormitories, condos and shopping mall parking lots, well, this landscape, on the eastern edge of Lévis, will soon be wiped out by a "third link", urban sprawl and the pollution that goes with it. Grandma, the same movements that have limited your horizons and pointed out my difference are also those that threaten the Earth and the river. Grandma, I want us to remember the generosity and altruism that guided your life, and to wish you the greatest possible freedom where you are now. You will have seen Quebec open up in so many ways during your long life. I promise you that I will do my best to make sure that it does not close itself up again. It won't be easy every day. But with vigilance - and especially with the memory of where we came from - I think we can do it.

titre: El Paso, la faute à l’«aliénation économique»?
texte: When Donald Trump was elected in November 2016, countless people around the world were in shock. Until the last hour, they refused to believe it. Then, people tried to understand. On every channel, all sorts of personalities denounced the arrogance of the American liberal elites and the sense of economic alienation of a middle class still reeling from the 2008 crisis. There was talk of popular frustration with globalization, and of the Democrats' inability to respond to the needs of blue-collar workers in "deep" America. Immediately, other voices were raised, mainly black, Latino, Muslim, Jewish, to denounce the role of racism and white supremacy in popular support for Trump. Underrepresented in the mainstream media, these perspectives have sought to warn the public about the economic alienation theory. When the demographic profile of Republican voters was made public, it became clear that they were right. Wealthier Americans voted for Trump in greater proportions than poorer ones. White men with college degrees voted overwhelmingly for Trump. And despite all the sexual assault accusations that had surfaced during the campaign, a majority of white American women voted for Trump. In contrast, racial minorities mostly supported the Democratic side. More than 94 percent of African-American women voted for Hillary Clinton. Despite this, the theory of working class alienation continued to hold and serve as the basis for countless essays, open letters and blog posts. Why are black women, "economically alienated" since the days of the thirteen colonies, also the least supportive of Donald Trump? Mystery and gumdrop. Why, when Trump openly talked during his campaign about Mexicans as rapists, did they seek to minimize the role of racism in his election? Could it be that white journalists - even progressive ones - have difficulty addressing racial issues? Did the lack of media attention to people who are knowledgeable about racism - primarily racialized people themselves - contribute to the misinformation of the public? To ask these questions is to answer them. Moreover, the problem is not exclusively American: in Canada, too, the public debate about the campaign of our neighbors to the south has echoed the discourse of white male economic frustration that downplays the racist dimension of the ideology promoted by Trump. As if the nostalgia for the "good old days" contained in the slogan "Make America Great Again" could be addressed to anyone but a white audience. What other Americans (or Westerners, for that matter) can associate the past with the good life? But not everyone saw the obvious, far from it. Nearly three years later, we have to make sense of the El Paso massacre. And the El Paso massacre follows attacks on the African-American church in Charleston, synagogues in Pittsburgh and California, and the LGBTQ and Latino club in Orlando. Before El Paso, there was also the neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville, the rise of right-wing guru Stephen Bannon as chief strategist in the White House, the "Muslim ban," the stubbornness to build a wall motivating the longest shutdown in history, mass deportations, Central American children held in cages, and countless racist statements by the U.S. President. At the same time, there has been little action to relieve the "economic anxiety" of the ordinary world. Little by little, we are coming to understand. But not quite yet. In Canada, many of those who can admit to part of the problem in the south minimize its existence here. Of course, each country has its own particularities. But the rhetoric that seeks to motivate each other's inequalities, both real and legal, goes back to the West, to the United States and here. This is a major challenge of our time, along with climate change. I don't know what else it will take for these issues to stop being considered a "niche" issue or an activist obsession. We're on the eve of a federal election, which pits a Conservative Party that campaigned four years ago on the hunt for "barbaric cultural practices" against a man, Maxime Bernier, who feels his political family didn't go far enough and seems to be taking direct inspiration from Donald Trump to feed his Twitter account. And then there's Jagmeet Singh: this will be the first time in Canada that one of the major parties has been led in a campaign by a racialized person, and one who wears a religious symbol to boot. Do we realize the potential for abuse? What space will be given to what voices during this campaign? Are we really ready to understand and analyze what will happen? Or will we wake up little by little, a few years too late, with a big headache, and a "great again" country?

titre: Au nom de la sécurité
texte: Almost two years ago, the management of the residence I was sharing with several roommates from around the world decided to install, without prior notice, Google Nest cameras near our common areas. The pretext: to monitor the front doors in case of thieves, at a lower cost than outdoor cameras. The reality is that today's cameras are not the blurred images of yesteryear stored on VHS that we hastily erase. Google Nest cameras are equipped with facial recognition technology. All people entering and leaving the residence are identified by the cameras; the number of comings and goings is calculated. The cameras are connected to the residence's wi-fi network, just like our phones: if you have your cell phone on you, the camera knows in which room of the residence each person is located, with great precision. The cameras are also equipped with powerful microphones: our conversations could be captured and recorded at any moment. Finally, they are controlled from a cell phone app; residence managers could listen to the video (and audio) feed at any time, be alerted to the whereabouts of a particular individual, or store portions of our private life in a cloud. It immediately felt like we were unwilling participants in a reality show. Some of my roommates had already experienced spying in countries where human rights activists are openly monitored - even imprisoned - by national authorities. Let's just say that none of us welcomed the cameras with joy and glee, but for some of us, the situation would even awaken traumas. And let me tell you: no thief was caught during our stay. I will spare you the details of this particular case. Just know that the laws and social norms regarding surveillance are unclear. So vague that you are probably being monitored without your knowledge. Many of Quebec's large shopping malls now use facial recognition not only for security, but also to identify the demographics of their customers. Hidden cameras read your face to guess your gender, age, mood, general level of satisfaction and who knows what else. With no announcement, no warning, and no accountability process. Google Nest cameras, or similar types, are also becoming more common in schools. They are everywhere in Quebec in school buses, near bathrooms, at the entrance to classrooms. The management of the Vanguard school in Saint-Laurent is even being sued by its teachers' union in response to the installation of some 60 such devices in the school. The teachers say they feel constantly spied on, that the situation creates a significant stress at work. According to La Presse, there were about 35 cameras per school at the Marguerite-Bourgeoys School Board... in 2013. The number has increased since then. On the other hand, if you live in a condo complex or work in an office tower, I would ask some questions. A lot of things are justified in the name of security. In the past two weeks, the City of Montreal has begun to slowly, and timidly, think about surveillance, following a motion tabled by Marvin Rotrand, an independent member of Montreal City Council, calling for a moratorium on the use of facial recognition technologies by the SPVM. Last year, the city acquired 730 video surveillance cameras, 415 of which were turned over to the SPVM. We know that the City of Toronto uses them, and that the Sûreté du Québec is in the process of calling for tenders to purchase them as well. The SPVM, for its part, still refuses to tell the public whether or not these new gadgets have been deployed in the city. This obscurantism is apparently normal in a democracy. As a society, we are unaware of the staggering difference between today's technologies and the VHS brontosaurus of yesteryear. While a few individuals, still isolated, are painfully and miserably raising these fundamental issues in Quebec, protesters in Hong Kong are having to use laser pointers to jam facial recognition devices installed in the streets by Chinese authorities eager for political profiling and repression. Quebec is not China. But Quebecers would surely benefit from listening to the testimonies of Chinese, Turkish... and even aboriginal, environmentalist, communist or sovereignist activists here, spied on over time by the RCMP, to realize that democracy, civil liberties and fundamental rights are easily eroded, especially under the pretext of security. The potential uses of what is taking hold here in indifference are much broader than one might imagine. And the impact on daily life can be felt quickly, without warning. You can believe me.

titre: Les paroles légitimes
texte: The participation of Maxime Bernier, leader of the People's Party of Canada (PPC), in the October 7 and 10 leaders' debates has been accepted in extremis according to a series of specific criteria, all of which are devoid of political considerations. On Monday, the head of the commission responsible for organizing the leaders' debates, David Johnston, agreed that Maxime Bernier's People's Party has "a legitimate chance of winning seats" and is therefore eligible for the exercise. Analysts are dissecting the relevance of the Commission's criteria to the leaders' debates and the implications of the news for each party's chances of winning. It is acknowledged that Bernier's ideas clash with the "living together" that one would like to see in Canada. But it is argued that the decision to give visibility to the CPP should not be ethical, but statistical, in short, "objective. To those concerned about the normalization of far-right ideas, the answer is that it is legitimate to give the spittoon to a man whose ideas are shared by a substantial portion of the population. In theory, the argument holds water. In practice, the forums that have an aura of legitimacy and authority have limited space and resources. On a daily basis, people who work in these forums prioritize speech, reject the contributions of some and amplify the speech of others according to what they deem to contribute to good public information and healthy democracy. Some projects are subsidized, others have their funds cut. These decisions are made on the basis of values, explicit or tacit. If you want to call this process "censorship", so be it! Censorship" happens every day in a democracy. There are still, for example, many people in Canada who believe that gays and lesbians should not be allowed to attend primary and secondary schools, so as not to "corrupt" children with their "deviance". They are not, however, given much air time. Climate skeptics are not invited on every TV show to make the treatment of the environmental cause "objective," nor are masculinists brought in to "balance" every segment on the #MeToo movement. Contributors to shows of all kinds have lost their platforms for making comments deemed inappropriate on air or on social media. Political parties are doing the same with their candidates, and not a single election goes by without someone being thrown out for statements deemed unacceptable. In Quebec, we are particularly quick to ask that comments be removed from the public space - when it comes to Quebec bashing. We remember the scandal surrounding the famous Maclean's cover associating corruption with the Bonhomme Carnaval or the pressure exerted - successfully - on the CBC to withdraw a program that did not represent the battle of the Plains of Abraham to the liking of Francophones. From the unanimous denunciations of the National Assembly to the demands for resignation or apology from prominent public figures, there is no hesitation in declaring that the limits of freedom of expression have been exceeded if national dignity is deemed to be at stake. When it comes to racism or transphobia, to name a few issues, however, it is still often believed that the best way to inform the public is to present the pros and cons. Those who question the consequences of the spread of far-right ideas, such as those of the People's Party, are caricatured as censors, as weaklings too "sensitive" to have their ideals thwarted, or as fools too unable to articulate their positions to wish to debate them reasonably. It is this double standard that annoys more than anything else. How can we avoid concluding that there are second-class citizens when we see "censored" remarks that offend the best-represented groups and submitted to debate ideas that attack the others? The question goes far beyond the context of the leaders' debate. In 2019, we defend the growing place in the public square of the Maxime Bernier of this world by repeating that exposure to the greatest number of points of view necessarily favours free thought. At the same time, we hide behind freedom of expression to refuse any serious reflection on the consequences of the widespread dissemination of certain ideologies. Allow me to detect a certain paradox in this. And if a federal party wanted to abolish French as an official language, would we applaud its inclusion in the leaders' debate? I doubt it very much. Nor do I believe that we would short-circuit the thinking by labelling those who would publicly express concern about the possible consequences as "censors.

titre: Pour la sécurité des femmes
texte: Since I started working in the Quebec feminist community, I have not seen any issue that tears women apart as much as issues related to the sex industry and sexual exploitation. It makes sense. After all, it's about the safety of people and the preservation of their most intimate dignity. Laws that address these realities are passed by elected officials who have no personal experience of what they are talking about. And for many women and their families, these political decisions can be a matter of life and death. At the Special Commission on the Sexual Exploitation of Minors created by the National Assembly, emotions are running high. We share the stories of young girls who have experienced unprecedented violence. How can we remain insensitive to such stories and to the pain of the families? In the face of such ordeals and traumas, it is only human - and commendable - for the survivors, their loved ones and the interveners to hope that no one else will have to experience similar violence. The problem is that trauma causes the human brain to be in a constant state of alert and to perceive danger everywhere. When we let pain alone guide all our reasoning, analysis and reactions, we can fall into a Manichean view of reality and replace a complex evaluation of the social issues involved with absolutist judgments. And even if this solves few things, in short. From the revolt against sexual violence suffered by young underage girls, we believe we can conclude the best course of action for the sex industry as a whole and understand the situation of all prostitutes, regardless of their age, their situation and their life path. On one side, there are the victims, and on the other, the vultures. It would be that simple. Everywhere. All the time. And we would like to send the police, like Marvel superheroes, to hunt the vultures. But it would be hard to make the case that criminalization, incarceration and increased policing have ever been the ideal solution to complex social problems that pose a risk to the lives of the most vulnerable. For decades, women in the sex trade have been talking about how criminalizing clients puts them at risk. They tell of how a client who feels potentially hounded by the police takes them to remote locations where there are few witnesses and therefore little protection. When "superheroes" get involved, massage parlors, brothels, hotels, and all places where women can exercise greater control over their safety are closed. Our laws regularly threaten these same women with eviction from their homes. They also prevent those who continue to be seen as absolute victims from accessing the same tools that have improved workplace safety in so many other settings. Negotiating terms through an intermediary, organizing as a group, or using technology to screen clients is often legally tantamount to promoting services - in short, being a pimp. The measures put in place to counter the vultures' malice have the effect of disarming those we want to protect. We defend ourselves from wanting to stigmatize women and to target only the clients... As if the war on drug dealers had never endangered the simple users. We denounce the high risk of violence for women who are in the sex industry while creating a legal environment that discourages these women from reporting to the police. The real vultures know this, which makes prostitutes even easier targets. When sex workers are assaulted, many judges still take their occupation into account to doubt whether rape has occurred or whether it was "serious" rape. The stigmatization of prostitution undermines the pursuit of justice and perpetuates the risk of violence for which these vultures are believed to be solely responsible. Yet, it is still believed that repeating the message that it is wrong to exchange sex for money can help protect girls. These realities have led organizations such as Amnesty International, the World Health Organization, UN Women, UNAIDS, the International Labor Organization, the Global Alliance Against Trafficking in Women, the Global Network of Sex Work Projects, the Global Commission on HIV and the Law, Human Rights Watch, the Open Society Foundations, and Anti-Slavery International to support groups that have long called for the decriminalization of sex work. This is entirely possible and necessary while protecting minors from sexual exploitation and fighting human trafficking. But is listening and nuance still possible?

titre: La paresse et la dominance
texte: Peter MacKay, and more generally all English-speaking politicians who, while harbouring great national ambitions, never take the time to learn French, have been much mocked lately. This is rightly seen as an expression of contempt, or at best indifference, towards Quebecers and other francophones in Canada. I don't know how many times, during the years I lived in Toronto, I was approached to confess a jealousy about my bilingualism. "Ah, I need to get back into French," those who were in high school immersion programs a little too long ago say to me in English or in broken French. "But it's hard," they add. In these situations, I know the person is acting in good faith. I am also certain, until proven otherwise, that they will never get serious about French again. Professionally, she doesn't need it. And she can travel anywhere in the world and expect the local population to address her in her language. The temptation to be lazy is not insurmountable, but it is very strong. Often, the person who makes this remark underestimates the work that has been required of me, as a Francophone from the South Shore of the Quebec City region, to master his or her language. The bilingualism of the Francos is often taken for granted. What is more true is that most Francophones learn the dominant language of the continent with the conviction that it is not only "interesting" but necessary, or at least very useful. When one learns with the feeling that it is important to learn, the results are different. With the role of the dominant, the majority, comes many privileges. But there is also a tendency to laziness that often creates an asymmetry of knowledge - and not just linguistic knowledge. I have always experienced this laziness of dominance at home in Quebec. As a black woman, I often feel that I have to constantly repeat myself on issues of diversity, inclusion, and anti-racism. I know that I am dealing with someone who rarely feels the urgency, the need to learn - except in times of public relations crisis, because the protesters have gotten involved. Otherwise, individual or organizational ignorance of large parts of the reality of minorities in Quebec is still of little consequence. I do not deny that collective consciousness is changing. But there is a slowness of evolution that is normalized. I know that in other circumstances, we would be able to do better. I also know that, as a non-aboriginal person, it would be tempting to be lazy in my turn. I am one of those people who learned almost nothing about First Nations, Métis and Inuit realities in school, other than the distinction between a teepee, a longhouse and an igloo. It is difficult as an adult to be interested in a subject with such a weak foundation: it confronts us with our ignorance. I might also feel ashamed, guilty, and paralyzed by it. But I prefer to be angry at the education system that has served us so poorly and demand better for the next generations. Besides, I have experienced the laziness of the dominant often enough to try not to be part of the problem myself. I will always have a lot to learn. But I can kick my ass and get on with it. Seriously. "Reconciliation is dead." Many Indigenous activists have used the phrase since the beginning of the year. Images of Wet'suwet'en women being forcibly removed by the RCMP in the middle of a ceremony have gone viral. The solidarity movement for recognition of aboriginal sovereignty and against the new Coastal GasLink pipeline has been going on for a long time, but it has now grown to a level that the authorities did not anticipate. Marches held across Canada. Blocked trains and roads. And a generation announcing the death of reconciliation. But has it ever been properly alive? The Truth and Reconciliation Commission's report dates back to 2015. Ninety-four calls to action had been issued. Who has not yet taken the time to read it, since 2015? Do we sincerely want to rethink the power dynamics across this country? The challenge is heavy and complex. It requires knowledge of history, familiarity with Indigenous perspectives, trusting relationships and healthy dialogue built on shared understandings. Who among the non-Aboriginal community - particularly those with political, economic and media power - has taken this task seriously? And if they have, how diligently are they doing it? Are we driven by a sense of urgency, of necessity? Or will we continue to evolve at the same pace as Peter MacKay learns French and be satisfied with that? Will we still be interested and motivated once the trains start moving again?

titre: Ce qui nous rend malades
texte: The good thing about this coronavirus story - because we must also look at the positive side of things - is that we can see before our eyes the capacity for coordinated action of the human species, the rapid changes we can make in our behaviours and the sacrifices we are willing to make when faced with a sense of urgency. Health, which is basically the fear of dying or at least suffering, is a universal concern. When the World Health Organization issues guidelines and recommendations in the name of even the risk of getting sick from a virus, governments follow suit. Institutions tell us to stay at home, to avoid gatherings, to limit physical contact. We obey. It is important for everyone to do what they can. The authorities are there to protect us. However, we know that concerted action is much more difficult when the same governments, institutions and companies that have been claiming to have our health at heart for the past few weeks are precisely the source of our diseases. Many pesticides still used in agriculture here and elsewhere increase the risk of cancer. Air pollution caused by cars and industries has increased respiratory problems tenfold. Allergies develop from contact with chemicals. Plastic microparticles are lodged everywhere in our bodies. Stress in the workplace is directly linked to heart disease. All this in a wealthy society where technological changes are invariably presented as "progress". Many studies have long shown the link between the lack of green space in urban areas and the social isolation caused by our "modern" lifestyles and the increase in cases of depression, anxiety and suicide. It is estimated that 20% of Canadians will experience a mental illness at some point in their lives. And more and more people are becoming addicted to opioids because they can't take it anymore. The Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH) estimated in 2009 that the economic cost of mental health in Canada is nearly $51 billion per year, including care costs and lost productivity. As if that wasn't enough, an IRIS study released last week revealed an "explosion" of employer challenges to CNESST claims since the 1990s, and thus a growing difficulty for the workforce to receive compensation for workplace injuries. A movement of health professionals in Canada and elsewhere is putting the social determinants of health at the heart of its practice. In short, this means recognizing that our living environment has a far greater influence on our well-being than genetics. Living in poverty, living in the middle of a food desert or on contaminated land, experiencing domestic violence or the constant pressure of stress, not being able to use active transportation for daily commuting, living in a society of growing inequality and crumbling public services: these are all determinants of our health that our physicians are largely powerless to address in clinical settings. Last week, several hundred of these doctors opposed GNL-Québec, citing the public health risks of hydraulic fracturing operations. They are talking about cancers, heart disease and respiratory illnesses, among others. Will their voices be heard by the BAPE? How many natural resource exploitation projects, highway construction, urban sprawl and other concrete developments have been carried out without taking into account their effect not only on the environment, but also on our health? We know that there is a nine-year gap in life expectancy between certain neighbourhoods in the west and east of Montreal? What are we doing about it? Where is the state of emergency, the concerted action that will force change? When will a serious plan to eradicate poverty be prescribed? The truth is that it is much easier for mainstream medicine to tell us to eat better and join the gym, in short, to put all the responsibility for our well-being back on the individual, rather than to speak out against the politicians and corporations that are killing us. It can be reassuring, on the other hand, to think that the most serious problems can be avoided with a good washing of the hands. The current state of emergency shows what we are capable of when we are serious. It also shows that if so much suffering and absurd death persist in our existence, it is because the main people in charge of our collective destinies do not care enough.

titre: Nos anges gardiens
texte: This is the expression used by François Legault, during his daily press conferences, to emphasize the vital importance of the personnel of the Quebec health system. And he is quite right. Since the beginning of the crisis, there has necessarily been an acute awareness of the risks, sacrifices and dedication of these Quebec women who are so essential to our lives. I say Quebec women, because it is important to remember that 80% of the health care sector is made up of women. While half of all doctors are men, 90% of nurses and nursing assistants, and 80% of orderlies are women. In fact, women are most concentrated in occupations where they have the most regular contact with patients: even within hospitals, therefore, they are the ones most at risk of being infected in the coming weeks. When the government issued its call for retired health care professionals to back up the phone lines or elsewhere in the system, the vast majority of those who answered the call were also understandably women. The situation is similar for family caregivers, who play a crucial role in supporting seniors and vulnerable people who have been the subject of concern in recent weeks. Not only are the majority of caregivers women, but on average they spend more time with the people they support. Volunteers who help out in CHSLDs and a host of other organizations that are vital to the vulnerable have a similar profile. Many parents have been struggling for the past week to juggle telecommuting and caring for children at home. And who usually takes care of your children? Who frees up your time so you can contribute to the economy? 98% of child care workers are women. 75% of teachers are women. The domestic workers who lighten the load in many homes are almost all women. And many studies show that among heterosexual couples, daily tasks are still not equally divided. Even in normal times, the pressure to combine work, children, housework and errands falls mainly on Quebec women. Hours and hours of free work are thus provided as a "gift" to the normal functioning of society. It is in the care professions that we also find the greatest proportion of immigrant women, racialized women and women with precarious status. Generally speaking, these are jobs that remain underpaid, where working conditions are difficult, and where skills are largely devalued. With the same training, at the high school or technical college level, the average salaries and protections of the traditionally female trades remain out of line with those prevailing, for example, in the construction industry. As a result, even men who choose these "women's" trades find themselves in more precarious economic situations than their counterparts, precisely because they exist in a women's world. The feminist community has been denouncing these injustices for a long time. Year after year, we repeat that women's underpaid or even free work constitutes the basic net of society. What keeps us together, on our feet. Healthy. In times of crisis, the most essential dimensions of life are more salient than ever. Do we finally see, truly, completely, viscerally, the role that women play in Quebec society, even in normal times - and, comparatively, for so little? It would be possible to lose sight of these realities and all these heroines, behind the figures of good traditional fathers projected by a François Legault or a Horacio Arruda. When they talk about our guardian angels, we could forget whom we should thank, and whom we should respect, compensate, and celebrate to the fullest. We could also forget that poverty and job insecurity are social realities with a mostly female face. That confinement to the home increases the risk of domestic violence for these same women who give us so much. I can already see some of the comments here. Yes, men also contribute. Of course they do. We are in a great moment of solidarity where everyone has a crucial role in the collective good. But some will be called upon to do more in this time of crisis, and some - often the same ones - are more vulnerable to the aftershocks of the current situation. We have never shied away from highlighting the role of men sent to the front in wartime, and centering our narrative of history around their sacrifices and exploits in battle. At the time of the coronavirus, it is largely the women who are at the front. Let us underline it. Let us thank them. And also, let us give them justice.

titre: Pas faits pour vivre en cage
texte: Since the beginning of the pandemic, the authorities have adopted unprecedented measures to help the most vulnerable. People are concerned about the homeless, there is a sudden awareness of the financial needs of community organizations, and citizen initiatives to show solidarity and help the most vulnerable are multiplying. As soon as COVID-19 arrived in Canada, many experts sounded the alarm about the situation of the prison population, which is certainly among the groups most at risk of being infected by the virus. Even in normal times, hygiene is difficult and many institutions are overcrowded. Distancing oneself is almost impossible. Already, in Port-Cartier, two inmates and nine staff have tested positive. Even with the suspension of visits and additional security measures, workers cannot stop going back and forth between the prisons and their homes. The pandemic will reach the prisons. We just don't know yet when, and at what rate. COVID-19 is pushing the limits of the politically possible day by day. In a multitude of sectors, measures that some would have dismissed as utopian cloud-pulling only a few weeks ago are now taking shape before our eyes. But political leadership is still lacking for incarcerated populations. Yet many low-risk prisoners, soon to be eligible for parole or nearing the end of their sentences, could be sent home without affecting public safety. Some judges have recently begun to consider the risks associated with the pandemic in their bail decisions. And choosing to keep masses of people locked together in unsanitary conditions in the midst of a pandemic defies common sense even more when it is not even a question of criminality. This is the case in immigration holding centers, where they lock up, roughly speaking, people whom the government thinks it best to keep under surveillance while their asylum claims are assessed or while they await deportation. And what about detainees who are particularly vulnerable to complications if they contract COVID-19? Is it really necessary to persist in putting their lives at risk? Several migrants detained in Laval decided to go on hunger strike last week after several unsuccessful attempts to talk to the authorities. For those incarcerated, the means to be heard are very limited. If effective means of releasing those who are not a threat to public safety are not adopted very soon, it should not be surprising that such movements will multiply here and elsewhere in the country. The slow pace of political action can only be explained by the almost total ignorance of a large part of society of the realities of the prison environment. There is a caricatured idea, fed by the media coverage of extreme cases, of the kind of people who are there. For example, the Union of Canadian Correctional Officers, which is currently opposed to such emergency measures, attempts in its public statements to equate all prisoners with dangerous and violent individuals. There is also a belief that all sentences are deserved, without knowing exactly what conditions of life are deemed fair to sentence these people to. Little thought is given to the possibility of rehabilitation in an environment built primarily for punishment and surveillance. And above all, these people are forgotten, as if they existed completely outside of society. We don't think about their parents, their spouses, their children. Nor, apparently, to their health. Yet the limitations on individual freedoms that we are now forced to accept can lead to unsuspected insights. Last week, the American magazine Mother Jones published the advice that Keith Lamar, a prisoner placed for 27 years in solitary confinement in a maximum security facility, had for the general population suddenly confined to the house. To maintain a modicum of sanity, one should first and foremost learn to be good to oneself. Then make sure you cultivate your mind: learn, meditate, write, grow despite everything. Many people, just a few weeks ago, would not have believed that they could learn from an inmate and his experience in this way. Of course, today's social distancing measures are not comparable to outright imprisonment, especially if one thinks of solitary confinement in penitentiaries, long recognized as a form of torture. However, midlife does force one to be fully aware of the impact of limited movement and social contact on well-being. And perhaps to have a little more consideration for people who are thought to be fair to lock up and who are, it should be remembered, far from being all rapists or dangerous murderers. Human beings, we know now more than ever, are not made to live in cages.

titre: Docteur Privilège
texte: Much has been said about how the COVID-19 pandemic highlights pre-existing socio-economic inequities and institutional failures. In recent weeks, our attention has rightly focused on the impact of the current crisis on the most vulnerable. Instead, at his press conference on Wednesday, François Legault shed light - somewhat in spite of himself - on the parallel universe in which the wealthiest continue to operate, even in times of national emergency. For the moment, it is not known who "misspoke" and who "misunderstood" in the private exchanges between the Quebec government, the Fédération des médecins omnipraticiens (FMOQ) and the Fédération des médecins spécialistes (FMSQ), resulting in significant delays. But we know that, while the shortage of personnel has been glaring in CHSLDs for several weeks, it seems difficult - and time-consuming - to deploy physicians to support nurses and orderlies in their work. We also know that agreements had to be negotiated on the remuneration of these physicians, who normally bill on a fee-for-service basis for most of their activities. For example, a specialist could earn up to $2500 per day for assisting in a CHSLD under COVID-19. Since they already earn an average of $428,941 per year, this is about the normal compensation for them. We also know that the state of health emergency gives the government exceptional powers to mobilize public sector employees. Indeed, many working conditions have been unilaterally modified by Quebec in recent weeks in order to increase the capacity of our health care system. And earlier this week, a ministerial order was adopted to give itself the power to recruit and redeploy to the front lines college teachers trained in the relevant fields. Physicians practicing in the public system are technically self-employed, not salaried. It seems that, even in a public health emergency, the government cannot control them as much as other professionals. As a result, physician federations retain bargaining power that has been largely suspended elsewhere. While both sides are trying to "get it right", the pandemic continues to take its toll on our seniors. Of course, no one doctor can be directly "blamed" for the debacle of the past few days. Many doctors have offered their help repeatedly over the past few days, and are only looking to contribute to the collective effort. It will be said that the blow to the reputation of doctors dealt by Mr. Legault and Ms. McCann yesterday was unfair, and they will be right in large part. But we must also understand that if it is so easy for the FMOQ and the FMSQ to be seen as greedy groups that are detached from the public interest, it is not because of an emergency situation in a CHSLD or a pandemic. Rather, it is the indecent income disparities, the dizzying hierarchy of professions, and even institutionalized medical elitism that must be put in the dock. The situation depicted in yesterday's press conference is sure to make many Quebecers angry. Not directly, we hope, against doctors. But against the absurd inequalities that have been allowed, maintained and normalized over the decades in the health care system in particular and in society in general. With the crisis, all of Quebec became aware that some orderlies were working full time while earning less than the $2000 per month promised in emergency assistance to the population. The situation had to be denounced loud and clear before a meager bonus was granted. And while the question of how wealthy doctors should be involved and paid in times of pandemic was being debated, thousands of citizens continued to volunteer for organizations that meet the basic needs of the most vulnerable. The juxtaposition of these realities in people's minds, even if they are not linked by immediate causality, leaves a bitter taste. Getting rid of this label of doctors "above" the realities of the population will take more than a correction of the message or a marketing operation involving surgeons caught on camera feeding and washing sick seniors. It will take a louder voice from physicians who want more equitable working conditions for all essential health and human services personnel, and an end to being marginal voices within their own profession.

titre: Le nouveau condom
texte: Brazil's president, Jair Bolsonaro, is officially infected with COVID-19 as of Tuesday. Bolsonaro is the man who, not long ago, declared that the new disease was just a "little cold". The man who denigrates the wearing of masks, who organizes large political rallies without physical distancing measures and who dismisses public health experts who dare to express their dissent. Under this right-wing authoritarian with thinly veiled fascist tendencies, Brazil has become the second most affected country in the world by the pandemic, with more than 65,000 reported deaths. The parallels between Bolsonaro's Brazil and Donald Trump's United States are self-evident. In both cases, we are dealing with men who do not care about the people who pay the highest price for the negligence of public authorities. But also men who are very concerned about their image as "strong" men. Too "strong" to worry about viruses, disease, prevention, precautions. When this kind of machismo takes over the head of the state, the consequences are felt. In the United States, preliminary findings show that men in general, especially Republicans, are less likely to wear the mask in public. Several influential figures openly associate face coverings with weakness, with femininity. A lexical field akin to homophobic slurs is beginning to be used to describe those who care about protecting themselves and others. Sexual health experts, who have been fighting for decades to raise awareness about condom use, will not be surprised. In this area, several studies have already demonstrated the link between a certain ideological view of what masculinity should be and behaviors that put men and their partners at risk of spreading infections. Are the guys who are too macho to use a condom the same ones who refuse to wear masks in the United States, Brazil and elsewhere? Of course, we don't have clear numbers yet, but we can assume so. This ideology, which some call "toxic masculinity," has been wreaking havoc for a long time, not just in times of pandemic. It's about believing that what makes one a man does not lie in intrinsic and inalienable characteristics, but rather in behaviors or a social position that are always to be defended, renewed, and proven. One is not a man because one is oneself, but rather because one does not cry, because one controls all one's emotions except anger, because one holds certain jobs and not others, because one has a good salary, a house a car, because you can dominate others around you, because you have muscles, because you dress in a certain way and not in another, and perhaps, above all, because you never show that you are afraid. Because when we talk about masks, we are talking about fear. A rational, justified fear of the virus, which deserves a serious response. If one has never learned that fear is part of the register of valid emotions, acquired through evolution to guide human behavior, then one will be more inclined to reject the mask. Yet society has been bombarding men with messages in this sense since their early childhood. It is difficult to escape unscathed. If you believe this, then job loss, dissatisfaction with your social status, with the progress of women or minorities towards equality, vulnerability, painful emotion are not only normal dimensions of life, but also frontal attacks on your identity "as a man". When one adheres to this logic, even banal objects such as a condom or a mask can become threats to an important part of one's self-esteem. And this is the paradox: we construct these ideas in the name of strength, while defining strength by factors that are always a little, a lot, beyond the control of any individual, we make men vulnerable. To STIs, to coronavirus, but also to depression and emotional isolation. This idea that a "real man" cannot be afraid and must show dominance and fearlessness can also, of course, endanger his loved ones. And we're not just talking about infectious diseases here. We are fortunate, in Quebec and Canada, not to be guided for the moment by political figures who mix toxic masculinity and public health too abundantly. This is not to say that the phenomenon does not affect our culture. If François Legault is reluctant to make masks mandatory, it may be, among other things, that a portion of the population can still fall into these behaviours that are meant to be demonstrations of strength while, at the same time, signaling a great deal of vulnerability.

titre: Manifester fonctionne
texte: "The times called for it," they say. We're talking, of course, about the unprecedented visibility of the Black Lives Matter movement and the mobilization that never seems to completely wane in major American cities despite the pandemic. In April, 200 African-American women had demanded that Joe Biden's running mate be not only a woman, but a black woman, specifically. On Monday, 100 prominent African-American men followed suit. Biden needed a vice presidential candidate who would inspire Americans not just to vote against Trump, but to vote for Democrats. And a younger person who would offset his image as an aging man with little energy. But it was popular mobilization that forced the Democratic establishment to make a choice precisely for California Senator Kamala Harris. It took revolt and crisis for a racialized woman - black and South Asian - to be deemed competent and interesting enough to be chosen by one of the two major parties as a vice presidential candidate, for the first time in U.S. history. Clearly, protesting works. Normal conditions in American politics would not have led to this result. When "the times" call for change, those in power have no choice but to react and readjust to keep themselves in place. In many ways, this is true of Kamala Harris herself, who has not exactly built a reputation as a revolutionary throughout her career. As California's attorney general, she has rarely brought criminal charges against police officers who have killed civilians. She appealed a California ruling that declared the death penalty unconstitutional. She opposed the decriminalization of cannabis, when existing laws combined with routine racial profiling contributed greatly to the mass incarceration of Blacks and Latinos in her state. And she has intervened in several cases to seek harsher sentences for defendants from these same communities. We are not dealing here with a natural alignment with the Black Lives Matter movement or with the demands largely carried by a new generation of activists on the left flank of the Democratic Party. This professional baggage played a large role in undermining Harris' campaign for president last year. Many potential voters were skeptical that his personal rise would advance the lives of all African Americans, beyond the symbolic issues of representation. Young feminists had also shunned Hillary Clinton in 2016 for much the same reasons. Yet in the race for the Democratic nomination, she put forward a criminal justice reform proposal better aligned with the famous times. She has talked about legalizing cannabis, reforming police standards on the use of violence, fighting juvenile incarceration, and promoting social programs that would address the very causes of crime. In fact, she tries to explain that it is precisely because she was once Attorney General that she should be entrusted with the responsibility for such reform. She knows the system inside out. As with Clinton, we are dealing here with a politician who defines herself primarily as a "pragmatist. Pragmatism is understood here as a taste for working within the structures themselves, within the framework of what is part of the horizon of possibilities, i.e., what is not too costly politically. Over the course of Kamala Harris's long career, the horizon of the not-too-costly has expanded greatly, especially through the hard work of activists who will continue to be portrayed by the centrist establishment as impractical and strategic, and too polarizing to be serious candidates. The political platform of those eligible is changing accordingly. If the Biden-Harris duo comes to power and actually implements public policies that meet the needs of "our time," it will not be in spite of the "radical" left, but in large part because of it. It is because they will have gone to the polls in November and their weight in the party will have made them impossible to ignore in Congress. The conclusion is not only applicable to the United States. One of the reasons the federal government's emergency economic assistance package since March is meeting the needs of so many Canadians is that it is a minority government that had to negotiate NDP support to move forward with several programs. And if the "pragmatic" progressives currently in Montreal City Hall ever seriously address the criticisms of the SPVM from racialized and marginalized communities, it will be because the electoral cost of soft measures has been calculated to be greater than the cost of displeasing the next generation. Everywhere, protesting always ends up, sooner or later, with numbers, working.

titre: Dehors novembre
texte: It's a classic cycle. On the one hand, people who live on the street value freedom. Freedom to come and go as they please, to date their partner, to have access to their personal property, to have privacy, to have a pet, to not be asked too many questions when you step foot in the doorway. The kind of freedom we take for granted when we have a home. On the other hand, most of the resources available to them are rule-based. Rules that contribute in part to the safety of the shelters, make it easier for staff to do their jobs, and limit the legal risks to the agencies. A segment of the homeless population refuses to give up their freedom to adhere to such rigid programs, despite the dangers that abound, especially in winter. The system tries to stand up to them. Every year, we see the cold deaths, the overdoses. You wonder what could have been done better. David Chapman, coordinator of Resilience Montreal, is familiar with this endless battle between freedom and regulation. He believes that one of the problems is that funders are looking for "measurable results" from the programs they fund. How many people have you taken off the street, reintegrated? Necessarily, the most "effective" facilities are those that work with the "easiest" homeless population. The ones that can follow the rules. When agency funding is tied to achieving this type of outcome, services for the most vulnerable of the vulnerable necessarily become more scarce. "These people often fall through the cracks in the system," he explains. In times of pandemic and economic crisis, the cracks have become gaping crevices. Many downtown businesses and safe spaces have become more difficult to access, and the capacity of organizations has been reduced in order to comply with health measures. Women, especially indigenous women, are suffering the most from this limited access to resources. Jessica Quijano, from the Native Women's Shelter of Montreal, observes a marked increase in sexual assaults against women users. If women have nowhere to run, abusers know it and take advantage of it. It is difficult to put an exact figure on the phenomenon, since most of the survivors refuse to file a complaint. It is because they do not believe that the police will take the denunciation seriously. Or they fear reprisals from the aggressor or his group. Or they do not remember the details of the event clearly enough because of the state of intoxication, voluntary or forced. Even without official statistics, the problem has become serious enough that one worker asked, during a consultation meeting between organizations involved with this population, if a clothing bin should not be installed outside for women who reappear half-dressed, in crisis, during nights that are becoming increasingly cold. An image that marked Ms. Quijano. One of the solutions, she says, is more accessible resources, day and night, where women can feel truly welcome. Wish in Vancouver is a model of a non-judgmental resource center for all women, including trans women. Quijano also lamented the fact that Montreal's supervised injection services are concentrated in the east end of downtown, making them difficult to access for the Aboriginal homeless population in the Atwater area. We know that drug use has increased significantly since the beginning of the pandemic and that overdoses are becoming more frequent. The supply of resources should be adapted accordingly. For David Chapman, the way out of the crisis is also through a greater diversification of approaches. There are "fads", ideological movements that are becoming popular with the community concerned with people on the streets. He cites as an example the Housing First approach, which consists of providing access to stable housing as quickly as possible for people who are on the street. The model is popular with some clients. "But it's not a magic solution to centuries of cultural genocide and the intergenerational trauma it can leave behind," he says, thinking of his Aboriginal clients. "By insisting on efficiency, measuring success and mitigating risk, you leave humanity behind," he says.

titre: Mettre fin aux «freak shows»
texte: Long before mass media were developed enough to take over all the free time of the North American middle class, there was a golden age of the circus. As early as the 19th century, American companies traveled from city to city, on both sides of the border, entertaining young and old with their rides, games of skill, puppet shows, clowns, acrobats and unusual artists. To attract spectators, they compete with each other to recruit "fairground monsters". Sometimes they are extraordinary animals, preferably exotic, born with some kind of congenital malformation. More often, they are disabled people. By exhibiting them on stage, one seeks to make people laugh, to shock, to arouse horror, or even downright horror. Hear, hear! Ladies and Gentlemen! Come and see this child, born with two fingers on each hand! Or this little spider-girl (with four legs)! Or this bearded woman! Or this "elephant man" (suffering from a head tumor)! Or these Siamese twins who will do pirouettes for you! Come and see the remains of the "giant" Édouard Beaupré! The remains of this seven foot one inch half-breed man with gigantism, who died in 1904, were displayed at the entrance of Montreal's Eden Museum to attract passers-by, until the police got involved and the circus company abandoned the body in a shed. Or come visit the Dwarf Palace on Rachel Street! Where you could, as early as 1926, spy on the daily life of the members of a small family, which allowed them to make a living. The economic crisis of the 1930s hit freak shows hard, and the concept fell into disuse after the Second World War. While European and American companies entertained crowds with disabled people who were exhibited as "freaks", many governments had implemented eugenics policies. In Canada, the idea that "degenerates" should be eliminated from society gained ground especially in the West, resulting in laws for the forced sterilization of "feeble-minded" people in Alberta (1928) and British Columbia (1933). In Quebec, the Catholic Church was strongly opposed to any form of sterilization and thus to formal eugenics. That said, the idea that disabled people (physically or mentally) and other "freaks" (which at the time included alcoholics, sex workers, criminals, etc.) should be prevented from reproducing took root in some circles here as elsewhere. In Europe, the Nazis systematically locked up and then killed people with disabilities. After the Holocaust, the shocked West began to think a little more seriously about human rights. People still make fun of disabilities, both on television and in schoolyards. But we are at least asking ourselves if it is "politically correct" to do so. In the aftermath of the Supreme Court ruling in the Mike Ward and Jeremy Gabriel case, the question was asked: Is it okay to fantasize about killing a disabled child in a comedy show, just to get a laugh? But we neglected to ask the question: why does fantasizing about the murder of a disabled child make a critical mass of people laugh, to the point of being commercially viable? What is the historical connection between the entertainment industry, comedy shows and violence against people with disabilities? With these questions, we get out of the rather sterile paradigm, it seems to me, where we worry about our freedom to stigmatize without asking where the desire to do so comes from. That's where I think the reflection becomes more interesting. Peter Dinklage, the actor who brilliantly portrayed Tyrion Lannister in the Game of Thrones series, has spoken repeatedly about all the degrading roles he had to reject before stumbling upon a few rare projects where his dwarfism would not be pitted against his dignity. Even today, people with disabilities are often invisible in popular culture. Or they are featured in clichéd scenarios, where they are admired for having "overcome" their disability - necessarily presented as a problem to be solved - with extraordinary strength of character. It is still rare, both on screen and on stage, to simply see them being, in their individuality, their strengths, their weaknesses, their sexuality, their humor, in short, their humanity. Awareness is growing, however, and movements against ableism are progressing. Who knows, soon enough, we will have changed popular culture enough that it will no longer be commercially profitable to simply talk about murdering a child in front of crowds, as a joke. Who knows, we may even have made more room for people with disabilities in the comedy community, and we'll stop debating comedy and discrimination as if these artists didn't exist.

titre: La haine, tranquille
texte: The latest twist in the Conservative Party of Canada leadership race is particularly surreal. Pierre Poilievre, well ahead in the polls, shook hands with a supporter last weekend at a campaign event. The supporter turned out to be Jeremy Mackenzie, founder of the Diagolon - a man and group associated with "violent extremism" by the Integrated Terrorism Assessment Centre (ITAC), the federal agency responsible for identifying threats to national security. Understandably, in a crowd bath, a politician does not necessarily know the identity of everyone he shakes hands with. But since then, the identity of the person has become public. Conservative leadership candidate Jean Charest and NDP leader Jagmeet Singh have both asked Pierre Poilievre to denounce the individual. For the moment, it is radio silence on Poilievre's side. And this silence does not seem to affect particularly the campaign of the candidate. A few years ago, the incident would have seemed surreal to anyone who follows politics closely or remotely. But now the leader of the Conservative Party race can shake hands with a violent extremist under surveillance by Canadian anti-terrorism authorities, quietly, without making waves. After all, Mr. Poilievre and several of his fellow MPs also had no problem appearing with the so-called "freedom convoy" in Ottawa last February. Yet the CIET also identified the convoy as an important recruitment and networking "opportunity" for several violent extremist movements, according to a report released last week through an Access to Information request. This is not to say that all of the participants in the convoy belonged to violent extremist groups, of course. Rather, it is said that their presence was significant enough, particularly among the organizers, that it was very problematic, if not dangerous, for elected officials to associate with them. This recruitment and networking, and therefore the growth of violent groups associated with the far right since last February, has become palpable. As recently as two weeks ago, QAnon supporters attacked police officers in Peterborough, Ontario, under the pretense of making a "citizen's arrest. And several journalists - women, especially racialized ones - have been the subject of a targeted hate campaign in recent months. Emails, written in a similar pattern, use the vocabulary and hateful theories of far-right groups, while punctuating them with threats of rape and death. In view of the seriousness of the situation, the Toronto Star, Global News, the Hill Times and the Canadian Association of Journalists even had to make a joint statement to denounce the situation and to question the police services who had allegedly failed to treat many of the complaints received with sufficient seriousness. Let's summarize. Far-right activists, many of whom have been identified as terrorist threats, helped bring the nation's capital to a standstill last winter. Since then, they have multiplied, and some of them have attacked not only elected officials, but also journalists, and even police officers. Let's imagine for a moment that it is the leader of a terrorist group associated with Islamism who shakes hands with Pierre Poilievre, or who sends death and rape threats to journalists. Do you think the impact on the Conservative leadership race would be the same? Do you think the seriousness of the threats received would be trivialized as much? Let's imagine that an Aboriginal group decides to make a "citizen's arrest" of a police force. Would the news be treated as a routine summer political news item? To ask the question is to answer it. The trivialization of threats posed by the extreme right in Canada has been denounced for several years by experts in the field. And of course, this rise in hate affects not only public figures, but also ordinary people. Between 2019 and 2021, police-reported hate crimes increased by 72%, according to Statistics Canada compilations. Again, imagine a 72% increase in any other type of crime in Canada over a two-year period. Everyone would be talking about it. Often, when the threat comes from the extreme right, the police and media analysis focuses on "isolated incidents", "lone wolves". So the movement is there, in front of us, and it is growing. But it is still difficult to see it as a movement. Each complaint of a death threat or rape, for example, will be treated in isolation - if it is even treated at all. Most often, we are careful not to look at the networks to which the individual who pours out his hatred belongs. In order to stop trivializing the phenomenon, we must finally understand that, even when we are dealing with a man alone behind his keyboard, this man belongs to a very specific social context.

titre: Lâchez-nous avec Montréal
texte: Quebec Premier François Legault has in his possession studies on the relevance of a third highway link between Quebec City and Lévis. He refuses to make them public. Every time he is asked, his answer is more or less the same: the studies were done before the pandemic, the new reality of telecommuting is changing the situation, and their content must be updated. This will not be done - of course - until after the election campaign. This response is unacceptable. Why? Because the CAQ committed to carrying the project of a third link during the 2018 election campaign. The Prime Minister has been promoting a tunnel under the St. Lawrence for his entire mandate. Studies have been conducted on the relevance and feasibility of the project. Studies that the CAQ has never made public, while its advocacy continues. The population is entitled to know if in 2018, in 2019, in 2020, in 2021 and again in 2022, the Prime Minister sold the population a project that the experts disapprove of. If the CAQ made an unnecessary, unworkable, overpriced, useless or poorly designed third link one of its government's priorities before the pandemic, the studies on the issue done before the pandemic are of glaring public interest. Now. Not after Election Day. Not after new post-pandemic studies become available. Now. Last week, Bernard Drainville, CAQ candidate in Levis, launched a "get off my back about GHGs" in defense of the third link. It is time to reply to Mr. Drainville and his leader: give us a break! These studies, this expertise, were financed with public funds; they therefore belong to the public. During Radio-Canada's special program Cinq chefs, une élection last Sunday, François Legault said that the opposition to the third link comes from "Montrealers" who "look down on" the people of Quebec City and Lévis. It would be better, however, if the Prime Minister would also let us down with Montreal. After all, Bruno Marchand, the mayor of Quebec City, also believes that the studies on the project should be made public. Could it be that with his stubbornness, the Prime Minister is looking down on the Mayor of Quebec City? Does he think that the people of Quebec City and Lévis do not find scientific expertise important? Does he fear that the local population does not know how to intelligently read a study written in 2019? Refusing to make public the information that the government has on a major project for a region, is this not a lack of respect for its population and, more broadly, for the imperative of transparency in a democracy? To say that Montrealers look down on the people of Quebec City and Lévis is demagoguery. And demagogy is necessarily an intellectual shortcut that strikes a very real chord.
