As a child and teenager in Lévis, and during the three years I spent in Quebec City itself, I don't know how many times I heard that one. I had never spent any time in Montreal, but I already knew that there were people out there, especially on the mythical Plateau-Mont-Royal, who looked down on us. The urban legend was certainly conveyed by the local radio stations. And certain media realities could then be interpreted as evidence. Why is the universe of Quebec soap operas necessarily that of Montreal? Why, on the Téléjournal, do the journalists try to speak with the accent of the private colleges of Outremont? Is there a problem with our living environments? Our language? I've been on the other side of the mirror long enough to know that regional rivalries and classism do exist in Quebec, but that they are much more complex than the demagogic - yes, demagogic - statements we most often hear on the subject. A provincial election should not normally be the occasion to discuss the subject. One would like to believe that the people who aspire to the role of premier are driven, among other things, by an attachment to and respect for all Quebecers. And that uniting the population behind them is an important objective. We would like to believe this, but we should not be naive either. Our electoral system (which the CAQ has refused to reform) leads election campaigns to target their messages primarily at people in the Quebec City area and the suburbs of 450. both with its rhetoric and its legislative policy, the CAQ has done much in four years to exacerbate the division between Montreal and "the regions" in the collective imagination. We don't expect the political party to stop there. What is interesting this week is that François Legault is waving the scarecrow of Montrealers who take the people of the greater Quebec City region "down", in order to better take the population of this same region down. If local voices see through his game and denounce him, the strategy may fail.

titre: La honte d’avoir faim
texte: In The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism, one of the founders of modern sociology, Max Weber, examines the link between wealth and virtue, particularly in the Anglo-Saxon world. The idea here is that in Protestant cultures, financial prosperity is a sign of God's grace. Of course, one can recognize in this portrait a large part of American and Canadian society. With the historical strength of the Catholic Church in Quebec, the relationship to wealth, and therefore to poverty, is of course different. But it can be argued that with the break of a good part of the population from Catholicism, this Quebec difference has faded. It is clear that, rather than considering that "the last shall be first in the kingdom of God," Quebec elites have also internalized the Protestant ethic and the spirit of dominant capitalism. Being poor, for many, is necessarily a sign of vice. In North America - including Quebec - it takes courage to identify oneself as poor. The mythical "middle class" takes up so much space in our imaginations that we end up being unable to even put simple words to social inequalities. A household can earn three or four times the median income and still identify with the middle class. Similarly, a family that cannot pay its grocery bills will also continue to call itself "middle". Because in North America, poverty tends to be seen primarily as a "bad patch". It's as if every poor person is a potential bourgeois who is temporarily indisposed - and who will reveal his or her true social habitus to the world if he or she agrees to roll up his or her sleeves and "work hard. To admit that one is poor and not "broken for the moment" would be to say that one lacks discipline, talent, work ethic - all virtues that we are promised will guarantee access to material comfort. These beliefs are bullshit, of course. But it plays a very specific role. Shame, under capitalism, allows one to avoid revolt. The embarrassment of one's economic condition, the conviction that it is by personal default that one does not live better, the hesitation even to name one's precariousness are essential to the maintenance of the apparent order. If it weren't for the hold these ideas have on society, there would be tens of thousands of people in the streets, right now in Quebec, shouting that they are hungry. If it weren't for this nonsense, there would be crowds as far as the eye can see, in front of parliaments, chanting that no, you are not lazy. That no, with the current minimum wage, working full time, even more, does not necessarily lift you out of poverty. That no, Christian holiday charity is not a viable way to address hunger and malnutrition. You would repeat that no, living in a "rich country" does not guarantee that everyone has access to that wealth. That no, just because a person is disabled does not mean that he or she does not deserve anything better than a lifetime of miserable benefits. That no, prejudging people on social assistance is not the way to create a "productive" society. That no, seniors who are no longer in the "workforce" do not deserve to stop living in dignity overnight. Your frustration would become so great that politicians would have no choice but to propose at least some structural changes. After all, even the poor have the right to vote. But we are not there yet. We tell ourselves that the current hunger crisis is due to that damn inflation, to a potential one-time recession - not to the very organization of society. We keep telling ourselves that if people can't make ends meet, it's because they are still going through one of those mythical "bad times" - and not because we still consider, in our society, the existence of poverty as a consequence of an individual's lack of "effort". We prefer to be surprised by every economic crisis, taken aback by the breaking of the promise of perpetual prosperity on which America was founded. We wait patiently for a return to economic "normalcy". We refuse to see that even under this economic "normal", poverty and hunger have never ceased to be problems of rich countries. This week marked the 20th anniversary of the provincial Act to combat poverty and social exclusion. The Collective for a Poverty-Free Quebec took the opportunity to publish a critical review of its application and to take stock of its progress. People looking for concrete solutions can start looking here. There are many reasons why, 20 years later, we are still a long way from eliminating poverty. I don't know what profound change we can expect, unless shame stops being carried by the poor, and becomes instead the lot of those who impoverish.

titre: Les gens inquiets
texte: There is a part of the Quebec population that is used to being called "the people". For the last fifteen years, people have been more and more worried. Quebec is changing around them, and they have the feeling of losing the control they had more or less convinced themselves of having acquired over their destiny, not so long ago. People have been worried about their survival for generations. At the moment, this anxiety is justified not by the intergenerational passing of a collective narrative where difference threatens identity... but by the existence of the veil on planet Earth. To legislate on the basis of these concerns is to defend Quebec values. We said: let's legislate quickly, to move on. Once people are reassured, the page will be turned. The federal election has come. We talked again about people's concerns. Secularism is us," said the Bloc; "we will defend you. The day after October 21, we saw that the greater Montreal area - like Sherbrooke, Gatineau, downtown Quebec City and all Canadian metropolises, historically as now - voted red rather than blue (light or dark). This is proof that part of Quebec is escaping from the real national Quebec, popular tribunes and hyperactive web quidams alike have been saying. The threat is growing; the integration of the "others" and the re-education of traitors are urgent... We must remain on the lookout. Then, the provincial by-election in Jean-Talon, in Quebec City, was prepared. This election is a referendum on secularism, the CAQ repeated. The fight for your cultural "security" still goes on, in other words. There is still reason to be vigilant. Worry. On Wednesday, the Legault government announced that its values test for immigrants will come into effect in January. The underlying message of such a measure can only be this: "These people are not like us. We have to be wary of them. We must test them. Their values may not be the right ones. Let's be on our guard. The purpose of the measure: to reassure the famous people. Its real effect: to give the seal of state approval to the reflexes of anxiety and distrust towards "that world". To feed the anguish. It's to make sure that everyone understands that in Quebec we have gender equality," says Jolin-Barrette. Does the minister know that the three regions where there is the most domestic violence in Quebec are the North Shore (far ahead), Abitibi and Outaouais? Will the test be used there? Do we know of any programs that successfully deconstruct a group's patriarchal beliefs by having them fill out some kind of questionnaire? It doesn't matter. What matters is that we look like a bunch of tough guys putting on their pants and not letting them get away with it. People are concerned, but their concerns are often misdirected. Real issues are often ignored, and real solutions are rarely implemented. People are worried because they see their world changing, but they don't know how to adapt. They are worried because they don't understand the new technologies, cultures and ideas that are transforming their society. They are worried because they don't know how to adapt to these changes. However, the real solution to these concerns is not to legislate to reassure people, but rather to give them the tools to adapt to the changes. We must give them the means to understand and accept the new cultures and ideas that are transforming their society. We need to empower them to understand and use the new technologies that are transforming their world. We must empower them to adapt to the changes that are transforming their lives. Only by giving people the tools to adapt to the changes can we truly reassure people and give them hope that they can adapt to their new reality. Only by giving them the means to understand and accept the new cultures and ideas that are transforming their society can we truly reassure people and give them hope that they can adapt to their new reality. Only by empowering them to understand and use the new technologies that are transforming their world can we truly reassure people and give them hope that they can adapt to their new reality.

titre: Cette fameuse égalité des chances
texte: On Tuesday morning on the radio, Minister Lionel Carmant, now co-chair of the Caquist government's action group on racism, said that Quebec manages "three networks where there is equality of opportunity: education, daycare services and the health system." According to him, therefore, the mandate he has been given can be reasonably completed in three months, as the issue of racism in Quebec is well circumscribed. I don't know what hurt the most when I heard this statement. First, the memories that come back. The time the teacher got angry at me for being emotional over nothing, when a student had been calling me a nigger for weeks. The time another teacher exclaimed that the most amazing thing about my academic success was that I was gifted while black. Or the time I was told that wearing African braids was not part of the school's acceptable dress code. And then there are the times my brother, a very good student, had his locker searched by the principal in case drugs were found. After the personal memories comes the memory of the countless testimonies I received, often from complete strangers, given my visible role in the fight against racism. A mother caught with a daycare teacher who questions the hygiene of frizzy hair. A school that wants to start a cosom field hockey activity, but is wary of basketball because it attracts "gangs". Sometimes, it is also about talented young people whose dreams are extinguished and who are directed towards more "reasonable" careers in the technical sectors. Parents who dare not speak out against the abusive discipline their children face for fear that those same children will pay the price. Then there are the statistics and studies that have been published with indifference for too long. Black children who are over-diagnosed with behavioral and learning disabilities. Children from recent immigrant backgrounds who are labeled with a language disorder because there is a lack of acceptance that the brains of bilingual youth develop differently, and that this is not a problem. Two-tiered public schools, where racialized youth are virtually excluded from special education programs and remain concentrated in the "mainstream. And significant overrepresentation in dropout rates. And then, more broadly, there is the systemic racism that prevents parents from finding jobs commensurate with their qualifications and concentrates families in low-income neighborhoods, where the public school system is at its worst. | These examples are unfortunately too numerous and they reflect a reality of unequal opportunity. Racialized people face unique barriers to accessing services and opportunities that are within their reach. Systemic discrimination is deeply rooted in our society and is at the root of this inequality of opportunity. Racialized people often face prejudice and stereotypes that prevent them from accessing leadership positions, well-paying jobs, and quality services. Systemic discrimination also causes school segregation and unequal educational opportunities. Racialized youth often face teachers who are not trained in cross-cultural teaching and who are unaware of the biases and stereotypes that drive this inequality of opportunity. Racialized youth also face assessment systems that are not responsive to their needs and do not take into account their culture and history. This inequality of opportunity is a deeply rooted problem in our society and it is urgent to combat it. It is essential to put in place concrete measures to fight systemic racism and to ensure equal opportunities for all. It is necessary to train teachers in intercultural education and to put in place assessment systems that take into account the needs of racialized youth. It is also important to ensure that public services are accessible to all and that they are of high quality. Finally, it is essential to raise awareness about the fight against racism and the importance of equal opportunities. Only through collective and concerted action can inequality of opportunity be addressed and access to quality services and equal opportunities be guaranteed for all.

titre: Pour comprendre les survivantes
texte: One of the first reflexes of someone who has been sexually assaulted is often to try to forget everything, or to deny in one way or another the depth of the trauma. In this way, the brain tries, in its own way, to protect us from the realities that are too painful to face. This is because an assault can be profoundly destructive to the survivor, especially if she is very young. For many survivors, reporting in itself does not heal anything. The damage is done. Most women who are able to break the silence do so because the fear of facing the social and legal consequences or even their trauma is superseded by an even greater fear: that others will go through the same thing. And this protective instinct can become cardinal in their choices and guide their speaking out. One out of three women in Quebec has been assaulted in her lifetime. There are therefore a ton of aggressors among us. However, to make these tens of thousands of human beings rot in a cage, outcast from society, is not the ultimate goal of the current denunciation movement or of those that preceded it. Rather, it is to heal, acknowledge and repair the harm that has been done, to ensure the safety and fulfillment of women, to ensure that those who have committed harmful acts are no longer dangerous in the future, and to transform the social norms that have made the pandemic of violence possible. In the last few days, these aspirations have not been the focus of attention. Instead, concepts from three major institutions that were not designed by or for women have been mobilized, as if these were the keys to their movements. Firstly, everything has been reduced to the criminal justice system, which has been built over the centuries with a punitive rather than rehabilitative logic. Not only does a well-founded denunciation not necessarily lead to formal charges or a conviction, but it has never been demonstrated that these trials effectively lead a guilty person and the affected community towards introspection, reparation and transformation. Victims are told to go to the police "if they are telling the truth," without questioning whether the resources of the police, judges, and prison guards are truly consistent with the ideal of justice that motivates their approach. Second, there is an attempt to understand survivors through the managerial logic of minimizing business risks and protecting brand images. Feminists speak of rape culture, which implies that the entire system must be called upon to reflect on the power relations that run through it and that endanger women. Companies distance themselves from the few who "don't reflect their values" while denying that the problem is systemic. Finally, there is the media logic, which seeks to reduce complex stories to simple narratives and easily understood images. The media is often the first point of contact between survivors and the public, and can be a powerful tool for advancing the movement. But their tendency to reduce stories to "good" and "bad" people, "victims" and "perpetrators," "heroes" and "villains," can be very limiting. Media can also be a way to control discourse and reduce women's voices to "narratives" that are easier to understand and consume. The media can also be a way to control discourse and reduce women's voices to "narratives" that are easier to understand and consume. These three institutions are deeply embedded in our society and are often the only ones considered when addressing issues of justice and safety. But they are not the only ones who can help us understand survivors and offer them the support they need. Women who have experienced sexual assault have complex and varied stories, and their needs are equally varied. To help them heal and rebuild, we must look to solutions that are both more humane and more holistic. We need to listen to their stories and needs, and we need to make sure that their voices are heard and respected. We must also ensure that the solutions we propose are tailored to their needs and realities. We need to ensure that the solutions we propose are tailored to their needs and realities, and that we don't just answer questions that are not theirs. We must ensure that the solutions we propose are adapted to their needs and realities, and that we do not simply answer questions that are not theirs. We must also ensure that the solutions we propose are adapted to their needs and realities, and that we do not simply answer questions that are not theirs. We must ensure that the solutions we propose are adapted to their needs and realities, and that we do not simply answer questions that are not theirs. We must also ensure that the solutions we propose are adapted to their needs and realities, and that we do not simply answer questions that are not theirs. We must therefore ensure that the solutions we propose are adapted to the needs and realities of survivors, and that we do not simply answer questions that are not theirs. We must also ensure that the solutions we offer are tailored to their needs and realities.

titre: La démocratie et l’Empire
texte: After sending federal agents "as reinforcements" to Portland last week and to Chicago on Wednesday, Donald Trump is talking about deploying more in New York, Philadelphia, Detroit and Baltimore. These are heavily African-American cities, led by Democrats, where the Black Lives Matter protests are gaining momentum that displeases both his ideological agenda and his campaign schedule. On Saturday, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi condemned the president's decisions in an official statement: "We live in a democracy, not a banana republic." The phrase is fraught with meaning. The term first appeared in the early 20th century, when the large American corporation United Fruit Company was actively corrupting elected officials, destabilizing democracy and staging a coup in Honduras. The term became popular as the tactic was replicated throughout Latin America and the Caribbean. The goal: to establish regimes that are sympathetic to U.S. ambitions, willing to obediently write laws that allow capitalists to accumulate profits without worrying about expropriating local communities or overly burdensome labor standards. For more than a century, then, Ms. Pelosi's famous democracy has been importing bananas and exporting dictatorship. On several occasions, the United States has not hesitated to send the army to defend its economic interests abroad. On July 28, it will be exactly 105 years since Woodrow Wilson's marines landed in Haiti for a military occupation that officially lasted 20 years, but whose effects are still felt today. There is talk of rapes, assassinations, and torture. In Washington, they did not hide the fact that they preferred to deploy troops from the South, who would have more "disciplinary" experience with the Blacks. In fact, all the violence of Jim Crow was exported, while the laws of the Republic of Haiti were rewritten to allow American companies access to land and to force residents to destroy the island's forests for the export of wood. The ecological catastrophe that is undermining the country began at this time, under the boot of Washington. The American state, police and military violence that has been condemned in some circles in recent weeks has been in place for a long time. The country was first built by enslaving, terrorizing and dispossessing the indigenous and black populations of North America. Through the massacres of "Indians" by "cowboys," now romanticized in Hollywood westerns, westward expansion and extractive capitalism were made possible. Through Ku Klux Klan terrorism, racial segregation and systemic racism, African Americans were kept in the role of cheap labor with fragile rights, even after the abolition of slavery. These practices are still very much present today. The United States is always looking for new ways to grab resources and maintain its hegemony. Military interventions and coups are still a possibility, but increasingly they are being replaced by more subtle methods. The United States has become an expert in the art of manipulation and corruption. It is prepared to offer loans at exorbitant interest rates, impose economic sanctions and use the media to influence public opinion. The United States is also willing to ally itself with authoritarian regimes to ensure that its interests are protected. These practices are particularly detrimental to indigenous and black peoples. Indigenous peoples are often the first to suffer the consequences of military interventions and coups, and they are also the first to suffer the consequences of more subtle practices. Indigenous peoples are often the first to be expropriated from their lands and racially discriminated against. Black peoples are often the first to be victims of police violence and discriminatory practices. Democracy and Empire are thus closely linked. The U.S. has long used democracy as a means to capture resources and maintain its hegemony. Indigenous and Black peoples are the first to suffer the consequences. It is therefore essential that we remember history and be vigilant against U.S. attempts to grab resources and maintain its hegemony. We must ensure that democracy is used for the good of all and not for the benefit of one.

titre: L’ancien ordre n’existe plus
texte: My high school history teacher had never digested it. How could Quebec Premier Adélard Godbout have caved in to his federal counterpart, Mackenzie King, he exclaimed. How could he have agreed to the 1940 constitutional amendment that gave Ottawa sole responsibility for the new unemployment insurance program? It was a veritable Pandora's box that had been opened! Under the pretext of economic crisis and war, the central power was strengthened and the interests of Quebec were not defended! He is not the only one who remembers this significant passage. There are still nationalists on both the left and the right who are keen on history and who are quick to comment on this episode, which was indeed crucial to Canadian federalism. The creation of unemployment insurance (or employment insurance since 1996) marked a dramatic change in philosophy about the role of government. Conservative Prime Minister Richard Bennett, Mackenzie King's predecessor, had spent the early 1930s more or less acknowledging the historic severity of the Great Depression. Faced with staggering unemployment rates across the country, he had continued to promote a classic laissez-faire economic program. Faced with the lack of approval from the Canadian public, he had no choice but to radically transform his policies in 1935. The old order no longer exists," he announced on the radio. We are living in conditions that are new and strange to us... I am for reform. And in my mind, reform means government intervention." Taking his cue from U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, Bennett proposed a series of measures, including unemployment insurance, which was initially ruled unconstitutional and so could not be implemented until 1940 by Mackenzie King. The old order no longer exists. I don't know if there has been a year since the days of the Great Depression when those words have resonated so much. We are indeed living in 2020 in conditions that are new and strange to all of us. A new reality that we are still struggling to come to grips with, and that our political class has certainly not yet grasped. In Ottawa, Bill Morneau is stepping down as Finance Minister. In addition to the UNIS controversy, rumour has it that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office could no longer agree with his minister on the government's direction, particularly on the costly generosity of its public assistance programs and future economic stimulus plan. This week, the appointment of Chrystia Freeland as Finance Minister and the upcoming September Speech from the Throne are being touted as the end of the old order and the beginning of a new era marked by a greening of the Canadian economy and historic reform of Employment Insurance. This new era may well be an opportunity to reassess the role of the provinces in Canadian federalism. The Speech from the Throne could be an opportunity to reaffirm the role of the provinces in delivering EI and economic stimulus programs. The provinces could thus be better equipped to respond to the needs of their citizens and could even be able to propose programs that are better adapted to their realities. This new era could also be an opportunity to reassess the role of citizens in Canadian federalism. Citizens could be more involved in the decision-making process and could be better informed about the issues and decisions that are made. Citizens could be more aware of the consequences of decisions made by their governments and could better understand their rights and responsibilities. Finally, this new era could be an opportunity to reassess the role of business in Canadian federalism. Business could be better equipped to respond to the needs of citizens and could be able to propose programs that are more adapted to their realities. Business could also be more involved in the decision-making process and could be better informed about the issues and decisions that are made. This new era could be an opportunity to reassess the role of provinces, citizens and business in Canadian federalism. This reassessment could lead to a better understanding of the issues and decisions that are made and better equip the various actors to respond to the needs of citizens.

titre: Humilier ne mène nulle part
texte: In the anti-racist movement, there is a general effort to follow a cardinal rule: attack systems, policies, behaviors, arguments, actions and their consequences, not individuals. First, if you target a concrete problem, you can fix it. And above all, labeling an entire person causes an outcry that makes listening and dialogue impossible. The reaction is often infinitely violent towards the activists, who rarely have the social capital of their interlocutors. It is also for security reasons that one must avoid insulting people. Even the most diplomatic ones already receive more than their share of vitriol. Coming from this movement, I observe with great apprehension what is happening in Quebec. A large group of public figures are calling a growing segment of the population names because their trust in the mainstream media is eroding, because there is a fear of the mask, because conspiracy theories are gaining ground. Celebrities are outright attacking the intelligence of many ordinary citizens from their imposing platforms. They probably never learned to fear the consequences of contempt. Reporters ask themselves important ethical questions: should they cover these events or not, and is there a risk of giving them prominence? Often they are covered, but with caution. Then, opinion journalists, elected officials and other personalities are careful to condemn, with good reason, behaviors that are harmful to public health. But when we venture into personal insults, we create a powerful two-step public humiliation machine: newsrooms expose, commentators mock. Maybe we think we're being strong with well-felt insults, while we remain decidedly helpless in front of this rise of conspiracy. Probably we don't know what else to do. What is certain is that the dynamics of humiliation will in no way repair the damaged bond of trust towards science and journalism. We can see in the United States where the arrogance of the liberal elites has led them. Do we still remember the monster that Hillary Clinton fed by calling Donald Trump's supporters a "basket of deplorables" during the 2016 presidential campaign? The quips have been flying ever since. Is the United States better off? We're lucky in Quebec that no political party is trying to harness this humiliation to feed its populist movement - for now. But that's almost a quarter of Quebecers who, for example, believe that COVID-19 could have been created in a lab. If we continue to treat a quarter of the population as idiots-imbeciles-larks, where are we going? What if we were to stick instead to criticizing the behaviors that cause contagion, certainly, but especially the institutions that lead us into this dangerous era of post-truth? It seems to me that we would be better off, for example, redirecting anger and contempt towards a company like Facebook, which threatens the health of democracies like no physical weapon of mass destruction could. | This attitude of contempt and humiliation only aggravates the situation and leads to nothing constructive. Instead of attacking individuals, the root causes of these problems must be addressed. The mainstream media and institutions need to be more transparent and open to discussion. titre: Une démocratie prête à tomber
texte: Kali Akuno has never seen so many Confederate flags. The co-founder and co-director of the Jackson Cooperative, an African-American community organization in Mississippi's capital city, has noticed them on shirts and hats, stickers on cars, signs on lawns, everywhere. The phenomenon has been particularly strong since July, when the governor began efforts to change the official state flag of the Old South, which still contains the famous symbol of slavery. The white, conservative population of Mississippi has since redoubled its efforts to "defend its history. But if the Confederate flag is flying everywhere, it is also a sign of enthusiastic support for Donald Trump, according to Kali. That's because, while the suburbs and rural areas around Jackson are white, the city itself is 80 percent African-American. "If Trump's base dares to be so proud even here, it's because they're galvanized like never before," he explains. And the U.S. president is actively working to feed the sense that his voters' American identity is under attack. In a speech last week at the National Archives Museum, for example, Trump spoke of the radical left marching to force Americans to "abandon their values, heritage and way of life." Words that echo those of Confederate leaders at the dawn of the Civil War - no less. In the streets of Mississippi, heavily armed white militias have been marching regularly since the beginning of the summer, in order to frighten the Black Lives Matter protesters, but also Democratic voters, more generally. Some groups even set up shop on the border between rural counties and attempt to check the identity of citizens as they move about. For the black population, which remembers all too well the golden age of the Ku Klux Klan, the situation awakens many traumas. Already, last weekend, Republican activists tried to intimidate voters attempting to cast early ballots in Fairfax, Virginia. Kali is certain the tactic will be used elsewhere in the South, including his own home. After all, this kind of intimidation was commonplace before the victories of the civil rights movement. Isn't that what the slogan Make America great again means? To those who find his vision pessimistic, Kali replies, "Every black uprising in American history has been followed by a violent backlash. I don't see why this time would be any different." The activist also sees the militant energy of progressive whites waning as George Floyd's death becomes more distant. Meanwhile, nothing is settled. Across the country, people are anxiously awaiting the decision of the jury that will decide the fate of the police officers who killed Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old black woman, in Louisville last March. | The situation is particularly worrisome for racial minorities, who are already underrepresented in positions of power and who see their basic rights threatened. The November elections are therefore crucial to their future. Black activists and civil rights organizations are hard at work to make sure their voices are heard and their votes count. Initiatives like the Black Voters Matter Fund, which supports campaigns to educate and mobilize black voters, are critical to countering voter suppression efforts. But the fight for democracy is not limited to the United States. Around the world, authoritarian regimes are trying to hold on to power by limiting access to information and suppressing dissenting voices. The United States must therefore commit to defending democracy and human rights wherever they are threatened. This means supporting organizations that fight for freedom and justice, and ensuring that the United States is an example of democracy and freedom to the rest of the world. Finally, it is important to remember that democracy is not just about the ballot box. Democracy is about respect and dignity for all citizens, regardless of race, background or sexual orientation. The United States must commit to fighting all forms of discrimination and promoting equal rights for all. Only an inclusive and just democracy can provide all citizens with the freedom and security they need to live their lives fully.

titre: L’heure du test
texte: In June, Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was kneeling with protesters at Black Lives Matter rallies. He repeated everywhere, "I hear you, I hear you." In the recent Throne Speech, he repeated his intention to address systemic racism. This is very good - and certainly better than those in the National Assembly who are still mired in denial. The federal government is responding to a shift in public opinion, which is increasingly sensitive to this issue. But is it really ready to act? For three weeks now, Mamadou Konaté has been locked up at the Federal Detention Centre in Laval, awaiting deportation. The man of Ivorian origin worked in a CHSLD during the first wave of the pandemic. He contracted the virus himself and then returned to his job. He currently fears for his life if he were to return to Côte d'Ivoire, as he was previously imprisoned there during the civil war that tore the country apart in the early 2000s. Hectic elections are currently underway. Despite his work, Konaté is not eligible for the special program for asylum seekers because he was working as a housekeeper through an employment agency, rather than as an orderly. He is one of those essential workers who have been left out of the state's decidedly narrow "gratitude". Despite a petition with nearly 38,000 signatures and the support of opposition MPs, federal Immigration Minister Marco Mendicino refuses to comment on the issue, and Quebec City has decided not to pressure Ottawa. Konaté is far from alone in his situation. Mostafa Henaway, a community organizer at the Centre for Immigrant Workers (CTI), has been supporting several people with precarious status since the pandemic began. In particular, he tells me about a Nigerian-born couple who arrived here via the U.S. border in 2017 and whose asylum appeal was just rejected. He works in a Dollarama warehouse, she in a food distribution center. Their two-year-old daughter was born here. But barring a miracle, the entire family will soon face deportation as well. "The life stories of asylum seekers from West Africa tend to be routinely questioned by federal commissioners, who often have very little knowledge of the cultural and political context of these countries," Henaway laments. Warehouse and food industry workers are just as essential - and underpaid - as LTC staff. The federal government has repeatedly stated its intention to address systemic racism, but its actions have not kept pace. Essential workers, who are predominantly racialized people, are still too often left behind. Asylum seekers are also victims of this systemic discrimination. Federal commissioners, who decide on the eligibility of asylum claims, often have very little knowledge of the cultural and political context of the claimants' countries of origin, which means that their life stories are systematically questioned. The case of Mamadou Konaté is particularly revealing of this injustice. He worked in a CHSLD during the first wave of the pandemic, and even contracted the virus. Despite his essential work, he is not eligible for the special regularization program for asylum seekers because he held a position as a housekeeper through an employment agency. He is now locked up at the Federal Detention Centre in Laval, awaiting deportation. The federal government must act to end this systemic discrimination. It must recognize the essential work of warehouse and food industry workers and provide them with access to regularization programs. It must also ensure that federal commissioners are familiar with the cultural and political context of asylum seekers' countries of origin, so that their life stories are not routinely questioned. Only concrete and immediate action can end this injustice.

titre: L’égalité des chances d’écraser
texte: Last Friday, many people saw the appointment of former Montreal Police Service communicator Ian Lafrenière to the position of Minister of Aboriginal Affairs, replacing Sylvie D'Amours, as a problem of... parity. It is true that this is the fourth time that Premier François Legault has replaced female ministers whose performance left something to be desired with male colleagues. It is also true that, if the mistakes of male ministers were judged as harshly by Mr. Legault, Simon Jolin-Barrette would have lost his limousine as soon as he started messing up at Immigration. But in the context of the mobilization following the death of Joyce Echaquan, there was something out of place in this preoccupation with gender balance in the Quebec City cabinet. As if it were the main women's rights issue being targeted that day. As if it were not more outrageous that Aboriginal women, who had made the Viens Commission possible with their denunciations of the Val-d'Or police, would see an ex-police officer appointed to be in charge of the project that was started thanks to their efforts. As if the situation would have been better if Lafrenière had been an ex-policewoman instead. Because being a feminist is not expressed by deploring the fact that Caquist men and women still do not have an equal "chance" to block the advancement of the Aboriginal women's movement for their health, autonomy and dignity. Preferring a woman at all costs as the person in charge of the aboriginal women's file, however imperfectly she is managed, is not unlike the thesis put forward by Félix Boggio Éwanjé-Épée and Stella Magliani-Belkacem in their essay Les féministes blanches et l'empire, published in France in 2012. In particular, the authors review part of the history of the French feminist movement, which argued in the first half of the twentieth century that French possessions such as Algeria would be better administered if women were allowed a greater role in implementing colonial policies. This was because French women, it was believed, would have easier access to the privacy of the "Indigènes" home, which could facilitate the realization of the civilizing mission. The entry of certain European women into the labour market and their relative "emancipation" was thus achieved by trampling on the rights of women in the South. The link with Quebec? Here, it was in the 1960s that the state began to take an interest in the territory it then named Nouveau-Québec (could it be more colonial?), while the Quebec women's movement was taking off. The Quebec government wanted to forcibly assimilate the Inuit of Nunavik, for example, into the French culture, to replace the English culture that had been brought in (also by force) by Ottawa. And of course, Quebec women have since had significant leadership opportunities in all aspects of the colonization of the Far North through the administration of health, education and social services. | This nomination is therefore a reminder of Quebec's colonial history and how Quebec women were used to impose the dominance of Francophone culture. It is also a reminder of how Aboriginal women have been marginalized and excluded from decision-making processes. Lafrenière's appointment is therefore a reminder of how Quebec has always been a colonial state and how Aboriginal women have been systematically excluded from decision-making processes. This appointment is therefore a reminder of the importance of equal opportunity and the need to give Aboriginal women a greater voice and role in decision-making processes. It is essential that Aboriginal women be represented in positions of responsibility and that their voices be heard. It is also essential that Aboriginal women be treated with respect and dignity and that their rights be respected. This appointment is a reminder of the importance of equal opportunity and the need to give Aboriginal women a greater voice and role in decision-making processes. It is essential that Aboriginal women be represented in positions of responsibility and that their voices be heard. It is also essential that Aboriginal women be treated with respect and dignity and that their rights be respected. It is also important to recognize that Aboriginal women have unique knowledge and skills that can be used to improve the situation of Aboriginal women and to improve the quality of life in Aboriginal communities. This appointment is therefore a reminder of the importance of equal opportunity and the need to give Aboriginal women a greater voice and role in decision-making processes. It is essential that Aboriginal women be represented in positions of responsibility and that their voices be heard. It is also essential that Aboriginal women be treated with respect and dignity and that their rights be respected. It is also important to recognize that Aboriginal women have unique knowledge and skills that can be used to improve the situation of Aboriginal women and to improve the quality of life in Aboriginal communities. It is also important to recognize that Aboriginal women have the right to determine their own future and destiny and that their active participation in decision-making is essential to their well-being and safety.

titre: Porno, morale et révolution
texte: Let us recall the era of feudal rule and serfdom in Europe, or the slave regimes throughout the Americas. For a long time, these regimes were imagined to be eternal and inevitable, as the only ways in which agricultural production was possible. Yet the enslaved masses resisted, and abolitionist movements organized. Abolitionists of what, exactly? Not of agriculture itself, of course. But of the forces of exploitation at the heart of the organization of agricultural production. The precision may seem trivial, but it is important. For there are sectors of activity as old and inescapable as agriculture in the history of humanity that we would like to "abolish", since we have difficulty imagining them beyond their contemporary conditions. Because, yes, this is not a column about agriculture, but about the sex industry, and more precisely pornography, in view of the scandal related to the trafficking and sexual exploitation of minors on PornHub revealed this week in the New York Times. Above all, this is a plea for a political imagination that at the moment seems deeply unrealistic and unattainable. An invitation to consider and accept that, for hominids as well as for the great apes that are the closest to us, sexuality has always had and will always have a social dimension that goes beyond the sole reproductive needs of the species. A reminder that there can be consensual sexual relationships between people of all kinds from which everyone benefits for one reason or another, outside of the couple as understood in our societies in the 21st century. That imagination plays a great role in human sexualities and that the use of images that stimulate the sexual imagination - the basic concept of pornography - is therefore not a particularly modern idea nor intrinsically linked to the invention of the Internet or videography. That anthropologically speaking, these dimensions of Homo sapiens sapiens are irrevocable. And that it is therefore as absurd to try to abolish what we call pornography today as it would be to try to completely eliminate agriculture, mining or other sectors of activity where violence, exploitation and human trafficking are still widely practiced, historically as now. When you see what's happening with PornHub, you know that we are very far from the finish line. It is about filmed rapes, impossible to erase permanently from the Web. The site is full of young girls under the age of free and informed consent, but also videos in which women "play" minors and "virgins" and, in short, the fantasy of preying on teenage girls is made culturally inescapable, with all the consequences that entails. | This revelation is a painful reminder of how the sex industry is still deeply entrenched in exploitative and violent practices. titre: Lettre aux ados du Québec
texte: Soon you will have the world in your hands. It'll happen sooner than we think. But I hope we don't wait until we get there before we admit we owe you an apology. By "we", I mean society as a whole. Today's Quebec has failed you. I think many of you are already aware of this. The least we can do is to be humble and sincere enough to tell you about it and to express how sorry we are. I am writing this on the eve of a reconfinement (second? third?) in the midst of a pandemic that has turned everything upside down - starting with your lives. You're old enough to pass on the damn virus, but young enough to not risk getting too sick from it if you contract it. Old enough to worry less about it before considering online education for you, and young enough to be deeply affected by these life changes. Old enough to be asked to be productive and keep your grades up in a time of unprecedented global crisis, young enough to have your voices and perspectives on your own future ignored. You are caught in this vise, but none of this is your fault. Still, many of you feel the consequences weighing on your shoulders. This is not the case for everyone, and that's good! But the evidence is clear: more and more teens are feeling depressed, anxious and socially isolated. The January report card is coming up and already, teachers estimate that nearly a third of high school students are now failing. I think it's important to say it again: it's not your fault. Quebec society must apologize to you because, too often, you are still being sent the message that your value as a human being and your place in society depend on your grades. I don't mean to say that academic success is unimportant: in the education system we have, it can help you gain access, later on, to trades or professions that are aligned with your passions. But grades certainly don't determine what you deserve: a healthy environment, friends and family who love you and listen to you, a chance to grow and be happy, opportunities to create, play, laugh, explore, express yourself and influence the world around you. Sometimes, we more or less consciously send you the opposite message, and this contributes to making you even more anxious. We really need to stop. Adults really haven't finished their homework and lessons. Your report cards certainly don't measure all your talents and personal skills. The school system still doesn't measure very well, for example, whether you are empathetic humans who seek to be present for one another. | This is why, Quebec teens, I invite you to remember that you are more than your grades. You are human beings who deserve to be heard and respected. You are human beings who deserve to be encouraged and supported. You are human beings who deserve to be loved and understood. titre: Le retour d’ascenseur
texte: Good news! (For once.) It was announced this week that the search for a vaccine against HIV, which causes AIDS, has made very promising progress. After Phase 1 clinical trials, the newly developed vaccine formula was reported to produce the rare immune cells needed to produce effective antibodies against HIV in 97% of participants. In more than 30 years of scientific research, this is unheard of. We are not yet ready to claim victory. First, clinical trials must continue for this vaccine candidate. Second, the nonprofits behind this new hope, IAVI and Scripps Research, are announcing a partnership with Moderna to see if the messenger RNA technology used in its COVID-19 vaccine could accelerate the development of other HIV vaccine formulations. This is a return of sorts. HIV is particularly difficult to find a vaccine for because it is a virus that mutates very rapidly. A vaccine that works against one variant of the virus is not necessarily effective against another, unless you can find a formula that offers very broad protection against HIV in its various forms. Decades of HIV research have fueled the advancement of knowledge about the development of vaccines against viruses that have multiple variants, such as COVID-19 and several other coronaviruses. With the current pandemic, large sums of money have been allocated to pharmaceutical research to accelerate production. If this speed-up brings new hope to the fight against HIV, it is only fair. About 38 million people are still living with HIV in the world today. Not all of them have AIDS, however. With antiretroviral treatment, people can keep their viral loads low enough to avoid the most serious symptoms, as well as transmission. But medication is still far from being available to everyone, no matter where they are on the planet. Today, the virus continues to be transmitted mostly where antiretroviral treatment is least accessible: in impoverished countries in sub-Saharan Africa and in more marginalized groups in many societies, including our own. It is well known that the HIV/AIDS epidemic has been accompanied by dark moments of stigmatization from its very beginnings, and has deeply fueled homophobia, anti-black racism, and discrimination against sex workers and drug users. In recent years, considerable progress has been made in the fight against HIV/AIDS. Antiretroviral treatment has become more accessible and affordable, and transmission rates have dropped significantly. However, the development of an HIV vaccine is still a challenge. Researchers face considerable obstacles, including the fact that the virus is constantly changing and it is very difficult to find a formula that offers broad-spectrum protection against HIV in its various forms. Fortunately, advances in COVID-19 vaccine research may help accelerate the development of an HIV vaccine. However, it is important to emphasize that the fight against HIV/AIDS is not limited to vaccine research. It is essential to continue to educate the public about prevention and care for people living with HIV. It is also important to address the root causes of the epidemic, including stigma and discrimination, which are still very present in many societies. The fight against HIV/AIDS cannot be won without collective awareness and action. It is therefore essential that we continue to support non-profit organizations working on prevention and care for people living with HIV.

titre: Combattre le feu par le feu
texte: Contrary to the belief that generally prevails even in the most militant environmentalist circles, climate change is not solely responsible for the increase in forest fires throughout North America. In addition to periods of extreme heat and drought, we should also point the finger at the marginalization of indigenous knowledge. Let me explain. For hundreds, if not thousands of years, indigenous peoples from California to here in Quebec have used fire as a technology to maintain and manage the land. Basically, it is a matter of voluntarily setting off burns of controlled intensity in order to promote soil renewal and the growth of edible plants, to develop pastures for animals, or to facilitate the movement of certain herds, and of course humans. The traditional techniques also allow to dispose of the most easily flammable organic matter, and thus to decrease the risk of monstrous and uncontrollable forest fires like the ones that have been devastating the west coast and northern Ontario for several days now. Of course, the know-how varies from one territory and culture to another, depending on the specificities of the climate and the needs associated with the way of life. Everywhere, however, the same reality has been faced: with the takeover of the territory by the Canadian and American governments and the confinement of indigenous populations to reserves, the landscape of the continent has been profoundly altered. Throughout North America, colonial administrations passed laws criminalizing traditional indigenous burning in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. And the familiar strategy of suppressing even the smallest flame was harshly imposed, despite a relatively superficial knowledge of local ecosystems. The consequences are now all too apparent. In California, the failure of Eurocentric methods in the face of repeated disasters has been acknowledged. This can be seen as a way to reduce the risk of a "natural" or "cultural" disaster, but it can also be seen as a way to reduce the risk of a "natural" or "cultural" disaster, and to reduce the risk of a "natural" or "cultural" disaster. It is important to understand that traditional techniques differ greatly from the often higher intensity, preventative fires that firefighters sometimes recommend. This is as much about preventing dangerous fires as it is about better management of the land for wildlife and preserving certain species. As a result, the prevention of destructive fires and the revitalization of indigenous cultures go hand in hand. In Australia, indigenous people in the north of the country have also resumed their ancestral fire management practices over the past decade. According to the New York Times, forest fires have been cut in half in these areas since these programs were put in place. In Quebec, similar initiatives are underway. Aboriginal groups, environmental organizations and fire management services are joining forces to implement controlled burn programs. These programs aim to restore traditional practices and reduce the risk of forest fires. Controlled burns are conducted at specific times and locations, and at intensities appropriate to weather and vegetation conditions. They are carried out by experts who know the area well and are trained in traditional techniques. Controlled burns are both an ecological and cultural solution. It reduces the risk of forest fires, but also preserves indigenous knowledge and promotes its transmission to future generations. They are also an opportunity to re-establish the link between indigenous peoples and their territories, and to allow them to regain their place in forest management. Controlled burns are a promising solution, but they are not without risk. Fires can spread and get out of control, and they can also cause damage to wildlife. It is therefore important to ensure that controlled burns are conducted by qualified experts and that conditions are appropriate to the risks. Controlled burns are both an ecological and cultural solution. It can help reduce the risk of forest fires and preserve indigenous knowledge. But it is important to ensure that controlled burns are conducted by qualified experts and that conditions are appropriate to the risks.

titre: La banalisation tranquille
texte: We are at the main entrance, in front of the building, which had to be rebuilt twice. The children, in their revolt, succeeded twice in destroying it by fire. It was through this main entrance, therefore, that the children first arrived at the boarding school. This is also where the official photos were taken. For the rest of their stay, it would be off limits. On the first day, the girls and boys were separated, their hair was cut, all their clothes and personal items were taken away, and each child was assigned a number. From now on, they will only be addressed by their number. They will sleep, eat, work and sit in the order of their number. We also make sure to give the members of the same sibling group numbers that are far apart from each other. Just to the left is the visiting room. On the rare occasions when parents could visit, this is where they were put. The children were forbidden to speak any language other than English, which the parents were often not fluent in. The child had two options. Speak their language and be beaten and punished later. Or stick to English and not be understood by the parents. Often, the child would choose complete silence. A little further on, you have the infirmary. Because of the lack of beds, sick children stayed with the group (contaminating the others), unless they were really, really unable to stand. Parents were only notified of their child's illness when death was imminent. Often they could not get there in time. Pharmaceutical companies repeatedly experimented in this infirmary. Some children were given a treatment that was still under study, while others were denied it. The results were recorded. A little further on, we find ourselves in the main staircase, made of varnished wood. The children never had access to it, except for a few girls who were responsible for cleaning it. The girls spend their days doing domestic chores: cooking, washing, cleaning. They are almost never allowed to go outside. Some survivors recall that being assigned to clean the main staircase was a privilege: it gave them a chance to look out the window. Downstairs is the cafeteria. Basic oatmeal was served in the morning. Survivors say that if it was burnt, or if you found worms in it, you still had to eat it all the way through. If you didn't finish your bowl, it was brought back to the child at the next meal, and at the next until it was finished. The boys worked outside milking the cows, collecting eggs from the chicken coop, picking apples from the orchard. All of this was sold in the village, but they were forbidden to have access to it. A little further on, there is the furnace room. Just after that is the laundry room. It is in these two rooms that most of the physical and sexual abuse took place, according to the survivors. Today, the school is closed and the children are no longer there. But their memories are still there. The survivors remember the abuse, punishment, mistreatment and deprivation they endured. They remember the walls that enclosed them, the doors that prevented them from escaping, and the windows that prevented them from seeing the outside world. They remember the screams, the cries and the tears that echoed through the hallways. They remember the words that were forbidden to them and the languages they could not speak. They remember the drugs they were given without their consent and the experiments they were subjected to. They remember the inadequate meals and the hard work. They remember the separations and the abuse that was inflicted on them. But they also remember the moments of joy and happiness. They remember the laughter and games that echoed through the corridors. They remember the friendships that were formed and the bonds that were created. They remember the moments of comfort and support they shared. They remember the stories they told each other and the songs they sang. They remember the moments of freedom and peace they experienced. Today, the school is closed and the children are no longer there. But their memories are still there. The survivors remember the abuse and mistreatment they endured, but also the moments of joy and happiness they shared. They remember the walls that enclosed them, but also the bonds that were formed. They remember the words that were forbidden to them, but also the songs that they sang. They remember the deprivations and abuses they endured, but also the moments of freedom and peace they experienced. These memories are still vivid and remind us that the quiet trivialization of abuse and mistreatment must not be tolerated.

titre: L’éblouissement
texte: As a columnist, I choose a theme once a week according to my fields of interest, my skills, and the context. I ask myself what is important to say, what has not been said, and what risks not being said. To do this, I have to consult a large amount of information on a daily basis. There are times when it makes you dizzy. This week, I am dizzy. The images of Pacifique Niyokwizera, his face swollen, his eye reddened, are with me. I think of the teenagers who were manhandled by the Quebec City police while waiting for a friend outside the Dagobert in Quebec City. I think of the shock and worry of the families, similar to the shock and worry of we will never know how many families, after police interventions that were not captured on video. If Quebec is struck by the images of the Pacific, there is an opportunity to better understand how, as a society, we allow such incidents to happen again. So should I join the collective clamour? Or would it be more useful to focus attention on a tragedy that has hardly been spoken of? Another feminicide in Montreal. I was walking with a friend when I passed the security perimeter on November 5. A few days later, we learned that Daniel Schlafman, son of the owner of the Fairmount Bagel factory, had killed a 25-year-old woman. According to the Stella organization, Mr. Schlafman was known to Montreal sex workers as a dangerous and unpredictable client. The young victim, a resident of Quebec City and a visitor to the city, was not aware of this. Despite all the public debate on the phenomenon of feminicide since the beginning of the pandemic, this tragedy has gone almost completely under the radar. I can't help but think that if the victim had not been a sex worker, there would have been more public attention. Aren't all women equal? But I wonder if by focusing on these individual tragedies, which certainly affect entire communities as well as systemic issues, I am overlooking a higher intensity conflict. In British Columbia, the RCMP continues to arrest Wet'suwet'en Nation aboriginal activists and their allies. These "land defenders", who are rallying behind the Nation's so-called "hereditary" traditional leaders, are opposing the construction of the Coastal GasLink pipeline in their traditional territory. The government believes that the consent of the nation's band council, a political structure derived from the highly colonial Indian Act, is sufficient to conclude that the Wet'suwet'en have agreed to the project. A court injunction was obtained to stop the protests. Some of the images of RCMP operations to quell Aboriginal resistance are shockingly violent, particularly against unarmed Elders in the midst of a ceremony. These images of the RCMP quelling Aboriginal resistance are a tragedy that reminds us that colonialism is still alive and well in Canada. Aboriginal peoples continue to face discrimination and marginalization. The rights of Aboriginal peoples are often violated and their voices are too often ignored. The construction of the Coastal GasLink pipeline is an example of this injustice. The Wet'suwet'en have the right to decide their future and their land. titre: Cohérence recherchée
texte: What is affirmative action? It's about favouring, in certain settings, a group or groups of people who experience discrimination or systemic disadvantage in order to restore equal opportunity. Sometimes this can be done in the form of encouragement, incentives to offer positions to certain people from groups that might otherwise be underrepresented. Sometimes it goes further and requires a minimum threshold of representation. The Supreme Court of Canada Act, for example, requires that three of the nine sitting judges be from Quebec. This law was written by people who did not believe that all federal governments, regardless of their ideological inclination and the origin of their members of Parliament, would ensure the representation of Quebec civil law experts on the Supreme Court, simply out of goodwill and recognition of their skills. For fear of systemic bias against Quebec candidates, in particular, positions have been reserved for them. The Broadcasting Act, which gives its mandate to the CRTC and the CBC, among others, also makes extensive use of affirmative action. Across Canada, there has been a fear - essentially since the invention of mass media - that American content is flooding the airwaves and preventing our radio and television industry from growing. In the face of Goliath, we have armed David with quotas. Our mainstream media are required to produce or broadcast 40% to 60% Canadian content to keep their CRTC licence. To protect francophone culture, we go even further. The law requires French-language radio stations to devote at least 65% of their weekly popular music programming to music in French. These quotas necessarily boost the visibility of francophone artists, and have played an important role in the development of Quebec's cultural industry. Despite these measures, the "competence" of the musicians whose works are constantly played on the radio is not questioned. It is understandable that, in response to the unfair advantages (especially financial) that propel the careers of Anglo-American artists, positive discrimination has a role to play. Bill 101, too, is largely driven by affirmative action. In a context of significant systemic discrimination against Francophones in a range of employment sectors, the Quebec government adopted strong measures. Since then, a large part of the jobs offered in Quebec are reserved for candidates who master French. It is undeniable that the law has played a major role in improving the economic prospects of Franco-Quebecers in recent decades. At the federal level, the Official Languages Act also allows for the requirement of bilingualism in many public service positions. | Are these affirmative action measures still necessary? The question is complex and divides opinions. Some argue that these measures are still necessary to restore fairness and equality of opportunity, and that their effects are beneficial to the groups who benefit from them. Others argue that these measures are discriminatory and not necessary to restore fairness and equality of opportunity. It is important to note that affirmative action is not a quick fix. It cannot by itself restore equity and equality of opportunity. It can help restore fairness and equality of opportunity, but it cannot by itself solve the systemic problems that underlie discrimination and systemic disadvantage. It is also important to note that affirmative action should not be used as an excuse for not taking more radical steps to restore equity and equality of opportunity. Affirmative action can be a useful tool for restoring fairness and equal opportunity, but it alone cannot solve the systemic problems that underlie discrimination and systemic disadvantage. Finally, it is important to note that affirmative action should not be used to exclude or marginalize groups. Affirmative action should be used to promote the inclusion and participation of groups that are underrepresented or face systemic discrimination and disadvantage. Affirmative action should be used to create opportunities for these groups, not to exclude or marginalize them.

titre: L’autre option
texte: An outreach worker is a resource person, most often employed by a community organization, who is responsible for building relationships of trust with vulnerable clients. For example, this means being present and available for young people who are struggling with difficult socio-economic realities. The person who does community work spends a lot of time on the street, in parks and other popular gathering points for young people. They listen to them, advise them and refer them to specialized resources to help them find a job, fight drug addiction or deal with a family problem. On a day-to-day basis, community workers also play a key role in preventing conflict, and therefore violence. When they know the youth and the youth trust them, they can act as mediators, in a more or less formal way. Their presence can prevent an incident from getting out of hand, but it can also discourage the search for a retaliatory response after an initial tragedy, so that conflicts do not escalate. In many ways, community service is the opposite of policing. First, a community worker is normally directly from the community in which he or she is involved, and is committed to working there at all hours of the day. At the other end of the spectrum, we learned last summer that 84% of the 4,500 or so uniformed employees of the Montreal Police Service live off the island of Montreal. This situation may necessarily contribute to the perception that Montreal's so-called "hot" neighbourhoods are simply workplaces, rather than living environments, in all their complexity. Second, many community workers also have personal experience of the realities faced by their clients. The resource person may have had a very winding educational path before finally finding his or her vocation, may have struggled with addiction before choosing sobriety, or may have already fallen into delinquency before turning his or her life around. Either way, it's a good thing: this experience helps build her credibility with young people, who can see her as a role model. The message is: "since I was able to get out of it, I know you can too". Conversely, any "track record" serves to disqualify an aspiring police officer from the profession. Finally, community workers are inexpensive resources, most often paid at the low rates that prevail in the community. And despite the very low salaries, organizations struggle to find the funds to hire them. In Montreal North, for example, the two workers at the Multicultural Youth Café have long been the only ones walking the streets of the entire neighbourhood. You read that right: two, for the whole neighbourhood. If the borough will soon have six of them, it's thanks to funding from private foundations like Chagnon and Saputo. | These community workers are therefore valuable resource people who can make a difference in the lives of young people and communities. Unfortunately, their presence is often insufficient and their work is underestimated. Community workers often face challenges in obtaining funding and resources for their work. The community organizations that employ them are often strapped for funds and cannot offer them decent wages. In addition, midway work is often considered part-time work, not full-time work. This means that community workers are not always able to provide a consistent and regular presence in communities. These difficulties are of particular concern because milieu work is essential to preventing violence and conflict. Community workers are mediators who can help resolve conflicts before they escalate. They can also help youth find solutions to their problems and resources to help them cope. It is therefore essential that community workers be supported and recognized for their work. Community organizations must be supported for their work and their efforts to hire community workers. Governments must also ensure that community workers are well compensated and have access to adequate resources to do their work. Only then will community workers be able to make a difference in communities and prevent violence and conflict.

titre: Luamba contre Goliath
texte: In Canada, police forces have the power to stop and question any person driving a car and ask for their papers. They do not have to suspect that an offence has been committed or state any reason before proceeding. So, depending on what the eminently mysterious "police intuition" dictates, one becomes a legally obligated target to pull over to the side of the road, and justify being there. For decades, racialized people - black men in particular - and Aboriginal people have been speaking out about how this discretionary power is used by police officers to make their lives impossible. Several studies have also already shown that they are disproportionately targeted by these types of arbitrary stops. So much so that just about every black man I know has been targeted by an arbitrary police stop (or dozens of them) - especially if they own a car. Are the sections of the Criminal Code and the Highway Safety Code that give police this power racially biased? No. There is no law in Canada that explicitly encourages the harassment of Black men behind the wheel. That said, as long as there is a negative bias against certain groups - whether conscious or unconscious - any law written in a way that gives immense discretion to the person charged with enforcing it can become a vehicle for systemic discrimination. As long as a person can be stopped "on a whim", and that "whim" has been developed in a society that values some human lives more than others, injustices will in fact be perpetrated. Until police forces have to explain themselves before stopping a driver once, twice, ten times, fifty times, any institutional denunciation of racial profiling will remain wishful thinking. Or at least that's what Superior Court Justice Michel Yergeau seems to be saying in a landmark 170-page decision released Tuesday. I quote: "The discretionary power to momentarily deprive a citizen of his liberty in this context is the most arbitrary and unfiltered power available." Further, he adds that this power has "become for some a vehicle, even a safe harbor, for racial profiling against the black community." In his decision, Justice Yergeau declared unconstitutional the sections that conferred these powers on police forces and gave the institutions concerned six months to adapt. His words are of rare force in the justice system. "We cannot as a society wait for a segment of the population to continue to suffer in silence in the hope that a rule of law will finally be enforced by police forces in a manner that respects the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Canadian Charter," he wrote. This decision is an important step towards justice and freedom for racialized and Aboriginal people. It is a recognition of the systemic discrimination they face and the way in which discretion is used to harass them. However, this decision will not solve all the problems. The prejudices and stereotypes that underlie racial profiling are deeply rooted in society and will take time and effort to eradicate. It is important to note that this decision does not just apply to racialized and Aboriginal people. It applies to all Canadians who face arbitrary police action. It is a victory for all those who are victims of discrimination and harassment. This decision is an important step towards justice and freedom for all Canadians.
