titre: Le déclin de Davos
texte: Every year starts with the same news - only the exact time varies. On January 3, at 9:43 a.m., Canada's highest paid CEOs had already earned the equivalent of the average annual salary in the country, or $58,800. Here, the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives did the math and released a report that is, of course, widely reported in this slow news period. But the issue of ever-increasing wealth inequality also makes headlines elsewhere in the world almost every January. Every January, the issue is also back on the agenda because political and business leaders from around the world gather in Davos, in the heart of the Swiss Alps, for the World Economic Forum (WEF). This week, as it has every year for the past decade, Oxfam International is using the Forum to release a report that focuses on wealth inequality. In this latest edition, we learn, among other things, that the 1% of the super-rich have acquired twice as much capital in the last two years as the other 99% of humanity. But the WEF itself - its setting, its guests, the beauty and inaccessibility of its site - is already raising questions about the most privileged in this world for decades. And exasperation with the very existence of the Forum has perhaps not been so strong since the pandemic, when it has become the subject of particularly imaginative conspiracy theories among the populist right, first in the United States and then internationally. "The Great Reset" - the theme of the 2020 Forum - has been seized upon by conspiracy theorists to evoke the spectre of a world where the powerful and ultra-rich have used the pretext of the pandemic to inoculate people with vaccines that have the power to deprive them of their free will, in order to establish a new totalitarian political order. You see, it goes far. The professionals of disinformation themselves, and the laxity of social media towards the phenomenon, are rightly blamed for their role in the popularity of these far-fetched hypotheses. It should also be admitted that the context in which the WEF is held does not help. Many of us feel that the billionaires of this world live in a galaxy other than ours, or at least do not share the same human condition as the common man. As wealth inequality increases, the impact of these big capitalists' decisions on our lives only grows, and is accompanied by a growing sense of powerlessness. Frustration, coupled with a sense of unprecedented distance from these people, can become fertile ground for the imagination. With the current inflation and the uncertain economic context, here as elsewhere in the world, the idea of elites comfortably gathered in the middle of the Alps is all the more shocking. | The World Economic Forum has become a symbol of the inequality and social injustice that plague the world. Critics are numerous and voices are raised to denounce the fact that the richest and most powerful meet to discuss world problems without taking into account the opinions of the poorest. titre: Le hockey vu par la recherche
texte: Since the beginning of the week, many of us have been in shock. The Ontario Superior Court ruling on the class action suit filed by three former junior field hockey players, reported Monday by Martin Leclerc of Radio-Canada, is particularly hard to read. For the uninformed reader, the level of sexual, physical and psychological abuse that is described is deeply disturbing. But for sports experts, it is probably this very shock to the public that is most galling. Already, last July, 28 Canadian academics published an open letter entitled "Sexual abuse and misogyny are deeply rooted in men's field hockey. While the Ontario ruling depicts a systemic problem in field hockey, where the most degrading scenes take place in full view of coaches and managers, the July letter already spoke of a culture that "normalizes violence, aggression, alcohol, bullying, sexist and homophobic 'jokes' and the degradation of women and LGBTQ2+ people." Why, then, the general surprise, even from sports journalists? The answer also lies in the work of researchers. In particular, the collective letter directs us to read a 2013 paper published by sociologist Kristi A. Allain. Her title: "What happens in the locker room stays in the locker room." Her research focuses on the culture of secrecy in field hockey, and the mechanisms in place in the game to close the doors to outside eyes - especially if they are female. In short, field hockey players are socialized not to tell anyone, ever, and the social penalty for breaking this code is very high. There are two things to understand about this. First, the typical masculinity of the field hockey player - the quiet, even laconic, emotionally repressed guy we're used to seeing in post-game interviews - hides something darker. If this type of public personality is actively encouraged by the sport, it is also likely to be because it protects the environment from the outside world. Second, the three former players who have brought the issue of violence in sports to light are, in context, all the more courageous. Five years after the #MeToo movement, the taboo surrounding sexual violence in the locker room may seem surprising. But the more one reads the various papers, dissertations and theses of the research collective, the more one understands. The cultural barrier to be overcome in order to denounce is more like Mount Everest than a barrier. Will this week's political shockwave be enough to change things? Once again, another publication sheds light on this issue. | The researchers who signed the July open letter also highlighted the fact that women and LGBTQ2+ people are often excluded from conversations and debates about field hockey. This exclusion is particularly visible in the media, where women are underrepresented and sexist and homophobic comments are commonplace. This lack of representation and visibility contributes to a culture of silence and the normalization of violent and discriminatory behaviour. This week's Ontario Superior Court ruling highlighted the systemic problem of violence and discrimination in field hockey. But for things to change, women and LGBTQ2+ people need to be included in the conversations and debates about field hockey. Their voices need to be heard and their perspectives taken into account. We need the media to stop tolerating sexist and homophobic comments and give more visibility to women and LGBTQ2+ people. We need field hockey leaders to take action to address violence and discrimination and promote inclusion and equality. This week's Ontario Superior Court ruling highlighted the systemic problem of violence and discrimination in field hockey. But for change to occur, women and LGBTQ2+ people need to be included in the conversations and debates about field hockey. Their voices need to be heard and their perspectives taken into account. titre: Les violences obstétricales, ces «cas isolés» si nombreux
texte: Obstetrical violence is a phenomenon that is growing all over the world. Unfortunately, Quebec is not spared. This violence is often described as an "isolated case", but the number of cases is much greater than we think. Obstetrical violence is any act or word that violates the dignity and physical and psychological integrity of pregnant women or new mothers. It can take the form of harassment, discrimination, abuse, contempt or disrespect. This violence can be physical, psychological or sexual. Unfortunately, obstetric violence is still too often considered an "isolated case". However, studies show that such violence is more common than we think. A study conducted by the University of Montreal found that nearly half of the women surveyed had experienced obstetric violence. The consequences of obstetrical violence can be severe and long-lasting. Women who are victims may suffer from depression, post-traumatic stress, anxiety disorders and eating disorders. They may also have difficulty caring for and developing a healthy relationship with their baby. Fortunately, steps are being taken to address obstetric violence. Health care professionals are being educated about the problem and training is being provided to help them recognize and respond to obstetric violence. In addition, organizations such as the Centre d'aide et de lutte contre les agressions à caractère sexuel (CALACS) offer support services to women who have experienced obstetrical violence. Obstetrical violence is a serious problem that needs to be taken seriously. It is important to recognize that obstetrical violence is not an "isolated case" but a much more widespread phenomenon than we think. It is essential that measures be put in place to combat this scourge and to protect pregnant women and new mothers.

titre: Changements climatiques: bientôt trop tard
texte: Climate change is a reality that affects the entire world. Scientists agree that global warming is mainly due to human activities, notably the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation. The consequences of these changes are already visible in Quebec, and they are disturbing. Average annual temperatures are rising, and summers are getting hotter. Precipitation is more frequent and intense, leading to flooding and landslides. Winters are milder and shorter, affecting traditional winter activities such as skiing and skating. Climate change is also affecting wildlife. Species that are not adapted to these changes are at risk, and some may even disappear. Forests are also threatened by increasingly frequent and intense fires. Climate change has important economic consequences. Farmers face droughts and floods that affect their crops. Businesses that rely on winter activities are also affected by milder winters. Flooding and landslides can cause significant losses to homeowners and businesses. Fortunately, it is still possible to limit the effects of climate change. Governments must take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and encourage renewable energy. Citizens can also contribute by reducing their energy consumption and adopting more sustainable lifestyles. Unfortunately, we may already be at a point of no return. Scientists believe that if we do not take immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, climate change could have catastrophic consequences for Quebec and the world. It is therefore essential that we act quickly to limit the effects of climate change. If we don't act now, it may soon be too late.

titre: Le contrôle des hommes, et celui de l’État
texte: For centuries, humans have sought to control their environment and impose their will. In the modern world, this tendency has been amplified and has manifested itself in different forms. On the one hand, men seek to control their fellow men, through systems of domination and social control. On the other hand, the state seeks to control men, through laws and regulations. The control of men by men is an ancient and widespread practice. Systems of domination and social control are based on unequal power relations between individuals. These systems can take a variety of forms, ranging from caste systems to class systems to gender systems to race systems. These systems are often supported by discriminatory practices and stereotypes. State control of men is a more recent practice. States seek to control men through laws and regulations. These laws and regulations can be used to regulate the behavior of individuals, to protect the rights of citizens, and to promote the public interest. Laws and regulations can also be used to suppress undesirable behavior and to maintain social order. The control of men by men and by the state is a complex and controversial practice. On the one hand, these systems can be used to protect the rights of individuals and to promote the public interest. On the other hand, they can be used to suppress undesirable behavior and to maintain social order. In either case, it is important to recognize that human control is a practice that can have important consequences for the lives of individuals and for society as a whole.

titre: #FreeBritney, une question de droits de la personne
texte: For several years now, the #FreeBritney movement has taken hold on social networks. It is a movement to support the American singer Britney Spears, who has been under guardianship since 2008. This movement aims to denounce the lack of respect for human rights to which she is subjected. The guardianship of Britney Spears is a form of legal protection imposed on her by a judge. It prohibits her from making important decisions about her personal and professional life. She is under the responsibility of a guardian who decides for her on her finances, her contracts and her movements. This situation has caused a strong reaction from Internet users, who denounce the lack of respect for human rights that Britney Spears is subject to. They believe that the guardianship is a form of control and surveillance that takes away all freedom and autonomy. They also denounce the fact that the guardianship is imposed by a judge, without Britney Spears having been heard. The #FreeBritney movement has also highlighted the problem of guardianship of vulnerable adults. Guardianship is often imposed on the elderly, the disabled, or the mentally ill. These people are often deprived of their freedom and autonomy without being heard. The #FreeBritney movement has therefore brought the human rights issue of vulnerable adults to light. It has also raised awareness of the issue and exposed the lack of human rights respect for Britney Spears. The #FreeBritney movement has also sparked debate on the issue of guardianship of vulnerable adults. Some believe that guardianship is necessary to protect vulnerable people, while others believe that this form of protection is too restrictive and does not respect their rights. The #FreeBritney movement has therefore highlighted the human rights issue of vulnerable adults and the lack of respect for them. It has also sparked debate on the issue of guardianship of vulnerable adults and raised awareness of the issue.

titre: Le recul du droit à l’avortement n’est qu’un début
texte: The right to abortion has been a hotly debated topic for decades. Despite the progress made, the decline of this right is a reality in many countries. In Quebec, the debate is still very lively and opinions are very divided. The right to abortion is a fundamental right that allows women to control their bodies and their lives. It is recognized by law and protected by the Charter of Human Rights and Freedoms. Despite this, the rollback of this right is a reality in many countries. In Quebec, the debate on the right to abortion is very lively and opinions are very divided. Proponents of the right to abortion argue that it is a fundamental right that allows women to have control over their bodies and their lives. They also argue that the right to abortion is a fundamental right that must be protected and respected. Opponents of abortion rights argue that it is an immoral act and should be prohibited. They also argue that the right to abortion is a violation of the rights of the unborn child and should be limited or even banned. Despite the widely divided opinions, the rollback of abortion rights is a reality that is taking hold in several countries. In the United States, abortion rights are threatened by restrictive laws that limit access to abortion and make abortion rights more difficult to exercise. In Europe, many countries have adopted restrictive laws that limit access to abortion and make it more difficult to exercise the right to abortion. In Quebec, the debate on abortion rights is very heated and opinions are very divided. In spite of this, the decline of abortion rights is a reality in many countries. It is therefore important to remember that the right to abortion is a fundamental right that must be protected and respected. The decline in the right to abortion is a reality that is taking hold in several countries and is very worrisome. It is therefore important to remember that the right to abortion is a fundamental right that must be protected and respected. It is also important to remember that the decline in the right to abortion is only the beginning and that we must mobilize to defend it.

titre: Les mythes et réalités de la loi 21
texte: Since its passage on June 16, 2019, Quebec's Bill 21 has sparked heated and passionate debate. The law prohibits the wearing of religious symbols by people in positions of authority in the public sector, including teachers, police officers and judges. Although the law was presented as a measure to promote the secular nature of the state, it was criticized for its lack of clarity and discriminatory scope. Law 21 was presented as a measure to promote the secular nature of the state. According to the government, the purpose of the law is to ensure that public institutions are neutral and free of religious influence. However, some have criticized the law for being unclear and discriminatory. The law does not clearly define what a religious symbol is and does not specify which religions are covered. In addition, the law applies only to persons in positions of authority, which means that it does not apply to public sector employees. Some argue that Bill 21 is a necessary measure to protect the secular nature of the state and to ensure equality among citizens. They argue that the law is a fair and necessary measure to ensure that public institutions are neutral and free from religious influence. Others argue that the law is discriminatory and infringes on the rights of citizens. They argue that the law is an unfair measure that seeks to exclude people who wear religious symbols. Bill 21 has been the subject of heated and passionate debate. While some argue that the law is a necessary measure to protect the secularity of the state, others argue that the law is discriminatory and infringes on the rights of citizens. The truth is that Bill 21 is complex and it is difficult to decide between myths and realities. The only thing that is certain is that Bill 21 will continue to generate passionate and heated debate.

titre: Agresseur, victime, et autres mythes tenaces
texte: For decades, the myths surrounding abusers and victims have been persistent. These stereotypes are often based on prejudices and assumptions that are deeply rooted in society. Unfortunately, these myths can have negative consequences for those who are directly affected by violence. One of the most common myths is that abusers are men and victims are women. While this may be true in some cases, it is important to note that women can also be abusers and men can also be victims. Statistics show that women are more likely to be victims of domestic violence, but it is important to note that men can also be victims of domestic violence. Another myth is that abusers are violent and unpredictable people. While some abusers can be violent and unpredictable, it is important to note that most abusers are people who can be charming and caring in public, but can become violent and unpredictable in private. Another myth is that victims are weak and helpless. While some victims may feel weak and helpless, it is important to note that most victims are people who have strengths and abilities that allow them to defend and protect themselves. Another myth is that abusers and victims are people who come from disadvantaged backgrounds. While some abusers and victims may come from disadvantaged backgrounds, it is important to note that abuse can occur in all socioeconomic settings. Another myth is that abusers and victims are people who have a history of violence. While some abusers and victims may have a history of violence, it is important to note that violence can occur without any history of violence. Finally, another myth is that abusers and victims are people with mental health problems. Although some abusers and victims may have mental health problems, it is important to note that violence can occur without any mental health problems. It is important to note that these myths are persistent and can have negative consequences for those who are directly affected by abuse. Myths can hinder the ability of victims to recognize and report abuse, and can also hinder the ability of abusers to recognize and stop their abusive behaviours. It is therefore important to recognize that these myths are persistent and to deconstruct them. It is also important to recognize that violence can occur in all socio-economic settings and that it can occur without any history of violence or mental health problems. Finally, it is important to recognize that both perpetrators and victims can be male or female and that victims may have strengths and abilities that allow them to defend and protect themselves.

titre: CH : Logan Mailloux assure tout faire pour devenir une meilleure personne
texte: Nearly a year after the concussion caused by the selection of Logan Mailloux in the NHL draft, the Ontario defenseman is living his first experience with the Montreal Canadiens and he assures to invest all the necessary efforts to become a better person. Remember that the Canadiens, under Marc Bergevin, had drafted Mailloux even though he had indicated that he did not want to be selected in 2021. Mailloux felt he did not deserve the privilege because he had been fined in Sweden for sharing inappropriate photos of a woman with whom he had engaged in a sexual act. From that misstep, the Canadian at least made sure that Mailloux participated in several educational programs to understand the significance of his action and the importance of consent. "Since the incident, I've had all this education. I feel like I started from scratch and understood a lot. I had to mature quickly and I think I've done a good job of that," Mailloux humbly described in a scrum with Rob Ramage, the Canadiens' director of player development, who has become his mentor. "It's hard every day, I think about it every day and I know the victim has to deal with it too," he added. Mailloux realizes he can't erase his huge mistake and wishes he had done something different. "I would change everything I did... I've changed greatly as a person, I wasn't educated back then and I feel like I am now." "With what happened, it wasn't easy. I was around him all season last year, he was pretty down. He worked very hard, he met a lot of people to get through it. Today, I think he's a better person," said Francis Bouillon, who is involved in player development. In a way, the great media attention directed towards this incident can lead to a necessary evolution. This context allows many young people to be educated about consent and respect. Since, as Mailloux points out, education programs need to be widespread in the field hockey community

titre: LCF : Les Alouettes s'écrasent au quatrième quart devant les Blue Bombers, qui sont invaincus
texte: Although observers were not giving the Alouettes much of a chance against the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, the victory was within reach for the Montreal club, which was again sunk by its lack of opportunism. The defending champions managed to keep their perfect record (9-0) to win 35-20 but everything fell apart in the last quarter when the Alouettes were outscored 21-6. The Alouettes had evened the score at 14-14 in the third quarter and the daunting challenge of upsetting the undefeated team was motivating the fans. But you know a winning team when it matters and the Bombers showed it. In the relentless reality of professional sports, coming close to winning is worthless in the standings and the Alouettes find themselves with a 2-6 record. The Montreal team has the same 1-3 record under Danny Maciocia as it does under the fired Khari Jones. "This one hurts, especially the way we reacted. The problem we have is that we can't handle adversity. We're getting into trouble," lamented Maciocia, the general manager and interim coach who was particularly angry about a penalty on Tyrice Beverette for hitting an opponent with a helmet. "We had an opportunity to add a field goal, but that's unacceptable and I talked to (the players) about it," he said. After regaining control 21-14, Winnipeg saw off the Birds' legs by adding a major on a punt return. "It's going to be important to keep it up. After their touchdowns on special teams, it became amorphous and we definitely don't want that," admitted Marc-Antoine Dequoy. At the end of the game, Trevor Harris had to be daring and he was intercepted twice. Dominique Davis came in to complete the game at quarterback and completed a lucky touchdown pass. Maciocia acknowledged that he will be evaluating all options in the next few days including the quarterback position. "We have to go back to work and look at everything. Make decisions that will give us a chance to fix the problems and get some wins," noted the soccer boss. But we have to get back to the Alouettes' troubles to take advantage of their opportunities. The defensive unit finally excelled in Noel Thorpe's new defensive system. It created four very important turnovers. The major problem was that Montreal's offense only scored three microscopic points off of those turnovers. One of the reasons for the tiny score was a missed touchdown on a three-yard attempt to Eugene Lewis

titre: Après le choc, David Perron doit se réjouir
texte: When he signed his new contract at the opening of the free agent market, David Perron did not rush to give interviews to RDS and TSN as he regularly does on specials. The truth is that Perron needed time to absorb the blow. The blow being leaving the St. Louis Blues where he figured his third stint would continue by virtue of his convincing performances. Shocked that he did not receive a serious offer from the Blues before the autonomy was triggered, Perron fell back on the Detroit Red Wings' option with a two-year contract for 9.5 million. The Quebecer took a few days to give his thoughts to Jeremy Rutherford, the reporter assigned to cover the Blues for The Athletic. He needed some time because he was shaken and convinced that he could find a common ground with the Missouri club's management. Perron even revealed that his children cried when he told them that a move was necessary and that the family would be leaving St. Louis. On Tuesday at the Gagne-Bergeron Pro-Am, Perron agreed to reflect on the unexpected change. "It was disappointing because I spent many years of my career with the Blues, 11 out of 15 seasons. My kids grew up there, we were used to it and we loved it. On that point, it's really difficult," said the 34-year-old right-hander who felt a serious offer was worthwhile. "The seasons and my performance made me deserve, I think, to have a contract that made sense to stay with the team. It's been a few weeks so I think it's time to turn the page and be excited to go to Detroit," he said. Perron doesn't want to whine, he knows he's in a privileged position in society. He has come a long way to realize this better than many other players. Moreover, he joins the organization led by Steve Yzerman who stands out as he did on the ice. He arrived at a time when the Red Wings aspired to heat up the teams fighting for the playoffs. A field hockey maniac, Perron chose not to binge on videos or information about his new and young teammates. "Honestly, I don't know that much about the team. I want to come in with a clear head and give everyone a chance to get a first impression. I know we have some good kids, I always hear about them from my buddies or in interviews," explained Perron on an interesting note. If he was still one of the Blues' top scorers last season

titre: Canadiens : Pierrick Dubé expose de nouvelles armes au tournoi des recrues
texte: At the junior level, Pierrick Dubé was known to excel in crucial moments. To his great delight, the trend seems to continue in his professional tryout with the Canadiens. The 21 year old Quebecer showed a very encouraging performance for the future. Knowing full well that his leeway is minimal, Dubé made his mark for the right reasons. While it wasn't too surprising to see him get a few scoring chances, Dubé showed that he can add to his skill set by blocking shots and playing shorthanded. I think I played more shorthanded in this game than I have in my entire junior career," he said with a smile. I just want to be a complete player. I got a taste of a new aspect and I enjoyed it using my speed." "I know he's a power play player, but Lappy (assistant Martin Laperriere) ran him a little bit in Quebec City and we know his speed. He's smart and he uses his stick well," commented head coach Jean-François Houle who was not afraid to rely on him. In the course of questions after the game, it became clearer how Dubé was able to add new elements to his arsenal. "In junior, I was known more as an offensive player. But I practiced with guys like (Patrice) Bergeron and (Philip) Danault this summer. I went three times a week on the ice with them," said Dubé, who scored several important goals in the Shawinigan Cataractes' recent playoff run. "They gave me advice. There are thousands of offensive players in the NHL, if you can call them that, so if I want to get to the next level I have to work on defensive elements. I worked on that this summer with Bergeron, he helped me a lot", he continued. There is no doubt that Dubé has taken the means to be well surrounded as he wants to break through to the professional level. "It was the third summer that I trained with them. Being around guys who have long NHL careers and are dominant players is always fun. No matter what they tell me, it gets in one ear and stays in my head. It's advice that's worth its weight in gold. I can just build on that," admitted Dubé, who also trained with the Cataractes before this tournament. Of course, he would have loved to hit the target, especially when he snuck in a breakaway with two minutes left in the final third. "Those are chances you have to capitalize on in the pro, that's the second you have less compared to junior. It's not pleasant to miss your chance and that the opponent scores ten seconds later", reacted Dubé. His first professional test in a Canadiens jersey was a success. "I think I had a good first performance, I skated well, I was intense and I created chances to score", concluded Dubé, who had a good rapport with Cedrick Guindon and Brett Stapley.

titre: Canadiens - Owen Beck : précis comme un anesthésiste, fonceur comme un bélier
texte: If Owen Beck didn't have all that field hockey talent, he would have gone to medical school to become an anesthesiologist. On the ice, he has a style that combines precision in his actions with a keen eye for detail. Academically gifted, Beck has spent part of his summers in Montreal training since he was 15 years old. He is very familiar with the Quebec metropolis and understands French thanks to his academic background. In fact, since he was drafted 33rd overall in July at the Bell Centre, Beck has been working hard to speak the language of Maurice Richard. His selection raised some eyebrows among Canadiens fans who wished the Montreal club would have turned instead to a Quebec prospect (like Noah Warren and Tristan Luneau who were available) after drafting Juraj Slafkovsky and Filip Mesar twice in the first round in Slovakia. But Beck has an enviable reputation in the field hockey world. He already has a complete style as a center and stands out because of his intelligence. The downside to Beck is that his offensive potential could be limited, but he is working on correcting that. After seeing him shine at the rookie tournament in Buffalo, it wouldn't be surprising if he stayed with the Canadiens until the official training camp. "When he gets to the NHL, it will be to see if he establishes himself as a second or third center, but he won't be lower than that. He's not going to be the leader of the first three, he's not the type to cheat to go out and add points," described James Richmond, his coach with the Mississauga Steelheads. Richmond speaks with that confidence because he is a first-hand witness to the professionalism that defines Beck's attitude. He's not talking through his hat either, as every summer, NHL players like Tyler Toffoli return to train with him to fine-tune aspects. The coach confirms a perception that emerges from Beck, the 18-year-old right-hander doesn't seem to be impressed with the Bettman circuit athletes. "He respects the NHL and the players, but I don't think he's afraid to compete against them for a position. Some of the kids are amazed and their jaws drop... Owen knows this is the best league, but he thinks he can make it in. I think that's a positive," he said. "He's going like a battering ram!" Where Richmond sent us a curveball was in describing a trait we didn't suspect in Beck. "He charges like a battering ram! If you don't let him get around you, he's going to go over you. He's really fun to watch with his speed, leg power and quality of delivery," Richmond said. That description led to a probe of Arber Xhekaj who loves the strong game. The imposing defenseman faced Beck often last year in Ontario junior field hockey. "He surprised me a lot in the playoffs, we had some big defensemen on our team and some of their forwards were afraid to play against us. He didn't back down from anything. He's a forward with great skills," said Xhekaj. In the space of two games, Beck has earned praise from Jordan Harris and coach Jean-Francois Houle. In short, this little sample is not scientific, but it leads us to conclude that he will be able to postpone his studies, at least by a few years.

titre: Canadiens : la belle progression de Kaiden Guhle était à l'avant-plan face aux Jets
texte: Kaiden Guhle won't be able to fill all the question marks on the defensive side of the net, but he's doing everything possible to reassure the staff. In the space of a year, his evolution is remarkable and we would go so far as to say that he must surprise some players and managers of the Canadiens by his assumed offensive involvement. "In his head, the game doesn't seem to go too fast. I remember when I was young, at my first camps, I thought it was going so fast. I needed time for it to slow down and for me to show my attributes. Sometimes players have to adjust, like seeing the fastball from the pitchers. He adapts quickly," said Martin St-Louis. Guhle remains sober in his answers, another proof that he will not be out of place in the NHL. "I'm more comfortable with the pace and the professional style of play. It's a lot different than junior," agreed the 20-year-old left-hander, who was pleased with the crowd's loud reaction to his goal. Minutes after the scrum, Guhle opened up a bit more about how his offensive arsenal is working. "It feels good, I try to use my mobility as much as I can. The guys are telling me to do it and it's nice when the coaches and players push you in that direction," he noted. Pairing him with David Savard only helps Guhle venture out offensively. "It's great. He's consistent in his play, I know where he'll be on the ice. I love playing with him," said Guhle. Savard wasn't surprised to see Guhle stand out offensively. "The NHL is sometimes easier than junior, I think it will fall into his lap. His goal was a good example. He made his decision and went for it, it's nice to see him go. It's nice when young guys do well, they have a lot of pressure on their shoulders. He seems comfortable playing like he did in junior," described Savard. It's understandable that Savard is excited about Guhle's development. The veteran defenseman is able to envision the career he could have. "I've been saying it since the beginning of camp, he seems even more mature than last year." What they said "From one end of the ice to the other, you can see his strengths: his size, his skills, his great range, his skating. We're going to see him progress even more as he gets comfortable with what we're doing and the guys around him," St. Louis said of Kirby Dach, who has shown some interesting signs. "I don't know if I had thought about getting him set partners, I saw them more being able to complement him. He's always been a worker and we don't want to change that. But my approach is that I see he can make more field hockey decisions. We saw that in this game, he was receptive to what we presented," said St. Louis on Gallagher, who made some nice plays with Christian Dvorak and Evgenii Dadonov. "Cole has been scoring goals his whole life. I'm sure there are a lot of coaches, because I've experienced it, who let talented players do whatever they want to do to help the team win. But I've had conversations with Cole. He's a great scorer and you have to lead him to be a great field hockey player," concluded St. Louis, who sounds confident he can do it.

titre: Ne pas s'abaisser au niveau de l'adversaire (Chronique d'Éric Leblanc - Alouettes)
texte: The observation was made by two players after the loss, the Montreal Alouettes have developed a bad tendency to play at the level of their opponent. When the matchup is against Ottawa and it ends in a loss, you have to understand that it means lowering your level. With Monday's win in Montreal, the Rouge et Noir has won only four games this season. Yet this team has beaten the Alouettes on two occasions. "It's frustrating, everyone knows that. We shouldn't have lost that game. We always end up playing at our opponent's level. But we know our potential. We just need to execute better week after week. We're frustrated with our performance," said ball carrier William Stanback with a very serious look on his face. Where Stanback was at a loss for words was why. A few minutes earlier, even before retreating to the locker room, veteran Kristian Matte had come to the same conclusion. "We can't play at our opponent's level, we have to play at our level..." he said with exasperation. No doubt, the rivalry is still felt against Ottawa. Besides the geographical proximity, it is also explained by the presence of some former Alouettes with the Rouge et Noir. Especially since Patrick Levels and Monshadrik Hunter have never been outspoken. "I'm not going to lie, they've had some great games against Ottawa this season. They're banking on some Alouettes alumni and there's a lot of chatter. But we need to do a better job offensively, scoring touchdowns in the pay zone. We've also been taking penalties on defense," said Pickett. It's not often that defensive players like Pickett get to criticize the offensive performance. But with only one touchdown in six opportunities in the pay zone, that polite restraint can be jettisoned. Quarterback Trevor Harris, who hasn't posted bad stats (30 in 38 for 338 yards and a touchdown pass), admits his team has wasted too many points. "I agree, we need to execute better, we need to score touchdowns and not place them, it's clear that it makes a big difference," said the man who was unable to complete crucial plays. Inevitably, a doubt arises after this result: did some of the Alouettes players already have their minds on the two games against the Toronto Argonauts when the first place could be at stake? "I hope not and that the players knew we had a great opportunity in front of a big crowd (21,824). I can't believe they were thinking about those two games first. In fact, we need to win on Friday to keep this opportunity alive," said interim head coach and general manager Danny Maciocia. "There are no given games in the CFL. You have to show up to every game..." summarized Maciocia. An eternal optimist, Harris found a way not to leave with his head down as the team missed a chance to confirm their playoff berth. "It's disappointing, but we still control our destiny. We have to learn from this game and become a better team. That said, all of our games are close. I'd like us to put our foot on the gas and distance ourselves from our opponents, we have what it takes to do that," concluded Harris.

titre: LNH : Les Canadiens surprennent les Maple Leafs au match d'ouverture
texte: For a season that started with no expectations, it's not so bad that the Habs kicked off their schedule with a 4-3 win over the perennial rivals, the Toronto Maple Leafs. Here are our observations of the game played in front of a crowd that gave a very nice and somewhat emotional salute to Carey Price before the game. But for Caufield, expectations don't change It's hard to forget that Cole Caufield didn't show the production he was hoping for early last season. The small forward had time to find his touch afterwards and he had no intention of starting the 2022-2023 season in the same way. As he is likely to do often this year, he brought the crowd to its feet with his team's first goal AND second goal. A quick look at the stats will remind you that number 22 scored his first in his 13th game last season and waited until game 31 to get his second. So Caufield had good reason to smile after his successes as Nick Suzuki was complicit in his first goal. We'll go with caution here, but his second goal makes you wonder if he hasn't improved his pitching in the off-season. After glancing to his left, he unleashed an overhanded sinker to Matt Murray. "Yeah, it makes me feel good. As a hitter, it's always good to score quickly and it's nice to get off to a good start, but it takes consistency first," commented Caufield. After Caufield's two goals, the Canadian's hung in there in a tight game. Sean Monahan, in his CH debut, had even given Montreal a 3-2 lead with 2:30 remaining, but William Nylander tied it again 40 seconds later. With Caufield and Suzuki making their mark, it was clear that their trio partner, Josh Anderson, wanted to join the party. He did it with a bang, scoring the winning goal with 18.4 seconds on the clock. He earned a Caufield beak on his helmet! The Guhle-Savard duo The injuries to Michael Matheson and Joel Edmundson have already pushed the Canadiens' management to adopt their plan B. With an extremely young defensive squad, the plan was not to insert Guhle on the first pair of defensemen. But Guhle did admirably against the big guns of the Maple Leafs, especially Auston Matthews and Mitch Marner. Very useful speed, an adequate sturdy style, rarely perilous decisions and a more than reassuring confidence. "He's extremely comfortable, you can tell. He's calm on the ice and we saw that again in this game, he looked very good. He didn't seem to be nervous at all about playing Matthews and Marner for most of the game, it didn't bother him at all," Savard said. "It was crazy (to play Matthews)! He's quite a player, I wanted to limit his options and Savard was great at helping me against them," reacted Guhle with a rare exclamation in his voice. Even Guhle looked better at times than Savard, who also didn't expect to play that much up front. Savard did, however, provide valuable services on defense late in the night. His nine blocked shots out of 24 were an inspiration to his peers, including shorthanded players. Slafkovsky and Xhekaj still have a long way to go This mention will come up a lot, but the Tricolore's youngsters will need time

titre: Canadiens c. Wild : La jeune brigade défensive a montré ses lacunes face au Wild
texte: The Minnesota Wild posed a similar problem for the young Canadian defensive squad as the Dallas Stars. While it wasn't an ugly game, the Wild were able to take advantage of this matchup to take the win. Arber Xhekaj was set up in a few ways by the Wild, Johnathan Kovacevic blundered on a goal, Kaiden Guhle didn't have his early season poise. Also, as a veteran, Chris Wideman did nothing to help the cause. That left only David Savard and Jordan Harris, who played more than 25 minutes, to hold their own against an imposing offense. "Yeah, they're kind of a Dallas style team. It's a pretty straightforward, but intense, check-down forward. I think we did a better job of dealing with that, it's a step in the right direction," Savard said positively. You don't have to have been behind the bench to understand that coach Martin St-Louis didn't appreciate his act of indiscipline in cancelling a Montreal power play. "When you go on the power play, you can't give the referee the opportunity to call a penalty. It's an important part of a game. Whether it's a good decision or not, you can't put yourself in that position," the coach noted. On the other hand, St-Louis feels that his young defensemen deserve to play as many minutes. "I don't think they are being forced, they have earned their chance to play in the NHL. As an organization, at this point, we're developing young defensemen. There are plenty of options that exist as a package otherwise. Harris and Guhle have shown they are ready, their play has shown that. When the veterans (Joel Edmundson and Michael Matheson) are back, we'll have some decisions to make. It's valuable experience for them. They wouldn't be playing if they weren't ready in our opinion," he said. On a more general note, St-Louis didn't find the game too painful against the Wild. "I didn't think it was painful in that game. I'm not happy about losing, but we have to start over and the result isn't the whole story," added the coach. While captain Nick Suzuki felt his team lacked confidence to explain the lackluster offensive production, St. Louis aimed in a different direction. "We had a lot of chances, it was pretty even. To make those chances, it takes confidence. It's more that we lacked a little bit of finish. I don't find us to be a team that doesn't have confidence." In fact, the talk that came up most often in the Tricolore locker room was that it's important to score "ugly" goals. "You can't just try to score perfect goals, that doesn't happen often in this league. We tried to get pucks in front and we had players that were there. We talked about getting returns and stretching the offensive zone, we're working on that," said the CH pilot. "Yeah, it's always useful to score goals like that, but I think we could have eliminated the mistakes that led to their goals. We caused our own demise on those plays in this game," said Mike Hoffman who could have put the needle in more than once.

titre: Martin St-Louis : « S'il y avait une mêlée, c'était sûrement lui »
texte: Martin St-Louis' smile spoke volumes when he asked about the scene involving Brendan Gallagher, goalie Thatcher Demko and defenseman Oliver Ekman-Larsson. A little warrior in his own way, St-Louis must have seen several sequences from the time when he played against the Canadiens' little pest. The Tricolore's coach summed up his thoughts on Gallagher and his evolution well. "If there was a scrimmage, it was probably him. You knew he was going to disrupt the action, he was going to be in the semi-circle, in front of the goalie. Yes, he was scoring more goals, but if you study his game, he became a better player. He is asked to play the game, not just his game and he is still good at causing chaos," he testified. "I have a certain identity as a player and I have to stay true to that. That doesn't mean I can't learn or evolve," Gallagher commented in the locker room. Transparent, Samuel Montembeault admitted that he had no intention of interfering at the other end of the ice. "He's a big guy (Demko), there wasn't much chance of me crossing to the other side and the referee waved me over. I can understand the frustration, it was 3-0 and we were dominating the game," Montembeault reacted with a laugh. In any case, Montembeault had a great influence in front of the net for his team. Without being threatened very often, he met expectations another time. "It's a very difficult role, you have to stay ready and put in a lot of personal time. Every time he's played, he's been great. It's great to see his evolution," said Gallagher. Even though he had to defend himself against two opponents, Gallagher was able to offer some very interesting thoughts on his team's performance after 14 games (7-6-1). "I think we're making a lot of progress, we're getting a better understanding of the style we need to play each game. The guys understand their role and how they can contribute. It's only going to get more complex as the level goes up, but the exciting thing is that we're learning our lessons well and we're correcting our course quickly. For a young team, as people say, we have good veterans," said the right-hander. That view fits with St. Louis' approach to rebuilding. "There's always a lesson in a loss or in a win. If you only think about the results, you lose yourself (in the process). It helps us balance everything emotionally and move forward," said the coach. Tribute to David Savard Speaking of lessons, veteran David Savard gives a great presentation to the young defensemen around him. Obviously, St-Louis noticed and praised the Quebecer. "He's a good player! I've always said, I don't think people respect his offensive game. I'm not just talking about in the offensive zone, but in zone exits and in transition to get into space and with the right speed. He understands the game, he's very smart and that's why he defends very well," he explained. "The most important thing is that he takes care of the team. Like with a big blocked shot, a big play further down the ice, another one to take the pressure off by taking a check or when he goes backwards instead of forcing a move and then playing on our terms. He plays the game and if there's one thing they can learn, it's that," continued St. Louis.

titre: Alouettes : les changements à prévoir rendent Matte émotif
texte: With heads down and hearts heavy, the Montreal Alouettes players left the field after the loss in Toronto. The colossal Kristian Matte stopped to be comforted with a long hug by his father-in-law. When Matte was asked if he would tell us more about this touching scene, his eyes were filled with tears. "He came to see the game with a friend. He's been a soccer fan since before I was with the Alouettes. He's been a huge supporter of mine. Yeah, it was a special moment..." he agreed to tell us with emotion. Matte was heartbroken for more than one reason. Among them, it hurt him to know that this group, which had "something special", will be partly dismantled. "Players, when they retire, they always say you remember your teammates. Our locker room was very close. We were having fun playing soccer and it's special when that happens," noted the friendly fellow. "Yeah, after starting 2-6, it takes some good ingredients to get back up that hill. I'm doing my positive here, but we never gave up, we believed in ourselves," said Matte who was able to walk away from the disappointment for a few seconds. When our team wins the Grey Cup in our rookie season, you can only think that this euphoric scenario will happen once and even many times. But no, Matte has never had the chance to relive the ultimate game since the 2010 conquest. At 37, the veteran offensive lineman has another year left on his contract and it remains to be seen if the organization will retain his services. "We have to go get the ring. I'm under contract, but it's not always in our hands. I think I'm still playing really good soccer. The plan has not materialized, but I still want to play," Matte replied without leaving any doubt about his intentions. On the other hand, it was the last year of the contract of receiver Eugene Lewis, another big piece

titre: Canadiens : un exemple à suivre pour le Tricolore dans ce revers contre les Devils
texte: Depending on how quickly the rebuild takes place, the Habs see themselves progressing in the manner of the New Jersey Devils. In fact, on Tuesday night, the Tricolore saw their opponents execute their own recipe better. "They play very similarly to what we want to do, they are the first in the action, they do not concede much space, they have a frantic pace, they capitalize on the rebound, they use several waves to threaten the attack. They do a lot of things we want to do," said head coach Martin St-Louis. No matter what words were used, the Habs' players had a similar message. "They were in our face all night and we were lazy in our zone exits. They were able to take advantage of the situation and their forechecking was very effective," commented Nick Suzuki. Defenseman Joel Edmundson was able to see the parallels between where the Devils were and where his team is headed. "Yeah, in the last few games, we were playing like they do. They came in and beat us with our style of play. We know we can play at their level, but we haven't," Edmundson said. To pinpoint the issue, guard Jake Allen remains a keen analyst. "They limited our time and our options. Usually this is what we do to other teams. They beat us at our own game in this game. It was a good learning experience," he said. The Devils were such an obstacle that even a veteran like David Savard had trouble. As for the Tricolore's youngsters, this confrontation against a well-oiled team like the Devils allows them to better understand the different challenges of the Bettman circuit. "Growing up in the NHL comes with knowing other players and teams better. You have to take things away from every game," Allen said. "Overall, it wasn't a good effort by our group and we need to pick it up next game," Suzuki said. The Habs captain couldn't get a shot on net for the third time this season, "We couldn't keep pressure in the offensive zone and I'm talking about my trio. We need to do a better job of that," Suzuki said. On a different topic, Evgenii Dadonov will try to take advantage of Jonathan Drouin's extended absence (4 to 6 weeks) to revive his season. "He played with good speed, it was still a good game from him. He has to continue to show us what he can do in the NHL and what he has done in the NHL. There will be less traffic on offense with the injuries. Continuity should help him," said St. Louis.

titre: Canadiens (LNH) : les joueurs irrités par leur manque d'opportunisme en avantage numérique
texte: Losses are always frustrating and this is especially true when it comes to a shutout. But the feeling multiplies after a painful night on the power play. "We, the power play guys, are clearly frustrated. We want to be able to score and help our team win. It deflates the energy when you can't get good chances and you mess up those chances. We had chances, it just wasn't our night," said Nick Suzuki. The captain was right to express his displeasure. The Sharks killed off all six of the Habs' power play attempts, enough to irritate any field hockey player. "Of course, they're proud athletes, they expect to perform up to expectations. We did very well at five on five, we just didn't get the power play goal that could have changed the game," said Martin St-Louis. The Sharks don't lead the NHL in shorthanded scoring for nothing, but it would be too easy to give them all the credit for this performance. "It was a little bit of everything, we'll look at the video of the game and we'll probably learn from it," said St-Louis. "They're good, but it's a little bit because of our execution and maybe the coaches' work as well. We'll analyze that," he added. As a former power play specialist, St. Louis could relate to his charges. "As a player, you look for quick answers. They have the luxury of being able to look at the shelf. I think we're better organized against different types of shorthanded approaches. But in this game, we were a little off in terms of execution," said St-Louis. The coach doesn't want his players always waiting for the perfect opportunity. However, Suzuki felt that the players lacked patience. "After a few chances, we forced things a little too much instead of being patient," the captain said. [... I want us to be patient, if the luck seems bad, we have to wait. We're trying to create confusion by changing positions. It was up to us to have a better execution", mentioned the number 14. What they said In the positive category, a few of the Habs' young players blocked shots including Kaiden Guhle and Juraj Slafkovsky. This dedication did not go unnoticed. "Everyone in the locker room is willing to block shots and do what it takes to win games. We've seen it a few times this year, we've pulled off comebacks," Michael Matheson boasted. "It's critical, you see the veterans doing it and the young guys following suit. It's representative of the culture we want to instill in the team. I think it's great, it shows that we care a lot about the details," said Harris, who was pleased with his performance. "You don't want to take the stick out of his hands, he has to make the decisions. As a player, you always want to get three or four games back after a game. It's not always the right play to shoot, we have to be careful about bringing that up, we'll evaluate that. Before the NHL, he's never afraid to shoot, but he's young and he plays with veterans. If it becomes a trend, we'll discuss it," said St. Louis, who liked Slafkovsky's game, which could have been less generous against the Sharks.

titre: Canadiens : Une léthargie différente de la saison dernière pour le CH
texte: When Martin St-Louis was named coach of the Habs last season, the Habs had just suffered seven consecutive losses. Nearly a year later, the clock has just returned to that number. "In terms of atmosphere or practices, I couldn't even compare the lethargy to last season. The scores are the only similarity," Jake Evans reacted when this topic was brought up. "Everyone is working hard to rectify things and we proved we could play well early in the season. We're going to get back on track soon," continued Evans, who played a strong game both defensively and offensively. In the morning, the Canadiens thought it would be a good idea to hold a meeting to adjust their pipes. "That's where it starts (the defensive work), with how we get into our zone and how we organize ourselves in our territory afterwards. That was a big progression in this game, we had lost that element. We're going to build on that and get back into it as a team," said St. Louis. If anyone doubts it, it's a medium- to long-term process for the Habs. "Of course, we haven't won, but it's not about the wins right now. It's about getting our game back on track. If we can get back to where we were at the beginning of the season and execute the details well, starting with me and the whole team, we'll be fine," said goalie Jake Allen. The long trip did not stop the slide that began on Montreal soil. "We were getting away from the game plan," Allen said of the tough losses away from Quebec. With his veteran's perspective, Allen isn't worried about the current situation undermining morale. "It's tough, this lethargy is tough, there's no denying that. But we've spent a lot of time abroad in the last few weeks. We have a good group, there's no doubt about that. It's up to us to get through it and it's a good learning curve. Even when we're a very good team, we'll go through slumps like the Rangers did at the beginning of the season," the goalie said. Young leaders like Nick Suzuki need to make sure they help Allen and the older guys in the group. "The energy is good, we have several young guys learning. It's our job to communicate to play better," Suzuki agreed. What they said It would be as hard to write an article from Joel Armia's comments as it would be to keep Brendan Gallagher away from the opposing goalie when he's in uniform. But here's pretty much the entirety of his comments following his first goal of the season in his 27th game. "Yes, it's a weight off my shoulders," he admitted. "Our trio played very well, our forecheck was solid and we had good rhythm on the ice. I'm happy with our performance," added the Finn. "I know I'm not playing up to my potential, I'm trying to correct that," admitted the 29-year-old. "It's an honour to be back, but I'm focused on our team's performance first. I will enjoy it when the time comes," commented Suzuki on being named to the All-Star Game. "It's really deserved, it was probably a toss-up between him and Cole (Caufield). He's a complete player and they'll have many appearances over the years," said Allen.

titre: LNH : Un départ gênant et frustrant pour Martin St-Louis contre le Kraken
texte: In a context of rebuilding, Martin St-Louis appears serene after most losses. But this one, undermined by a horrible first period, he couldn't digest it so easily. "The second period and the third period really don't mean anything after a first period like that. It's flat...", St-Louis commented dryly with a glare. The coach said that performances like that get to him. He is well prepared to live with the ups and downs of a rebuild, but such a lack of commitment can only bring out his competitive spirit. In fact, his short answer was telling as to how he wanted his players to feel after their first period. "Embarrassed," he summed up in one word. "They know I wasn't happy," he added later. With his few frustration-tinged responses, one wondered how St. Louis would have handled such a disappointing start to his team in his playing days. One assumes it would have been a struggle on the bench. On that subject, veteran colleague Marc De Foy asked him if he lacked the leadership in his group to handle a situation like this. "I don't know, I'm not a little fly that hears everything that's said in the room. But it's unacceptable our first half. I don't know if it was communicated in the room between the players. "We're going to correct some things, but also the problem of having had a period like that," the coach assured. St. Louis' reaction was also justified by the fact that his team had just stopped a seven-game losing streak with a more encouraging performance. "After that big win, it looked like we took this game lightly. Still, there are no easy games in this league. Plus, against a team like the Kraken that is playing very well these days. We knew what we were getting into," said Nick Suzuki with incomprehension. "It's frustrating, we're playing very inconsistently right now", summarized Arber Xhekaj who himself had a disappointing night. This was a recurring theme when talking to the four players (Suzuki, Xhekaj, Montembeault and Slafkovsky) who met with the media after the game. "We tried to build off the win on Saturday, but it didn't happen. We won't play at that level next game, we didn't have it at all in the first half. It hurt us," noted Slafkovsky who was at the heart of some interesting sequences offensively. The only trio that performed better was Jake Evans, Joel Armia and Evgenii Dadonov. That was no consolation to the coach. "Yeah, that trio gives us consistency in their play. But it takes more than that, we had too many passengers in this game, especially starting," St. Louis identified. "We're not good enough as a team to have passengers," he insisted. Even though he had been left out for the past two games, Mike Hoffman was far from eager to eat the boards. Jonathan Drouin should also have been more incisive in his actions and the list could go on.

titre: Canadien : le directeur général Kent Hughes a dressé son bilan de l'équipe à la mi-saison
texte: Kent Hughes recognizes that there is no perfect answer to the development of Juraj Slafkovsky or the use of veterans while development remains the priority. It all becomes a question of balance. This is the learning curve for Hughes as he celebrates his first anniversary as the Habs' general manager, a position that is under intense scrutiny. On one hand, there is the desire to rebuild this organization with a winning culture. On the other, there's the immense temptation to add an extraordinary prospect like Connor Bedard in the draft. "I used to tell Martin (St. Louis, coach) that wins are good to a point, but losses are not good to a point," Hughes said with a smile. "I'm a big believer in team culture as opposed to putting money on a club that can't win, where there's no accountability and the players don't know how to win," he said. This issue has fans reacting as many claim that the Habs are giving too much use to veterans at the expense of the next generation. "I imagine that discussions are taking place among the 32 NHL clubs on this subject. I've talked to several veteran general managers about what they've experienced. We're all discussing it internally, but we're still going to allow the coaches to make the decisions about the players and their partners. Just like at the trade deadline (March 3), we want their input on players, but the management group will make the decisions on trades," Hughes said. "We know we don't have a team to win every game, but we expect the players to show up to win every game. It would be different to tell them, we're not capable of getting wins anymore, we're just going to play the young guys. I think we would lose the team, the room," said the leader. This tells us that the discussions must be interesting between the field hockey departments of the Tricolore. In fact, Hughes takes great pride in seeing the group assembled

titre: Espoirs des Canadiens : Owen Beck a maintenant Montréal en tête
texte: Just drafted by the Habs last summer, Owen Beck quickly became a revelation during the rookie tournament and training camp. Now that he's struck gold with Team Canada, he's looking forward to playing in Montreal next season. "Absolutely, I would like to be in the NHL as soon as possible, that's everyone's goal. I'm going to work towards that," said Beck, one of five members of the championship team honoured Tuesday night at the Bell Centre. The 18-year-old right-handed forward isn't the type to throw that wish up in the air. In fact, his personality is very much like the game he plays on the ice, a thoughtful style with just enough confidence to hold his own against top-notch opponents. An excellent student, Beck admits that he made sure to retain the learnings from the summer during his time with the Montreal organization. When he adds that to the confidence boost he gained in a Canadian uniform during the final stretch of the tournament, Beck calculates that his chances are realistic. "It's a huge event, it's great to be able to participate at 18. It should help me for next year. This experience will help me in all my games," said Beck, drafted 33rd overall by the CH this summer. The Mississauga Steelheads of the Ontario Junior League saw fit to trade him to the Peterborough Petes this year. This was a prudent move on the part of the Steelheads who could have lost him next year without getting anything in return. So far, in three games, Beck has been limited to one goal with his new team, but he is excited about the opportunity to further exploit his offensive skills. "My coaches in Mississauga and Peterborough are very detail oriented in order to get the system right. But I think there's more room for creativity in Peterborough and I'm excited about that, I can't wait to experience that in my game," said Beck in a phrase that should please some CH fans. All good things for Hinds If ECJ is banking on several blue-chip players for the next level

titre: Canadiens : discipline recherchée et Radko Gudas sème la colère chez les Canadiens
texte: During its rebuild, the Habs will not dominate many statistical categories in the NHL. And, to give themselves a chance to win, they shouldn't lead in penalty minutes like they do now. No wonder the CH was overcome with frustration against the Florida Panthers. The five penalties imposed on the Montreal team in the second period led to four goals by the visitors. Montreal finished the game with 53 minutes of penalties and a clear score of 6-2, "We were definitely frustrated with the way we played. It's tough when you have the best intentions, but it doesn't go your way," said Michael Matheson, who had to throw down the gauntlet against Matthew Tkachuk after the Panthers couldn't deal with his hit on Eric Staal, "We were frustrated with the way we played and the penalties we took. You just can't win with all those penalties," admitted Joel Edmundson. But the frustration wasn't just with the recurring indiscipline, it was also related to some perceived dirty hits by the Panthers and in particular Radko Gudas. "I think he's a dirty player and he's been that way throughout his career. But that's the way he plays. Except if you play like that and try to hurt players, you should at least answer for it," Anderson said shamelessly. Anderson wanted to go after Gudas late in the game as Gudas tried to hit Kirby Dach with a knee in revenge for a check down. "He's been aiming for his opponents' knees the whole game. Yes, he plays tough and I'll give him that, but he has to be held accountable," Arber Xhekaj added to the incessant debate about Gudas. In the final third, the emotion was palpable in the Bell Centre. There is no need to describe the scenes of violence, but the Canadiens players and their coach remembered the spirit of solidarity displayed. "They took over in our arena. Our penalties hurt a lot, but in the third period, we didn't want to let our teammates down," said Anderson. "I asked the boys to finish the game, to stick together. In the first period, some physical plays came up and wrote the rest of the game, we expected that a little bit," mentioned Martin St-Louis. What they said "I thought I had a good chance. You think it's going to come back 0-0, but you put them back on the power play. Our power play is better lately, but we struggled a little bit in this game," noted St-Louis about the challenge. "We need to play better than that especially after two good performances," lamented Xhekaj. "It was good to be on the bench at the beginning of the third period because I was pretty upset at the end of the second period. I had been hit in a vicious way," added Xhekaj. "We did a good job of sticking together, we're a tight knit group," concluded Suzuki.

titre: Deux quarts noirs au Super Bowl : Michael Vick ne croyait pas voir cela de son vivant
texte: Michael Vick began his NFL career in 2001, a few months after being drafted at the very top of his class. Despite his impressive track record, Vick never imagined that two black quarterbacks would one day face off in the Super Bowl.  That historic moment will finally happen on Sunday, as Jalen Hurts will want to show that his progression is enough to shake Patrick Mahomes' dominance.  "Seeing the evolution of this position, which started in the 1960s, we're at this big milestone and I never thought we'd see this, but anything is possible," Vick confided on Tuesday during the FOX network's personality media availability.  "A lot of people played a role in this to make it happen. The leaders I'm talking about allowed us to be accepted and have the opportunities to show our potential. It's not the only storyline, but you're going to see two very talented young black quarterbacks; too bad only one can win," Vick continued.  We have to say, it came as a bit of a surprise that even Vick didn't think it would happen.  "Never say never, but you have to take advantage of opportunities. I'm thankful that I was drafted first overall and it gave me hope that Donovan McNabb would be drafted second overall in 1999. It's becoming a great time to reflect on the progress we've made in soccer," noted the former left-handed quarterback. This week, Vick and McNabb each praised Hurts for the seriousness he displays. They mentioned that they wished they had handled the early years of their careers as well as he did. With his dedication, Hurts has risen to the top of the NFL, which bodes well for the future.  "I really appreciate their comments, I looked up to them when I was young. I've followed their respective careers a lot and I have tremendous respect for them. I just try to play with passion and prepare well for games," Hurts commented modestly.  Being so close to Mahomes, Travis Kelce became a key player this week to comment on this historic accomplishment. Kelce began by explaining that Mahomes really isn't the type to discuss such issues with his teammates.  "But Pat has this ability to understand and grasp the significance of his career and legacy. How he's a pioneer and how he inspires a ton of young people. It's really cool that we get to experience this alongside him," Kelce said in the same breath.  "I knew early on in his career that he was going to be considered one of the greats or the greatest," added the Chiefs tight end.  Kansas City center Creed Humphrey's sound bite was also very relevant as he was also Hurts' teammate at Oklahoma University.  "I can confirm that both are extremely competitive, they hold that ability to break down information on the court. There are always traits that exist in quarterbacks that become as good as they are and they possess them," Humphrey confided, acknowledging that he was more than fortunate in his journey.  When it comes to deciding which team will hoist the Vince-Lombardi Trophy, Vick manages to do as well as he did avoiding tackles.  "I can't say that especially since I push for both, I have a friendly relationship with everyone. I'm especially proud of Patrick and Jalen, they understand the importance of this game and the process to get there. You can never take that for granted," commented Vick.  "If you flipped the quarters for these two teams, you'd probably have the same result, they'd play each other in the Super Bowl. When the selected play collapses in front of them and they have to improvise, they manage to get by and expose all their talent," he continued.  Mobility is no longer an option Vick wasn't blessed with a Super Bowl win, but his exceptional mobility has inspired many teams and especially a ton of young athletes. These days, quarterbacks who are desperate to stay in their protective pouches are far more rare.  "I think mobility is essential now, it makes it so much easier to move up the field and win games. It's still a big part of Jalen and Pat's arsenal. A whole bunch of quarterbacks can run today and I'm proud of them. Joe Burrow, Aaron Rodgers and Trevor Lawrence are as confident in their mobility as their arms. It makes the sport better and it's perfect for the next generation," said Vick.  This mobility has been appealing to Andy Reid for many years.  "Michael is right, I like mobile quarterbacks. It's part of this offense. Joe Montana and Steve Young were mobile quarterbacks back in their day. It continued for me with Donovan McNabb coming to the Eagles. I also think of Brett Favre who wasn't the fastest, like Patrick, but could run when needed," commented Reid.  About Reid, Vick recalls that he was a demanding coach.  "You had to understand the playbook, you had to know why that play was selected (so you could look at the right things on the field). If you didn't understand it, he wasn't going to pick it," Vick stressed.  This approach allows Reid to make his charges comfortable in what they accomplish so well that they can excel.  "Players would break down a wall for Andy Reid because Andy would do it for his players! He demands respect and he'll give you the same respect in return," boasted Vick who remains in contact with Reid.  Reid's track record seems to show that he has a fondness for black quarterbacks.  "I've never discussed the possibility with him. However, I do know that the Eagles have had some excellent black quarterbacks. Jalen has to live up to those standards and I felt the same way in Philadelphia. In my opinion, Andy didn't care what color his quarterback was, as long as he could get the job done," Vick said.  There's no doubt about it, Hurts is moving in the right direction to make Randall Cunningham, McNabb and company proud.  "This is his second season in this system and it proves that he needed an offense like this. He can be consistent in this system, he has found his niche. You get better when you get there. He's at that level and he can't go back, get used to that performance from him," Vick assured.  One reporter tried to continue on the parallels between Mahomes (27) and Hurts (24) by asking the Chiefs quarterback if he saw anything in his Eagles counterpart that reminded him of his younger days in Kansas City.  "I'm not old yet," Mahomes was quick to respond, laughing, but still wanting to remind everyone that he's preparing for a long NFL career.  "You can tell he's working hard, he's getting better every year. It's the same for me. He continues to provide leadership and it's easy to see the Eagles rallying behind him," Mahomes concluded.

titre: Super Bowl : « Quand je dis que je dois tout à mon grand frère, c'est vrai » - Travis Kelce
texte: "When I say I owe everything to my big brother, it's true." Travis Kelce is an intense man in everything he does in life. With this sentence, launched in front of the media on Thursday, the close winger of the Kansas City Chiefs spoke from his heart to pay tribute to his brother, Jason, the center of the Philadelphia Eagles. The first confrontation between two brothers in Super Bowl history was already on everyone's lips. But this storyline becomes significantly more interesting when you step back 13 years. In 2010, Travis Kelce was suspended by the University of Cincinnati when he was scheduled to play his second season there. Marijuana use and his tendency to party too much had led to the decision. "When I was suspended from the team, I lost my scholarship. So I went to stay at my brother's apartment and slept in the same room as him. I didn't pay the rent and he also helped me with the food. He was my lifeline," said 33-year-old Travis Kelce. "He decided to talk to several of my coaches about getting me another chance. He put our name on the table and his own reputation on the line," he continued gratefully, as his career could have ended at that point, leaving soccer without this unique specimen. Instead, Kelce returned to action in 2011 and was selected in the third round by the Chiefs in 2013. As soon as Kelce was drafted, Andy Reid was quick to call him to congratulate him, but he immediately wanted to talk to the big brother. Legend has it that Reid put Jason Kelce on a mission to keep his little brother in line so he wouldn't screw up his career. "First of all, we didn't get the same version of this story as Coach Reid," Jason Kelce told RDS.ca with a smile. "Travis and I remember that call as Andy telling me to endorse my brother, that I take responsibility for guiding him well. And even to assure him that he wasn't going to ruin his future. When asked about this, Andy says it didn't happen that way. But hey, since Travis and I were so excited about him being drafted, I'll take Andy's word for it," said Jason, who is 35. "Andy knew me, I played two years for him in Philadelphia. So I think that helped him see past Travis' troubles. He had met Travis before and everyone who gets a chance to talk to him understands that he has a good heart and he's a good person," the friendly older brother continued. This tale of kindness doesn't take away from the very competitive spirit that the Kelce brothers have. "We compete for everything! Love from our parents, leftovers at Thanksgiving, everything. But most of all, we enjoy each other's company," laughed the Eagles veteran admitting that Travis dominated him as a field hockey player. By the end of the night on Sunday, one should be crying with joy and the other with sadness. "The emotions will be mixed as one will be so happy and the other so sad. Even the one who wins will feel a little bad for the other," admitted Jason. Maybe the loser will try to console himself with the cookies
