titre: LNH : Jonathan Marchessault et compagnie défendent l'imputabilité des Golden Knights
texte: Max Pacioretty's recent comments bemoaning the lack of accountability with the Golden Knights have made waves all the way to the Vegas desert. On Chris Nilan and Tim Stapleton's Raw Knuckles podcast, the former Canadiens captain noted that there is a huge difference between the pressure of the Montreal market and the reality of the Nevada organization. "When I first came to Vegas, it was weird that there was, like, no accountability," said Pacioretty. You couldn't feel the pressure coming from anyone else whether it was the coach or management." On Tuesday night, number 67's words echoed all the way to Quebec City as several Golden Knights players participated in the Gagné-Bergeron Pro-Am thanks to Jonathan Marchessault's involvement. To a certain extent, he doesn't hesitate to speak his mind and he reacted to Pacioretty's comments. "I don't need my general manager and my coach to tell me that we want to make the playoffs this year, I know that. If every player looks in the mirror and says he wants to do the job to be successful and help his team win every night, normally the club does well. I see it that way," Marchessault said. So, was he angry or disappointed when he heard that statement? "I know Max and he didn't want to badmouth us or say anything against the players or the organization. When I talked to him, I let him know that I understand how it works sometimes in interviews, that things come out of context, and I don't blame him, he's still a good friend of mine," he replied. Jack Eichel was one of the teammates who accepted Marchessault's invitation. While he also pleaded for "misperceived" comments, he acknowledged that the team can move forward on this issue. "I don't think he really meant that. Sometimes when you play in a climate like Vegas, you can lose sight of where you are in the season. It's not like when it snows. But accountability is the most important thing in a locker room and we have to make sure everyone is accountable. In every locker room, unless you've lifted the Stanley Cup, there are things that need to be improved," noted Eichel, who finally got healthy but couldn't declare himself 100%. In becoming one of the Knights' key pieces, Eichel has to pull his partners in the right direction and he's banking on humility. "You have to take criticism, that's how good teams become great," Eichel admitted of the collective. Fleury's silence Without meaning to, goaltender Marc-Andre may have given the best answer with two evocative silences when asked about the subject. "The Golden Knights showed great cohesion and solidarity in responding to Pacioretty's comments. Their response is a sign that the team is aware of the need for accountability and is willing to work towards it. Captain Mark Stone was one of the first to respond to Pacioretty's comments. "We are a very close team and we have always supported each other. We know we have to be accountable and we work hard to do that. We are a team that supports and respects each other," he said. General Manager George McPhee also reacted to Pacioretty's comments. "We are a very competitive organization and we strive to get better every day. We know we have to be accountable and we work hard to do that. We are a team that supports and respects each other," he said. Defenseman Nate Schmidt also spoke up in defense of the Golden Knights' accountability. "We are a very close-knit team and we have always supported each other. We realize that we need to be accountable and we work hard to do that. We are a team that supports and respects each other," he said. Goaltender Marc-Andre Fleury also spoke up for the Golden Knights' accountability. "We are a very united team and we have always supported each other. We know we have to be accountable and we work hard to do that. We are a team that supports and respects each other," he said. The Golden Knights have also put measures in place to ensure accountability is maintained. They have put in place extra practice sessions for players who are not living up to their expectations and viewing sessions for players who need more time to understand the game system. They have also implemented mentoring sessions for young players to give them the tools to succeed in the NHL. The Golden Knights are a supportive and self-respecting team that realizes the need for accountability. They are working hard to achieve this and are ready for the challenge.

titre: Sénateurs : Thomas Chabot ne s'attendait pas à tout ce renfort
texte: Even Thomas Chabot didn't expect his team, the Ottawa Senators, to acquire the services of Alex DeBrincat, Claude Giroux and Cam Talbot during the upcoming off-season. "Not necessarily all of those players, I won't lie," said the Sens' inexhaustible defenseman. At the end of last season, the fifth in a row leading up to Ottawa's playoff exit, Chabot and Brady Tkachuk took the time to tell general manager Pierre Dorion that it was time to find reinforcements to maximize the talent on the young team. At some point, losing is enough. But the two youngsters wouldn't have dared demand that a scoring ace like DeBrincat, a high-quality veteran like Giroux and a solid goalie like Talbot end up in Ottawa. "DeBrincat, any team would dream of a player like him who can score 40 goals. You can't find that overnight. It's special to have him with us. With the guys we already have around him, it's really going to help our team," noted Chabot. "To add a guy like Giroux, with his amazing career, he's going to bring a lot of talent on the ice. His experience of having been a captain for many years will help our young group a lot", agreed Chabot who sees the desired stability with Talbot and Anton Forsberg in net. On two occasions, Chabot made sure to point out that the team must remain realistic considering the power of the Atlantic Division. It's still a tall order to win a playoff spot from the Panthers, Lightning, Maple Leafs or Bruins. But for a rare time, the word exciting is associated with the Sens' upcoming campaign. "It's fun, we're a bunch of kids who were drafted in the same area, we've grown up together and we're still moving forward. We're ready to take another step and get the city of Ottawa, the fans, behind us. They deserve it. We haven't been to the playoffs since I've been here," commented the left-hander. While the reinforcement on offense has been more than satisfactory, Chabot must continue to ask questions as he looks around to patrol the blue line. | Chabot is aware that the task will not be easy, but is optimistic that he can succeed. "It's a very competitive division, but I think we have the tools to succeed. We have a young, talented team that has a lot of potential. We now have experienced players who can help us achieve our goals. Now we need to work hard and prepare for the upcoming season." Chabot is also aware that expectations are high for the upcoming season. "We have to live up to the expectations. We have to make sure we are ready to play our best and give our best every time we step on the ice. We have to make sure we are ready to challenge and fight for a playoff spot." Chabot is confident that the Senators are poised to take a big step forward this season. "We are a young, talented team with a lot of potential. We now have experienced players who can help us achieve our goals. Now we need to work hard and prepare for the upcoming season. We are ready to take on the challenge and fight for a playoff spot."

titre: Canadiens : le nom de Carey Price inscrit sur la liste des blessés à long terme
texte: The Habs were able to make Kirby Dach's new deal official as Carey Price's name was placed on the long-term off-season injury list. The general manager set in motion the dominoes game that was anticipated. It was a given that Price's name would be placed on that list. The big question was when to do it. In an ideal world, Hughes would have waited until the regular season. But he felt it was best not to wait any longer in order to help Dach acclimate. "We got to a point where we had to get Kirby's deal done. Bringing him here was more important to get him with the group than showing up at training camp and dealing with the distractions of not having a contract in place," explained the Tricolore's general manager. "If we had made another trade, we wouldn't have had to put Price on that list in the off-season. This would have given us more flexibility during the regular season," added Hughes. It should be noted that NHL teams can exceed the salary cap by 10% during the off-season. However, by confirming Dach's contract, the Montreal club no longer respected this clause. The Price-related move therefore had to be brought forward. True to form since taking over, Hughes leaned towards transparency when talking about the Dach file, which has dragged on because of this economic issue. "It was a little different in the sense that the negotiations didn't take that long. When we knew what the contract could look like, we paused to see if we could complete any trades or make another move," Hughes noted, confirming that the wait was related to the Price case. On the medical front, Hughes returned to Quebec on Tuesday and did not meet with team doctors. Hughes' move was welcomed by Habs fans, who were reassured that the general manager has taken the necessary steps to ensure the club remains competitive. Although Price's name is on the long-term injury list, the Habs still have a chance to make the playoffs. Fans can take heart in the fact that the club was able to close the Dach deal and the dominoes have been set in motion. The Habs also announced that Price will be evaluated by the team doctors and will be cleared for practice and games as soon as he is ready. This means that the Habs will have a chance to see Price in action this season and that the club will be able to count on him to help achieve their goals. The Habs also announced that goaltender Charlie Lindgren will be the starting goaltender for the start of the season. Lindgren made his NHL debut last year and has shown great maturity and confidence. He has been a great asset to the Habs and is ready to assume the starting goaltending role. The Habs also announced that goaltender Antti Niemi will be the backup goalie for the start of the season. Niemi has a long history in the NHL and has been a great asset to the Habs when called upon to play. He is ready to take on the backup role and help the Habs achieve their goals. The Habs also announced that goaltender Cayden Primeau will be the third goaltender for the start of the season. Primeau made his NHL debut last year and has shown great maturity and confidence. He is ready to take on the role of third goalie and help the Habs achieve their goals. The Habs also announced that goaltender Michael McNiven will be the fourth goalie for the start of the season. McNiven made his NHL debut last year and has shown great maturity and confidence. He is ready to take on the role of fourth goalie and help the Habs achieve their goals. The Habs also announced that goaltender Keith Kinkaid will be the fifth goaltender for the start of the season. Kinkaid has a long history in the NHL and has been a great asset to the Habs when called upon to play. He is ready to take on the role of fifth goalie and help the Habs achieve their goals. So the Habs have a solid goaltending team in place for the start of the season. Fans can take comfort in the fact that the club has taken the necessary steps to ensure that the club remains competitive and has the right players to achieve its goals.

titre: LCF : Le 1er départ de Pier-Olivier Lestage, des Alouettes, tombe bien contre Hamilton
texte: Pier-Olivier Lestage is expected to make his debut as a starter on Friday against the Hamilton Tiger-Cats, a tough matchup that has him salivating. Left guard Phillippe Gagnon missed the Montreal Alouettes' practice on Tuesday due to back problems. Lestage patrolled the position and is expected to keep it for the game. "Unfortunately, Philippe is not here and I hope he can practice on Wednesday. For sure, if he doesn't practice, it will be hard to dress him. But we have depth with P-O who can play, I'm convinced he can be up to the task," said Danny Maciocia. The soccer operations boss has seen Lestage adapt over the past few weeks. "Yes, I feel he is ready. He's very comfortable with the playbook and at different positions. When I watch him go, I see a confidence I know from him," Maciocia said of Lestage's years with the University of Montreal Carabins. "I'm ready, I've been waiting a few weeks for this. Initially, I had reps as a center back and close wing. Against the Lions, I got some playing time on the line so I see it as the next thing, I'm really looking forward to it," said Lestage. Luc Brodeur-Jourdain, the offensive line coach, was reassuring. "His evolution is very good, you can see that he has understood his soccer well over the years. Of course, he doesn't know the CFL players in detail. But, even if he is a rookie in the CFL, I see something worthy of a veteran in him," targeted Brodeur-Jourdain. "Obviously, he'll make mistakes left and right. But that happens to veterans of 14-15 seasons," he added. | Lestage is aware that the game against Hamilton will be a challenge. "I know it's going to be a tough game, but I'm up for the challenge. I know I have to rise to the occasion and I will do my best to help the team win," he said. The Alouettes are confident in Lestage's ability to adapt to the league. "He's made great strides since the beginning of the season and I'm sure he'll be up to the task," Maciocia said. "He has a good understanding of the game and he is very smart. He knows how to adapt to every situation and I'm sure he will do a good job." Brodeur-Jourdain is also optimistic about Lestage's performance. "He's made great strides and I'm sure he'll be up to the task," he said. "He has a good understanding of the game and he's very smart. He knows how to adapt to every situation and I'm sure he will do a good job." Lestage is ready for the challenge and to help the team win. "I know I have to rise to the occasion and I will do my best to help the team win," he said. "I know it's going to be a tough game, but I'm ready to rise to the challenge and do my best to help the team win." The Alouettes are confident in Lestage's ability to adapt to the league and help the team win. With his intelligence and understanding of the game, he is ready to take on the challenge and help the team win.

titre: LCF : La relance des Alouettes rendue possible par quelques changements
texte: During the first half of the calendar, the players and the management of the Alouettes repeated ad nauseam that they were a better team than their record showed. Slowly, but surely, the Montreal organization seems to be proving it. After posting a 2-6 record, the Birds are getting closer to the desired altitude with a 6-7 record thanks to four wins in five outings. "I like this team, I like it a lot and I've always liked it. Our players didn't have it easy. We had a plan A at the beginning of the year, but we had to find another way, except the destination remains the same. The guys are giving maximum effort, they are buying into what we are proposing," said Danny Maciocia, GM and head coach. This revival has necessitated some changes, especially on defense, with players like Micah Awe, Raheem Wilson, Nafees Lyon, Mustafa Johnson, Thomas Costigan and Jamal Davis now playing as starters. Next week in Edmonton, Montreal could get to .500 with a win. Maciocia used his good sense of repartee on the subject. "I wouldn't be surprised if we were at .500. I was more surprised that we were 2-6. I always said we were a good team. Not everyone believed me, but that's okay. A lot of people have probably written us off. But we have good players and good coaches. I'm just enjoying the moment," he commented. On the offensive side of the ball, success could only come from a solid performance by quarterback Trevor Harris. While not excelling, committing a few errant passes, Harris finished his game with 74.3% pass completion for 244 yards and two touchdowns. "It's only a matter of finishing games the right way. We have to have that confidence. Our team is not a finished product yet, I've missed some games myself. We know the little things can come back to haunt us," Harris said when asked if this club looks more like the picture he envisioned. | The Alouettes have been able to get back on track with a stronger defense and more consistent performances from their quarterback. The offensive line also played an important role in their success, protecting Harris and giving him time to find his receivers. The Alouettes also benefited from the addition of new players, including defensive end Micah Awe and defensive back Raheem Wilson, who brought a new dynamic to the team. The Alouettes also benefited from the presence of experienced players such as Vernon Adams Jr. who was a leader on the field and helped guide the younger players. The Alouettes also benefited from the arrival of new coaches, including Head Coach Danny Maciocia, who brought a new vision and energy to the team. The Alouettes have also benefited from the support of their fans, who have always been there to support and encourage them. The Alouettes now have a chance to make the playoffs and show what a competitive team they are. With their recent performances, the Alouettes have proven that they are a team to be taken seriously and that they can be a force to be reckoned with in the CFL.

texte: While Owen Beck is making eyes wide open at the Canadiens training camp, Mississauga teammate Zakary Lavoie is trying to prove that he deserves the trust of an NHL team. This summer, Lavoie experienced a big disappointment when he was passed over in the draft. Since he lives only two hours away from the Bell Centre, there was no way he was going to miss this appointment despite the risk associated with it. The Franco-Ontarian did not expect to be selected in the second round like Beck and Luca Del Bel Belluz, his partners with the Mississauga Steelheads. However, he believed that his 23 goals and 21 assists in 64 games were enough to get him in. He was able to get rid of some of his bitterness when he received an invitation to the Senators' development camp. "The Sens were quick to call me and say, 'Oh, you were right, Coach, he's got some great assets,'" said James Richmond, his coach in Mississauga. So it was only natural for the Senators to reserve a spot for him at the rookie tournament in Buffalo where he was used in two games. I want to show that I deserve my place with everyone here, that I'm not the odd man out," said the 5-foot-10, 178-pound right-handed forward. titre: Canadiens : une dose de confiance rafraîchissante, à la limite de l'arrogance (Éric Leblanc)
texte: As the season progresses, some of the games will be more difficult, but the fun experienced by the Habs' youngsters exposes a promising potential. It's no secret that the success of the rebuild will depend on the success of the organization's top prospects. In recent years, a host of young athletes have shown that they can excel in the NHL. Confidence is essential to showcase this kind of performance and it is acquired through good feelings on the ice. On Thursday night, you only had to see the huge smiles on the faces of Juraj Slafkovsky and Arber Xhekaj to understand that this game will have a positive influence on their development. While Kaiden Guhle has already taken off, Slafkovsky, Xhekaj and Jordan Harris are looking to do the same. Cole Caufield can also be remembered for finding his lighted face when he started counting again last season. On occasion, the fun will border on arrogance, but that's nothing negative according to Martin St. Louis. "I'm glad they're having fun and feeling confident on the ice. The NHL is a very serious league, but you have to have fun too and the guys had fun because it's still a game we play. The young guys gained confidence in this game, that's important and it will help us collectively", targeted the coach. The fact that Xhekaj was instrumental in Slafkovsky's goal only added to the fun night for the two. His daring check from deep in the offensive zone paid off, to say the least. "He scored on top of it, we got a little excited. We were yelling at the other guy (Josh Brown) a little bit. It was a nice moment," Xhekaj reacted. Juraj told me in the locker room that it's fun to play when I'm on the ice." "I like when our defensemen 'pinch', but I thought it was a little far to do it. Except he had an idea in his head and he surprised their defenseman. Sometimes as a coach, you just have to turn your head (not to look)," laughed St-Louis. Slafkovsky's goal sparked a round of applause at the Bell Centre and it was hard to stay indifferent. "I turned to Harris and told him how cool it was. It shows how wonderful our fans are," said Xhekaj. "Nothing better could have happened after my goal. Brendan told me to stand up and wave to the crowd, but oh my God," said Slafkovsky who became the fourth youngest player in Canadiens history to score after Mario Tremblay, Jesperi Kotkaniemi and Claude Lemieux. That confidence and arrogance are qualities that are necessary to succeed in the NHL. The Habs' young players have shown that they can play at a high level and have fun at the same time. This positive and optimistic attitude is contagious and can help the team reach new heights. The players are aware of their potential and are ready for the challenge. This confidence and arrogance are also qualities that can be passed on to other players. The Habs' young players are an example to others and can help inspire and motivate their teammates. They can show other players how to have fun and how to work hard to achieve their goals. This confidence and arrogance is also something that can be passed on to the fans. The Habs' young players are an inspiration to the fans and can give them hope that their team can reach new heights. Fans can see that their players are confident and ready for the challenge and this can encourage them to support their team. Finally, this confidence and arrogance are qualities that can be passed on to other teams. The Habs' young players are an example to other teams and can show them how to have fun and how to work hard to achieve their goals. Other teams can see that the Habs are a team that is willing to take on the challenge and this can encourage them to work harder to achieve their goals. In short, the confidence and arrogance of the Habs' young players are qualities that can be passed on to everyone around them. These qualities can help the team reach new heights and can inspire and motivate other players, fans and other teams.

titre: LNH : Nicolas Beaudin détient les atouts pour jouer à droite avec le Canadien
texte: Last season, Nicolas Beaudin only had two short games in the NHL. When he was limited to 71 seconds of action in the second game, it became more than obvious that a trade was in order. The change in the Chicago Blackhawks' staff quickly sent the 2018 first-round pick (27th overall) tumbling down the team's pecking order. No wonder the five-foot-11, 188-pound Beaudin clan is welcoming the new start. "Yes, Nicolas needed a change of scenery as they say in the field hockey world. [...] Since the Habs are rebuilding, it gives him a chance to showcase his talents," admitted André Ruel, his agent and Pat Brisson's right-hand man in Quebec. Being left-handed, his new destination surprised many Canadiens fans. However, it's a safe bet that Beaudin will be able to showcase his strengths by playing right-handed. "He is more comfortable on that side. In my opinion, in the NHL, he will like playing on the right better than on the left. I think it will allow him to become a regular defenseman in the NHL. I think that's an avenue for the Habs to pursue," said Ruel, "His stick is becoming more effective, his reach is greater to the boards and that helps him a lot. He can play on the right side because his understanding of the game is high and he's good with the puck," the agent said. In Chicago, he just didn't fit into management's approach anymore. "Their new philosophy is to go with big defensemen. They even acquired (Jarred) Tinordi, who had been on I don't know how many teams. In short, you could see that the style of defenseman like Nicolas was less popular. He was falling a little bit in a vacuum, there were more or less chairs for him in relation to the way he played", added Ruel. When a rebuilding team like the Hawks prefers to bet on Tinordi and a veteran like Jack Johnson, it's not easy to accept for a 23-year-old. Beaudin saw himself becoming an interesting cog in the Hawks' wheel this season. "As soon as he arrived at training camp, he was kind of relegated to the back end of the lineup, starting as the seventh or eighth defenseman," Ruel said. The message from the Hawks was that they felt Beaudin needed to do a better job of using his stick to win duels, be more competitive in front of the net and have a greater sense of urgency on the ice. Beaudin was acquired by the Habs on October 28 and has already proven himself in the AHL. He was named the league's top defenseman in 2019-2020 and was named to the league's All-Star team twice. He was also named to the Canadian Junior Hockey League All-Star team in 2017-2018. Beaudin is a very versatile defenseman who can play both left and right. He is very skilled with the puck and has good vision. He is also very good in duels and knows how to move around the ice. He is very good at rebounding and knows how to position himself to block shots. Beaudin is a very promising defenseman and he has all the qualities to become a regular defenseman in the NHL. He has the potential to become a very reliable defenseman and could help the Habs get back on track. He is very young and still has a lot to learn, but he has all the qualities to become a very reliable defenseman and could help the Habs get back on track.

titre: Alouettes : Noel Thorpe poursuit parfois le travail jusque dans le sous-sol de Danny Maciocia
texte: Soccer coaches practically sleep in the office. For the Alouettes, work sometimes continues at Danny Maciocia's house as defensive coordinator Noel Thorpe lives in his good friend's basement. Since Thorpe was brought in to take over the defensive unit in the middle of the season, he chose the option of staying with Maciocia, the interim general manager and head coach. In addition to the hours invested in the soccer operations headquarters at Olympic Stadium, Maciocia and Thorpe were able to continue discussions at home to help implement a new defensive system. Thorpe was a bit surprised that Maciocia made the confidence during an interview with BPM Sports, but he took it all in stride. "The vast majority of the preparation is done in the offices at Olympic Stadium. Anyway, when we leave the office, it's pretty late, it's time to go rest a little bit," he commented to RDS.ca. That was especially true during the regular season, but when the playoffs start, Maciocia and Thorpe presumably struggle to find other things to talk about. Last Sunday, in the Eastern semifinal triumph over Hamilton, it was felt that Thorpe had found an ideal aggressive approach to handcuffing the Tiger-Cats. Maciocia was keen for his defense to do just that. This week, there will be plenty of discussion between Maciocia, Thorpe and all the other coaches as the Argonauts present a completely different challenge. "This is a completely different team. The offensive system is not the same at all. The defensive front relies mostly on four-man pressure, they're less likely to send pressure from the outside. You have to adjust and build a plan accordingly," agreed Maciocia. As for the aggressiveness against Hamilton, it will be interesting to see if the Birds are less bold. The Argos' aerial threat features several receivers while Hamilon was banking on Tim White. "The key is we can't leave them alone for several seconds. We have an idea of how much time we have to get to the quarterback," noted Maciocia as the Birds look to have another strong game for pressure on the opposing quarterback. "It's very important that we find other ways of what we showed last week," he said. On the defensive side of the ball, the Argonauts excel at throwing interceptions and quarterback Trevor Harris doesn't need to be told that the danger will be there. | The Alouettes have good reason to feel confident heading into the East final. With the arrival of Noel Thorpe, the defensive unit has undergone a dramatic transformation and was one of the main drivers of the win over Hamilton. Thorpe put together an aggressive defensive system that put the Tiger-Cats in trouble throughout the game. This week, Thorpe and Maciocia are working to adapt their system to the Argonauts' offense. "We have to find ways to adapt to the Argonauts' offense," Maciocia said. "We have to find ways to adapt to their offensive system and their defensive front." The Larks will also have to find ways to counter the Argonauts' aerial threat. "We have to find ways to make sure we don't leave the Argonauts' receivers alone for long periods of time," Maciocia said. "We have to find ways to make sure we are able to press the Argonauts' quarterback." The Alouettes are confident that Thorpe and Maciocia will be able to find ways to counter the Argonauts' offense and put them in trouble. With their aggressive defensive system and ability to adapt to different offenses, the Alouettes are ready to take on the Argonauts and try to win the East final.

titre: LCF : La défense des Alouettes a été dominée par les Argonauts
texte: "Defensively, we didn't do our part. We take it on ourselves, it's not the kind of game we wanted to play. It's disappointing to finish this way." Marc-Antoine Dequoy is used to giving fans the straight goods, and he didn't shy away from it in an interview with colleague Didier Orméjuste after the Montreal Alouettes were eliminated in the Eastern final. Without having to deconstruct the game, it is obvious that the Montreal defense was exploited by the Toronto Argonauts. Quarterback McLeod Bethel-Thompson came close to 300 air yards and had seven different targets that bothered the Birds. Even ball carriers Andrew Harris and A.J. Ouellette caught passes that paid off big time. "We didn't play those plays well, that explains our frustration on the sidelines. We need to do a better job of that," Danny Maciocia said of those sequences. As for the major mistake on DaVaris Daniels' touchdown, left alone on the sidelines on a second down and a yard, Maciocia spelled out some details. "We got trapped on a turnover on defense. Wes (Sutton) had been injured the previous game and he hadn't been replaced during the change," Maciocia said as defensive coordinator Noel Thorpe - who is often tipped to replace Maciocia as head coach - had delegated a different combination of players to stop what was supposed to be a quarterback sneak. Once the disappointment wears off, the Alouettes will have to slam themselves on watching this game. Particularly on the defensive side of the ball, some of the footage will raise eyebrows. "We'll watch the video when we're ready to watch it, it's going to hurt for a little bit so it's going to take some time to do that," admitted offensive lineman Kristian Matte. Despite the loss, the Alouettes can take solace in the fact that they had an outstanding season. After finishing the regular season with an 11-7 record, they won their first playoff game since 2014 and reached the East finals for the first time since 2014. The Larks showed great strength and determination throughout the season and were able to compete with the best teams in the league. Despite the disappointment of the loss, the Alouettes can look back and be proud of their season. They showed great strength and determination and were able to compete with the best teams in the league. The Alouettes also showed great cohesion and togetherness, which was essential to their success. The Alouettes were also able to rely on their key players, including quarterback Vernon Adams Jr., pass catcher Eugene Lewis and defensive back Tommie Campbell. The Alouettes can also take solace in the fact that they had a remarkable season and showed great strength and determination. They can also take solace in the fact that they did their best and were able to compete with the best teams in the league. The Alouettes can also take solace in the fact that they showed great cohesion and solidarity and were able to rely on their key players. The Alouettes can also take comfort in the fact that they had a remarkable season and did their best to achieve their goals.

titre: Canadiens : la série de deux victoires prend fin avec une défaite de 4 à 0 face aux Sharks
texte: To say that the Canadiens missed their chances against the San Jose Sharks would be an understatement. Finishing the night 0 for 6 on the power play, it was hard to avoid a setback. The Sharks took advantage of this situation and left the Bell Centre with a 4-0 win. Here are our observations from this particular matchup. Trailing 1-0 after 40 minutes of action, the Habs had a chance to go into the final period five-on-three for 55 seconds. Presumably, the second intermission served as a laboratory to identify strategies to break through the Sharks' shorthanded wall. The CH could not solve the puzzle and was shut out in the final score. It was only the second time this season that Montreal failed to score. "We had a plan, but we didn't really execute it, we looked disorganized," said Martin St-Louis. "The power play let us down... We need to be able to score when we get six chances, one of which is five on three. We'll have to go back to the drawing board and see what happened," reacted Nick Suzuki. "We had a little meeting (at the second intermission), discussed the plan. We tried to force a shot when we were running out of time. We should have executed our attempt earlier. We talked about some other specific things, but we kind of drifted away from it for reasons I don't know. We'll have to talk to the guys about that," Suzuki said. Even worse, the Sharks built on that momentum by putting two more goals in Jake Allen's cage in a span of 75 seconds (Tomas Hertl and Logan Couture). Instead of tying the score, the Tricolore found themselves in a 3-0 deficit four minutes into the third period and the fans had little faith in the comeback. A strange night for Allen Allen was hoping this game would help him get out of his slump. His goal took a hit in the 93rd second as the Sharks threaded the needle early. Matt Nieto pushed the puck behind Allen on the return of a well-executed spinner by Alexander Barabanov. Allen would need help from Joel Edmundson who didn't watch Nieto properly. "It's never easy for a team, but it wasn't his fault. He's a pro, he knows how he can play," Matheson said. Allen was able to rally during the Sharks' power play threats as they took a 7-0 lead in shots in the first period. Surprisingly, the Sharks disappeared from the map after that. The Habs unleashed eight straight shots while San Jose did not test Allen for an interminable 19 minutes and 19 seconds. The statistics now show that Allen has allowed at least three goals in eight of his last nine starts. Despite the loss, the Habs showed a good attitude and a will to win. They showed determination and perseverance throughout the game, even though the Sharks were more effective. The Habs had several opportunities to score, but were unable to capitalize on them. The Sharks were more aggressive and were able to exploit the Habs' mistakes to score goals. The Sharks also had a very effective power play, which allowed them to take the lead. The Habs tried to fight until the end, but they were unable to turn the tide. The loss is a lesson for the Habs and they will have to learn from their mistakes to be more effective in the future.

titre: LAH : On ne plaisante plus chez le Rocket (Chronique d'Éric Leblanc)
texte: Seven wins in 23 games, 94 goals conceded, six games with six or more goals allowed. It was understandable that coach Jean-Francois Houle was less patient when his team returned to practice after a five-game road trip. Without attending the majority of the Laval Rocket's practices, it was easy to understand that Houle was not laughing on Wednesday morning at Place Bell. Every drill had been prepared to work on puck battles and the intensity had to be there. And if the message wasn't clear yet, it became clear when Houle threw a resounding "Take the f...ing hit" to defenseman Nicolas Beaudin. "Our job is to get them to the NHL. If we don't correct their shortcomings, they're not going to get better. Like I told (William) Trudeau, I'm going to be tough on him because you can't get beat one on one at this level. I'm going to do the same thing with Beaudin and I've been doing it in this practice. It's part of my job," Houle said. The final touch was the famous line drill to insist that the effort needs to go up a few notches from here on out. "It's important not to accept losing," Houle said, explaining the mood of the session. "We have to play harder on defense and that's why we raised the tone today. We need to play harder on defense and that's why we got tough today, so the guys know we mean business," he said. Captain Alex Belzile was pleased with the approach after the 7-5, 6-3 losses this weekend. "With our performances lately, it wasn't out of context to have a practice like this. Sometimes it sets the record straight. When you don't win games night in and night out, there are consequences and that's okay," said Belzile, who returned to action Saturday in Abbotsford. "The message is we have to practice the way we want to play. This is too tough a league to settle for a partial effort or an every other night effort. Consistency has been our problem since the beginning of the season and it's something that is addressed first in practice. I'm on board with that, I'm all for it," he said. The striker Peter Abbandonato also gave his approval. "We all want to win, that's why we're here. So for sure, with only seven wins, JF and the other coaches want us to play harder," noted Abbandonato, who has seven goals and eight assists in 17 games. When a team struggles to break out of the same bad patterns after 20 games, it's rare that the coach doesn't come under fire. | It's at that point that the players have to take responsibility and live up to expectations. "It's up to us to adapt and improve. We have to be more disciplined and more focused defensively. We have to be more aggressive and smarter with our movement," Belzile said. titre: LAH : Peter Abbandonato surpasse les attentes avec le Rocket de Laval
texte: In the space of a few months, Peter Abbandonato went from the Trois-Rivières Lions, to a reserve role with the Laval Rocket, to becoming one of the best forwards in the Canadiens' training camp. Frankly, Rocket officials didn't anticipate that the 24-year-old could excel in the top-six where he's been used frequently in recent weeks. "No, you never plan for that. You make threesomes in your head, and sometimes some players outperform the plan. Like him and (Xavier) Simoneau. They deserve their playing time," praised head coach Jean-François Houle. Abbandonato, who has watched the first four games from the stands, is fourth in scoring for the Rocket behind Anthony Richard, Jesse Ylönen and Simoneau. With 15 points (seven goals and eight assists) in 17 games, he trails only Richard in points per game average. "We have a slogan above our door that says 'Seize your opportunity' and he did. When we opened the door for him, it didn't close. He's excellent offensively and he produces. Whether he's on the first or fourth line, the plays come with him. I'm very happy for Peter, he's outperforming other players," said Houle. When your team has been on a tear all season, it's not easy to talk about your personal success. Abbandonato approached the subject in the same way his career has evolved: without aiming for flamboyance. "I had my chance to get into the lineup and it's been going well since then. Knock on wood," he commented, pretending to bang his head. But I want to win games with my team and get back to the atmosphere of last year's playoffs. It was pretty crazy and really fun." His teammate, friend and mentor in his own time, Alex Belzile, made sure to give him the praise he deserves. "He's an extremely efficient guy who can play wing and center. He's good offensively and defensively. He's kind of always had that kind of track record. Even at the junior level, he's gone his own way without moving much air. But he progresses every year and he really came out of his shell at 20 years old", recalled Belzile as Abbandonato amassed 111 points (36 more than the previous year) with the Rouyn-Noranda Huskies. "I talk to him a lot and I really like how he plays. He has a great head for field hockey", said the captain who also had to go through the ECHL before settling in the AHL. Without being the biggest guy (five feet ten inches and 194 pounds), nor the fastest or the one with the best shot, Abbandonato excels in many areas. From our perception, he is a master at gauging space and time with his opponents to find openings to exploit. Abbandonato has also shown great maturity and attitude towards his teammates and head coach. "He's very professional and he's very respectful to everyone," Houle said. "He is very open to learning and he is very conscientious. He's very good at listening and applying what he's told." titre: Alouettes/LCF : Jason Maas, une branche intense de l'arbre de Marc Trestman
texte: Jason Maas comes from Marc Trestman's "coaching tree", but the new Montreal Alouettes coach is a thousand times more intense on the sidelines. If you've never seen his "eruptions" of character as he describes them, this video is worth a thousand words. However, since those episodes as head coach in Edmonton, Maas has been relegated to an offensive coordinator role with the Saskatchewan Roughriders for the past three years. "My mood swings were discussed during the interview. I don't know if it came up with the others, but it was on the agenda for me," Maas replied, approaching the question with a smile. "I'm always going to stay true to my personality. I'm intense and you'll see my emotions. But I can assure you that I have thought long and hard about my reactions. Some players are going to understand me, but others are going to have doubts. I want to be a good example for the whole team. I've had three years to grow and learn. When I have a blowout, I will react differently. I can't promise it won't happen again, but you're going to see me differently," said the man who learned the trade under Scott Milanovich, one of Trestman's runners-up. Without missing a beat, general manager Danny Maciocia jumped at the chance to add this clarification. "We have an agreement in his contract that he'll pay for anything he breaks," Maciocia laughed as Maas didn't go easy on his headphones. But that's hardly a profile of the American, who hails from Wisconsin. He inherited the Alouettes' reins for two specific reasons: his leadership attributes and his knowledge of running an offense. "The fact that he's been a head coach before is a plus. In three of his four seasons in Edmonton, he made it to the association finals. We have a history together too. He was a player, but a coach on the field. I often told him that it was only a matter of time before he was a coach," said Maciocia. The Alouettes executive said he validated his opinion with several players and coaches who had been around him. "I spent an hour on the phone with Ricky Ray. He wanted to let me know what he thought of him. Mike Reilly, who I never managed, told me that his best three years were with Jason," said Maciocia, who sees him as the ideal candidate. "Jason is genuine, there's nothing wrong with him. We live in a particular society. Even with professionals, we sometimes tend to tell them what they want to hear and not give them the right information. That's not the case with him and the players like his sincerity. | Maas has demonstrated his ability to adapt to difficult situations. He has been able to adapt to various offensive systems and apply them successfully. He has also demonstrated his ability to adapt to different players and help them reach their full potential. He has also demonstrated the ability to adapt to difficult situations and find solutions to overcome them. In addition to his coaching skills, Maas is also an excellent communicator. He is able to communicate clearly and concisely with his players and coaches. He is also able to communicate with the media and provide them with accurate and relevant information. Maas is also an excellent manager. He is able to effectively manage the time and resources available to him. He is also able to manage conflicts and find solutions to resolve them. He is also able to manage the expectations of players and coaches and help them achieve their goals. Finally, Maas is an excellent leader. He is able to motivate his players and coaches and help them achieve their goals. He is also able to make tough decisions and implement them successfully. He is also able to lead his players and coaches and help them achieve their goals. In conclusion, Maas is an exceptional coach who has the skills and qualities necessary to succeed in Montreal. He is able to adapt to difficult situations, communicate clearly and manage his time and resources effectively. He is also an excellent leader who is able to motivate his players and coaches and help them achieve their goals. With Maas at the helm, the Alouettes are well positioned for success.

titre: LCF : André Bolduc croyait mériter sa chance de diriger les Alouettes de Montréal
texte: Last Saturday, André Bolduc was in Stoneham with his extended family to celebrate Christmas, early because of an upcoming trip. It was in this particular context that he learned that he had been preferred to Jason Maas to lead the Montreal Alouettes. "People saw my disappointment and it was a little awkward. It was like 'I didn't get the job, but we're having a good day anyway...'," Bolduc told RDS.ca, with his always appreciated candour. "It's not bitterness, but disappointment, as a Quebecer, not to have had the chance to get this job. I've seen so many other guys who got it on a silver platter and failed," said the soccer man who was convinced he was up to the task. One of the reasons he felt ready was that during his nine years on the Alouettes' staff, he had weathered the storms and endured the odd decision with seven head coaches. After being part of the process to inherit the title, he couldn't imagine staying with an eighth immediate boss. "I would say 80 percent of the population would have done the same thing. I couldn't sit in my little office and keep doing the same job. Until what?" said Bolduc, who was quickly hired by the Saskatchewan Roughriders as the ground attack coordinator. "This challenge will be good for me too," added the 51-year-old coach who had nothing negative to say about Maas. With his knowledge of the business, Bolduc could only deduce what was next when the hiring process stretched on with the Alouettes. "During the second week, I was starting to feel like it wasn't going to be me. I was hopeful, but not as hopeful as the people around me," he admitted. "Jason has been a head coach for four seasons, so I definitely don't have that. But where else do you start? With nine years including three seasons as an assistant head coach, the experience is there. Nothing would have surprised me in this job in the off-season or in the season. Someone will have to give me the chance one day to gain that experience," Bolduc analyzed. If it didn't happen in Montreal, his expertise is recognized elsewhere as his new start has come at a rapid pace. Contacts were made with Khari Jones in Ottawa and his other friend Ryan Dinwiddie in Toronto. "But I was approached by another organization for other reasons. Kelly Jeffrey (the offensive coordinator) and Craig Dickenson (the head coach), they like the work I do. Dickenson even analyzed how I perform on the sidelines, so they knew a lot about me. Bolduc has always been passionate about soccer and has always been willing to take on new challenges. So he jumped at the opportunity to work with the Saskatchewan Roughriders and embark on a new chapter in his career. "I'm very excited about working with the Roughriders. I know I can make a significant contribution to the team and I can't wait to see what the future holds," he said. Bolduc is aware that the Montreal Alouettes have made their choice and he is willing to accept their decision. "I understand their decision and I respect their choice. I wish Jason Maas and the team all the best and I know they will do their best to achieve their goals," he said. Despite his disappointment, Bolduc is optimistic about his future and is ready for new challenges. "I am very excited to be working with the Roughriders and I know I can make a significant contribution to the team. I'm looking forward to what the future holds and I'm ready for new challenges," he concluded.

titre: CH : Sans Cole Caufield, le collectif fait avancer le train
texte: The Habs were already without a host of players, but the loss of Cole Caufield could have derailed things. Martin St-Louis used the train analogy to rally his players to the collective cause while Alex Belzile predicted Rem Pitlick's winning goal. The author of these lines will not inundate you with puns, but how can we avoid the allusion that the winning goal was scored by the one named Rem. While we are still waiting for the REM to be launched in the Montreal region, Pitlick found an opportune moment to score this important goal. "Belzile is great, I was looking forward to seeing him. It's great to know that he has confidence in me, we built a great chemistry together in Laval", reacted Pitlick when he heard Belzile's happy prediction. "I talk to the players a lot that we're trying to build a train. Guys are going to get on and off the train, but the guys that stay on the train have to take care of it. That's what we did in this game," the coach identified. "When I look around the roster, I can't find one that didn't give it their all. This result is a big step in the right direction," he added gratefully. Collective involvement was the only way to save things. "That's the way we have to look at it. If everyone answers the call, great things will happen. All the players contributed, it's encouraging, there's no doubt about it," testified Josh Anderson. Even though the athletes were very confident in their abilities, they knew that the Leafs were the favourites for this match-up. But hard work trumped talent in this game. "We're not stupid either, we knew the lineups. But it's played on the ice, it's too good a league to play only with talent", admitted Alex Belzile with frankness. "It's good for morale on a beautiful Saturday night like that against the Leafs. There was a great atmosphere," he added. titre: Super Bowl : Refonte réussie de la ligne offensive des Chiefs pour protéger Patrick Mahomes
texte: Three years ago, when the Kansas City Chiefs won the Super Bowl, Laurent Duvernay-Tardif was patrolling the right guard position. The Chiefs had to rebuild that crucial unit to protect Patrick Mahomes even though some would say he is skilled enough to handle himself. Mahomes' exploits not only fascinate fans, many players and coaches polled Monday night at media night still share that admiration. But to ensure his continued success, Chiefs officials made a move to rejuvenate the offensive line. It was a risky gamble in the early stages of the process, but it doesn't seem like it anymore. In addition to Joe Thuney, the veteran and two-time Super Bowl champion who solidified the left guard position, the Chiefs relied on succession. Orlando Brown Jr. was acquired to become the blocker at left, Creed Humphrey inherited the center role, Trey Smith replaced LDT and Andrew Wylie was moved to right blocker. "Our leaders are finding good athletes, but more importantly, good people. Young people who like to work and invest in their craft. We have a system and a standard that the guys are happy to adopt," said offensive line coach Andy Heck, who was happy to hear a hint of a French accent in the question. Crossing paths at various points on the Footprint Center floor, Wylie and Smith agreed with their position coach. "We get along really well together, I have a lot of love for these guys," noted Wylie, who had strolled with the Colts, Browns and Chargers in 2017 before getting the trust, which will have been key, from the Chiefs. "These guys are wonderful. From last year in my first season, the veteran group was great at teaching me how to perform. I still have a lot of work to do, but I'm thankful," said Smith with his impressive six foot six inch, 321 pound stature. This giant has shown that he can handle the job as a starter. Plus, as an offensive lineman, the fact that he misses very few games works in his favor. "Oh, he's incredible as a player. Not many athletes have that kind of impact at his age at that position. He's a physical specimen, I'm having a lot of fun around him," said Wylie. The Chiefs bet on the next generation of players and their gamble paid off. The young offensive linemen have shown great maturity and have adapted quickly to their new environment. They have shown great cohesion and excellent communication, which has allowed the team to develop and progress. The performances of these young players have been outstanding and their presence has been an asset to the Chiefs. They were able to protect Mahomes and provide him with the best protection possible. The Chiefs leadership has been very forward thinking and has been able to find the right players to replace the veterans. They were able to find talented players and integrate them into the team. The Chiefs were able to create a solid, consistent offensive line that allowed Mahomes to flourish and perform exceptionally well. The Chiefs were able to create an offensive line that lived up to expectations and helped the team win the Super Bowl.

titre: Super Bowl : À contrecoeur, Benjamin St-Juste favorise les Eagles pour vaincre les Chiefs
texte: On November 14, the Philadelphia Eagles were already looking forward to a ninth win in as many games when they met the Washington Commanders. Little did they know that Benjamin St-Juste would derail their plan with a key play. With less than six minutes left in the final quarter, St-Juste forced a fumble by tackling receiver Quez Watkins. The turnover allowed the Commanders to hold on to their lead and hand the Eagles their first loss. A month earlier, the 25-year-old Quebecer made another crucial play when he prevented Darnell Mooney of the Chicago Bears from scoring a touchdown on a fourth down and a yard to go late in the game. These are just two examples of how much St. Just has improved in his second season in the NFL. "I've made a lot of progress. I've developed as a player on and off the field. Getting into the NFL is a process, there's a lot to learn and I think I made a good jump in my second year. It's very promising for the next one," assessed the six foot three inch, 200 pound athlete. St. Just isn't wrong with that verdict and the Commanders proved it by giving him a starting cornerback position during the season. As a result, he competed against many of the NFL's most formidable receivers. "I'm very proud of the fact that I've consistently shown progress from week to week. In the NFL, it's very difficult, but I've adapted well to the change," said St-Juste, who traveled to Arizona to work with the RDS team and participate in events. For example, St-Juste and the Commanders had to compete against the Eagles on two occasions. As a result, St-Juste found himself covering A.J. Brown and DeVonta Smith quite often. "They're a team full of offensive weapons, they have key players all over the place. Brown and Smith gave me a lot of trouble in the two games against them. Brown helped me develop as a player, I had to be 100% against him. He's a very physical athlete who can catch balls over your head," commented the equally natural with a microphone in hand. "The key against the Eagles will be to limit explosive plays. Brown and Jalen Hurts really like to have a nice connection for long plays. If the Kansas City Chiefs can limit that, they'll have a better chance to win," he added. To complete long passes, however, Hurts will have to show he is recovered from his season-ending right shoulder injury. Since the start of the playoffs, the Eagles' air game has been less in demand due to their dominance. | Despite his preference for the Chiefs, St. Just believes the Eagles have the goods to win the Super Bowl. "The Eagles have a very good defense and a very complete offense. They have a good offensive line and a good ground game. They also have a good variety of receivers and a good quarterback. I think if they can maintain their air game and ground game, they can win the Super Bowl," he said. St. Just also noted that the Eagles have good team chemistry and a good mentality. "They have a good attitude and mentality. They are very unified and they work very hard. They are very disciplined and they are willing to give it their all to win. They have good team chemistry and they are very motivated," he added. St. Just also noted that the Eagles have good preparation and strategy. "They have good preparation and strategy. They know what they need to do and how to do it. They are very well prepared and they know how to play to their strengths and compensate for their weaknesses. They are very smart and they know how to play to their advantage," he concluded. With the right preparation, strategy and team chemistry, the Eagles are well positioned to win the Super Bowl. Only time will tell if St. Just was right.

titre: Alouettes : le directeur général Danny Maciocia revient sur l'actualité des dernières semaines
texte: You'd understand it if you didn't, but Danny Maciocia admits he considered leaving the Alouettes' nest in a moment of frustration over this other surreal chapter in the Montreal organization. "I did consider it at one point, but you really have to be careful when you find yourself in a state like that. I wondered about it for maybe 30 seconds while I was feeling frustrated," explained Maciocia who was slamming a recruiting trip as he saw the house of cards collapse around him. Because yes, for the second time since 2019, the Alouettes are under the tutelage of the Canadian Football League in order to sell the team to new owners. It was already a few months that the estate of Sid Spiegel (who owned 75% of the club) and Gary Stern (shareholder at 25%) were trying to attract local investors or sell the team. The sale option became the most logical, but the process dragged on and the CFL took over the rights to the team in order to speed up the process. Since nothing is done easily in the CFL, this phase of uncertainty occurred in the crucial period leading up to the opening of the free agent market. This left Maciocia with his hands tied while his counterparts were spending. "It's been going on for a few weeks (since then). At one point, I got an email saying I couldn't spend any more money, so that's when the frustration and other questions went through my head," the general manager said Wednesday. Fortunately, Maciocia knew that this constraint would lead to the club's transfer to the CFL. "I had to be patient, but for sure, every day it got a little bit heavier," he admitted. Like many fans, Maciocia has wondered several times why this process didn't conclude sooner. He doesn't have time to think about it now, but he understands the dismay felt by those who care about the Alouettes. "I could only imagine what our fans were going through during that time. I grew up in this organization, volunteering there in 1996 and 1997. When I look at all the players who come from Quebec, who get scholarships in the United States or who make a living from soccer, I am more than convinced that there is a place for a CFL team in Montreal," he commented. "It's given me the juice to keep fighting with the staff in all departments. There is good news coming and we were able to save some furniture (players) on the soccer side," continued the GM. That more positive tangent began Tuesday morning at 9:00 a.m. when Maciocia received confirmation that the CFL was in control of the rest of the process, allowing him to close deals with a few players like Walter Fletcher, Greg Ellingson and Jumal Rolle. | Maciocia was able to focus on recruiting and ensure the Alouettes remain competitive despite the circumstances. "We were able to recruit players that will help us achieve our goals. We were able to keep players that are important to the team and we were able to recruit players that will help us achieve our goals," he said. "We are very happy with what we were able to accomplish and we are ready to move into the 2021 season." Despite all the uncertainties, Maciocia is optimistic about the Alouettes' future. "We are very excited to work with the new owners and build a team that will be competitive and make the city of Montreal proud," he said. "We are looking forward to what the future holds and are ready for the challenge." Maciocia also stressed the importance of the Montreal community to the Alouettes' success. "We are very grateful to the fans who have supported us during this difficult time and we hope they will continue to support us in the future," he said. "We look forward to seeing the fans fill the stadium and hearing them cheer for the team." Maciocia concluded by saying he was happy to see the Alouettes are on the verge of a new era. "We are very excited to work with the new owners and build a team that will be competitive and make the city of Montreal proud," he said. "We look forward to what the future holds and are ready for the challenge."

Anonymous, efficient and well connected, XOXO. With twists and turns every 15 minutes. And honestly, this collection of compromising screenshots and incriminating stories made for one of the best, most embarrassing, but oh so captivating episodes of Quebec reality TV. From day to day, juicy info came out on OD Scoop: falsified PCR tests with Vaseline in the nose, a slew of complaints to the Mexican hotel where the noisy group was staying, bravado towards the media, these touristatas were sinking before our eyes, completely unaware of the consequences of their actions. Seriously, what were these night owls thinking when they boarded the Sunwing Air Cabochon charter flight on December 30? The images first relayed by OD Scoop, and then picked up by Le Journal de Montréal, leave no room for interpretation. Exalted passengers are vaping, dancing in the aisle, jumping from one bench to another, screaming like lost souls, bodysurfing, chugging Grey Goose, dangerous actions that would have amply justified an emergency landing, it seems to me. At this level of stupidity and recklessness, the lack of a mask and the spread of COVID-19 in the cabin become minor offenses on the long list of infractions committed in a few hours of flight. And the most absurd thing is that our amigos themselves published the videos of their party in the air. Live by social media, perish by social media. Boomerang of karma. Our national pride ended up on the home pages of the popular TMZ or Daily Mail sites. A real shame. "Duct tape and tie wraps work wonders in similar cases. And where were the security people on that plane?", TMZ asks, correctly. Transport Canada is already investigating the case. So is Sunwing. Like Air Canada, Air Transat refused Wednesday to repatriate the partygoers who were trying to return to Quebec. Until the conclusion of the Transport Canada investigation, these people "will not be able to fly with us unless some of the members of this group provide very convincing evidence that they did not participate in this disgraceful and illegal event," explains Air Transat spokesperson Marie-Christine Pouliot. According to her, "this type of behavior is unacceptable on our wings". But let's get back to the OD Scoop Instagram account, which lit the first match in this story that ignited Quebec. For the past six months, this page has been revealing exclusive info and leaks, which have notably angered the production team of Occupation double in the West. It is very rare that OD Scoop is wrong. It relies on reliable and connected informants. "What I publish, I double and triple check. I receive thousands of messages a day and I have to make sure they are credible," explains the person in charge of the OD Scoop account, a young man of 33 who refuses to reveal his identity. A bit like La Clique du Plateau (the website) in 2009. Or like the TV show Gossip Girl, which operates in the same way. Before Christmas, OD Scoop had 35,000 subscribers. As of early Wednesday evening, more than 141,000 people were following the account, whose popularity exploded with the saga of the cuckoo's nest in Tulum. Precisely, who are they, these reality TV participants who have stretched their five minutes of fame? We agree that they are not the cream of the influencers, far from it. We're talking about players from very minor leagues. From Noovo's reality show Occupation Double South Africa, there was Karl Sabourin, whose most important feat was to popularize the phrase "this is our home". Also from OD South Africa, we reconnected with Dragos Calistru, who is pursuing a local DJ career. TVA's Love Island provided a trio of champions in model Anna-Maëlle Laprise, influencer Sandrine Séguin and airplane pilot Isabelle Labrecque. Yes, there was a pilot in that plane that didn't seem to have one. In Tulum, publications also show Anthony Jackson-Hamel, a former Impact player who also recycled himself as a DJ. In islander language, I "slid into the DMs" of all these Nobel Prize winners and no one answered me. As they say to the Señor Frog of Cancún: "Never give up, bro. The organizer of the Air Cabochon fiasco, James William Awad, a 28-year-old from Laval also known as Senior Artist, declined to be interviewed. He chirped that "it was worth it" before taking down his post and writing that he was taking the situation seriously, that he would try to sort it all out. The return to reality for these poor man's influencers may be a lot harder than a day after a spicy margarita night. And the fines hanging over their heads won't be able to be sponsored.

titre: The Gilded Age | C’est Downton Abbey à New York et c’est bon
texte: Polish the family silver, tighten the corsets, slip on the elbow-length satin gloves and brew tea in the finest china in the house, because it's time to fall under the lavish spell of The Gilded Age, the new period drama from Downton Abbey creator Julian Fellowes. There will be no hiding here: The Gilded Age, which comes out this Monday in English on Crave and in French on Super Écran, is exactly like Downton Abbey, but in New York City, in 1882. The dramatic violins that punctuate the opening credits, the twisted relationships between servants and employers, the crucial importance of social rank, the lavish parties of the privileged castes, the repressed homosexuality of a pivotal character, as well as the money, always the money: The Gilded Age will serve up all the luxurious ingredients of Downton Abbey, but in a less sultry version. The soapy side of Downton Abbey has been toned down in The Gilded Age, which is wiser. At least in the first three episodes (out of a total of nine) that I have seen. The first episode alone is a bit watered down and lasts almost an hour and a half without commercial breaks, the length of a movie. Despite a few cringing crinolines, this is very good television, both intelligent and entertaining, with a princely budget. Everything sparkles in this charming production, from the gorgeous costumes to the acting, including the wonderful Christine Baranski (The Good Fight), who reprises a role similar to that of the unforgettable Dowager Countess Violet Crawley (Maggie Smith) from Downton Abbey. In The Gilded Age, Christine Baranski plays the overbearing widow Agnes van Rhijn, who lives with her "spinster" sister Ada (Cynthia Nixon) in a splendid mansion east of Central Park. Agnes van Rhijn represents old New York money, the kind that has been passed down from family to family for generations. Agnes and her wealthy friends - very boring too, let's face it - form the aristocracy of the late 19th century and control the most important institutions in the city. Nothing is more vulgar in their eyes than the new rich called Rockefeller or Vanderbilt, whom the Industrial Revolution has made richer. No class, frankly. But, surprise, a couple of these upstart bourgeois move into a huge palace - what a lack of taste! - built across the street from where the van Rhijns live. They are George Russell (Morgan Spector) and his wife Bertha Russell (Carrie Coon). George has made a fortune in railroad construction. His wife Bertha is working hard to break into the tight circle of upper class ladies. George and Bertha Russell are a formidable pair. They are ambitious, united and cruel. They will stop at nothing in their quest for social recognition. The excellent third episode, which has an air of Succession, shows how far the Russells will go to punish the good society that has rejected them. The other agent of change in the miniseries is Marian Brook, played by Meryl Streep's youngest daughter, Louisa Jacobson. A penniless orphan, Marian arrives at her aunts Ada and Agnes van Rhijn's house with "progressive" ideas like wanting to marry a man she loves and not finding a good match with the right last name. Insert sigh of discouragement from Aunt Agnes here. Marian also brings to New York her new African-American friend Peggy Scott (Denée Benton), who dreams of becoming a writer. An unattainable profession "for a colored woman" in 1882. Yes, I would have taken more of the scandalous elements from The Gilded Age. But, hey. When the crystal shines so brightly, we won't start rubbing the glassware unnecessarily like a Marie-Chantal Toupin on a kitchen counter in Big Brother. SCREEN CAPTURE OF THE SHOW Stéphane Fallu on Big Brother Celebrity Comedian Stéphane Fallu really didn't stand a chance on Big Brother Celebrity on Noovo. He was targeted, ostracized and sacrificed only because he entered the house a week too late. It was really distressing, borderline pathetic, to see all his housemates ganging up on him for no good reason. The boss of the week, the youtuber Pierre-Luc Cloutier, even spoke of a great "injustice". Let's see. Comedian and artist Tranna Wintour, the last contestant to catch COVID-19, left the house to live out her seclusion in a hotel. Will she be punished upon her return because she spent several days less in the adventure than the others? Poor Stéphane Fallu. He was pitiful in front of host Marie-Mai. The comedian tried very hard not to denigrate the other candidates, including Guylaine Guay, who got her head, but you could feel that he had a lot on his mind. After his eviction on Sunday night, France Beaudoin asked him on Twitter if he would sit in the chair of Radio-Canada's En direct de l'univers. He said yes. We also saw on Sunday night that the next target of the reality TV majority alliance is called Valérie Carpentier, who seems to be in a very bad way, poor girl. Why don't the people in power in Big Brother try to take out dominant contestants like Martin Vachon or Guylaine Guay? It's easy to target Stéphane Fallu or Valérie Carpentier. It's easy, predictable and very cowardly.

titre: Archive 81 | Les vidéocassettes du diable
texte: There are more and more series that deal with the supernatural and horror, and that's good. Cop shows, lawyer shows and doctor shows are great, but popular titles like Yellowjackets and Squid Game show the voracious appetite of television viewers for genre productions slathered in fright and terror. You won't be screaming in terror every five seconds in Archive 81, Netflix's new satanic-tinged horror series, whose popularity is swelling thanks to favorable word of mouth. Instead, the eight hour-long episodes, offered in both English and French, trigger a sneaky paranoia, slowly but surely seeping into our coconuts. After the fourth hour, I was ready to hold a Ouija board while speaking Latin, my eyes rolling back, foaming at the mouth. That's how bewitched I was. As the episodes progress, the division between past and present becomes more and more blurred. The nightmare encroaches on reality. And fear screws into our minds to a background of Amityville music. Archive 81 follows young archivist Dan Turner (Mamoudou Athie), a tape restoration specialist, who accepts a lucrative and mysterious contract. A billionaire (Martin Donovan) entrusts him with a box of videotapes that were rescued from a fire in a landmark Manhattan building. These damaged tapes were shot in the spring of 1994 by a young documentary filmmaker, Melody Pendras (Dina Shihabi), who was preparing a thesis on the building's inhabitants, each one stranger than the next. The billionaire installs Dan in a bunker in the countryside to clean up the analog equipment without distraction, WiFi or cellular network. Isolated and psychologically fragile, Dan pushes the first videotape into the VCR and plunges into the creepy world of the building's residents, under the sway of a demonic entity. Mephistophelian rituals, seances and satanic symbols, terrible things happen in these apartments, especially on the sixth floor, the cursed floor. Without giving anything away, Dan will discover a direct link between his own life and those of the 1994 spectres that parade on his monitor. PHOTO CLIFTON PRESCOD/NETFLIX Dina Shihabi plays the Melody Pendras character that Dan discovers in the videotapes. Archive 81 contains notes from The Blair Witch Project (the unstable video camera), The Ring (stare intently at the images on TV) and The Shining (for the residence with the long corridors). Horror fans will also detect touches of Rosemary's Baby. Back to the plot, the billionaire who hired Dan to retrieve the famous video archive is hiding his game. What exactly is he looking for? Why does he know Dan's detailed medical history? What is he hiding in the labyrinthine house where he has installed our good Dan? And beyond the paranormal, this is also a TV series about childhood trauma and mental illness. Warning, though. Archive 81 moves at a slower pace than a series like American Horror Story. It's hypnotic as a proposition. And like the protagonist obsessed with ghosts from the past, we sink into a state of acute distrust. It's watching with the lights off, with a bunch of lit candles, one of which is placed in the center of a circle, obviously. The plot of Radio-Canada's Une autre histoire jumped a year on Monday night, giving a nice boost to Chantal Cadieux's soap opera, which will be off the air for good this spring. The jump in time allowed viewers to see that Sébastien's (Benoît McGinnis) Alzheimer's has progressed dramatically, while Manon/Anémone's (Marina Orsini) condition has deteriorated, never more so than her son's. The scenes of confusion and absence played by Benoît McGinnis and Marina Orsini were striking. These moments could have turned into caricatures and sketches. They were full of truth, especially when Sébastien did not recognize his brother Jean-Olivier (Adam Kosh) and when Anémone started a striptease in front of her family. We felt perfectly the distress of the characters. PHOTO TAKEN FROM THE SHOW'S FACEBOOK PAGE Emilien (Patrice Godin) and Maryse (Marie-Laurence Moreau), characters in Une autre histoire In Belleville, Maryse (Marie-Laurence Moreau) and Emilien (Patrice Godin) form a beautiful couple. An unlikely couple, but well matched. Let's not forget that Émilien, a former lover of Anémone, gave a child to her daughter Karla (Marilou Morin), who is now dating Vincent (Sébastien Ricard), Maryse's ex-boyfriend. Jean-Olivier's former flame, the unstable Bianka (Élizabeth Duperré) is officially dating her half-brother Simon (Mikhaïl Ahooja). Follow closely here. Bianka is the daughter of Patricia (Marie Turgeon), who was long married to Ron (Vincent Graton), who has returned to live with Manon/Anémone, Simon's mother. I love writer Chantal Cadieux for this: she has fun with the codes of soap opera and assumes it. Oh yes, RIP to the character of the evil Valaire (Steve Banner), Caroline's biological father - he raped Manon/Anémone back then, remember. That same Caroline (Debbie Lynch-White) finally discovered that the father of her murdered half-sister Mona (Marie-Évelyne Baribeau) was not the villainous Valaire but... Ron! Everything stays in the family at Blanchette-Leduc-Romero-Petterson.

titre: Un diagnostic de fièvre olympique
texte: Every two years, a global virus sweeps through our couch potato bodies and manifests itself in the form of big chills, heart arrhythmias, uncontrollable tears and guttural screams worthy of Louis Cyr lifting a 4092 pound platform with his back. It's Olympic fever, which bites hard and shortens our nights by several hours. Do you suffer from it? I do, badly. This stuff is even more contagious than... ah, what the heck, leave it to the gags of COVID-19. No longer able to hear them. Now here's how to diagnose this five-ringed global virus (positively). You'll be crying even more than usual in front of your screen. Because the golden journey of 27-year-old snowboarder Maxence Parrot beats any Hollywood sports movie. What an inspiring story, featuring a likeable Bromont athlete knocked out by cancer three years ago and crushing all his opponents. You can't make this stuff up. PHOTO MARTIN CHAMBERLAND, LA PRESSE Justine Dufour-Lapointe couldn't suppress her tears after falling in the final moguls event. You cry even more in the defeat of our darling representatives. Justine Dufour-Lapointe's heartbreaking fall in the moguls, her sister Chloe consoling her, but most of all, the honest and moving interview Justine gave at the bottom of the hill resulted in a magnificent demonstration of humility and courage. You can understand - without judging - why analyst Marianne St-Gelais also shed tears after skater Kim Boutin's sparkling bronze medal in the 500m. It was a poignant moment at the Beijing Olympics, not to mention the elegance and eloquence of silver medalist Mikaël Kingsbury, another champion with a heart of gold. What class! For the past week, you've been talking to "we" with a Canadian pride that surprises you. We won a medal in mixed team ski jumping! We beat the Americans in women's field hockey! We should buy a red scarf embroidered with the letters CACA! PHOTO MARTIN CHAMBERLAND, LA PRESSE Team Canada flag bearers Marie-Philip Poulin and Charles Hamelin entering the stadium with their Canada scarves partially legible... You think about recording Alain Goldberg's whispered comments at figure skating for a future ASMR video. It's hypnotic and mesmerizing until a triple lutz and he yells: RE-U-SSI!
