You became bilingual faster than with Duolingo by watching the slopestyle and big air events on Radio-Canada. Backside double cork 1260 or triple cork 1620, not to mention the safety catch or the goofy position, these technical expressions will eventually have French equivalents, one day. I agree with you: this English-speaking slopestyle vocabulary is a real eardrum-buster. The Office québécois de la langue française (OQLF) suggests translations like frontside air, backside, corkscrew and goofy. Who will dare to use them on air? PHOTO MARTIN CHAMBERLAND, LA PRESSE Kim Boutin won the bronze medal in short track skating. You suddenly feel like getting up at the crack of dawn, or training in the middle of the night with a headlamp, to get that feeling of accomplishment so well portrayed in the Petro-Canada ads. These symptoms won't last, rest assured. You'll find urban poetry in the Chernobyl-like, disused industrial setting where the big jump events take place. These grey chimneys and cooling towers are very brutalist in their approach, you say in the tone of a Sunday art critic wearing Denis Gagnon clothes. You feel the need to have your coffee with Jacinthe Taillon, Dominick Gauthier and Hassoun Camara, who always have intelligent and relevant discussions. A medal for them. You flick frantically and wonder why Radio-Canada doesn't post the names of featured sportscasters and analysts more often. It's very rare that you follow a competition from the beginning, where the host identifies the commentators, to the end. This little reminder - in mortise - would be nice. PHOTO MARTIN CHAMBERLAND, LA PRESSE The Canadian women's team had several sparkling wins, including this 11-1 victory over Switzerland. You've discovered the existence of RDS2, a channel you've been subscribing to for ages, but rarely tune into. Hello, RDS2. You've renewed your gym membership, which reopens Monday. Your new set of gym clothes is already picked out. These euphoric symptoms won't last, unfortunately. You become an expert in highly technical sports within five minutes. Skier X misjudged the turn before entering the bowl! Skater Y didn't complete the rotation of her triple axel, come on! The Italians will be unbeatable in curling this year! You feel like moving, putting on the pipe skates, going outside or going down a mountain, that's the most magical effect of this Olympic fever. Enjoy it. Because this alpine buzz will fade in about ten days. Go, go, go. This shout of encouragement is brought to you by (name of a popular credit card). Back in the studio with Marie-José Turcotte.

titre: District 911
texte: It was during the night, on a Sunday, in the fall of 2006. The phone rang at 3 a.m. at the home of Fabienne Larouche, who was then writing and producing the daily Virginie for Radio-Canada. On the other end of the line, the spouse of an actor from the series: "It's to tell you that [name of the actor in question] will not be in the studio in a few hours. He attempted suicide and has been admitted to hospital. Fabienne Larouche jumped out of bed and threw herself on her computer to rework an entire episode of Virginie between 3:00 and 6:30 a.m. The actor in question, who fortunately pulled through, appeared in two-thirds of the scenes in the episode, which began filming on Monday at 7 a.m., four hours after he was admitted to the hospital. Not knowing when the actor would recover, Fabienne Larouche rewrote the script in a hurry so that the shooting of Virginie would continue without the hospitalized actor. The actors of the show learned their new texts - fresh from the printer - in the make-up room or on their lunch hour. And the episode was wrapped up without the viewers noticing the drama that had taken place behind the scenes. Parenthetically: no, this actor was not part of the main cast of Virginia. He had landed an important episodic role. "I remember that day very well. I've been writing or producing a daily show at Radio-Canada for 26 years and, yes, I've seen some things. When the unexpected happens, it's the strength of the group that counts. When everyone gets together, it moves mountains," says author and producer Fabienne Larouche. PHOTO ALAIN ROBERGE, ARCHIVES LA PRESSE Producer Fabienne Larouche The production of a daily series imposes this infernal work rhythm, which does not allow any respite to the craftsmen and does not tolerate any delay. The rocket train leaves the station at breakneck speed and only stops at the final destination. Any delay costs tens of thousands of dollars, which the already shrinking budgets of these soap operas obviously do not allow. Author Luc Dionne experienced a similar moment on February 2nd. It was a Wednesday. One of the star actors of his daily show District 31 had tested positive for COVID-19. This actor from the core of the police series played in almost all the scenes that the District 31 team had to put in the can in the coming days. Without him, it was impossible to shoot the episodes as they were written by Luc Dionne. What to do with such a case of District 911? Luc Dionne, the bosses of Radio-Canada and the producers Fabienne Larouche and Michel Trudeau, from Aetios, considered suspending the broadcast of District 31 during the Beijing Olympics, while the sick actor heals. The problem is that District 31 never takes a break. It's our television flagship. The viewing habit is firmly established at 7 p.m. among fans. We had to keep going. But how? Luc Dionne rewrote four episodes in three days, twice as fast as his usual intense pace. The scripts were delivered the day before to the actors, who had to memorize them even faster than usual. The episodes in question aired this week and will run until the end of next week. Did you notice a difference? I didn't. Yes, it's been rockin' and rollin', but that's part of the job. You have no idea how much work went into post-production and editing. Luc Dionne So we had to weave a quilt with the plots that had already been started, bring back characters to make up for the absence of the covidated actor, and postpone plots that had not been resolved. In short, it was a hyper-complex puzzle that was put together under difficult conditions. "When I die, they'll write 'resilient and resistant' on my tombstone," jokes District 31 producer Fabienne Larouche. Luc Dionne will finish writing the sixth and final season of District 31 on Tuesday, if he keeps to his usual work schedule. With ratings holding steady around 1.5 million viewers, the popular pressure is not diminishing, on the contrary. "It's a daily, it goes fast. It's almost like filmed drama, but people expect a heavy series every night," says Luc Dionne. For those of you who are scratching your heads, no, the prolific writer has not forgotten the story of the burned man from September and will soon be tying it into the main storyline. Be patient. PHOTO FROM THE SHOW'S FACEBOOK PAGE Gildor Roy as Commander Chiasson. You may have noticed that Luc Dionne is having even more fun with Major Daniel Chiasson (Gildor Roy) and his magic phone. These comical scenes of a ringing drawer or a department of miracles are delicious. "For me, with Gildor Roy, it's the perfect match between an author and an actor," reveals Luc Dionne. Bruno's (Michel Charette) new girlfriend, the overly nice Laurie (Jeanne Roux-Côté), is suspicious and shady. Too perfect, too understanding, too everything. This Laurie hides something not quite right, but what exactly? We agree that a woman who sends letters to the psychopath Yanick Dubeau (Patrice Godin) in prison can't be 100% balanced. It doesn't look good for Bruno. It smells familiar, I'd say.

titre: Star Académie | Grâce à Footloose, Jérémy survit
texte: The teachers, who have been trying to break Jeremy Plante since the beginning of the school year in Waterloo, failed again in their attempt to expel this recalcitrant student. For the second time, viewers saved the 25-year-old from elimination on Sunday night during a Star Académie gala with a pop art feel. On the stage of the packed Mels Studios, Jérémy Plante, sporting a Grease-like look, opted for the catchy song Footloose by Kenny Loggins. And like a Ren McCormack (Kevin Bacon) in an abandoned warehouse in Bomont, Utah, he danced his way to the vote. All that was missing was Ariel, Willard, Rusty and Reverend Shaw's blessing. Was Jeremy's performance extraordinary? No. But, finally, a TVA academician who doesn't opt for a sad, whiny or depressing song. The audience rewarded Jeremy Plante's pep and perseverance. Beware of the big head syndrome, though. That's what's in store for Jeremy. All week long, the teachers reminded Sandrine Hébert, 25, from Coaticook, that she was always singing off key, that she needed to correct her pitch problems. Not surprisingly, Sandrine was cut after a not at all dishonorable rereading of C'est zéro, Julie Masse's big hit written by Manuel Tadros, Xavier Dolan's father. PHOTO FROM STAR ACADÉMIE's FACEBOOK PAGE Sandrine Hébert The faculty protected Marily Dorion, 27, from Sherbrooke, an artist more original and creative than Sandrine. Her interpretation of Je t'aimais, je t'aime et je t'aimerai, by Francis Cabrel, was very nice. PHOTO FROM STAR ACADÉMIE's FACEBOOK PAGE Marily Dorion Surprisingly, the number she cobbled together with Belgian pop star Angèle, 26, was not the most sparkling of the evening. It started on Tout oublier with tight shots in a Citroën car, which bordered on claustrophobia. And the academics had a hard time with the Belgian singer's register. Even the best of the group, Audrey-Louise, was not at her best. At the very end of this 2 hr 05 min gala, Ingrid St-Pierre was the most moving, in simplicity and sweetness. Les joailliers (with Olivier) and Ficelles (with Audrey-Louise and Julien) brought shivers to our living rooms. And what eloquence in the interview with the host Marc Dupré. Very nice tribute to Renée Martel with Paul Daraîche, Isabelle Boulay, Annie Blanchard and Guillaume Lafond. Once again, Audrey-Louise stood out on Je vais à Londres, as did Krystel and Édouard on Un amour qui ne veut pas mourir. Six days after the definitive resignation of Dany Bédar, the group La Chicane showed up with their bag of hits such as Tu m'manques and Calvaire (perfect for Olivier). Boom Desjardins, always in voice, took the opportunity to announce that Jean-Marc Couture, champion of Star Académie 2012, was joining the Abitibi band as a guitarist. It was a big night for the former academicians with the return of Annie Blanchard (2005), Jean-Marc Couture (2012) and Guillaume Lafond (2021). Many of you are complaining about the clothes worn by the academicians. Not me. It's good to be daring and to avoid the too classic black outfits. On Sunday night, we felt like we were flipping through a comic book with vitaminized colors. A mix of 90's influences and Archie. Following the shenanigans of Éléonore Lagacé on Big Brother Celebrity was more difficult than understanding the dense plot of Lovecraft Country, Westworld or Watchmen on HBO. It's Lysanne coming out, no, it's Stephanie coming out, no, it's Eddy coming out! SCREEN CAPTURE OF A VIDEO ON NOOVO.CA Éléonore Lagacé The boss of the disco week never found her rhythm and pushed false notes in the house-studio. Big disappointment. Copying comedian Michelle Desrochers' (dubious) strategy, Éléonore aka Léo made alliances with everything in sight, including the Hello Fresh burger topped with halloumi. Leo had us completely lost in his mountain of lies. Seconds before Sunday night's ouster vote, who sent comedian Eddy King home, who really understood where the axe would fall? Even cyclist Hugo Barrette was speechless. That's saying something. SCREEN CAPTURE OF A VIDEO ON NOOVO.CA Eddy King Member of no dominant coalition, the placid Eddy King was sacrificed. Honestly, Eddy didn't play hard like his peers and only won one challenge in two months. Too little, too late. Tranna Wintour never wins either, except when Lysanne Richard gives up her musical chair, but she gets involved in the backstage dealings, unlike Eddy. There are two alliances that will compete in the next few days: Marie-Mai's, which includes the five women (Claudia, Léo, Stéphanie, Tranna and Lysanne), and the group of five, which includes Martin, Hugo, Claudia, Léo and Stéphanie. Hence the importance of the election of the next boss, which will be decided unanimously, like in a real jury. If Tranna Wintour moves into the boss's room, she will target Hugo and Martin, her enemy since day one. If Martin Vachon wins over the jurors, he will try to eliminate Tranna or Lysanne. The game is getting tougher like a big California wine, folks.

titre: Fascinantes fraudeuses fabulatrices
texte: In her English with a Russian-German accent, Anna Sorokin, aka Anna Delvey, spent nine episodes of Inventing Anna (Netflix) repeating that her father was rich in your... That the wire transfer had been made, that the money would arrive in a few days, that there must be a problem with the bank, ah, international transfers, could I borrow your credit card? Her creditors harassed her, her "friends" confronted her about her alleged wealth, but nothing burst Anna's bubble, unshakeable behind her oversized Celine glasses. Even in prison, Anna was adamant that her daddy would sort it all out by dipping into his trust fund. Anna Sorokin is still waiting for her transfers. The Dropout miniseries, the first three episodes of which were dropped on Disney+ in English and French, tells a similar (and 100% true) story of a young fraudster who thinks big and falls off the edge. It's about Elizabeth Holmes, played brilliantly by Amanda Seyfried, the fallen boss of the Theranos company, who promised the medical industry the world before being swallowed up by the wave of her lies. Ambitious (she learns Mandarin in her spare time, you get the idea), the hyper-bright Elizabeth Holmes dropped out of the prestigious Stanford University in 2003 to found her own company. What does this 19-year-old entrepreneur offer to Silicon Valley investors? A portable gizmo the size of a pencil sharpener that will perform a battery of tests from a single drop of blood. No more need for needles, syringes or test tubes to detect diseases, a mini-puncture on the tip of a finger - like for blood sugar tests - will suffice. And the analysis will be done at home, without a big, expensive lab. How cool is that? Elizabeth Holmes and her baby Theranos win over the trade press and raise millions in funding. The value of Theranos climbs to $9 billion, the contracts with pharmaceutical companies line up and the pressure mounts on Elizabeth Holmes, who is not yet 25 years old. Unlike the evanescent con artist Anna Sorokin, Elizabeth Holmes has had a hard time breaking into the "dudecracy" or "boys club" of the techno-medical sphere. She slept on the couch in her office for a long time, putting in 20-hour workdays. She studied the methods of Apple's Steve Jobs and even copied his work uniform, the famous black turtleneck by Issey Miyake. To gain authority in this misogynistic world, Elizabeth Holmes also practiced for hours lowering her voice by an octave. It's amazing to see her repeat sentences in front of her mirror while never blinking. Actress Amanda Seyfried does an incredible job in her portrayal of Elizabeth Holmes. The fall of the Theranos CEO was more dizzying than her rise. An initial faked result led to a half-truth, which led to a web of lies that became impossible to unravel. The former businesswoman, now 37, is awaiting sentencing after being convicted last January of knowingly selling technology that didn't work. Filmmaker Adam McKay (Don't Look Up) is currently preparing the film Bad Blood about the Theranos fiasco with Jennifer Lawrence as Elizabeth Holmes. Very, very excited to see it. These complex and nuanced scandals, all of which have been the subject of books, podcasts or feature articles in Vanity Fair magazine, are fascinating in many ways. They incorporate elements of Greek tragedies (power, ambition, betrayal, decay) and set them in today's world, which values success at all costs. Even if it means cheating or stealing, one must crush, climb, defraud and climb again. PHOTO NIC COURY, ASSOCIATED PRESS The real Elizabeth Holmes at her trial. The former Theranos executive was convicted of defrauding investors last January. U.S. TV is abuzz with the real-life setbacks of darling companies - and their megalomaniac executives - that have recently rolled down the hill. The Apple TV+ service will launch the first three episodes of WeCrashed on Friday, March 18, about the dramatic collapse of WeWork, which offered shared workspaces around the world. WeCrashed focuses on the couple of Adam Neumann (Jared Leto) and his wife, Rebekah (Anne Hathaway), the two charismatic and narcissistic figures of WeWork. Before the big collapse, WeWork orchestrated wild parties and swam in the money. Adam and Rebekah, very esoteric, also increased their questionable behavior and epic bickering. In short, all the ingredients for a Shakespearean drama are found in WeCrashed. On the Crave side, the platform is already offering two episodes of Super Pumped: The Battle for Uber, which details the guerrilla warfare that ousted the founder of his own cab service. It's Joseph Gordon-Levitt who plays Uber's first big boss, Travis Kalanick, who borrows the same pompous, empty vocabulary as Kendall (Jeremy Strong) in Succession. Spying on drivers, a PR fiasco and surveillance of overly curious reporters is more than enough to give Super Pumped: The Battle for Uber a three-star rating. Bonus: you don't have to fuel any idle conversation during your TV ride.

titre: Star Académie | Ramenez Audrey-Louise, ça presse !
texte: One of the most talented students of Star Académie was cut on Sunday night and it is incomprehensible. It's all a big mess. The three endangerments of the last gala were hardly justified. Why oppose three such strong candidates, when there was still a lot of dead wood at the Waterloo mansion? Some singers, exhausted or too often flayed by the teachers, were spared this guillotine as cruel as inexplicable. It is unfair to Audrey-Louise Beauséjour, 23 years old, from Brossard, who had never been worried before this week. A series of questionable decisions cost her her seat on the blue bus. What a mess. Since the beginning of the competition, Audrey-Louise has shined in each of her appearances, her fellow students excluded also predicted her to win, but no, the faculty preferred her to Krystel Mongeau, 25 years old, from Sherbrooke, who was very solid on I Won't Let Go, by the Rascal Flatts, it must be noted. PHOTO TAKEN FROM STAR ACADÉMIE's FACEBOOK PAGE Krystel Mongeau It's no scandal that Krystel is continuing her apprenticeship on TVA's TV talent show, don't get me wrong. She has a nice voice and an unmatched assurance on stage. What doesn't make sense is the choice to put Audrey-Louise against Krystel so early in the competition. The fans did not digest it. The gall poured in hectoliters on social networks. Because Audrey-Louise and Krystel, the two young mothers of the cohort, did not miss anything since the first day and their mid-term report card showed only A's. The same cannot be said for Marily, Sarah-Maude, Camélia, Olivier, Édouard or Jérémy. When Guylaine Tremblay announced that Krystel was staying, we all thought it was a blunder like the one made at the Oscars in 2017. LOL! Seeing that Audrey-Louise was eliminated after being so good on Celine Dion's L'amour existe encore is a joke, show us the envelope! Except that no, no gag here. Even the academics looked stunned by the result. It's such a shame. This controversy has cast a big shadow on the best orchestrated gala of the 2022 season. An online petition was even started to reinstate the deposed contestant. PHOTO FROM STAR ACADEMY'S FACEBOOK PAGE Éloi Cummings The public vote was not at all surprising. Éloi Cummings, 16, from the Magdalen Islands, chose a piece that was perfect for him, La ballade du Irving Whale, by Zachary Richard. It was as if the same phenomenon that pushed Wilfred LeBouthillier to victory in 2003 was happening again. Éloi is young, charming, engaging and hard-working. It was obvious that viewers would fall for this Shawn Mendes look-alike, even if he is not the best singer in the group. The public vote was more often on the side of the boys than on the side of the girls. As for the rest of the 2 hr 10 min gala, it was amazing, starting with the ambitious Gerry Boulet tribute act, which brought together Dan Bigras, Breen LeBœuf, Daniel Boucher, Lulu Hughes and Claude Cobra of Bleu Jeans Bleu. The 80-90s jazz pop cabaret, put together by artistic director Pierre Lapointe, was tasty. T'es dans la lune, by the BB, Dors Caroline, by Johanne Blouin, Recherché, by Jano Bergeron or Ça va bien, by Kathleen, we would have taken a full show. At the very end, Guylaine Tanguay proved why Quebecers love her. She is generous, talented and has the gift of putting some pep in our living rooms. From a kamikaze rescue at the vet to a double-cross maneuver that turned into a trap for Lysanne Richard, the final week of Big Brother Celebrities on Noovo proved just how well Martin Vachon masters this strategy game. The complex maneuver the comedian executed was the most daring and stunning of the season. A high level of dexterity and fake tears (like Leo's hyper-exaggerated ones), which puts Martin among the most serious contenders for the title of reality TV champion. NOOVO SCREEN CAPTURE Lysanne Richard Everything lined up to make his plan to get Lysanne out of the water work. Martin won the vault privilege, he protected Claudia Bouvette, and then his colleague Stephanie Harvey removed Eleonore Lagace from the elimination block, hoping to buy her loyalty. The way was paved and completely clear for Lysanne's ouster, without Martin's boss getting his hands dirty or betraying his alliance. Even in telling Lysanne that he had no choice but to put her in danger, Martin sounded sincere (break out the violins). And Lysanne bought it, not understanding the level of deception. Oops. Now it's obvious that Martin is drawing a target on his back by going through the weeks with such virtuosity. Claudia and Eleanor realized it on Sunday: they now have the chance to get rid of their biggest rival. Will they dare to betray the alliance of five? They must, if Claudia and Eleanor are to survive to the end. Tranna Wintour has been widely criticized for her lack of motivation in the challenges. But she was excellent in the social aspect of Big Brother this week. She did everything she could to stop Lysanne from being voted out. She called out the loyalty bargaining shenanigans. She scored 75%, which is Stephanie Harvey's level of certainty about the identity of Kim Rusk's father.

titre: Star Académie | L’hymne au printemps pour celle qui a quitté
texte: It was a quiet Sunday night at Star Académie, where Marily Dorion's departure did not shake the columns of the musical temple as much as Audrey-Louise's, which plunged the 2022 cohort into a serious seasonal depression. To lift the spirits and combat the March doldrums, what could be better than pastel Easter-coconut inspired clothing and a stunning spring awakening number by choreographer and dancer Lydia Bouchard? It was all pretty. It was soft, round and supple, with a beautiful fade-out of Gilles Vigneault's Pendant que and Aquarius (Let the Sunshine in) by The 5 th Dimension. The three endangered contestants' performances were inferior to those of Éloi Cummings, Audrey-Louise Beauséjour and Krystel Mongeau last Sunday, it must be said. It's as if the Star Académie timeline had been screwed up. As if the final had been moved up by six weeks. PHOTO TAKEN FROM STAR ACADÉMIE's FACEBOOK PAGE Camélia Zaki Without surprise, Camélia Zaki, 17 years old, from Sherbrooke, was acclaimed by the public with her interpretation of an almost unknown piece, Voilà by Barbara Pravi, which sounds like Padam Padam by Édith Piaf. Without taking anything away from the talent of the teenager, it is obvious that the surprise return of her Moroccan father allowed her to collect several votes. The production has put a lot of emphasis on this family story since the beginning of the season. Sarah-Maude Desgagné, 23, from Amos, re-did Tina Turner's River Deep Mountain High with some accuracy (and screaming, I might add) problems. Still, it was enough and convincing for the faculty to keep her at the Waterloo Mansion. PHOTO FROM STAR ACADEMY'S FACEBOOK PAGE Sarah-Maude Desgagné So it was the one with the strongest artistic identity, 27-year-old Marily Dorion from Sherbrooke, who was thanked. Her Tour de l'île by Félix Leclerc was not overwhelming or extraordinary. No scandal here, we expected it. What we didn't anticipate, however, was the rebirth of 25-year-old Jeremy Plante. As much as he was kicking ass at the start, he was the strongest competitor on Sunday night. Jeremy, who has completely changed his attitude, looked like he was having fun, while performing well in each of his appearances. Is this the Footloose effect? Édouard Lagacé, 27, stood out on Crier tout bas in the "nautical" medley of Cœur de pirate, who was very generous with the academics. Special mention to Julien Charbonneau, 23 years old, excellent during Place de la République with Béatrice Martin at the piano. The sequence on the platform was very nice. Plummeted by small clashes, the segment with Daniel Lavoie seemed less polished than the rest of the show. But what a voice and what a catalog of hits such as Jours de plaine (perfect Krystel), Ils s'aiment (wobbly Olivier) and Tension attention (amazing Éloi). The stay at the sugar shack, led by Yves Lambert, Édith Butler and Jérôme 50, made us all tap our feet in our living rooms. It felt like New Year's Eve Live from the Universe, really. As for the huge controversy surrounding Audrey-Louise's eviction, Marc Dupré found the best way to deal with it: through laughter. He wrote and performed the humorous song Une semaine pleine d'émotions to address the grumbling without fanning it. It was exactly the right thing to do. It was a heroic week for Big Brother Celebrity's Tranna Wintour, who won the biggest veto of the season (so far). Not only did the English-speaking comedian save her skin, alone against the group of five that dominated the house, but she also orchestrated the departure of one of the season's most feared players, comedian and actor Martin Vachon. The English-speaking comedian Tranna Wintour saved her skin on Big Brother Celebrity. The latter left the Noovo reality show on Sunday with elegance, dignity and humor. A great example of a successful exit. The show's golden retriever was true to his character: endearing and just biting enough. The alliance of five then exploded into a can-opening noise from Beach Day Every Day. And what squeaked more in our TVs were the endless dithering of Éléonore Lagacé, who was torn for half an hour between a) saving Martin Vachon or b) keeping Stéphanie Harvey in the game. To. Rescue. Decide. You. Hugo Barrette is not wasting any breath, we've known that for ten weeks. On Sunday, the cyclist used one of his few outbursts per episode to play in Leo's head and whip up his guilt. This well-executed strategy of manipulation was curbed by Tranna, who once again pulled the feminist card: why not orchestrate an all-female top 3? Tranna Wintour phrased it well. Her return to Big Brother Celebrity was more flamboyant than Cher's 1998 song Believe. No one believed in her chances of getting out of trouble. Tranna hadn't won anything all season and had given up several challenges without forcing herself. Yes, it was painful to watch at times. But like a basketball game where the ball is floating in the air when the final buzzer sounds, Tranna scored the most valuable basket of his career. Now, with Hugo Barrette lining up for the boss's job and sure to target her, will Tranna be "strong enough" like her favorite diva?

titre: Safia et les médias
texte: Today's loaded question, written with three pairs of white gloves. Is there a way to talk about Safia Nolin without necessarily flirting with extremes? Is it possible to discuss her stormy relationship with the media - social and traditional - without automatically sanctifying her or dragging her through the mud in a malicious way? Marie-Louise Arsenault navigated this nuanced area on Wednesday night on Télé-Québec's Dans les médias. Her interview with the 30-year-old singer-songwriter was excellent. Neither complacent nor aggressive, the host explored the grey area surrounding this singer, whose every appearance triggers a deluge of hatred. With aplomb, Safia Nolin answered all of the host's questions, without shying away, even when Marie-Louise Arsenault asked her if she was willingly playing the victim. The singer's answer: society is difficult for someone who is not thin, white and heterosexual. On that point, Safia Nolin, whose father is Algerian, is right. In the great lottery of life, she didn't pick the winning numbers, let's be honest. She describes herself as a fat, lesbian, hairy and Arab woman. Safia Nolin speaks franglais. She shows off her beard and bushy armpits on Instagram. Yes, it's confronting, disturbing, even for a so-called open-minded person, we must admit. But from there to eviscerate the artist from Limoilou on Facebook or Twitter, there is a huge step that most of us do not cross, fortunately. Safia Nolin remains an enigma. As much as I find her courageous to defend her sometimes controversial opinions, I wonder if it's not self-destruction, provocation or lack of judgment. We see her promoting body diversity on Instagram or denouncing the lack of place for women in the music industry and we think: go Safia, don't give up on these important fights. Then, the next day, Safia Nolin poses with a shirt stamped with the acronym ACAB (All Cops Are Bastards), and we say: but why did she do that? Why would a singer who fights against stereotypes and labels fall into these gross generalizations? A blatant example of boots not following lips. Safia Nolin is hard to follow. We feel like telling her to pick her battles to protect herself from the trolls who are only waiting for the moment she opens the door to them to ransack her house. These trolls will not disappear, alas! and the comments they pour out on Safia are odious and of an unheard-of violence. No one deserves that. At the same time, the musician knows that her public interventions, even the most insignificant, will inevitably bring her a volley of insults. She systematically suffers from it, but she continues to go for it, with her head down and her mouth full of "Broil". Unconsciousness or bravery? I don't know anymore. Why not channel all that energy into lyrics or songs? Safia Nolin is not easy to understand. She's treading on slippery ground (example: sexual assault allegations against Patrick Bruel) that requires a lot of context, which an ephemeral "story" on Instagram doesn't allow. Yet Safia is the first to take offense when columnists - or gossip sites - turn corners on her. Now let's talk about Quebecor's headliners, who write about her antics very, very often. Safia Nolin's record company, Bonsound, published an open letter to Sophie Durocher and Richard Martineau asking them to stop intimidating her "at the slightest comment she makes. This outing in support of Safia Nolin was clumsy. By specifically targeting two individuals, the Bonsound label should have known that it would reignite hostilities and that these two analysts would place themselves in the position of victim, crying out for freedom of expression. No one is going to tell them what to write, right! Indeed, when Safia Nolin speaks out on current issues, such as the secular nature of the State or inclusive writing, she exposes herself to criticism. This is true. But there is a difference between fair criticism and relentlessness. Richard Martineau and Sophie Durocher know that by talking about Safia Nolin on all their platforms, they are redirecting hordes of enraged people to her. They can't ignore their power, though. With great power comes great responsibility, to quote Spider-Man. The other problem with Safia Nolin's media persona is that there is rarely any debate about her ideas or her talent. Right away, her body is attacked, her clothes are targeted or her sexual orientation is ridiculed. I am not a fan of Safia Nolin's songs, far from it. But I don't feel the need to call her names. Still today, some Internet users accuse Safia Nolin of having orchestrated the cancellation of Maripier Morin in July 2020. Let's close this file once and for all. The only person responsible for the fall of Maripier Morin is Maripier Morin herself. Yes, Safia Nolin blows hot and cold. But that's not a valid reason to freeze her out with such a vengeance.

titre: Suzanne Clément en quotidienne à Radio-Canada
texte: Here's a good scoop fresh out of the oven: it's Suzanne Clément who has landed the lead role in the new daily drama series that will replace District 31 this fall. This is a great catch for Radio-Canada, as Suzanne Clément rarely plays on Quebec TV. Her last appearance here was on the soap opera Unité 9, where she played the rambunctious inmate Shandy Galarneau, a role she left in the spring of 2013 when her one-year contract expired. According to my information, this novelty, whose title has not yet been found, will be set in the hospital environment and will bear the signature of author Marie-Andrée Labbé (Sans rendez-vous, Trop). Fans can rest assured that Marie-Andrée Labbé has completed the writing of the second season of the comedy Sans rendez-vous before throwing herself, solo, into the marathon of scripting a daily show. A task that requires a lot of energy, combined with an iron discipline. In this medical series, which will run for 120 half-hours a year, like District 31, Suzanne Clément will play emergency room physician Emmanuelle Lacombe, who is attached to a large Montreal hospital. The sets of this health institution will be built in the MEL's studios in Saint-Hubert, the same place where the detective sergeants of District 31 interrogate their suspects. Danièle Méthot, Fabienne Larouche's collaborator since Virginie, will remain the director-coordinator. In theory, Suzanne Clément will cross swords with TVA's Sébastien Delorme, who has inherited the lead role in the daily series Indéfendable, by author Nadine Bismuth (Un lien familial), scheduled for the September schedule. Other interesting information: Fabienne Larouche and Michel Trudeau of Aetios will co-produce this daily soap opera with Guillaume Lespérance of A Média (Les mecs, Discussions avec mes parents, Tout le monde en parle). An alliance that few observers saw coming in the TV industry. PHOTO EDOUARD PLANTE-FRÉCHETTE, LA PRESSE Fabienne Larouche I wrote and produced 20 years of daily shows at Radio-Canada, I had a six-year bonus with Luc Dionne on District 31. We joined forces with Guillaume Lespérance to share the task and eventually pass the torch. Fabienne Larouche "This is the first time that Fabienne Larouche and I will be collaborating. I discovered people at Aetios who are like me. I have a lot of admiration for hard-working people who have the knife between their teeth," said Guillaume Lespérance in a telephone interview. It was not possible to speak with Suzanne Clément on Monday. In the last 10 years, the 52-year-old actress has mostly participated in French TV series, including Versailles, La forêt, Vampires and Dérapages, all on Netflix except Versailles, hosted by Crave. Suzanne Clément's rare presence in the credits of a Quebec series has caused a stir behind the scenes, I'm told. The actress was also to join the cast of the new miniseries Chouchou that Simon Boulerice wrote for the Bell Media-owned channel Noovo. Suzanne Clément would have played the mother of Sandrick (Lévi Doré), a 17-year-old student who has an illicit relationship with his 37-year-old French teacher, Chanelle Chouinard (Évelyne Brochu), known as Chouchou. The casting of Suzanne Clément in Chouchou was to be announced on Thursday, March 17 during a virtual press conference. This announcement never took place. Because the day before the announcement, Radio-Canada and Aetios learned that Noovo and Bell Media were about to cut the ground from under their feet by announcing - as a premiere - the great return of Suzanne Clément in a Quebec fiction. Panic in the tower, you can imagine. In Chouchou, Suzanne Clément would have obtained a dozen days of shooting. In the new medical series, Suzanne Clément will have a hundred, or ten times more. The actress, who had to commit to several seasons at Radio-Canada, had to make a choice. Why? Because the headliners of daily series sign a tacit exclusivity clause. These stars are paid very well for their services and are expected to devote themselves to only one project. For the past six years, Vincent-Guillaume Otis, a.k.a. Detective Sergeant Patrick Bissonnette, has only appeared in District 31. And if Michel Charette was able to cross in Le bonheur at TVA, it is because a) District 31 was ending and b) it is the same producer who elaborated the schedules. According to Suzanne Clément's agent, Maxime Vanasse, "there was no war between Bell and Radio-Canada, and Suzanne Clément simply had to make a choice between two interesting projects," he says. According to my spies, the people at Bell Media would not have appreciated losing Suzanne Clément under these competitive circumstances. The producer of Chouchou, Vicky Bounadère of Passez Go (Lou et Sophie, L'académie), preferred not to comment on Suzanne Clément's last-minute withdrawal. According to sources familiar with the matter, the Passez Go company did in fact have a duly negotiated contract with the actress. Bell Media confirms that Suzanne Clément was approached for a role in the series Chouchou, without however specifying why the actress withdrew a few hours before the press conference of the project of Simon Boulerice.

titre: Les chefs ! | Donnez de la sauce à Jean-Luc Boulay !
texte: Today's youth have no respect for tradition. Can you believe that the contestants of the succulent show Les chefs! skimped on the sauce during the first challenge of the Radio-Canada reality show, which consisted of cooking a typically Madelinot pot-en-pot? You don't do that to Jean-Luc Boulay. The abundance of sauce, the seasoning of the dishes and the sacrosanct respect of the products form the backbone of his mantra at Chefs! since 2010. I know it, you know it and the 13 new candidates of the new brigade have learned the hard way that Mr. Boulay is not served a dry pâté. Unacceptable! Unacceptable! Outrageous! All kidding aside, this 11th season of Chefs! returns on Monday, April 18 at 8:00 p.m. after a pandemic break, and promises to be delicious and even crisper than the previous ones. It brings back classics like our favorite espuma (with potato skins, mind you), Thermomix, chopstick plate assembly, sparkling water chin-chin, Orpheus House oils, finger cuts, and Élyse Marquis' famous "I'd ask you to stop everything, I have an announcement to make." And in 2022, not only is the product respected at Chefs! but it's also maximized. After the first round of pot-en-pot, a seafood tourtière from the Magdalen Islands that is pronounced "potte en potte," the aspiring chefs threw far too much good food in the garbage. As a result, their new coach Colombe St-Pierre is forcing them to cook compost the following week - carrot tops, broccoli stalks and potato peels. PHOTO PROVIDED BY RADIO-CANADA Colombe St-Pierre, chef/owner of Chez Saint-Pierre, is the coach on the show. No, Daniel Vézina is not taking over his role as mentor, which has been entrusted to Colombe St-Pierre, owner of Chez Saint-Pierre restaurant in Bic. On camera, the dynamic chef comes through with flying colors. She is funny, engaging, involved, a good teacher and concludes each episode with a nice comic proverb. The table of judges is also becoming more feminine. To the original trio, composed of Normand Laprise, Pasquale Vari and Jean-Luc Boulay, is added Isabelle Deschamps-Plante, who was a finalist in Chefs! in 2013 as well as in 2014 during the edition Les chefs! : la revanche. PHOTO PROVIDED BY RADIO-CANADA Les juges des Chefs ! judges: Normand Laprise, Jean-Luc Boulay, Isabelle Deschamps-Plante and Pasquale Vari As a judge, Isabelle Deschamps-Plante, who now works as an executive chef at Ricardo's cafés and counters, complements the expertise of her male comrades, who have been on the job since the first season. She brings a different color to the analysis of the dishes, that of a former participant who has lived through this stress in front of the cameras. She is not cheesy, however, nor is she fiendish. It's all about balance, as in any self-respecting recipe. The first episode of Les Chefs! is fast-paced, and the second episode has the same breathless pace. The introduction of the ten boys and three girls of the 2022 brigade is interspersed between the challenges, and the action never slows down, with an intense Game of Thrones-style musical backdrop. On the screen, this new squad immediately seems to be more cohesive and united. Why is that? Because before filming began, the contestants were isolated in a hotel for two weeks. They were able to communicate with each other through Zoom and create a complicity that was less present in the previous chapters. This quarantine also allowed them to study gastronomy classics in depth, which always helps when it comes to a challenge of grébiche sauce or custard that you never whip when it heats up, lord, would you finish Normand Laprise? Also, the bubble formed on the Chefs! stage allows the combatants to pop on top of each other, without worrying about the "two meters of distance". It feels like a return to normalcy as we watch them flail around on our TV. PHOTO PROVIDED BY RADIO-CANADA Amine Laabi, 29, from Laval, sous-chef at Westmount's Gentile Several cooks quickly stand out from the crowd, including the likeable Amine Laabi, 29, from Laval, sous-chef at Westmount's Café Gentile. His spontaneous reactions make him very likeable. Jean-Christophe Beaudin, 30 years old, sous-chef at Foxy, comes into the workshop with his huge metal toolbox full of sharpened instruments. Anthony Vien, 25, from Lévis, sous-chef at La Tanière in Quebec City, starts as a lion, but will he end up as a pig, as the saying goes? Among the favorites are Adrian Pastor, 30, from Rimouski, chef de midi at L'Arlequin, and Elliot Beaudoin, 27, chef at Quebec City's Légende restaurant, who is nicknamed the botanist. The tenors of the show also feed off the enthusiasm of the up-and-coming chefs. In the second episode, veteran chef Normand Laprise of Toqué! even learns the meaning of the expression "snacking on a partridge". As a viewer, the stress level during the duels at the end of the show still takes our breath away. And that's just fine. You know you never blow on a burning dish. You smother the blaze with a lid. Tip from a fire pro here.

titre: Le temps des framboises | J’vais t’en prendre trois casseaux !
texte: The first episode of Club illico's Raspberry Times gives us the false impression of plowing a field in 5e Rang, but with twice the budget and English-language music. Like Marie-Luce Goulet (Maude Guérin) in Valmont, the heroine (Sandrine Bisson) of Le Temps des framboises wears her hair short and brown, suddenly becomes a widow, inherits a Hemmingford vegetable farm that requires foreign workers, suffers the wrath of a rude mother-in-law (Micheline Lanctôt) and four sisters with varying moods complicate her life on the farm. I mean, that's a lot of coincidences. Fortunately, from the second episode on, the beauty and uniqueness of Raspberry Time emerges. This unclassifiable show plows its own original furrow and breaks away from 5th Row, which has been digging into agricultural crime for a few seasons now. And yes, Le temps des framboises is very good, thanks in part to the inspired direction of Philippe Falardeau (Monsieur Lazhar), who magnifies the plots of brilliant authors Florence Longpré and Suzie Bouchard. It's cinema on the small screen with a delightful soundtrack. It's more accessible than Audrey est retour, another excellent work by Florence Longpré, whose unique writing breaks the conventional mold of Quebec TV. It's hard to describe Le temps des framboises with accuracy and precision. There are touches of absurdist humor intertwined with poignant moments. It is sweet and hard, funny and grating, tragic and comic. It's a finely woven story of grief, exile and the inability to communicate. In ten one-hour episodes, the series revolves around farmer John Conley (Anthony Lemke) and his wife Elisabeth (Sandrine Bisson), a city official uprooted in the countryside. Good John runs the family farm with his mother Martha (Micheline Lanctôt) and his five bilingual siblings. Elisabeth takes pride in the crops and is unable to distinguish Emilio from Francisco or Santiago, who live only a stone's throw from her house. We can feel the deep malaise in the first episodes: the Spanish-speaking employees - sometimes illiterate - do not mix with the others and live, once again, in isolation from society. An invisible wall, similar to the one erected between Mexico and the United States, separates them. After John's unexpected death, which of course reveals several surprises, everything changes for Elizabeth. She inherits the farm and the mean-spirited in-laws. In short, the equivalent of a worst-case scenario for her. In addition, Elisabeth is estranged from her teenage son Junior (Elijah Patrice-Baudelot), a jock with a lot of pent-up anger. And she scoops up her youngest, William (Xavier Chalifoux), who is deaf. PHOTO FROM IMDB Sandrine Bisson stars in the series Le temps des framboises. Sandrine Bisson, who appears in almost every scene of Le Temps des framboises, is a real eye-catcher. Her character of a broken woman is rebuilt, piece by piece, before our eyes. Throughout the episodes, Elisabeth finds comfort where she least expects it: among the outcasts, the seasonal farmers on her farm, whom she cared so little about before the death of her husband John. Raspberry Time also delves into the unspoken words that have shaped the Conley family, scattered between English, French, Spanish and sign language. With small flashbacks, director Philippe Falardeau traces the history of John and Elizabeth's tumultuous relationship, which hid a side that was neither frosty nor sweet. No spoilers here. Like Audrey est retour or M'entends-tu?, Florence Longpré and Suzie Bouchard's Le temps des framboises tackles local issues to open up universal themes. It's the kind of "foreign" series that would have a great career on Netflix if it ever got out of Videotron's Club illico. It shows Quebec, its farmlands and its specialized labor problems, but also characters adrift, caught in chaos, struggling to connect with each other. It screams, it cries and it laughs in Le temps des framboises. And it's as full of flavor as a Quebec raspberry bursting with water and sunshine. The spring season has officially arrived on Quebec TV with the return of Chefs!, Bonsoir bonsoir! and L'île de l'amour on TVA. Radio-Canada's culinary reality show rallied 738,000 living room epicureans, a small tick below TVA's Star Académie (824,000). The summer talk show Bonsoir bonsoir! took off with 591,000 viewers and the start of the second season of La Maison-Bleue on Radio-Canada attracted 620,000 viewers. On TVA, the adventures of the island bachelors in L'île de l'amour entertained 370,000 fans of the reality show Cupid (and Mehdi Bousaidan's gags). Unsurprisingly, District 31 (1,460,000) remained at the top of the ratings in its farewell week. Due to the Easter vacation, all Sunday night productions dropped in the ratings. Star Académie's penultimate gala was watched by 1,307,000 fans, while 756,000 tuned in to Guy A. Lepage's Tout le monde en parle, where water turned to white wine.

titre: Star Académie | Les noces de Krystel
texte: Lara Fabian's surprised face as she opened the envelope immediately betrayed the identity of the Star Académie 2022 winner. While Éloi Cummings seemed to be heading for a triumph that was as easy as it was predictable, the amazing Krystel Mongeau, 25, from Sherbrooke, blocked the popular storm that was blowing in from the Magdalen Islands. Éloi Cummings, 16, won all but the most crucial public vote, the grand finale of the TVA reality show. As for Krystel Mongeau, a young mother and professional hairdresser, she becomes the second woman (in seven editions) to win Star Académie, after Stéphanie Lapointe in 2004. And what a deserved victory it was. Talent and popularity have rhymed in the case of Krystel, magnificent in her long black sequined dress. Her impeccable rendition of Ginette Reno's Je ne suis qu'une chanson outshone the chamber version of Eloi Cummings' Quand les hommes vivront d'amour. The discrepancy between the two performances certainly whipped up the audience into a frenzy as they tried to put the brakes on Eloi's rise. Krystel couldn't lose after being so masterful for three months. And Eloi, even if he is super endearing, could not win after being so lukewarm. Explanation? The abstainers who were bitching about Eloi in their living rooms finally tapped their phones to get out the vote, which favored the best, hallelujah. Throughout the season, the teachers never hid their admiration for Krystel Mongeau, a former member of Lara Fabian's 2018 Voice 6 team. Even though we felt that Éloi Cummings' love rating irritated the faculty, including Gregory Charles, who called the young Madelinot lazy. In last week's gala, Guylaine Tremblay, Lara Fabian and Gregory Charles jumped out of their seats after the numbers of all the endangered singers, except for Éloi Cummings. Oops. Favoritism? Maybe. The fact remains that teachers have no say in the election. PHOTO BERTEXERTIER - PHOTOGRAPHY, TAKEN FROM THE SHOW'S FACEBOOK PAGE Éloi Cummings Krystel Mongeau's coronation also torpedoed the belief that the Madelinots had been "packing" the vote for Éloi since the beginning of the contest. This foggy theory does not hold up 199 between Cap-aux-Meules and Havre-aux-Maisons. Why not? Because the population of the Magdalen Islands is around 13,000, while Quebec has 8.5 million. The electoral weight of the Magdalen Islands in Star Académie is therefore 0.15% for the whole province. We agree that 0.15% is tiny, it is a grain of sand on the great beach of the TVA reality show. The Magdalen Islands alone did not have the strength to push the 16-year-old to the finish line. This is a rare occurrence on Sunday night. In this type of television competition, viewers rarely vote for the most talented like Audrey-Louise Beauséjour or Krystel Mongeau. Why give a pat on the back to these artists with established careers? On the other hand, a vote for Éloi Cummings or for Olivier Bergeron, 20, from Kedwick, New Brunswick, is more useful and rewarding. He helps write the first chapter of the fairy tale where an overlooked competitor - the famous underdog - climbs the steps to glory one by one. More shy and less comfortable in his body than his peers, Éloi Cummings quickly charmed Star Académie fans, who took him under their wing. From week to week, we saw him stumble, get up, work and improve. That's exactly what makes for good television. And at 16, Éloi has his whole professional life ahead of him. Does Krystel's dedication signal the end of our habit of privileging the underdog? Let's hope so. Krystel did not steal her title. She did not commit any faux pas and less false notes than all her roommates in Waterloo (except Audrey-Louise, who was ousted much too quickly, no, I won't come back, thank you). In this 13th and final Star Académie gala, lasting 2 hours and 20 minutes, the group Salebarbes injected a hyper contagious energy in the Mels studios. Unfortunately, we can't say the same about Julien Clerc, who seemed completely turned off, poor guy. The singer Mika, who caught the COVID-19 at the beginning of the month, also pulled out all the stops vocally. Julien Charbonneau was more amazing than Mika on his own song. A solid musical comedy number orchestrated by Gregory Charles, who was an exceptional teacher this winter. His rigor, his infinite knowledge and his enthusiasm were contagious. Lara Fabian brought back the day with her 15 little hearts and we would have gladly taken a long medley. A crispy potin à la Lady Whistledown, in conclusion. A couple was formed during this edition of Star Académie. We're talking about a love at first sight, because the two members of this new couple were each in a stable relationship when they entered the TVA show. And yes, we've seen their respective sweet halves on the daily shows, which is why they don't publicly declare their love. This recent union has caused some collateral damage, as you can imagine. Who are they? I'll let them have the pleasure (or not) of talking about it. XOXO folks.

titre: Tout le monde les aime… sauf nous !
texte: There are cult shows that critics love, that win all the prestigious awards, that our friends worship like the diversity at Penelope's, but that interest us as much as catching simian pox, also known as monkey pox. It is normal. We shouldn't be ashamed of the fact that we don't get all the so-called "must-see" TV shows. And this, even if the lapidary judgment of our peers falls on us like a frying pan from the set of Chefs! What? You don't like (insert title of a for-mi-da-ble series here)? Pfft. Nonsense. You don't know anything about TV. You're a philistine! Marie-Louise Arsenault plays this amusing game every Friday on her radio show Plus on est de fous, plus on lit at 95.1 FM. The host asks the main guest to name a literary masterpiece that he or she feels is overrated. The answers are wide-ranging and often touch on classics: Jack Kerouac's On the Road, Leon Tolstoy's War and Peace, Donna Tartt's The Goldfinch or Félix-Antoine Savard's Menaud, maître-draveur. And it's very correct. There is nothing dishonorable about not embracing the complete works of Marie-Claire Blais or Marcel Proust. The same exercise in overrated work applies, of course, to TV. There are series that captivate the entire planet... except us, it seems. Now, which of these small-screen gems have an overrated reputation? Before I reveal the informal results of a Facebook poll, it's my duty as a columnist to get wet first. So here goes. I don't understand the buzz surrounding the Ozark series on Netflix. It's said, it's written. I dipped my toe in the first season and then dropped out. Finito for Hugo. And with about forty episodes to catch up on before the denouement, the mountain is too high to climb. Bye. PHOTO PROVIDED BY NBC Jason Alexander and Jerry Seinfeld in the series Seinfeld, now on Netflix Another tricky and slippery subject: Seinfeld. Not capable. Sorry, Patrick Lagacé and Jean-Philippe Wauthier, ultimate fans of this American comedy. I've tried, tried again and again, but I never got into the offbeat universe of Jerry Seinfeld and his weird friends. I want so much to like it and be part of the cult, but I preferred Friends. Go ahead and stone me. Call me a humor illiterate, damn me. Many of you are singing the praises of Narcos, the popular Netflix series about the criminal Pablo Escobar and the Colombian cartels. Meh... Still here, I didn't tripping so much. Same situation with La casa de papel. It was very entertaining at the beginning before quickly becoming redundant and long. In my book, Breaking Bad and its spin-off Better Call Saul fall into the category of: yes, it's good, but that good? That's no, good. Now, here are your responses from shows with abnormally inflated reputations, all taken from my Facebook page. There are a few things that need to be carefully deconstructed, as finished fans of shows feel personally attacked when they discover that their TV obsession doesn't please the whole world. Namaste, Toltec agreements and world peace, please. PHOTO PROVIDED BY RADIO-CANADA Patrice Robitaille and François Létourneau in the series C'est comme ça que je t'aime After a quick count of more than 2,000 comments, the Quebec show that garnered the most votes is, scandal alert, Radio-Canada's C'est comme ça que je t'aime. Too absurd, too burlesque, too cliched, you decided. I'm not that surprised. Personally, I loved this work by François Létourneau and Jean-François Rivard. The problem is that all the reviews of the criminal-love life of the Sainte-Foy kingpins have been dithyrambic. When the hype reaches such stratospheric levels, the viewer can only be disappointed and wonder why they don't get on board as much as the opinion leaders. District 31 was mentioned several times, too. That was to be expected. A phenomenon series inevitably leaves people stranded, not having 360 free hours to pick up the storylines from the beginning. I can understand why HBO's Succession didn't pass the test with readers, who gave up halfway through the first season. It is indeed a singular proposition. And those who love Succession really love Succession. They like to trumpet it on every platform. PHOTO PROVIDED BY HBO CANADA Sandor The Hound Clegane, one of the many chainmail-wearing characters in the Game of Thrones series, who is far from a unanimous Game of Thrones and its medieval-fantasy look has repelled those allergic to chainmail and cups of mead. Granted, the release of each season of Game of Thrones has triggered media eclipses visible on every continent. Let's calm down (I'm including myself in the mix). Among other unexplained popularity phenomena on TV, you've mentioned, loosely, This Is Us, Squid Game, Breaking Bad, Ozark and The Walking Dead. All legitimate suggestions. A few people mentioned The Sopranos and I almost died "live there," as they say on Love Island. No, but, what an affront, what sacrilege, what heresy. As you know, fans feel personally attacked when their favorite show is scratched. So, no touching of Tony and Carmela, unless you absolutely want to take a ride in the suitcase of the tank.

titre: Le bureau des légendes
texte: Sand the Codorniu for $13.45! We've survived: a) another Siberian-like winter in the age of climate change b) a 42nd wave of the devil's COVID-19 and c) Patio Design's 98.5 FM radio commercial, as enjoyable as a cold eardrum drill. But, hooray! for us, summer is slowly coming, the surgical masks are coming off and there's a sweet smell of freedom in the air, mixed with the fetid odor of old compost bin bottoms; that's what city life is all about. This slow exit from the pandemic, after two very difficult years, has pushed the first domino on a cascade of departures - not always voluntary, let's say - of popular media figures loved by the public. It is unprecedented in Quebec, so many television and radio tenors who simultaneously turn off their microphones with a snap of the fingers, like Denis Lévesque at LCN. It's as if these monumental hosts were announcing to their listeners and viewers: OK, we held out while the virus terrorized us, but the time has come for us to leave, thanks for everything. PHOTO PHILIPPE BOIVIN, ARCHIVES LA PRESSE Joël Le Bigot in the studio at Radio-Canada during his show Samedi et rien d'autre The coming week will be full of goodbyes and farewells. Joël Le Bigot will drop his radio show Samedi et rien d'autre on Saturday, June 18, Pierre Bruneau will read his last news bulletin at TVA on Thursday, June 16, Paul Houde will vacate the 98.5 FM studio on Sunday, June 19, and his colleague Jacques Fabi, the station's most patient man, will answer the phone one last time on Friday, June 17. The list of future retirees also includes Michel Lacombe (95.1 FM), Denis Gagné (L'épicerie) and Pierre Therrien (ICI Musique). Yes, all white males 60 years and older. So what? These pillars of the communications world have left their mark on the airwaves, each in their own way. These legends have influenced and shaped the generation breathing down their necks. It's only right - and respectful - to salute them, to thank them for being with us for so long. PHOTO FROM THE HOST'S FACEBOOK ACCOUNT Denis Lévesque hosted his last show on May 19. Because TV and radio are anchored in habits of listening and stability, which set markers in our routines. We jump into the shower after Chantal Hébert's political column at 7:15 a.m. on Tout un matin, we take the dog out after Paul Arcand's tour de table at 8 a.m., we adjust our schedule according to Salut Bonjour. The slightest change in alignment irritates us. Now imagine the inconvenience of replacing a favourite host who has been on the air for years. It's hell. The number one station for ages, 98.5 FM is about to go through a period of intense upheaval. After the surprise departure of Bernard Drainville to the CAQ, Cogeco's talk show will lose its king of the airwaves in two years, when his contract expires. 98.5 FM without Paul Arcand in the morning is a huge hole to fill. PHOTO MARTIN TREMBLAY, ARCHIVES LA PRESSE Paul Arcand will leave a big hole at 98,5 FM. Supreme star of the radio, Paul Arcand, 62 years old, dictates the news. If Paul Arcand tackled a hot topic on his show Puisqu'il faut se lever, you can be sure that all the newsroom bosses in Quebec passed it on to one of their journalists. Mr. Paul, as my colleague Louise Cousineau called him, conducts tight interviews and refuses to hear taped answers. We forget, however, that he is capable of having fun with his team. When the director sends funny clips between two serious interviews, it happily relaxes the atmosphere. This is what explains Paul Arcand's success, this balance between the more "in-your-face" segments and the complicity with his team, which does not seem at all feigned. Discipline, rigor and bursts of lightness, with a moment of zen and a riddle at the end. Around the table, you can feel that Catherine Brisson, Alain Crête, Esther Morin, Élisabeth Crête, Marc Brière and Bénédicte Lebel are enjoying working with their captain. You can hear it in our cars (yes, I have a car, help, excommunicate me from the kingdom of Rosemont). On Radio-Canada radio, the contributors to the morning show didn't always click with the host - or with each other - and it was unpleasant for the ears. Passive aggression at dawn doesn't dissolve as well in coffee. Patrick Masbourian is better at gathering his troops, I think. The fact remains that no one has yet the agility, flexibility and speed of Paul Arcand. Who will be in his chair in 2024? Paul Arcand's runner-up is Patrick Lagacé, that's obvious. The two communicators share the same incisive and direct style. In the last year, Patrick Lagacé has developed his more frosty side in Quebec now alongside MC Gilles and Catherine Beauchamp, who have rounded out his squarer angles. For example, the "groovy vindredis" at 6 p.m. lead to a half-hour of radio that could last twice as long because it's so nice. Paul Arcand, Pierre Bruneau or Joël Le Bigot, the office of media legends is certainly getting empty. But we need to free up space if we want to create more legends. To quote Dungeons and Dragons, legends are not born, they are created (or something like that).

titre: Cerebrum 2 | Viol au-dessus d’un lit de coucou
texte: It's great, Cerebrum 2. It's better than the first season, which was, let's remember, quite good. It's a clever combination of crime thriller, psychological suspense and so-called classic medical series. It's speckled with David Fincher-esque twists with a splash of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and several poffs of levity, which allow the series to breathe and lower its anxiety level. On the menu for the first five episodes, which will appear Thursday on Tou.TV's Extra: cut-out letters that form a menacing anagram, a dark web maniac who manipulates an unstable man, abducted and murdered young women, as well as heavy cases in the office of psychiatrist Henri Lacombe (François Papineau). Now, before unpacking the plot, a big reminder is in order. Because the sequel of Cerebrum shows the tip of its nose three years after the release of the first chapter, in the summer of 2019. The pandemic and the withdrawal of the main actor Claude Legault, who suffered from burnout, delayed the start of this drama series signed Richard Blaimert (Hubert and Fanny, Nouvelle adresse) and co-directed by Guy Édoin and Catherine Therrien. Photo provided by Radio-Canada François Papineau reprises the lead role of the series, played by Claude Legault in the first season. For those whose television memory fades after two days (good evening!), here is the quick summary of the first part of Cerebrum. So, psychologist Anne Beaulieu (Évelyne de la Chenelière), wife of renowned psychiatrist Henri Lacombe (Claude Legault), mysteriously disappeared and the investigation concluded that she had been shot. And who had shot Anne? Her friend - cuckolded wife - Sophie Bérubé-Lacroix (Jacynthe René). Anne was sleeping with Sophie's husband, the minister Richard Lacroix (Gabriel Sabourin), an adultery that shattered the life of Henri and his two grown children, William (Henri Picard) and Marine (Marianne Verville). Cerebrum 2 picks up about six months after these tragic events. The transition between Claude Legault and François Papineau, who replaces him in the lead role, occurs naturally, without a break. Back from a long trip to Japan, Henri Lacombe (François Papineau) takes a) his destiny in hand and b) his practice at the hospital. But soon, his troubled past catches up with him. Two young women have been kidnapped and killed, and policewoman Simone Vallier (Christine Beaulieu) arrests someone in Dr. Lacombe's entourage. At the same time, the trial of the alleged murderer Sophie Bérubé-Lacroix (Jacynthe René) is underway, which brings back painful memories for the Lacombe family. Especially since William (Henri Picard) is now dating the daughter (Marguerite Bouchard) of Sophie (Jacynthe René), who killed her own mother (Évelyne de la Chenelière). Are you still here? Cool. Also, Cerebrum 2 puts a former patient of Dr. Lacombe's, the one played by the talented Alexis Martin, back at the center of the story. Remember him? His name was Jules Côté and he was forcibly committed for five months. This lonely, alcoholic and deranged man attracts trouble in spite of himself, it seems. Photo provided by Radio-Canada Alexis Martin plays the character of Jules Côté, a lonely and alcoholic man. Micheline Lanctôt plays Jules' mother, who can no longer swallow the lies of this sick son who has disappointed her for so long. This complex and gangrenous mother-son relationship leads to some very intense scenes. Another important reminder before you start watching Cerebrum 2: Ludivine Reding and Antoine Desrochers played the incestuous twins Laure and Toby in the first season. On a softer note, the cat Ming Lee also returns. The first episode of Cerebrum 2 rolls fast and reframes the story promptly. I love Kanuk investigator Simone Vallier and her partner Danno Boulianne (Olivier Gervais-Courchesne), who form a mismatched but very effective duo. Their sibling-like pickiness softens the creepier moments of Cerebrum. They are perfect. Photo courtesy of Radio-Canada In Cerebrum 2, Henri Lacombe's son William (Henri Picard) is dating Sara (Marguerite Bouchard), who is Sophie's daughter... his mother's murderer. Among the new characters is a young father (excellent Frédéric Millaire-Zouvi) who suffers from a huge post-traumatic shock related to his unconventional and confidential job. A bodyguard (Éric Robidoux) also enters the picture and Frédéric Pierre slips into the shoes of the shrink consulted by Henri Lacombe. The last five episodes of Cerebrum 2 will land on Tou.TV's Extra on Thursday, June 30. Those who do not subscribe to this pay service will see Cerebrum 2 on Radio-Canada in September, on Tuesdays at 9 p.m. The soap opera 5e Rang moves to Mondays at 8:00 p.m. in the former time slot of Une autre histoire. Like Série noire, Cerebrum takes place in the middle of winter, a season that lasts six months and that Quebec TV rarely shows. It's refreshing (LOL) to see these sequences of snowstorms and characters who emit clouds of condensation when they talk outside. Especially when the humidex is about to explode and our air conditioners are coughing like they've caught COVID-19.

titre: La déesse de l’enchantement
texte: Did I want to watch the Canadian radio mini-series about the childhood of writer Gabrielle Roy? Zero and one. A Manitoba-Quebec regional co-production, a low budget for a period series and an abuse of melancholic violins, all the elements converged towards a cathodic disaster of the À la valdrague type (phew!). In fact, I passed when ARTV broadcast the eight half-hour episodes of Le Monde de Gabrielle Roy in March. Thanks, but no thanks. PHOTO PROVIDED BY RADIO-CANADA Martine Francke in Le monde de Gabrielle Roy When Radio-Canada put the work back on its schedule at the end of June (Mondays at 7:30 p.m.), I kept an ear out and an eye out. Especially since Le monde de Gabrielle Roy had received two major nominations for the Gémeaux gala in September: best actress (Martine Francke) and best director (Renée Blanchar). The verdict? It's likeable, touching and charming, not at all quaint. Really, my prejudices have clouded my judgment, sorry. This slow, poetic series resembles the television adaptations that have been made of Lucy Maud Montgomery's novels, including Anne of Green Gables. The free component of Tou.tv offers the first two episodes of Le Monde de Gabrielle Roy. The third episode airs Monday night and the complete collection is available on Tou.tv's Extra. Set between 1919 and 1929, Le monde de Gabrielle Roy is made up of eight memories of the famous writer's youth that would build her literary universe and feed her creative obsessions. Through the sparkling eyes of 10-year-old Gabrielle Roy (Léa-Kim Lafrance-Leroux), the viewer is immersed in the emancipation movement of Manitoban women, the struggle to preserve the French language outside of Quebec, the exile and oppression of francophones, the social class struggle and the desire to escape of a future star of international literature. PHOTO PROVIDED BY RADIO-CANADA Martine Francke and Léa-Kim Lafrance-Leroux in Le monde de Gabrielle Roy No, you won't see the creation of Bonheur d'occasion. Le monde de Gabrielle Roy concludes in the middle of an economic crisis when the heroine (now played by Romane Denis) is 20 years old and studying to become a teacher. In nearly 95% of the scenes in the miniseries, it is the 10-year-old Gabrielle we follow, a curious, dreamy, nosy little girl, along with her older sisters Bernadette, Alicia and Clémence. The character of Gabrielle Roy's mother, Mélina Landry (excellent Martine Francke), clearly stands out. It is she who encourages her daughter Gabrielle to "be part of the big world". A world of lavish balls, silk gloves and shopping at Eaton's that Mélina has never entered. This pious, intense, proud and protective woman is the heart of the family home on Deschambault Street in Saint-Boniface. A seamstress, Mélina is torn between religious traditions and the winds of modernity blowing across the Prairies. Her husband, Léon Roy (Gaston Lepage), fits the stereotype of the man of his time. Both gruff and sensitive, he worked for a long time as a colonization agent for the federal government before losing his job. It is Léon who encourages his daughters to get an education, an invaluable tool for escaping from poverty. Gabrielle Roy's world contains a few irritants, including the omnipresent music that sometimes spoils the mood. This is not a classic biography either, as writer/director Renée Blanchar (Belle-Baie) has taken some historical liberties to embroider her story. No matter. To tan smarter, Le monde de Gabrielle Roy is closer to enchantment than distress. Don't waste your time with Netflix's Snowflake Mountain reality show. It's bad and the "script" - do you still think these shows are unscripted? - is far too obvious to buy into. The concept had an appealing and catchy feel to it though. Ten influencers or rich kids in their twenties, who are allergic to authority since birth, believe they are participating in a luxurious Ibiza villa-type reality show with an infinity pool and unlimited champagne. But they were wrong. The production team lands them in the mountains, in the middle of a forest, where they will have to survive with the means at hand (and without their beauty kit). Who's the woke one here, huh? You are going to suffer, my little ingrates! Of course, these ten members of Generation Z were chosen to represent the stereotype of the "snowflake", a fragile young person unable to tolerate an opinion contrary to their own without taking offense. Of course, two former military men, animators Joel Graves and Matt Tate, try to break them down and toughen them up. Send, you lazy bastards! Log your wood! Pick your fruit! Hunt your meat! And put away your damn cell phones! I gave up after three episodes, which end up repeating the same story: young people today are so shallow, blah, blah, blah. It's big, long. With a little less bad faith, Snowflake Mountain could have been an entertaining show. Its conservative bias, not even exploited with humor, only reinforces prejudices and widens the gap between two generations. Snowflake Mountain thus stays at base camp and doesn't come anywhere near the top.

titre: Qui a le droit, qui a les droits ?
texte: Bowl of Ruffles on the thighs, you go through, in French, the first five chapters of Queen of the South on Netflix. At the sixth season, sorry, the French version is no longer offered to customers. It is possible to watch Queen of the South 6 in Polish, Turkish or Japanese, but not in French. In your living room, you're swearing. Quite loudly, anyway. The next day, you start the first four seasons - dubbed in French - of Animal Kingdom on Netflix. By the fifth season, the French language disappears from the menu. It is impossible to watch Animal Kingdom 5 in any other language than English. Why not? You're screaming a string of church words. These irritating situations, where the French versions of your favorite series disappear or simply don't appear, have been multiplying in recent years. The Kafkaesque case of New Amsterdam illustrates the extent to which programs are scattered, without clear rules for consumers, on different pay platforms. Let's take a closer look at the situation. So TVA relays New Amsterdam Hospital in its regular schedule and Videotron's Club illico offers it in bursts. That's clear. But Radio-Canada's Extra also offers the first three seasons of New Amsterdam to its subscribers, the Global channel has the English-language premiere, while Netflix only offers the first two seasons of this popular American medical series, in English and French. No, but, what an unnecessarily complicated headache. I can understand you being lost in this labyrinth that forces the telephile to play ping-pong with platforms. It's my job to be aware of these details and I myself am mixed up like a deck of cards shuffled by Luc Langevin. PHOTO PETER KRAMER, PROVIDED BY NBC Parveen Kaur and Melissa Roxburgh in Manifest, all three seasons of which can only be viewed in English on Netflix. The case of Manifest - Turbulences, in French - shows how much the viewer loses in this platform war. Currently, the three seasons of Manifest can only be viewed in English on Netflix. It is impossible to watch them in French anywhere. Why not? Because Radio-Canada lost the digital broadcast rights to Manifest/Turbulences when Netflix bought the series from NBC in the summer of 2021. Conclusion: you will not consume Manifest/Turbulences 3 on Tou.TV Extra. You'll have to tune in to Netflix to see it, one day, when Netflix decides to add the French tracks, at a phantom date that has not been announced. Now, how do we find out where our favorite show will be in French? Alas, there is no simple way to find out this information, which is the result of confidential business agreements. "That's a flat answer and it's hard to summarize, because it's always case by case. Every contract is different, depending on who distributes, who produces and who buys," says Radio-Canada's director of acquisitions, Simon Dupuis. Julie Godon, director of French-language specialty channels at Corus, agrees: "It's become very, very complicated, I'm almost as mixed up as the consumers and it will be even worse in the future. The rights are becoming more and more specific and are negotiated in an even more specific way," she explains. That's why the sixth season of Outlander: The Thistle and the Tartan is missing from Netflix. The French-language premiere belongs to ARTV. That's why Peaky Blinders 6 is not available in French on Netflix. The first broadcast was acquired by TV5Unis. And that's why the sixth season of Riverdale is not available on Netflix. It is Vrak, owned by Bell Media, that presents it first, in French. Again, the length of these French-language exclusives varies greatly from contract to contract. It can range from six months to five years. Each clause is negotiated in private. Often, these exclusives cause delays in broadcasting that anger viewers. Take This Is Us. After six seasons, NBC aired the grand finale of this family saga at the end of May. In French, no one has yet "legally" seen the conclusion of This Is Us, as ARTV has included it in its fall 2022 schedule. In France, this final episode of This Is Us was made available almost at the same time as the original English version. In short, there is nothing simple for the average customer. To close out the files, you should know that Queen of the South 6 is available on Séries Plus, a specialized channel of Corus. For Animal Kingdom 5, you have to look at Z. Now, how do you catch up on, say, eight seasons of Homeland, a gripping spy thriller? Take notes, folks, it's byzantine. In English, all eight seasons of Homeland are on Netflix. In French, you have to open Disney+, which hosts the first seven seasons, but not the eighth. So where can you find this eighth season of the international adventures of the bipolar spy Carrie Mathison (Claire Danes)? On the Télé-Québec side, imagine that. The public channel still holds the rights to Homeland 8, but it is not available on its website. And there are no reruns on the schedule. In short, finding a French version of Homeland 8 or infiltrating the Taliban in Afghanistan is the same battle, which is not fought on equal terms.

titre: Never Have I Ever | Jamais, vous ne regrettez jamais votre première fois !
texte: It's great to see the brilliant third season of Never Have I Ever racking up tens of millions of views on the Netflix platform. As of Wednesday, this witty teen comedy with punchy dialogue was the second most-watched show on Netflix, behind blockbuster The Sandman, but ahead of soap opera Virgin River. Even in its third chapter, this atypical teen drama has not lost its liveliness and originality, on the contrary. It's still funny, charming and finely written. Finally, a mainstream comedy that talks about sexual or ethnic diversity without sounding like a lecture or a CBC radio segment.
