Teens and their allies (cuckoo!) deserve this kind of quality television that speaks their language and interweaves so-called light-hearted topics with heavier issues like sexual humiliation, the disappearance of a parent or the weight of an immigrant family's traditions. In each of the 10 half-hours, the viewer never feels that the writers are sending pseudo-educational messages. The plots, both airy and deep, unfold efficiently between a sharp gag and two tonic lines. And the tone waltzes between humor and drama, without a false note or misstep. At the beginning of the third season of My First Times, heroine Devi Vishwakumar, 16, is dating handsome Paxton Hall-Yoshida (Darren Barnet), the most coveted athlete at Sherman Oaks High School, an affluent suburb in Southern California. This was Devi's goal at the very beginning of the series: to hang out with the cool gang, get a hot boyfriend and get into Princeton University. Devi will soon realize that dating the hottest guy in school won't magically erase all her problems. The Canadian actress who plays Devi, Maitreyi Ramakrishnan, has an incredible sense of comedy. What's even better is that the teenage character she plays wears a variety of masks, allowing the young actress to show off her range. There is the sarcastic, drooling, ultra-confident Devi. There is the Devi greatly affected by the sudden death of her father. There is the worried and egotistical Devi, who throws her anxieties in the face of her shrink. There is the Devi who lives in an Indo-American household with her mother Nalini (who is becoming less and less strict), her grandmother Nirmala, who is very attached to her culture, as well as her cousin, who is also in search of emancipation. All the Devis coexist in harmony in this multi-ethnic and multi-generational universe. Devi's friends, the scientist Fabiola and the actress Eleanor, also have heart problems. Ben, Devi's "rival friend", is always in the orbit of the trio of girls and a third suitor, the attractive Nirdesh, will confuse our beloved Devi's feelings radar. The cherry on top of My First Times is the narration of almost every episode by John McEnroe. Yes, yes, John McEnroe, the legendary tennis player. His detached yet invested tone adds even more color to this delightful rainbow series. It's the return of the colony's inspector (Louis Champagne), the mud, the bugs and the rudimentary tools! Huge success on the Historia channel in 2017, the reality show The Devil's Lot will return to the airwaves on Friday, November 11 with new adventures seasoned with the salt of the Gaspé. PHOTO LAURENCE LABAT, PROVIDED BY CORUS Louis Champagne in The Devil's Lot After the woods, the contestant-colons of The Devil's Lot - The Conquest of the Sea will now survive near a Paspébiac fishing bank in the 1930s. The prize is $100,000. And no question of relying on current conveniences, because all the challenges will be carried out as in the time of the Great Depression. Also on Historia, two new Quebec productions will enhance the fall line-up: Secrets de villages (October 26), about big secrets hidden in small Quebec villages, and the docu-drama Hells Angels - La chute (December 10), about the end of the reign of terror of Maurice "Mom" Boucher. Émile Schneider will play the informer Stéphane "Godasse" Gagné. You will also see on Historia new episodes of Perdu dans la poussière (August 30), Transmission impossible (September 1) and La fièvre des enchères - Nouvelle génération (October 4). Séries Plus has kept two Quebec series for the winter. The first one is based on the novel Haute démolition by Jean-Philippe Baril Guérard, with Étienne Galloy, Léane Labrèche-Dor and Irdens Exantus in the main roles. The second is called Les bombes and stars Olivia Palacci, Debbie Lynch-White, Sarah Desjeunes Rico and Julie de Lafrenière. Created by Kim Lévesque-Lizotte, Les bombes will tell the story of the torments of four thirty-somethings who are struggling with addictions. Still on Séries Plus, there is no question of touching NCIS Mondays or FBI Tuesdays. The Corus-owned specialty channel has picked up Moonshine (Aug. 31), Red Election (Sept. 2) and 4400 (Sept. 2), as well as renewed episodes of Blue Bloods, Bull, Station 19, Charmed, Last Stop, The Resident and An Exemplary Fight. Come on, it's time to empty your recorders. Because the brand new stock is coming soon!

titre: District 31 | Parlons du bon commandant Chiasson !
texte: The "suspense" won't last as long as the case of the stolen land from Judge Pelland of the Ké-Pac mail service (or something like that). You'll find out this Monday night, in the opening minutes of District 31 on Radio-Canada, what will happen to our good Commander Chiasson (Gildor Roy), who was kidnapped by the two most influential members of the Sixers in the last episode that aired in December. Quick reminder here. Daniel Chiasson, the main character of Luc Dionne's show, was driving his Dodge Durango when he was intercepted by fake policemen, who then delivered him to François Labelle (Peter Miller) and Ryan Robin (Dan Bigras). Standing in a dimly lit warehouse, big shot François Labelle told Chiasson, in the only tone of voice we've heard from him so far, "Phaneuf, it happened in the back of a salad cart. You, it will happen here. Oh! Of course, the fans have gone crazy, still traumatized by the murder of Poupou (Sébastien Delorme), the departure of Gabrielle Simard (Geneviève Brouillette) and the new hair of Sonia Blanchard (Pascale Montpetit). If they kill Chiasson, for real, I'll hand in my badge, my gun and my resignation, you threatened, taking you all for mini Me Durand (Stéphan Côté) in court. You must believe that the big cleanup by the writer and producer Fabienne Larouche has worked well. You are all afraid now. Like in Game of Thrones, you know that no character in District 31, even a nice guy like Stéphane Pouliot, is safe from doing a Nick Romano (Mathieu Baron), i.e. disappearing without a trace. One thing you should know, however, is that before Daniel Chiasson dies or runs away - no spoilers, don't worry - he has a long conversation with his two "captors". And these scenes are full of crucial information for the continuation of the investigations. Speaking of investigations, the one involving the purchase and repatriation of the RV to the United States is about to be closed. This means that Sylvain Coulombe (Denis Bouchard) will no longer spend so much money at the restaurant at lunch. The dirty cop in Denis Corbin (Paul Doucet) remains at the heart of the story in the first four episodes of 2022 that I previewed. Corbin has been arrested, and the detective sergeants at 31 are scrambling to link him to Poupou's murder. This Monday we'll find out whether or not Major Chiasson will get away with it. But whatever happens, we're sure there will be plenty of suspense and action. Fans of District 31 can't wait to see how the detective sergeants of 31 will solve the Corbin case and link the murder of Poupou to the purchase and repatriation of the RV to the United States. What is certain is that the good Commander Chiasson has always been a central character in the series. He has always been there for his colleagues and to protect them. He is their mentor and guide, and they will do anything to save him. As we wait with bated breath to see what happens next, we are sure that Commander Chiasson will have a significant influence on the course of events. Whether he is saved or not, we are sure that his presence will always be felt in District 31.

titre: Aller simple | Jouer à Clue à la télé !
texte: Yes, the TV schedule is already overflowing with great series to watch, with Netflix's overstuffed catalog beckoning, as well as the 42 other pay platforms packed with prestigious shows that rack up awards. But save yourself an hour a week for Noovo's One Way, a gripping thriller that borrows as much from the works of Agatha Christie as it does from an excellent series like Disney+'s Only Murders in the Building or films like Knives Out, with a darker twist. Message to readers who can't find Only Murders in the Building on Disney+: remove the parental filter, which automatically blocks so-called adult programming. You're welcome. So, One Way. It starts Wednesday at 8 p.m. on Noovo against Les enfants de la télé on Radio-Canada and Les moments parfaits on TVA. Three proposals that will appeal to three different audiences. If it's any consolation to check it out, or better yet, both, Aller simple comes from the effective team behind Epidemic and The Imposter on TVA: writers Bernard Dansereau, Annie Piérard and Étienne Piérard-Dansereau, as well as skilled director Yan Lanouette Turgeon. After seeing the first two episodes on Monday, I would have gladly put on the last four to solve this intriguing mystery. But who is pulling the strings in this human game of Clue? Why have these six people - plus a last-minute companion - been thrown together on this journey that turns into a nightmare? Who is trying to punish them for their past mistakes? That's where the pleasure lies in watching One Way, a miniseries where protagonists die very quickly (don't get too attached) and where no character shows his or her true face. We then look for clues, linger on all the details and speculate on who did what and why in this very well knitted story. One Way is a production onion, which reveals itself layer by layer, with punches at the end of each episode. It's rudely appealing. At first, the six passengers of One Way don't know each other. They meet on the tarmac as they prepare to board a private helicopter bound for Val-Beaulac, an estate owned by eccentric billionaire Robert Beaulac (Germain Houde). PHOTO YAN TURCOTTE, PROVIDED BY NOOVO Éric Bruneau plays one of the six passengers in Aller simple. All six passengers are complex characters with hidden secrets and motivations. We gradually discover their stories, their connections and their secrets, which makes Clue's play even more interesting. The actors are all very good, and their performances are very convincing. Eric Bruneau plays the main character, a lawyer who is in trouble with the law and is looking for redemption. He is surrounded by characters such as the young and ambitious entrepreneur Marie-Ève (Mélissa Bédard), the doctor and ex-military man Jean-François (Éric Robidoux), the mysterious and dark Étienne (Émile Proulx-Cloutier), the rich and eccentric Élise (Marianne Verville) and the young and talented musician Mathieu (Émile Schneider). Each of these characters has their own story and secrets, and their interactions are very interesting to watch. The scenes are well shot and the suspense is well maintained throughout the series. Viewers are invited to play Clue with the characters, trying to guess who the culprit is and discovering everyone's secrets. One Way is a captivating series that will keep viewers entertained and intrigued. So get ready to play Clue on TV and find out who the culprit is!

titre: Big Brother Covidés et Star Épidémie
texte: The Omicron variant continues to plague Quebec's two biggest reality shows. After comedian Eddy King, five other Celebrity Big Brother contestants - out of a total of 17 - have contracted COVID-19, forcing production to rearrange the studio house to separate the sick from the rest of the healthy players, well-connected sources tell me. The six cases of COVID-19 in the cast of Noovo's Big Brother Celebrity did not stop filming from continuing in a warehouse in Anjou, on the east side of Montreal, I am told. The five who were left out are Martin Vachon, Michelle Desrochers (my favorite), Lysanne Richard, Valérie Carpentier and Stéphanie Harvey. As for Star Académie, the first Sunday gala has been postponed for another week, as six academicians tested positive for COVID-19 earlier this week, bringing the number of infected contestants to ten out of a cohort of 19. This is starting to look like herd immunity. According to my information, Star Ac director Lara Fabian has also fallen ill, although her press secretary, Junior Bombardier, has neither confirmed nor denied this. The first Sunday gala of the popular TV talent show is now scheduled for January 30 at 7 p.m. With the drastic measures that have been taken since the outbreak and the number of contestants who have already contracted COVID-19, "it is unlikely that this will require an additional postponement," TVA said in a statement. Producers Jean-Philippe Dion and Benoit Clermont of Déferlantes, as well as TVA management, declined interview requests Wednesday. The week-long move of Star Académie cost millions, revealed Jean-Philippe Dion, Monday night, during his appearance on Patrick Huard's special program La tour. Back on Big Brother Celebrity, the increase in cases has split the game into two factions: the covids, who have moved into the boss's room with an adjacent bathroom, and the negatives, who are in the rest of the studio house. The two groups do not mix. You'll see this clear division - and the enforcement of the new health rules - in the episode of Celebrity Big Brother that Noovo will relay Thursday at 6:30 p.m. Of course, an infected contestant still has the option, like comedian Eddy King, of moving to the hotel and returning healthy without penalty. However, the five people with COVID-19 chose to do their lockdown in front of the cameras, in their quarantine dormitory. | Celebrity Big Brother and Star Académie producers have taken extra measures to ensure the safety of contestants and crew members. Screening tests are conducted daily and contestants are required to wear masks and follow social distancing guidelines. titre: Fans de District 31, calmez-vous !
texte: "This is really the year of too much District 31! Frankly, the bulletproof vest thing, so improbable and ridiculous! OK, Luc Dionne is so uninspired that he tried to get rid of Noélie [Catherine St-Laurent], that's it for me!" Dear District 31 fans, calm down. It's getting heavy, your litany of complaints and your threats to abandon the popular Radio-Canada series at the slightest annoyance. You bitch about everything, all the time, without taking a filtered coffee break or taking a walk in the parking lot. It wears on you, all this repeated nagging. When COVID-19 stopped filming the popular crime drama, you all climbed into the curtains. But what are we going to do at 7 p.m., right? District 31 is an essential service! Bring back our investigators! In a very difficult health context, District 31 managed to turn its cameras back on by respecting a bunch of restrictive technical instructions. A small miracle, in the summer of 2020, remember. And what was your reaction upon viewing these distanced episodes, which were delivered with pain and misery? The machine gun of blame. "Come on, characters standing six feet apart is so awkward and poorly done!" You then spent the next two weeks noting every time the distancing was visible on screen. Oh, it was visible, the distancing. But it was either that or nothing. A few months later, when author Luc Dionne, to spice up his story, sketched out a potential departure of Major Daniel Chiasson (Gildor Roy), you collectively cringed. "For real, if Major Chiasson dies, I will never watch District 31 again, it's over! You've just lost your most loyal viewer," you wrote on social networks. I've read this comment at least 1000 times. It comes back at fixed times, like Stéphanie Malo (Virginie Ranger-Beauregard) with her work case. For the past two years, you have not given the new characters in District 31 a chance. Right away, it's the guillotine. After only one appearance of Detective-Lieutenant Mélanie Charron (Ève Landry), your judgment fell: I "hated her", she's stupid, not enough this, too much that. You even called for the return of (the late) Nadine Legrand (Magalie Lépine-Blondeau) at 31. Many of you think that Nadine was not killed, that she will reappear for the grand finale. That's a load of nonsense. Nadine is dead and buried. Forget about her. PHOTO FROM THE SHOW'S FACEBOOK PAGE Major Chiasson (Gildor Roy) and Detective-Lieutenant Mélanie Charron (Ève Landry) The death of Poupou (Sébastien Delorme) also shook you up: how dare Luc Dionne do this to us? I'm sure I'd be stumped without Poupou! But no, another empty threat. But you know what? You're welcome in the world of District 31. You are welcome to criticize, to complain, to be moved and to rejoice. You are welcome to get involved and to engage. You are welcome to share your opinions and feedback. You are welcome to care and to be involved. You are welcome to feel a part of the District 31 universe. But you know what? You are welcome to remember that District 31 is fiction. You are welcome to remember that the characters are characters and their actions don't always make sense. You are welcome to remember that writers are allowed to take liberties and risks. You are welcome to remember that writers have the right to create stories that are not always predictable. You are welcome to remember that writers have the right to make decisions that are not always popular. So, District 31 fans, calm down. Appreciate the work of the writers and actors. Appreciate their courage and determination. Appreciate their willingness to entertain and move you. Appreciate their willingness to make you laugh and to make you cry. Appreciate their willingness to make you think and react. Appreciate their will to make you experience adventures and emotions. Appreciate their desire to make you experience stories that touch you and make you think. Appreciate their will to make you live moments that make you vibrate and that make you dream. Appreciate their willingness to give you moments that make you feel alive and connected. Appreciate their will to make you live moments that make you feel alive and connected to the District 31 universe.

titre: Un Lac-Noir peu profond
texte: So, is the supernatural crime thriller Lac-Noir, available this Thursday on Videotron's Club illico? I would answer: no. It's not great or bad. Just okay and average. At least in the two episodes out of a total of eight that I saw on Wednesday. It's disappointing, because all the ingredients of a captivating suspense are there: a forest village a la Twin Peaks, a summer camp a la Friday the 13th - or even a la Jeremiah, for the romances -, rumors of Satanism, a half-senile old lady who serves as an oracle, a clairvoyant priest, wooden pentacles like in Servant from Apple TV+, this proven recipe titillates any fan of genre series. On screen, Black Lake suffers from the lame construction of its story. For example, the first episode opens with a super-strong scene involving a cop in distress (Marc Fournier), who has to deal with a (information deleted to preserve the punch). It's gory, scary and addictive. And then? And then, nothing. The story picks up about the charming village of Lac-Noir, deep in the Laurentians, and hardly mentions this investigator, who has surely lost a lot of blood. Let's start here with a nice country music. In fact, one suspects that the inhabitants of Lac-Noir, behind their cold smiles, hide something very dark. Like: they worship the devil in a clearing on the nights of the full moon. The problem? Authors Martin Girard and Charles Dionne don't give enough clues to hook us. It's too slow. Especially for a mini-series that lasts only eight hours. And as long as you're making a horror series, why not embrace it fully? Lac-Noir drives with its foot on the brake, it seems. Maybe the next six episodes will suck us into a vortex of fear, we'll have to see. Lac-Noir begins with the arrival in the village of a new SQ policewoman, Valerie (Mélissa Désormeaux-Poulin). This patrolwoman has experienced a traumatic event in Montreal (tormented cop: check!) and flees into the woods with her son Dave (Anthony Therrien of Les Bracelets rouges). At the tiny SQ station, not unlike the one in 5e rang, Valerie investigates with police chief Adrien (Stéphane Demers). Valerie and Adrien are quickly confronted with supernatural events and dark forces that threaten the village. The inhabitants are divided between those who believe in the supernatural forces and those who reject them. The two policemen are soon confronted with forces beyond their understanding and ability to solve the mystery. The scenes are well shot and the special effects are well done. The actors are good and their performances are convincing. The music is also very well chosen and fits perfectly with the dark and mysterious atmosphere of the series. Despite all these positive elements, Black Lake lacks depth and suspense. The characters are too shallow and the events are too predictable. There are too few action scenes and too few suspenseful moments. The series also lacks rhythm and dynamism. The episodes are too long and the revelations too slow. Nevertheless, Black Lake is an entertaining series that is worth watching. Fans of supernatural thrillers should enjoy this series and its mysteries. Others should find enough entertainment to have a good time in front of their TV.

titre: La vie d’factrie d’Olivier
texte: It's hard to remain unmoved by a moving story like that of Olivier Bergeron of Star Académie. The 20-year-old New Brunswicker was headed for elimination earlier this week. His placement in jeopardy alongside Mathieu Rheault and Édouard Lagacé looked like a sure-fire eviction. Olivier Bergeron, who works in a sawmill in Kedgwick, a job he hates, saw his musical dream slip through his fingers. And he broke down in front of the cameras. I don't want to leave," he said in essence, "I want to make a living with my music, I'm finally doing something I love in life, don't take that away from me. PHOTO TAKEN FROM STAR ACADEMY'S FACEBOOK PAGE Olivier Bergeron In the office of the director, Lara Fabian, the shy Olivier Bergeron uttered phrases that crushed the hearts of viewers: "Here in Waterloo, I don't need to drink to feel good, while before, I was just looking forward to the weekend to destroy myself in drink." It was an unexpected moment of very raw truth. After such touching and heartfelt confessions, reminiscent of Clémence DesRochers' La vie d'factrie, it was impossible not to support this young man in the conquest of his dreams. That's what TVA viewers did on Sunday night, protecting Olivier from elimination. Vocally, Olivier Bergeron is not the most gifted of the academicians, but he chose a song tailored to him, À hauteur d'homme, by Vincent Vallières, which almost tells the story of his own life. He performed it soberly, sitting on a stool, and won the hearts of the voters. No one could have predicted such a turnaround last week. PHOTO FROM STAR ACADEMY'S FACEBOOK PAGE Édouard Lagacé The three teachers selected Édouard Lagacé, 27, from Cowansville, who covered High Hopes, by the Irish group Kodaline. A decent performance, but lacking in depth. Édouard suffers from a strong impostor syndrome that his teachers are working hard to eradicate. Mathieu Rheault, 27, from Laval, was sent home. Since he was the least solid of the three - with his lukewarm replay of Serge Gainsbourg's Je suis venu te dire que je m'en vais - the logical order was respected. PHOTO FROM STAR ACADÉMIE's FACEBOOK PAGE Mathieu Rheault This fifth gala took off with a medley of Simple Plan's pop-punk hits, where Audrey-Louise (on Jet Lag) and Krystel (on The Antidote) stole the show. Jérémy Plante was also very good on I'd Do Anything. Funny idea to add a BMX in the picture. It must look young, I guess. The number orchestrated by Mitsou, the first guest artistic director of the season, was surprising and flamboyant, but would have benefited from more depth on stage. That said, the string of La corrida, Les Chinois, Bye bye mon cowboy, Lettre à un cowboy, C'est chaud, Le yaya and Dis-moi, dis-moi put a smile on our faces, as did Roxane Bruneau's funny comments about the three guys in danger. This week, Olivier Bergeron managed to stand out and be noticed by his peers and by viewers. His performance was remarkable and showed how passionate he is about music. He was able to convey his emotions through his song and touch the audience. This week, Olivier proved that he is more than just an academician and that he is capable of surpassing himself and showing his true personality. This week, viewers got to see the real Olivier Bergeron and his passion for music. He managed to stand out and show how talented he is. He also managed to convey his emotions through his song and touch the audience. This week, Olivier proved that he was more than just an academician and that he was able to surpass himself and show his true personality. This week, Olivier Bergeron managed to stand out and be noticed by his peers and by the viewers. His performance was remarkable and showed how passionate he is about music. He was able to convey his emotions through his song and touch the audience. His performance was also noticed by the teachers, who were impressed by his passion and determination. This week, Olivier Bergeron proved that he was more than just an academician and that he was able to surpass himself and show his true personality. He managed to stand out and be noticed by his peers and by the viewers. His performance was remarkable and showed how passionate he is about music. He managed to convey his emotions through his song and touch the audience. His performance was also noticed by the teachers, who were impressed by his passion and determination. Olivier Bergeron proved that he is capable of realizing his dreams and making a living from his music.

titre: L’homme n’aimera plus trop à Noovo
texte: The artist-sculptor Nadira, the restorer Josée or the orthopedagogue Geneviève? Which of the women in his life would forgive Marc-Alexandre and take him home to live (finally) happily and have many (more) children? None of the three, we found out on Tuesday night in the eighth and final episode of the intriguing miniseries The Man Who Loved Too Much, written by Anne Boyer and Michel d'Astous for Noovo. For those of you who are late to the screen, the trigger alert here sounds like one of the two cell phones of the traveling salesman Marc-Alexandre (Patrice Godin), but which one? OK, that's it. The Man Who Loved Too Much ended in a bloodbath, which Nostradumas, though an old hand, did not see coming. Rejected and humiliated, the new mother Nadira (Nadia Kounda) followed Marc-Alexandre to Montreal and shot him in the street. In front of his two other families, gathered for Sophie's birthday (Romy Bouchard). For Nadira, the abandonment was unforgivable, it was intolerable. We had been preparing this from the beginning and even showed her brother's [Reda Guerinik] gun in the second episode. Michel d'Astous, writer of The Man Who Loved Too Much Without his anti-hero, you will understand that The Man Who Loved Too Much will not have a second season. It is well and truly over. At the beginning, this psychological thriller, which I liked, had been imagined as a closed work, without possibility of continuation. Except that in the middle of filming, the two authors strongly considered not to liquidate their central character anymore to continue the exploration of polyamory in a second chapter. "We would have had to change the ending, obviously. But we would have liked that, to see how Marc-Alexandre's polyamory would be lived, if everyone got on board. What would it have been like?" wonders Michel d'Astous. The idea was abandoned, mainly because of a lack of time to write eight new episodes, and the initial ending remained in the script, which sealed the fate of all the protagonists. Marc-Alexandre's first wife, the elegant Josée (Hélène Florent), slept with her ex one last time to free herself from him. This scene of reclaiming power in a relationship was powerful. PHOTO MARCO CAMPANOZZI, LA PRESSE Writer Michel d'Astous In Magog, after shedding all the tears in her body, Geneviève (Fanny Mallette) also understood that the bond of trust with Marc-Alexandre would never be restored. And she made peace with that. Seen by 562,000 people on Tuesday nights, L'homme qui aimait trop, which explores the triple life of a man who would not be described as an asshole, was difficult to write and sell to the Noovo network, recalls Michel d'Astous: "This series was a real challenge for the writers, because it deals with taboo and controversial subjects such as polyamory and polygamy. Despite this, it has succeeded in captivating the audience and sparking conversations about these topics. The characters are complex and their stories are very well written. The actors delivered outstanding performances and their interpretations of the characters were very convincing. The series was also very well directed and the music helped to create an intense and captivating atmosphere. Finally, the script was very well constructed and managed to maintain the suspense until the end. All in all, The Man Who Loved Too Much is a series worth seeing and has managed to captivate the audience."

titre: OD Croatie, c’est remis !
texte: After OD Chez nous at Cut Mountain and OD out West at Whistler, the next destination for Noovo's cupid reality show had been chosen, according to my faithful spies. It was Croatia, a European country that has been experiencing a huge tourism boom for many years. Now imagine an ODefi in the old town of Dubrovnik, the pearl of the Adriatic, where part of the magnificent Game of Thrones series was filmed. Think of our singles popping a Popper on the beach of Zlatni Rat, known as the Golden Horn. Let's say it's a change from virtual trips to a half-basement in St. Jean de Matha. Since the beginning of the pandemic, it was the first time that Jay Du Temple and his band could have settled outside Canada. But the unpredictable and dangerous war in the Ukraine forced the Double Occupation team to change their base camp for safety reasons. The two houses where the new batch of OD would have lived were about 900 kilometers from the Ukrainian border. But no risk was taken, decided Productions J, which manufactures Double Occupancy for Noovo. The safety of the contestants and the 100 or so employees of the reality show comes first. The production of OD is currently looking for an alternative location, where the weather will be warm and sunny and the political climate will be less explosive. Let's bet it won't be Las Terrenas, in the Dominican Republic, where TVA's L'île de l'amour will soon be moving. In any case, OD was shot there in 2009. And there's no question of a repeat edition of OD in Quebec or Canada, unless there is a 13th wave of COVID-19 in the fall. Officially, Occupation double has not yet "flushed 100% of the houses in Croatia", according to a source within the team. There is still a slim chance that the adventure will take place there. But don't bet a can of Shaker Mixology on it. You'd risk losing the deposit prize. PHOTO PROVIDED BY PRODUCTION Normand Daneau, Yanic Truesdale, Christian Bégin and Alexis Martin, the four guys The last two episodes of the comedy Les mecs à Radio-Canada led us to believe that the character of Étienne Lebeau (Yanic Truesdale) was disappearing from the series. Without preamble, we learned that Étienne was subletting his condo, that he was entrusting the gym to his assistant (Catherine Renaud) and that he was taking off with his boyfriend Dan (Guillaume Lambert) for a year-long getaway. Check it out: no, Etienne was not removed from the script. If writer Jacques Davidts sent the fourth member of the foursome on a trip, it was to temporarily free up actor Yanic Truesdale, who participated in the filming last spring of the new Netflix series God's Favorite Idiot, alongside his friend Melissa McCarthy (Gilmore Girls). This year, Quebec viewers will be able to follow the adventures of the Occupation Double bachelors in an as-yet unknown location. Rumors are flying and speculation is rife. Some are betting on a return to Las Terrenas, in the Dominican Republic, where the series was shot in 2009. Others believe that the production is looking for an alternative, safer location, where the political climate is less explosive. Either way, OD fans can't wait to find out the final destination and see their favorite bachelors have fun and find love. Stay tuned for more details on the upcoming season of Occupation Double, which promises to be more exciting than ever!

titre: 5 gars pour moi | On veut Louise Sigouin, bon !
texte: Spring is already dull and grey and it will sink even deeper into darkness and coldness without our goddess of dualities, Louise Sigouin. It tears my soul to write it, but here it is: TVA has moved the next edition of Si on s'aimait to the fall - and maybe even to 2023. And unlike the participants of this reality show, I am unable to swallow, digest and burp this devastating information. It's a disaster even worse than the emotional slip-up between Audrey and Dominic after an aqua-siren class. Worse than the moldy strawberries Tim served to golfer Marie-Denise. Worse than a bagpipe show orchestrated by Jean-François on his suburban patio. How will we survive without healing our wounds of shame? Who will help us set our boundaries and connect with our inner world, huh? Are we allowed to live vicariously through marital bliss with Vicky and François, please? OK, no. Strike the last sentence. Vicky and François, the darling couple of If We Loved Each Other, have broken up, according to my moles. They went to the end of their adventure and that's why their joint Facebook page is closed, I'm told. Another disappointment: the spring show that will replace Si on s'aimait is no match for him - or for Gabriel's tattooed thigh. This daily, which starts Monday at 7 p.m. on TVA, is called 5 gars pour moi and its title encapsulates all its content. PHOTO JAY ARSENAULT, TAKEN FROM THE 5 GARS POUR MOI WEBSITE The first contestant, Janie, 35, a translation project manager, hosts five suitors in her home and eliminates one a day until she keeps only the right one at the end of the week. A single woman hosts five suitors in her home and eliminates one a day until she keeps only the right one at the end of the week. This English format (Five Guys a Week) resembles the Cupid's version of Dinner with a twist. The first four 30-minute episodes revolve around Janie, 35, a translation project manager. A mechanic (Simon, 41), a civil servant (Mathieu, 34), a project manager (Alexandre, 41), a sales manager and bartender (Dany, 36) and a sales consultant (Marc-André, 37) drop off at Janie's Monteregie home in the hopes of winning her heart. In a "Wood & Leather" type setting, the men cook tataki (classic!) and sell their salad (fresh!) to Janie, who "exudes a beautiful personality", according to Alexandre, a poet and imitator of the Gaspesian accent. Since the candidates on 5 Guys for Me change every week, it's impossible to get attached to them or to follow their evolution. It's suburban speed dating without the accompaniment of Louise Sigouin and the exposed bare feet of Guillaume Lemay-Thivierge and Émily Bégin. Despite their absence, we can always look to Louise Sigouin to guide us through this new adventure. After all, she taught us to love and accept ourselves and to find happiness in our lives. She showed us how we can connect to our inner world and our limits. She taught us to open up to others and to love ourselves. She showed us how we can find happiness and peace in our lives. That's why, even though 5 Guys for Me can't replace If We Loved Each Other, we can always look to Louise Sigouin for guidance and inspiration. We can always remember her lessons and use them to find happiness and peace in our lives. We can always remember that we are capable of finding happiness and peace, even if we are not watching If We Loved Each Other. We can always remember that we are capable of finding happiness and peace, even if we are not watching 5 Guys for Me.

titre: Cuisiner par procuration devant la télévision
texte: I cook like a pot. I waste food - hello bag of moldy spinach shoots at the bottom of the vegetable drawer. I throw out the kale, Jean-Luc Boulay would go into syncope, I pay rapper Loud's salary in Uber Eats and my oven has never been super stained or ultra sticky. Yeah for me! On the other hand, put a cake competition on Netflix (Nailed It!) or a reality show like The Chefs! in front of me and I devour everything until I lick the bottom of the plate like an Ostrogoth. To paraphrase Jean-Jacques Goldman, I cook by proxy in front of my television set, even if I don't put old bread on my balcony. I love food shows, prepared in any way: competition, fiction or marathon. The latest on the menu? HBO's period mini-series Julia on the Crave platform, in French and English. It's absolutely charming and cracking. It's comfort food the way we like it: warm, generous and not pretentious. With a few Mad Men touches, Julia focuses on the television debut of America's most European of chefs, Julia Child, played by the excellent British actress Sarah Lancashire, better than Meryl Streep in the 2009 film Julie & Julia. The first of eight episodes of Julia begins in 1962, in Cambridge, a suburb of Boston. The wife of a diplomat who was deployed throughout Europe, the vivacious Julia Child published her first cookbook, Mastering the Art of French Cooking, a classic for food lovers. Julia Child's relative celebrity in Boston piques the interest of the young, switched-on producer of a snobbish local public television literary show, which no one watches. Julia Child is suspicious. What will she talk about with the host who usually hosts obscure, pipe-smoking authors? At the last minute, Julia stuffs eggs, butter and a whisk into her bag. On the set, she asks for an electric skillet and prepares, live, a creamy omelet in front of the dumbfounded crew. The jovial Julia Child shines in front of the cameras. She's funny, witty and natural, which is quite a contrast in this rigid and austere environment. Despite letters from viewers demanding her return, the station's bosses despise Julia Child. titre: Merci Stranger Things et Kate Bush !
texte: Telephoners who binged the fourth chapter of Stranger Things this weekend are currently unable to extract a (great) song from the coconut. A haunting 1985 tune so aptly employed in the fourth episode - but also echoing in Max's walkman in the first episode - that it has catapulted its performer into the hot topics of Twitter. It's Kate Bush's Running Up That Hill (A Deal With God), a song from the album Hounds of Love. Since Friday morning, nostalgic fans are rediscovering the immense talent of this British singer-songwriter, and a new generation is compulsively listening on Spotify to the one who has been nicknamed the "witch of sound". The marriage between the strange Kate Bush and Stranger Things on Netflix could not have been better celebrated. First, Running Up That Hill's script fits perfectly with the reality of teenager Max (Sadie Sink), who feels guilty about the death of her older brother Billy and puts up an emotional barrier between her and her friends. Then, the harrowing scene where Max runs to save herself from the clawed hands of the demon Vecna syncs perfectly with the percussive beat of Running Up That Hill. This sequence is a great example of how a carefully chosen song magnifies a storyline and elevates the work to levels rarely achieved. It is superb. Expected for three years - that's a looong time - this fourth season of Stranger Things, more violent and gory than the previous ones, arrives in jumbo format: all episodes last between 1 hour and 1 hour 40 minutes. And fans, like me, will feast on this buffet of pop culture. Stranger Things' more mature turn takes us out of the Goonies and Indiana Jones and catapults us into horror worlds like Carrie, The Exorcist, Hellraiser and A Nightmare on Elm Street (what a classic!), which obviously inspired the creators of Stranger Things, twins Matt and Ross Duffer. Goodbye John Hughes, hello Wes Craven. PHOTO PROVIDED BY NETFLIX Stranger Things 4 Robert Englund, who long donned the sharp claws and striped sweater of the murderous Freddy Krueger in A Nightmare on Elm Street, even appears in the fourth episode as Victor Creel, the prisoner with the gouged-out eyes. I love it. Stranger Things has aged, as have its performers, and its references are no longer aimed at pre-teens. It's become a chilling It-style horror series, where the new villain Vecna looks like the terrifying Night King in Game of Thrones. The first episode of Stranger Things 4 frames the story nicely, picking up six months after the epic mall battle.| Stranger Things fans are ecstatic about this fourth season, which has been critically acclaimed for its maturity and depth. The characters are more complex and the storylines are darker, giving the series a new dimension. Fans are also pleased to see that the series draws inspiration from classic horror films, such as Carrie, The Exorcist, Hellraiser and A Nightmare on Elm Street. The presence of Robert Englund, who played Freddy Krueger in A Nightmare on Elm Street, is another highlight of this season. The music is also an important element of the series. Fans were delighted to discover that Kate Bush's song Running Up That Hill (A Deal With God) was aptly used in the fourth episode. The song fits perfectly with the atmosphere of the series and adds an extra layer to the plot. The series was also praised for its representation of female characters. Max, played by Sadie Sink, is a strong, independent character who stands up for what she believes in. She is a role model for young women watching the series who are looking for a positive female role model. The fourth season of Stranger Things has been a success and fans can't wait to see what the series has in store for us next.

titre: Pourquoi personne ne parle de Wentworth ?
texte: I've got a hard-on for Wentworth, Australia's equivalent of Unit 9 about all the designer drugs that female prisoners manage to snort, smoke, inject or swallow illegally. In Wentworth Prison, the Lietteville of Australian TV, Bowling Ball, Jeanne Biron and Britanny Sizzla would collapse at the drop of a hat in front of freak Joan Ferguson, psychopath Lou Kelly or the very militant Kaz Proctor. The corridors of Wentworth ooze fear and danger. Inmates trap each other in the showers, challenge each other to handmade knife fights and torture each other with a steam press. It's closer to Oz than Orange Is the New Black, say. It's the Game of Thrones of the prison universe, where the heroines rarely survive more than three years in their cells. Don't get too attached to them, except in handcuffs. Tears flow louder than adulterated alcohol. The final episodes of Wentworth's eighth and final season are online on Netflix and (in French subtitled version) on Tou.tv's Extra. Netflix has the entire Wentworth collection, 100 episodes, if you're looking for TV to binge watch this weekend. By the way, I'm surprised that Wentworth isn't more successful and that people don't discuss it more on social networks: it's an extremely effective show, full of twists and turns. Why praise such a violent and ruthless TV show? Because it fulfills its entertainment mandate. Because the actresses are shocking. Because a federal prison like the one depicted in Wentworth is not a Club Med where you braid your hair between two Macarena choreographies. Back in the eighth chapter of Wentworth, the tension rises to "bingo" level just hours before the grand finale. Two gruesome murders have been committed inside the walls of Wentworth, the management is tightening the screws even more and the prisoners are plotting non-stop to eliminate their rivals. And Wentworth wouldn't exist without its drug trade, its time in the hole, its physical abuse, its internal wars for control of the prison, its riots, its pipe bombs and its bad food. Coming from all socio-economic backgrounds, the women locked up at Wentworth - who donned the teal uniform - allowed us to explore a ton of topics, including friendship, motherhood, transgenderism, homosexuality, addiction, racism, abuse of power and mental illness. I am so envious of those who will discover, for the first time, the desperate spirit of hairdresser Bea Smith (and her fire-engine red mane), the survival instincts of slick, charismatic former reality TV star Franky Doyle, and the peculiar humor of the endearing Boomer, the colossus with a heart of gold. Wentworth's characters are complex and their stories are compelling. Each character has his or her own story and motivations, which makes their interpretation very interesting. The actresses are all very talented and their performances are outstanding. They are able to make us feel their emotions and fears, which makes their characters even more real. The writers have done an excellent job of creating complex characters and making them evolve over the seasons. The plots are well-constructed and the twists and turns are numerous. The scenes are very well realized and the special effects are very successful. The music is also very well chosen and contributes to create an intense and oppressive atmosphere. Wentworth is a series that deserves to be seen and discussed. It offers a unique and realistic view of life in prison and the difficulties faced by the inmates. It reminds us that people who are locked up are human beings and that their lives are as complex and rich as anyone else's. Wentworth is a series that deserves to be seen and discussed. It offers a unique and realistic view of life in prison and the difficulties that inmates face. It reminds us that people who are locked up are human beings and that their lives are as complex and rich as anyone else's. Wentworth is a series worth watching and discussing. titre: Irma Vep | La brillante série du remake d’un remake
texte: There are many levels of reading and mise en abyme in HBO's funny and dense Irma Vep miniseries, so let's keep it as simple as possible, shall we? Let's close a pressing issue right now: Irma Vep does not refer to the over-the-top play The Mystery of Irma Vep with Serge Postigo, Eric Bernier and their arsenal of funky wigs. Irma Vep - an anagram of the word vampire - takes us back to Olivier Assayas' 1996 film with his then partner, the stunning Hong Kong actress Maggie Cheung. And what was Irma Vep about in 1996? The story of the chaotic shooting of a real silent film, The Vampires, directed by Louis Feuillade in 1915. You still follow? I'm good. I googled everything so you don't have to. So, Irma Vep is the name of the heroine of the cult film The Vampires, cut into ten episodes of about forty minutes each. The Parisian actress Musidora - muse of the surrealists - played this Irma Vep in 1915, a sultry femme fatale, one of the first vamps of French cinema. So much for the appetizer. Let's continue. Twenty-six years after the creation of his own film, Olivier Assayas (Carlos, Clean) is reworking Irma Vep into a Franco-American television series of eight one-hour episodes for HBO, which the Crave platform is offering in English and in a subtitled French version. The plot of 2022 remains the same as in 1996, but the actors change, of course. Basically, it's a remake of a remake, orchestrated by the same person (Olivier Assayas). Very meta concept. It's a sophisticated series of Russian dolls that fit together. Yes, on reading, Irma Vep may seem self-referential and hermetic. It isn't. If I, who have trouble following a print run of The Golden Goose without losing the thread, could get on board with Irma Vep, anyone can. Yolo the gang. Photo Carole Bethuel, provided by HBO Scene from the Irma Vep series In 2022's Irma Vep, the excellent Alicia Vikander (The Danish Girl, Ex Machina) plays a young American actress who rocks in blockbusters, which she grows tired of. In search of love and professional credibility, she accepts the role of Irma Vep in the new version of the film The Vampires of 1915, which is being prepared by a renowned filmmaker whom she admires. The Hollywood star arrives in Paris for several months and dives into this bewitching project, which drives the entire production team a little crazy, let's say. Beyond the plot, Irma Vep is a series that explores the relationships between the characters and the different layers of society. The characters are complex and their motivations are varied. The actors are all excellent and their performances are outstanding. The series deals with themes such as creativity, culture, politics and religion. The scenes are well shot and the dialogue is intelligent. The music is also very well chosen and fits perfectly with the atmosphere of the series. Irma Vep is a series worth seeing and offers a rich and entertaining experience. It is both entertaining and intelligent and offers an interesting view of life and society. It is a series that is worth seeing and offers a rich and entertaining experience.

titre: Mixmania a brisé la glace et pris sa place
texte: Without Mixmania, there would be no Star Académie. Without Mixmania, there would not have been eight chapters of The Voice, let alone editions of The Junior Voice. Without Mixmania, there would have been no earworms like Tu t'en vas (and that's just fine with me)! Twenty years ago, in August 2002, Vrak launched one of Quebec's first music reality shows, which brought together eight teenagers - the famous Mix - in a huge, colourful loft. Divided into two groups, No Regrets (the girls) and Urban Defense (the guys), these young people learned to sing and move in front of the cameras. And they performed in a candy pop 100% francophone. No one could have predicted the stratospheric success of Mixmania, which almost caused a riot at the Galeries de la Capitale in Quebec City, where 12,000 fans screamed the lyrics to Toucher le ciel. "You and me to the top, you and me, we'll never stop!" Let's go back to 2002, a pre-Star Académie period when hot shows like American Idol had been thundering for just a few weeks. It was a time when purists were throwing up on this television sub-genre that was destined to disappear in shame with the butterfly pins in the hair and the ketchup chip colored headbands. Ew, reality TV! These "artists" are not making art, but indigestible sausage with a commercial flavor. How wrong these killjoys were. How short-sighted they were. Twenty years after Mixmania took off, two of its former participants, William Cloutier (Mixmania 3) and Krystel Mongeau (Mix 4), won the last few seasons of TVA's Star Académie. Claudia Bouvette from Mixmania 2 went very far in Big Brother Célébrités on Noovo and released an excellent electropop album called The Paradise Club. Photo CATHERINE LEFEBVRE, Special Collaboration Claudia Bouvette participated in season 2 of Mixmania before embarking on the Big Brother Celebrity adventure and releasing an album, The Paradise Club. If you follow La voix, you've probably seen a bunch of former Mix contestants including Krystel Mongeau (her again!), Redgee (Mix 4 winner), Gabriel Forest (Mixmania 3) and Tommy Tremblay (Mixmania 2). Oh yes, Anne-Sophie Demers (Mixmania 2) also moved into the cardboard condos of XOXO, but let's not open that still painful file, thanks. To measure the strong impact of Quebec's longest-running music reality show, Crave is releasing the documentary Mixmania: 20 Years Later on Wednesday, which shines the spotlight on the 2002 cohort, the original Mixes. It's very good, if a little short at about 40 minutes. | Mixmania gave birth to a new generation of Quebec stars. Former participants in the show have become role models for young people, who see them as examples of perseverance and determination. The original Mixes paved the way for a new era in Quebec music, allowing artists of all ages and backgrounds to express themselves. The documentary Mixmania: 20 Years Later is a unique opportunity to see how these young people have grown and evolved over the years. Viewers will discover their journeys, their successes and failures, and understand how their experiences at Mixmania have shaped their careers. Mixmania has also contributed to the evolution of reality TV in Quebec. The show was one of the first to showcase Quebec artists and give them a platform to express themselves. It paved the way for other music reality shows, which allowed artists of all ages and backgrounds to express themselves. Mixmania has been a catalyst for Quebec music and has contributed to the emergence of new talent. Former participants in the show have become role models for young people, who see them as examples of perseverance and determination. The documentary Mixmania : 20 ans plus tard is a unique opportunity to see how these young people have grown and evolved over the years.

titre: La série qui sent l’été, tout léger
texte: There are series and TV movies that perfectly encapsulate the spirit of Christmas with their merry bells, their flow of sweet feelings and their fluffy snow that never pinches the protagonists' faces in a sleet-like fashion. We watch these bluettes with misty eyes and the desire to leave Montreal and open a Christmas tree farm in a pretty village on the edge of Vermont, where someone from our high school lives who now has a manual trade. There is the same kind of TV show that smells of sea salt, sun-kissed skin and beach fires. It's called The Summer I Turned Pretty, in French version, available on Amazon Prime Video. And it's very good, in this very precise genre of learning story, where everything changes during a sunny summer. From the very first episode, the urge to book an overpriced cedar-shingled house in Nantucket, Ogunquit or Cape Cod takes over. The Summer I Turned Pretty, based on novels written by Jenny Han (To All the Boys I've Ever Loved), is set in a gorgeous summer home in a fictional resort on the American East Coast. Think more Martha's Vineyard than Old Orchard Beach. This beautiful castle filled with fresh flowers belongs to the wealthy Fisher family of Boston. The Fishers have always spent their summers - idyllic, of course - at the beach with the Conklin family. The Fisher mother, painter Susannah, has known the Conklin mother, writer Laurel, since college, and their four children have grown up together between games of Marco Polo in the in-ground pool. The long vacations at the seaside are similar until the one where the heroine, Belly, celebrates her 16th birthday. Like in a Britney Spears song, Belly is no longer a child, but not yet a woman either. Susannah's two sons (reminder: she is the bohemian painter who owns the rich house) now look at Belly with different eyes, and that's what Belly wants: to get rid of her image of a naive little girl with glasses and brooches. Belly thus begins a summer of flirtations, love triangles and first frozen margaritas with pomegranate. It's a classic, almost cliché. The first two episodes (out of a total of seven) look candy pink, very Vanity Fair magazine in the New England aesthetic, but wait. | The cast of The Summer I Turned Pretty is composed of young actors who are all very talented. The star of the series is the young American actress, Sydney Park, who plays Belly. She is surrounded by Jordan Fisher, who plays the role of Conrad, Belly's older brother, and Kiana Madeira, who plays the role of Susannah, Belly's mother. The other main actors are Shannon Chan-Kent, who plays Taylor, Belly's best friend, and Graham Rogers, who plays Jeremiah, Belly's younger brother. The series is also filled with interesting secondary characters, including the character of Steven, played by the American actor, Jackson White. The Summer I Turned Pretty is an entertaining series that offers a beautiful range of emotions. The characters are engaging and their stories are captivating. The scenes are well shot and the settings are beautiful. The series is filled with both funny and sad moments, which makes it a very moving series. The characters evolve and grow throughout the series, which makes it a very interesting series to watch. The Summer I Turned Pretty is a series that will make you dream and feel like you are at the beach. It is a series that will make you smile and make you think. It is a series that will make you feel good and that will make you remember that summer is a magical season.

titre: Des trucs pour adoucir la facture télé !
texte: It's a classic, like sweaty reports at Fairmount Bagel on a hot day. As soon as the words Netflix, Club illico or Amazon Prime appear in a column, the emails from angry, disappointed or perplexed readers pile up tightly in my inbox. Messages - not at all aggressive, mind you - like this one: "I didn't jump on the Netflix, Crave, etc. bandwagon. I believe and, above all, I still hope that conventional TV with Quebec content will still be accessible to people like us for as long as possible," says Mario L. Marie-Josée B. also denounces the small screen of the rich: "You always have to subscribe to different channels. It becomes frustrating in the long run to have these kinds of programs suggested to us, as our finances can't support such amounts. Patricia B. has the same budgetary concerns: "When you add up the cost of subscribing to all these platforms, in the context of current inflation, it's not possible and it makes me angry that some of these Quebec series have been subsidized. Why should I have to pay again to see them? So too bad, I won't see Audrey est retour or Une affaire criminelle," she notes. Too many digital platforms, too many automatic additions to the credit card, too expensive, I understand. When I look at my own bills, I console myself by reminding myself that I no longer buy DVD sets at $60 each, which is the equivalent of five months of Disney+ with unlimited content. Still. In Quebec, 71% of households subscribe to at least one digital platform, compared to 66% who pay for traditional cable (or fiber optic), according to a recent report by the Academy of Digital Transformation at Laval University. Netflix remains the most popular pay service in Quebec with a subscription rate approaching 60%. That's huge. That's almost two-thirds of the population. The American giant Netflix thus eclipses the influence of the majority of regular Quebec specialty channels (Évasion, Historia, Investigation, etc.). Amazon Prime Video ranks second with a 30% penetration rate, followed by Disney+ (18%), Club illico (16%), Tou.TV's Extra (9%) and Crave (8%), according to Laval University's Academy of Digital Transformation. titre: Larry | La vie, la vie d’un flic déchu
texte: Multi-ethnic neighbourhood in the north of Montreal. A gunfight breaks out between two street gangs in broad daylight. A stray bullet hits an (innocent) bystander in the back. The suspects slip through the fingers of the cops. Is this a recent article from the news section of your favorite newspaper? Nope. It's more like the starting point of the excellent crime thriller Larry, from the mythical tandem that created La vie, la vie, i.e. writer Stéphane Bourguignon and director Patrice Sauvé. I watched the first three episodes of Larry on Monday without blinking an eye, and I'm looking forward to the next seven, which will land on Tou.TV's Extra on Thursday. For those who don't subscribe to this pay platform, you should know that Radio-Canada will drop Larry in its next regular TV season. Larry doesn't fit into the traditional crime series genre. Sure, this dense and brilliant work contains a breathless investigation and unexpected twists and turns, but it incorporates comic touches and personal drama that color the entire plot. All of this, topped with psychedelic 1970s music and delivered in a visual package reminiscent of director William Friedkin's classic film The French Connection. It's downright captivating. The Larry of the series title is a former undercover cop (solid Benoît Gouin) with the Montreal police who was ostracized after a questionable tailing case where he allegedly got involved with organized crime. Bitter, disappointed and humiliated, Larry, 62, has turned in his badge and gun. For the past eight years, he has been working as a security guard in an anonymous building. But the failure of his last investigation, coupled with an acute feeling of betrayal, still obsesses him. The day his wife France (aptly named Monique Spaziani) is shot in the spine, Larry turns on the vigilante mode. PHOTO PROVIDED BY RADIO-CANADA Monique Spaziani in Larry First, because guilt is eating away at him. He was unable to protect his wife. He abandoned her in the middle of a gunfight. He could have and should have prevented the attack, frankly. Second, because Larry refuses to face the challenges that lie ahead. His partner of 40 years will never walk on two legs again. And the life they've built together will change drastically. Larry is on the run from all of this in his parallel - and not at all legal - investigation of the streets of Parc-Extension. Larry is a man who has lived a life of challenges and difficulties. He has been faced with difficult choices and decisions that have changed his life forever. He was forced to leave the police force and turn to a security job, but he never gave up his desire for justice. When his wife is injured by a stray bullet, Larry embarks on a personal investigation to find the culprit. He finds himself plunged into a world of corruption and violence, where he must deal with street gangs, drug dealers and corrupt police. He must also confront his own demons and mistakes. Larry is a complex and deeply human character who reminds us that justice is not always as simple as it seems. He reminds us that life is about choices and consequences, and that we must be prepared to face the consequences of our actions. Larry is a compelling series that reminds us that justice is a constant struggle and that we must be willing to fight for what we believe in.

titre: Bonjour la police chez Vrak !
texte: When you think of Vrak, you think of Le Chalet, Jérémie, Code F, Code G or the (late) KARV gala. Forget about that "youth" stuff, yo. Bell Media's specialty channel is now aimed at adults who like series featuring police officers, firefighters and first responders. It's the Holy Trinity of the 3Ps in television, which differs from the delicious trio of the 3Ps in gastronomy: pasta, bread and potatoes. Yes, Vrak's bosses have thought about changing the name of their station to better reflect its mature shift, completed last spring. But the Vrak brand, which has existed since 2001, still resonates strongly with subscribers. So it will remain intact, unchanged, Vrak la vie, Vrak pour la vie. The cop-doctor-stepper niche is not going away - turn on the sirens here - as evidenced by the thunderous programming of competing stations such as Addik (Coroner, Chicago Fire, S.W.A.T.), Séries Plus (Blue Bloods, FBI, NCIS) or Max (Dr House, Bones). Nevertheless. With its cops and doctors, Vrak has more than doubled its audience," says Suzane Landry, vice-president of programming and information at Bell Media. Fun fact: the average age of Vrak's clients is now 46. That's a far cry from Radio-Enfer and Canal Famille. Starting next week, Vrak will present some strong, award-winning series that have made Crave subscribers happy in recent months. I'm thinking of Yellowjackets (September 13), Easttown with Kate Winslet (August 24) or The Landscapers with Olivia Colman (November 22). The third season of Transplanted will take off on Wednesday, October 12 at 9pm. Fans of feuds and twists, don't pull out your bleached hair. Vrak remains the place to go for extras and new episodes of Occupation double (back on September 12) or Big Brother Celebrity 3 (in January). Even though the sun is still shining brightly in our pools, the specialty channels have slowly begun their comeback (argh!) before the big boom of the traditional channels, scheduled for the week of September 12. PHOTO ANNIE SIMARD, PROVIDED BY BELL Mélissa Bédard fulfills a dream by buying her first house in a reality show called Ma première maison, broadcast on Canal Vie. On Canal Vie, singer and actress Mélissa Bédard is living a dream by buying her first house in a reality show entitled Ma première maison, duh, which starts Tuesday, August 23 at 7:30 p.m. Expect chaos with six kids under one roof (renovated, of course). In A New Day (August 22), we meet trans people preparing for gender-affirming surgery at Montreal's GrS Hospital, a facility that specializes in such procedures. In Cœurs migratoires (November 2), we will follow the love story - not the disaster - of couples where one of the members lives abroad or is about to settle in Quebec. In addition to these series, Vrak also offers documentaries that explore a variety of subjects. Viewers will discover inspiring stories and fascinating characters in documentaries such as "Life on the Other Side", which explores the lives of people living on the border between Mexico and the United States, or "Women of the Mafia", which tells the story of women who were once part of the Italian mafia. Vrak also offers films that are perfect for movie nights at home. Viewers will enjoy films such as "Life is Beautiful," which tells the story of a man who tries to save his family from Nazi persecution, or "The Secret Life of Writers," which explores the lives of writers trying to break into the publishing world. Vrak also offers reality shows that are perfect for reality TV fans. Viewers will be able to discover shows such as "Survivors", which follows the adventures of people trying to survive in hostile environments, or "Adventurers of the World", which follows adventurers exploring exotic locations. Vrak is the perfect channel for viewers looking for varied and entertaining series, documentaries and movies.

titre: Le rattrapage avant le grand déballage
texte: Group ! There are three weeks left before the return of the fall programming on the major Quebec TV channels. Group! So there are three weeks left to catch up on and devour the series that shone on the summer TV radar. Here are a few suggestions for shows to catch up on before we get swamped with the new shows of the fall season (yes, that rhymes and that was intentional, right). The second season of Industry, available in French and English on the Crave platform, is great. Do we understand all its opaque language about transactions that take place on the floor of a powerful investment bank? No, we really don't. If the characters were speaking in Klingon - or the language of Cirque du Soleil - it would sound the same. Bling, you have to sell this foreign fund in bitcoins, alegria, it's "short" on the Japanese currency market, kooza, a block of shares is released in a speculative capitalization fintech. Undecipherable economic gobbledygook, which surprisingly does not put off. At the end of each episode, the compulsion pushes us to trigger the next, and the next, and the next. The beating heart of Industry, which sits at the crossroads of Succession, Billions and Euphoria, is the motivations that drive these young (and not so young) sharks of the London City. How far will they go to recruit deep-pocketed clients? Very far. As much in drugs, burnout, seduction, panic attacks as in sex, obviously. This ferocious financial environment crushes the weakest and pulverizes friendships, including the one between the two heroines, Yasmin and Harper. The lines of cocaine stretch further than Matane and Baton Rouge. And a quiet Tuesday night turns into a drunken party where potential rich investors always cross paths. In Industry, work never stops and swallows everything, especially outside the 9 to 5. PHOTO BARBARA NITKE, PROVIDED BY NETFLIX Neil Patrick Harris stars as Michael Lawson in the series Uncoupled. He is seen here with Peter Porte, as Josh. On Netflix, the comedy Uncoupled, or Découplé, in French version, offers a nice entertainment to the Sex and the City, but in the world of gay singles in New York. Neil Patrick Harris, the Barney of How I Met Your Mother, plays real estate agent Michael, who is dumped by his partner without warning after 17 years together. This unexpected breakup demolishes our good Michael, who doesn't know how to date in the age of Grindr, Tinder and unsolicited penis pictures. We're not going to be secretive here: Michael is essentially the male version of Carrie Bradshaw (Sarah Jessica Parker), a forty-something who is at once comical, selfish, brilliant and a champion of self-deprecation. The recipe for Sex and the City also applies to the good friends that surround Michael. Uncoupled is a series that stands out for its humor and its ability to tackle serious subjects with a light touch. The series tackles themes such as family, friendship, work and love, and explores how these things can be difficult to navigate for LGBTQ+ people. Michael and his friends face challenges that are familiar to many people, but are often ignored in the media. The series addresses issues such as the social pressure to find love, the difficulty of finding a job, and the difficulty of finding one's place in the world. The characters are complex and the stories are well written, making it an entertaining and interesting series to watch. The series is also very inclusive and represents a variety of LGBTQ+ characters. The characters are diverse and represent a variety of perspectives and experiences. The series is a great way to pass the time before the big unpacking of new back-to-school series.

titre: Le Dr Gagnon revient, Audrey aussi !
texte: Tele-Quebec's fall programming includes De garde 24/7. It's basic care - not comfort care. It's a strong vital sign that this pulsating docureality is still at the top of the public channel's most popular programs. Of course, the good Dr. Eric Gagnon of Maisonneuve-Rosemont Hospital will be rolling up his sleeves in this eighth season, as will the formidable Dr. Nathalie Zan and the energetic Dr. Massimiliano Iseppon. The first patients will show up at Télé-Québec on Thursday, September 8 at 8 p.m. New this year, De garde 24/7 will devote four episodes to the practice of medicine outside urban centers. Filming took place in Baie-Comeau, Maria (in Gaspésie) and Murdochville. And guess who the team met on their regional tour? Dr. Camille Hudon, an emergency physician and family medicine resident who participated in the first edition of De garde 24/7 at Charles-LeMoyne Hospital seven years ago. Another welcome return: Télé-Québec will relay the dramatic comedy Audrey est retour on Thursdays at 9 p.m. starting September 29. Pardon? Didn't Club illico de Vidéotron have the first look at this strangely endearing series? Yes, good point. PHOTO PROVIDED BY TÉLÉ-QUÉBEC Audrey est revenue will air on Télé-Québec on Thursdays at 9 p.m. starting September 29. According to Marie Collin, the CEO of Télé-Québec, it was Québecor that contacted Télé-Québec to sell it the first broadcast of Audrey est revenue on a conventional channel. This kind of lateral business move, between two competing broadcasters, happens very rarely. So let's take advantage of it. And between you and me, Audrey est revenue, co-written by Florence Longpré and Guillaume Lambert, really fits better at Télé-Québec than at TVA, where this singular comedy would have been squeezed between Le tricheur, Chanteurs masqués and L'échappée. Competing for 13 Gémeaux awards, Audrey est retour tells the story of the slow awakening of a 35-year-old Soreloise woman (Florence Longpré) after 18 years in a coma. From Monday to Thursday at 6:30 p.m., Télé-Québec will broadcast a new daily series for 9 to 12 year-olds called Comme des têtes pas de poule. The series follows the Babin-Bibeau family, consisting of a musician father (David Savard), a mother who is going back to school to study carpentry (Mélanie Pilon) and their three teenagers with strong characters. Author Pierre-Yves Bernard (Dans une galaxie près de chez vous, Minuit le soir) writes the texts and it starts on September 5th. In the new magazine À boire et à manger, Vanessa Pilon, Rémi-Pierre Paquin and Lindsay Brun talk about the optimal pressure to inflate your winter tires. Well, no, the trio will be renting cottages all over Quebec, which will become the anchor for a mouth-watering gourmet tour of various local producers. The first episode of À boire et à manger will play on Friday, September 9 at 8 p.m. | In addition to these new series, Télé-Québec will also offer special programs to celebrate Montreal's 375th anniversary. On Sunday, September 11 at 8 p.m., the special program Montréal 375, presented by actor and host Jean-Philippe Wauthier, will air. This program will feature artists and personalities who have contributed to the city and its culture. Viewers will also be able to discover musical performances, interviews and reports that celebrate the history and diversity of Montreal. On Sunday, September 18 at 8 p.m., Télé-Québec will also broadcast a special program entitled Montréal 375: Neighbours' Day. This program will feature Montreal neighbors who have come together to celebrate the city's 375th anniversary. Viewers will be treated to musical performances, interviews and reports that celebrate Montreal's diversity and community spirit. Finally, on Sunday, September 25 at 8:00 p.m., Télé-Québec will broadcast a special program entitled Montréal 375: La fête des familles. This program will feature Montreal families who have come together to celebrate the city's 375th anniversary. Viewers will be treated to musical performances, interviews and reports that celebrate the diversity and family spirit of Montreal. These specials are a great opportunity to celebrate Montreal's 375th anniversary and discover the stories and cultures that make Montreal unique. So whether it's De garde 24/7, Audrey est retour, Comme des têtes pas de poule or the Montreal 375 specials, Télé-Québec offers varied and entertaining programming for all viewers.

titre: Faut-il finir toutes les séries que l’on commence ?

titre: L'augmentation salariale du maire de Saint-Lambert reportée
texte: Pierre Brodeur has been mayor of Saint-Lambert since November 6, 2017 Photo: Facebook Saint-Lambert's elected officials were to vote themselves a substantial salary increase, a second in two years, Monday night at the city council. As a result, Mayor Pierre Brodeur's total compensation was to increase to $120,000. However, the vote was pulled from the agenda at the last minute and it is unknown when it will resurface. The elected officials justify this proposed increase, among other things, by the pressure they are experiencing from citizens on social media. Saint-Lambert has 22,500 inhabitants. Its elected officials have been complaining for several years that they earn less than their counterparts in other municipalities of equivalent size. The new salary increases would increase the income of councillors by 34% and that of the mayor by 45%. And that's not counting his other sources of income. His total compensation for 2019 is expected to exceed $120,000, according to our calculations. Among the reasons given to justify these new increases, the elected officials of Saint-Lambert mention the fact that their work is increasingly demanding. "Regardless of the size of the city, elected officials have more and more responsibilities," reads the public notice of the proposed bylaw. "To do their job well, they must take on a greater workload than before, especially in an agglomeration context, as is the case for Saint-Lambert." "Elected officials argue that they are often called upon by citizens "in public places or at their personal residences. In addition, "the accessibility of information and the speed of exchanges generated by social media add additional pressure," they write. Among other reasons given for the increase in their salaries, the elected officials explain that the expense allowances they receive are now imposed by the federal government. Despite this new increase, Saint-Lambert will still be among the cities of similar size that pay their elected officials the least. Please note that the CBC does not endorse the opinions expressed. titre: L'ONF victime d'un virus informatique depuis plus de deux semaines
texte: NFB studios across Canada have yet to regain access to shared files after falling victim to the computer virus. Photo: CBC Operations at all National Film Board of Canada offices have been significantly slowed since February 9 due to a computer virus, Radio-Canada has learned. Productions delayed, payroll system affected, tools and data inaccessible... The emergency cell set up by the NFB has not yet managed to restore everything. "The institution is recovering from a rather ferocious virus," says NFB producer Hugues Sweeney on his Facebook page. Like many other employees, he had to leave the federal agency's Montreal offices and find refuge elsewhere to work. "They talked about a computer attack," says another employee, which the NFB would not confirm. "It's a virus, but we're not naming it, so as not to promote it," says press relations officer Marie-Claude Lamoureux. National Film Board studios across Canada have not yet regained access to shared files. As for production systems, they should be gradually reconnected this week, the NFB says. "At the height of the crisis, employees across the country no longer had access to the intranet, or even the Internet at all. All tools and databases remained inaccessible for several days. "The majority of systems are now reconnected to the network and servers," says the NFB, which says it preferred to "be thorough more than quick." IT teams had to check the contents of all computers, electronic devices and USB keys of the 400 employees to ensure that the virus had disappeared. The National Film Board is a federal government agency that operates a dozen studios in most major cities across the country. Its head office is in Montreal. texte: From left to right: Raquel, Fahmid and Nancy.
