titre: Mort d'un bébé à Joliette : la Commission des droits ouvre une enquête
texte: The case is already under investigation by the Sûreté du Québec. Photo: Radio-Canada / Félix B. Desfossés The Commission des droits de la personne et des droits de la jeunesse (Human Rights and Youth Rights Commission) has opened an investigation following the death of a two-year-old child in Joliette, on Thursday, during an intervention by the DPJ. The investigation aims to determine if the rights of the child whose situation was being evaluated by the Lanaudière Youth Protection Branch (DPJ) were violated, explains the Commission, in a press release. On Thursday, the child died suddenly of respiratory distress, while the social services workers had left his home for a few moments. The DPJ had discovered a family of four children with skin and head infections, in a residence in a state of advanced insalubrity. The case, revealed by Radio-Canada, shows that the situation of this family had been reported to the DPJ of Lanaudière in January. The file had been classified as non-urgent. However, it should have been processed within a few days. However, it took more than two months before the interveners visited. The abundance of files is said to be the cause. At the end of this investigation, the Commission will be able to make recommendations to the DPJ of the CISSS de Lanaudière and to any other concerned authority, depending on the findings. The Sûreté du Québec's major crimes unit is also investigating. An autopsy was also to be performed. On the day of the tragedy, the Commission on Children's Rights and Youth Protection had made a public appearance to express its concerns in the context of the coronavirus pandemic. This crisis creates a risk zone for child abuse and this is even more true in families already affected by various personal or social problems, argued the Commission Laurent. titre: Un Américain se réfugie au Canada à cause de la COVID-19 | Coronavirus
texte: "The situation is not too bad in Quebec, at the moment, compared to the United States." Cameron Akhavan entered Canada on March 13. Photo: Radio-Canada Cameron Akhavan, 22, cancelled his return ticket and hopes to stay in Montreal as long as he can. He is afraid to return to his country, which is facing an unprecedented health crisis. I'll stay as long as I can, I'm allowed six months," said the student, who follows the disturbing news from the United States every day. On Tuesday, President Donald Trump announced the extension of the isolation measures until April 30. The coronavirus has reached 183,000 Americans and 3,700 have died, more than the official death toll in China. The situation is not too bad in Quebec at the moment, compared to the United States," says Cameron Akhavan. He deplores the fact that many Americans do not respect the social distancing instructions. "The U.S. government is handling the situation very poorly and is showing a great lack of preparedness. The infection rate in the U.S. is much higher than in Canada, at 43 infections per 100,000 people, compared to 15 per 100,000 people in Canada. In California, where Cameron usually lives, the number of hospitalizations has doubled in the past four days and the number of patients in intensive care has tripled. Meanwhile, the engineering student is continuing his education online through courses offered during the crisis by the University of Southern California. The student is fortunate to be staying with his girlfriend's family in Montreal. He arrived to visit her on March 13, the day many countries began closing their borders. The border between Canada and the United States is closed to travelers. What Cameron Akhavan did is no longer possible today. Does he consider himself a refugee? Yes, in a sense, I have found a refuge. Please note that CBC does not endorse the opinions expressed. Your comments will be moderated, and published if they respect netiquette. Enjoy the discussion! titre: Éclosion de COVID-19 à l'Hôpital général du Lakeshore | Coronavirus
texte: The Lakeshore General Hospital is located in Pointe-Claire, on the island of Montreal. Photo: Radio-Canada / Davide Gentile The Lakeshore Hospital has joined the list of institutions that have experienced outbreaks within their walls. The virus has infected 15 patients in a cold zone unit of the facility. Patients on a fourth floor unit contracted COVID-19, even though that was not the reason they were in the hospital. There was movement of personnel between cold and hot zones," said Johanne Riendeau, president of the FIQ-Union of Health Care Professionals of the West Island of Montreal. The CIUSSS de l'Ouest-de-l'Île-de-Montréal confirms the outbreak. We have a team on site that is reorganizing the containment areas," said spokesperson Guillaume Bérubé. The hospital's emergency room occupancy rate is 110%, but the situation is not critical at this time, CIUSSS said. However, we are monitoring it closely," he says. The Lakeshore General Hospital is designated to receive patients with COVID, and 79 are hospitalized there. The mobile hospital set up by the Red Cross in a LaSalle arena could be used to increase capacity at Lakeshore, CIUSSS believes. titre: Éclosions de COVID-19 à l'Hôpital Pierre-Boucher de Longueuil
texte: Pierre-Boucher Hospital in Longueuil. Photo: Radio-Canada / Ivanoh Demers Another hospital has been added to the list of those suffering from coronavirus outbreaks. Radio-Canada has learned that the virus has spread within the walls of Pierre-Boucher Hospital in Longueuil. Two units are affected. Five patients in two units contracted COVID-19 when they entered Pierre-Boucher Hospital for another reason. Initially, on Tuesday, the Centre intégré de santé et de services sociaux (CISSS) de la Montérégie-Est spoke of three outbreaks and 29 affected users, but it has corrected its assessment. Several measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus, said CISSS spokesperson Hugo Bourgoin. A security officer has been posted at the entrance to each affected unit. He ensures that hand washing is performed at the entrance and exit of the unit and that all personnel wear a procedure mask. Hygiene and sanitation interventions have also been enhanced on the affected units," explains the CISSS. We are also ensuring that all employees and physicians who worked on the affected units are screened. Like Charles-Lemoyne Hospital, Pierre-Boucher is designated by the Ministry of Health to receive patients with COVID, but like many other institutions, it has not been able to contain the virus in the hot units. In recent weeks, outbreaks have destabilized Maisonneuve-Rosemont Hospital, which has had to cancel surgeries and send patients elsewhere. Montreal's Sacré-Coeur Hospital has also had to call on other facilities for help. The Lakeshore, Santa Cabrini, Jean-Talon, Fleury and Verdun hospitals are also experiencing outbreaks. titre: Visière et masque deviennent obligatoires dans plusieurs hôpitaux du Québec | Coronavirus
texte: All health care workers, including physicians, will be required to wear them in the workplace. In Quebec, 5,000 health care workers have caught COVID-19, mainly in Montreal. Photo: Radio-Canada / Sébastien Tanguay Tens of thousands of nurses, attendants and doctors in hospitals in Montreal and surrounding areas are now required to protect their faces with a procedure mask and visor. Radio-Canada obtained a directive from the Quebec Ministry of Health addressed to the CEOs of CISSS, CIUSSS and CHU on May 13. It states that the measure must be implemented in hospital centers in the following regions: "The procedure mask and visor must be worn by all health care workers (including physicians), in their work environment in a hospital center." The measure has officially been in effect since May 13, but in the field many have not been informed of it by their management, and the measure is not yet being implemented everywhere. Sources question whether there will be enough visors to equip everyone, even if they can be washed and reused. In his letter, Deputy Minister Yvan Gendron explains that this direction comes from the infection prevention and control work being done in collaboration with the Public Health Branch. The letter does not explain why the directive does not apply to CHSLDs. The recommendations for wearing the N95 mask do not change. It must be worn when health care personnel are treating patients in intensive care and for any procedure that generates aerosols. In Quebec, 5000 healthcare workers have been infected with COVID-19, mainly in Montreal. Many outbreaks have occurred in cold areas of hospitals and even in facilities that were not intended to receive people infected with the coronavirus. titre: Québec généralise le port du masque et de la protection oculaire dans la santé
texte: Most health care workers and caregivers must now protect their mouth, nose and eyes. Masks and visors are the new standard in the health care system. Photo: Reuters / Patrick Doyle A new directive from the Ministry of Health reinforces the protection of tens of thousands of workers and caregivers in hospitals, CHSLDs, residences or intermediate and family resources. With the exception of cold zones outside the Montreal Metropolitan Community (MMC), the rule becomes the same everywhere and for everyone: wear a medical mask (procedure) and eye protection (goggles or visor) to avoid catching or spreading COVID-19. In a letter sent on May 25 to the directors of the health network, the deputy minister asks that these protective measures be put in place "upon entering the building". The following care environments are concerned: In the MMC, the obligation applies to both hot zones and buffer zones and cold zones. In the rest of Quebec, hot zones and buffer zones must follow the same directive. Only cold zones outside of BMC will be limited to medical masks. In the MWC, administrative staff will also have to wear these protections, except inside their offices. This new directive replaces the May 13 directive that required the wearing of masks and visors only in Greater Montreal hospitals. The recommendations concerning the wearing of the N95 mask do not change. It must be worn when health care personnel treat patients in intensive care and for any procedure that generates aerosols. In Quebec, more than 5,000 health care workers have been infected with COVID-19, mainly in Montreal. Many outbreaks have occurred in cold areas of hospitals and even in facilities that were not intended to receive people infected with the coronavirus. titre: Le CHUM suspend les visites aux patients | Coronavirus
texte: A "difficult decision" taken because of the "growing risk of community contamination related to COVID-19" The University of Montreal Hospital Centre (CHUM) Photo: Radio-Canada / Benoît Chapdelaine As of Thursday evening, at midnight, visitors will no longer be able to go to the bedside of patients at the University of Montreal Hospital Centre (CHUM), except for end-of-life care and deliveries. In an internal memo dated October 1, obtained by Radio-Canada, management explains that it made this "difficult decision" to ensure the safety of patients and employees. The measure is valid until further notice. As of Thursday, patients began to be notified of the new rules so that they could inform their loved ones. Starting next week, CHUM will distribute electronic tablets and phones to allow patients to maintain contact with family and friends. Medical appointments will be maintained if teleconsultation is not an option. However, anyone who is symptomatic, waiting for a test result, has been in contact with a positive case or has been diagnosed with COVID-19 within the last 21 days will be denied access to the hospital. titre: Le CHUM victime de sa première éclosion de COVID-19
texte: The state-of-the-art hospital had previously kept the coronavirus under control within its walls. The Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM) Photo: Radio-Canada / Ivanoh Demers The Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM) is facing its first outbreak since the pandemic began, Radio-Canada has learned. Several patients in an internal medicine unit have been infected. The CHUM confirms the outbreak, which involves less than five patients. According to our information, it is the 18th floor north unit that is affected, an internal medicine unit. Five patient rooms are newly vacant, indicating that those infected with COVID-19 have been transferred to a warm area. Several measures have been put in place, management says, such as full disinfection of the unit. "We are testing all employees as well as all patients on the unit. We will also be conducting regular testing of all of our employees working on that unit as well as patients over the next 14 days." All family visits have been canceled, except for compassionate visits. Infection prevention and control staff have also been mobilized. According to our sources, the CHUM is preparing to open a second COVID-19 patient unit to accommodate patients from other hospitals. In Montreal, the number of hospitalizations is on the rise, with nearly 300 beds occupied by COVID-19 cases out of a total of 1,000 available. In addition, 450 health care workers are in isolation or awaiting test results. On Thursday, Montreal broke its record of new cases in a single day. Hospitals in the metropolis are still facing recurrent outbreak problems since the spring. This is the case at Lakeshore Hospital, where management has asked the public to avoid its busy emergency room. Stretcher occupancy rates are 110% at the Lakeshore, 125% at the CHUM, 129% at the Montreal General Hospital, 146% at the Verdun Hospital and 157% at Maisonneuve-Rosemont. Earlier this week, the Quebec government asked hospital centers to implement their load shedding plan. Institutions are asked to reduce normal operating room activities by half to free up beds for coronavirus-infected patients. Please note that the CBC does not endorse the views expressed. titre: Les fortes ventes à la SAQ, un indice que des  partys  illégaux se préparent?
texte: Sales are up 4% at the SAQ compared to the same period last year. Photo: Radio-Canada At his press conference Thursday, Quebec Health Minister Christian Dubé presented "the very strong orders at the moment at the SAQ [Société des alcools du Québec]" as a "sign" that [illegal] parties are being prepared among Quebecers. He said that worries him. "I've heard that the orders at the SAQ are very strong right now. That's not a good sign. Those of you who have already bought your liquor to have parties, save it for later, please." According to figures from the Société des alcools du Québec, sales growth is about 4% over the same period last year, but that's nothing out of the ordinary. This is a similar level of growth to the previous year in a non-pandemic context," explains SAQ spokesperson Yann Langlais Plante. The attraction of the branches is also explained by the closure of restaurants and bars. Since last March, there has been a shift in sales from licensees to our store network and to the grocery store network," explains the SAQ. Finally, the corporation notes that the respect of the sanitary measures in effect also leads customers to plan their purchases so that they come to the store less often. This is my case," says Claude Boucher on Twitter. Instead of going to the store near me for one bottle of wine, I go less often and get four bottles. That's exactly what I did yesterday," says Tommy Guénard, "to avoid going back during the holidays and avoid the rush! And no party planned... still. titre: Des rendez-vous de vaccination annulés dans Lanaudière par manque de doses | Coronavirus
texte: Some people got the bad news the morning of their appointment. Some residents of the region learned the bad news the very morning of their appointment. Photo: Radio-Canada / Isabelle Larose Residents of Lanaudière who had obtained an appointment for vaccination between April 1 and 6 have unfortunately seen it cancelled due to a lack of doses in the region, Radio-Canada has learned. And no new date was offered to them. From being eager and excited to receive their COVID-19 vaccine, they are now disappointed. We are very sorry for the inconvenience caused by these postponements, which are beyond our control, and we thank our users for their understanding and cooperation," explains CISSS de Lanaudière spokesperson Hélène Gaboury. "As we did not receive the number of doses planned for the period of April 1 to 6, we had to cancel some appointments." As you probably know, appointments are granted according to the doses that are delivered to us, explains the CISSS. In Lanaudière, vaccination is open to people over 65 years of age. titre: Québec simplifie l'accès aux tests rapides qui dorment dans des entrepôts | Coronavirus
texte: The government wants to provide more autonomy for businesses and individuals to use them. The government wants to empower more companies and individuals to use them. Photo: Montreal Heart Institute The example of the Montreal Heart Institute, which provides do-it-yourself COVID-19 rapid tests to its employees and their families, is inspiring the Quebec government. The health minister's office wants companies to follow suit, but that meant simplifying access to the tests, which have been sitting unused for months. As of April 19, there were 4,650,816 rapid tests in storage that had not been used and only 100,252 tests had been used. Sixty percent of the unused tests are being stored by health care facilities or companies. As reported in La Presse on Tuesday, as of this week, it will no longer be necessary for companies to provide a complex protocol to public health in order to have access to the rapid tests, explained the press secretary to the Minister of Health, Marjaurie Côté-Boileau. The companies themselves will be able to use the rapid tests according to Public Health's recommendations, she adds. "With these advances, we aim to subsequently offer more autonomy to individuals in the use of rapid tests, as discussed at the Montreal Heart Institute, for example." The Montreal Heart Institute (MHI) was inspired by the United Kingdom, which provides free rapid tests for people to do at home. The MHI has distributed thousands to its employees and their families. All volunteer staff are invited to test twice a week, as well as those living in the same household. The test gives results in 15 minutes. The government wants rapid testing to complement the conventional testing approach in Quebec. We will be able to observe the response to this new approach in the coming weeks," explains the Minister's press secretary. Please note that Radio-Canada does not endorse the opinions expressed. titre: Josée Latendresse sera candidate à la mairie de Longueuil
texte: She had lost by 110 votes in 2017, before retiring from municipal politics. Josée Latendresse was previously leader of Longueuil citoyen, a party she will have to fight. Photo: Radio-Canada Another new candidate for mayor of Longueuil. Radio-Canada has learned that Josée Latendresse returned to the arena with a new party, called Ensemble. Already five party leaders are eyeing the head of the City, after the announcement of the departure of the mayor Sylvie Parent. Josée Latendresse will have to fight against her former party, Longueuil citoyen, which has already announced its candidate. She will also have as an opponent another party with which she sat: Action Longueuil. In 2017, she had failed by a very narrow margin in the race for mayor, by 110 votes, against Sylvie Parent. A fratricidal struggle had enamelled the months preceding the election. The rifts continued during the campaign and after the election. Municipal politics in Longueuil has been marked by divisions ever since. Josée Latendresse's party, Ensemble, will have two current elected officials among its candidates, Councillors Jacques Lemire and Jacques E. Poitras. Longueuil citoyen will be led by the CEO of the Orchestre symphonique de Longueuil, Jean-Marc Léveillé. The independent provincial MNA Catherine Fournier is also a candidate with Coalition Longueuil. The former president of the CSN, Jacques Létourneau, is taking the helm of the party in power, Action Longueuil. A fifth party, Vert Longueuil, led by Guy Sauvé, is also in the race. titre: COVID-19 : la Croix-Rouge appelée en renfort par le gouvernement du Québec | Coronavirus
texte: The Canadian Red Cross was called upon to help in the fight against the pandemic in 2020, particularly in the CHSLDs. Photo: Radio-Canada / Ivanoh Demers After the call for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, the Quebec Ministry of Health is seeking the support of Red Cross workers, Radio-Canada has learned. The humanitarian organization had already provided assistance in 2020 in the Residential and Long-Term Care Centers (CHSLD). According to our sources, the Legault government would like to have the support of the specialized teams again to strengthen the prevention and control of infections in the institutions in difficulty. These shock teams, nicknamed "SWAT", had intervened in several CHSLDs with serious outbreaks during the second wave. The Department of Health would also like to recruit more than 300 service assistants to perform cleaning and maintenance. In June 2020, after the withdrawal of the Canadian military from the CHSLDs, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau had announced the reinforcement of the Red Cross. The humanitarian organization confirms that it has received Quebec's request, but would not say whether it will respond favorably. titre: Passage au niveau 4 du délestage pour le CIUSSS du Centre-Sud, à Montréal | Coronavirus
texte: Notre-Dame Hospital is part of CIUSSS du Centre-Sud de Montréal. Photo: Radio-Canada / Ivanoh Demers The Centre intégré universitaire de santé et de services sociaux (CIUSSS) du Centre-Sud-de-l'Île-de-Montréal is moving to the next level of offloading to free up beds and staff to deal with the increase in hospitalizations of people with COVID-19, Radio-Canada has learned. Among the CIUSSS establishments, there are two hospitals: Notre-Dame Hospital and Verdun Hospital. In surgery, the number of interventions will be reduced by more than 50% and could reach up to 25% of normal operations. On the other hand, emergency and oncology services will be preserved, the CIUSSS assures us, as will services for youth and intellectual disabilities. Endoscopy activities will be slowed down. Some nurses will be reassigned from outpatient clinics to hospitals. The number of non-urgent appointments in family medicine groups will be reduced. The CIUSSS is also calling for volunteers to help out health care staff through the Je contribue platform. (New Window) As of Thursday, there were 58 patients hospitalized in beds reserved for COVID-19 at the Verdun Hospital, including 3 in intensive care, and 59 at the Notre-Dame Hospital, including 7 in intensive care. On Monday, the CIUSSS du Nord-de-l'Île-de-Montréal became the first Montreal institution to switch to stage 4 of the load shedding process. All regions around the metropolis are already at stage 4. This level makes it possible to postpone up to 80% of surgical operations and to postpone certain follow-ups in order to free up even more beds to deal with the onslaught of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus. The Quebec government has prepared a level 5 relief plan to free up to 4,000 hospital beds for patients infected with COVID-19. Currently, more than 3085 people are occupying a bed, and this total is expected to increase over the weekend, the government warned. Please note that the CBC does not endorse the opinions expressed. titre: COVID-19 : plus de 5000 tests PCR ont été jetés sans être analysés | Coronavirus
texte: Those who have been waiting for a test result since early January have learned that they will never receive it. PCR tests are now reserved for certain priority clients in Quebec. Photo: Associated Press / Damian Dovarganes Bad luck has struck 5462 people who took a PCR test in early January in Montreal's north end. They have just received a letter informing them that the sample from their test has been destroyed without them being able to find out the result. The bad news concerns citizens who were tested between January 2 and 7 in a clinic or CLSC of the CIUSSS du Nord-de-l'Île-de-Montréal. On Wednesday, the institution sent them the following message: "Unfortunately, your sample could not be analyzed within the prescribed 72-hour period and is no longer considered valid. Therefore, your sample has been destroyed and we will not be able to issue a result for it." The CIUSSS explains that successive breakdowns of several analyzers in the laboratory are to blame, but also that the abnormally high volume of samples for the screening caused an unusual delay in the analysis. Spokesperson Émilie Jacob reports that the Sacré-Coeur-de-Montréal hospital laboratory can analyze approximately 3,000 tests per day. Between January 3 and 7, more than 5,000 tests were received daily. Until January 5, all people with symptoms were invited to undergo PCR testing. Thereafter, these tests were reserved for certain priority categories, such as essential workers. CIUSSS assures that health care workers who identified themselves as such did not lose their results, as their specimens were prioritized. "We are aware that this may have caused some inconvenience and we are very sorry for that." Fortunately, the situation has since been rectified, the spokesperson assures us, and since the criteria for clinic testing have since been revised, this is unlikely to happen again. titre: Un grand pas vers la protection du boisé Steinberg dans l’est de Montréal
texte: The City of Montreal and Hydro-Quebec will announce on Monday that they have reached an agreement to transfer land to each other. Steinberg Woods is located in the borough of Mercier-Hochelaga-Maisonneuve. Photo: Radio-Canada Good news for citizens who have been fighting for years to protect the Steinberg woodland, located in the middle of an industrial district. Radio-Canada has learned that Hydro-Québec will sell the part of the woodland it owns to the City of Montreal. According to our sources, the state-owned company has purchased a nearby industrial lot, north of Hochelaga Street, to install a transformer station, rather than carry out this project in the natural area. Transactions for the land would represent several tens of millions of dollars. Details will be released Monday. The City of Montreal would not provide information prior to the announcement, and Hydro-Québec would only confirm by email that its land purchase is a substation project to meet the growing demand for electricity in the east end of the city. Anaïs Houde, a resident of the neighbourhood, is delighted with this very good news. She dreams of a protected nature park in this wooded area that offers her an incredible sense of well-being. We like to walk there with our dog, with the children, we have picnics..., she adds. A few years ago, a highway bypass project threatened the woodland, but the idea was abandoned in 2020. However, the Quebec government has on its list of priority projects the extension of Assomption Boulevard to ensure better flow of trucks entering the Port of Montreal, which would eat into the eastern part of the woodland. Steinberg Woods was in the news in 2021, when a homeless camp was dismantled. Please note that Radio-Canada does not endorse the opinions expressed. titre: Frédéric Abergel est pressenti pour prendre la tête du CHUM
texte: The Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal is the main university hospital center in Quebec. Frédéric Abergel is currently CEO of CIUSSS du Nord-de-l'Île-de-Montréal. Photo: Radio-Canada The waltz of CEOs in Quebec's health care system shows no signs of letting up. All indications are that the government will appoint Frédéric Abergel as CEO of the Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM) in the next few days. He is currently CEO of CIUSSS du Nord-de-l'Île-de-Montréal. According to two Radio-Canada sources, the CHUM board of directors has notified the government of its choice, which must still be approved by the Conseil des ministres. Frédéric Abergel, who is highly regarded at the highest levels of the network and even by his subordinates, will replace Fabrice Brunet, who did not wish to renew his mandate at CHUM. The CHUM employs 18,000 people. Photo: Radio-Canada / Martin Thibault Frédéric Abergel was CEO of the CIUSSS du Nord-de-l'Île-de-Montréal since 2018. His mandate had been renewed in 2022 for four years. Previously, he had held a director position at the former Agence de la santé et des services sociaux de Montréal. At the time of his reappointment, the Minister of Health and Social Services, Christian Dubé, praised his remarkable leadership and great skills. During the pandemic, he was probably the CEO who faced the strongest storm, as Montreal's northern neighborhoods were among the most affected by COVID-19. In 2018, he had replaced Pierre Gfeller, who left that position due to his appointment as CEO of the McGill University Health Centre. Yesterday, the Council of Ministers approved the appointment of Dr. Lucie Opatrny to replace Mr. Gfeller. She was previously Assistant Deputy Minister of Health. As revealed by Radio-Canada in April, the majority of CISSS and CIUSSS CEOs in office during the pandemic are no longer in their positions. titre: Violences sexuelles : l'UQAM, McGill et la moitié des cégeps ne se conforment pas à la loi
texte: UQAM is one of the Quebec universities that has not yet adopted a policy to prevent and combat sexual violence. Photo: Radio-Canada / Martin Thibault Two universities and 26 CEGEPs out of 48 have still not adopted a policy to prevent and combat sexual violence, as required by the law passed in the wake of the #MeToo movement. Yet the Quebec government required all higher education institutions to do so by January 1, 2019. The Ministry of Education and Higher Education published on its website on Thursday its list of good students, that is, universities and CEGEPs that have complied with the law. However, it is noted that many institutions are missing from this list. On December 8, 2017, the National Assembly unanimously adopted the bill carried by former minister Hélène David that required universities and CEGEPs to implement a specific policy against sexual violence before January 1, 2019. The law extends the concept of sexual violence to include misconduct, such as unwanted sexual gestures, words, behaviors or attitudes expressed directly or indirectly, including in cyberspace. Many institutions have been slow to initiate the policy development process. In mid-November, Radio-Canada reported that no college or university had yet adopted a policy. Institutional representatives had complained that they had only received the accompanying guide from the ministry at the end of the summer. Institutions must implement the policy by September 1, 2019. Any delay in adopting the policy could make the process of implementing it on the ground more difficult. The Fédération étudiante collégiale du Québec is calling on the Minister of Education and Higher Education, Jean-François Roberge, to ensure that the planned policies and services go into effect for September, despite the delay. For her part, former minister Hélène David said she was "disappointed": "It's been 13 months since the law was adopted and it is very clear. The subject is still extremely topical. How much time will they have left to implement it?" "The vice-president of the National Federation of Teachers of Quebec, Richard Bousquet, is less worried about the situation. For us, the important thing is that there be real consultation in the institutions," he says. We prefer to have a little delay in the adoption, but that it be done as much as possible by consensus. That will make it easier to implement. The law also requires colleges and universities to consult with students, administrators and staff as part of their policy work. Despite the government's efforts to encourage institutions to adopt a sexual violence policy, lack of time and resources to put these policies in place has been a barrier for many institutions. Students and staff at institutions that have not yet adopted a policy are concerned about how sexual violence will be addressed at their institutions. titre: Les maisons les plus abordables et les plus inabordables au monde sont au Canada
texte: In Cape Breton, the median home price is $162,000 and the median income is $75,700. Photo: iStock Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, has the easiest access to homeownership, according to an annual study comparing various housing markets around the world. In contrast, Vancouver, which is "extremely unaffordable," is ranked second to last in the world. According to the U.S.-based Demographia International Housing Affordability study, released Monday, the median price of a home is twice the median household income in Cape Breton. A housing market is considered affordable when it does not exceed three times that ratio. On the other side of the country, in Vancouver, it takes 12.6 times the annual income to afford a median-priced home. Not to be confused with the average price, the median price means that half of the homes cost more and half cost less. The study compares 309 housing markets in Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand, Ireland, Hong Kong and Singapore. The data is from the fourth quarter of 2018. Canada has 17 cities with "extremely unaffordable" housing markets, meaning median home prices are more than five times median household income. In addition, 5 cities are "very unaffordable" (ratio between 4.1 and 5), 16 are "moderately unaffordable" (ratio of 3.1 to 4), and 12 are "affordable" (3 and below). Cape Breton (2.1) is the most affordable market of all the countries surveyed. Also among the cities with the most affordable homes by income are Fort McMurray (2.2), Moncton (2.3) and Fredericton (2.4). In Montreal, a household needs 4.6 times its median income to afford a home, placing the Quebec metropolis in the "very unaffordable" markets. In 2004, Montreal was on the edge of affordability (3.1). High-rise apartments in Vancouver Photo: CBC / Christer Waara This year, Vancouver (12.6) surpasses Sydney (11.7), Australia in the world's unaffordable market. Hong Kong tops the list (20.9). Toronto's situation is also deteriorating, as the Ontario metropolis (8.3) is as unaffordable as London (8.3) and even less affordable than New York (5.5). "Over the past 15 years, the housing market has become increasingly unaffordable in Canada's major cities. Photo: Demographia International Housing Affordability Survey 2019 The study's authors note that "national and international organizations have expressed concern about the potential impact of these price increases on the Canadian economy." | According to the study, the most affordable Canadian cities are Cape Breton, Fort McMurray, Moncton and Fredericton. The most unaffordable cities are Vancouver, Toronto, Montreal and London. The consequences of these price increases are worrisome for the Canadian economy. Low-income households are the most affected by this situation, as they are unable to afford a home. The authors of the study stress that governments must take action to help low-income households access home ownership. Solutions could include low-interest loan programs, home purchase subsidies and affordable housing construction programs. Governments should also ensure that house prices are not artificially inflated by foreign investors. Finally, it is important to remember that Canada is one of the most affordable countries to buy a home, which is good news for Canadians.

titre: Vague de démissions au journal  Métro
texte: The Montreal daily is going through a crisis. Photo: Radio-Canada / Jérôme Labbé It's a massacre at Montreal's Métro newspaper, where nearly a dozen employees have resigned in the last few days, most of them in the newsroom. The director also left his position on March 1. According to our information, a quarter of the total staff has quit. Among the resignations are the two news directors: Marie-Ève Shaffer and Baptiste Barbe. In addition, there is a web news director and at least three journalists, including a regular supernumerary. A sales manager also resigned in the last few days. In addition, the senior director of operations, Yves Bédard, left his position on March 1. He had been with the paper since its first day, 18 years ago. "Some employees have denounced a great lack of listening and communication on the part of the new management team, which arrived in August following the sale of the newspaper. Several events have undermined the confidence of employees. The last straw was the move of the premises planned for the end of the month, in the borough of Saint-Laurent. The owner wishes to regroup its different media under one roof. The Métro newspaper was bought, like other TC Transcontinental publications, by businessman Michael Raffoul in April. Andrew Mulé, vice-president of the company that owns Métro Média, confirmed the resignations, but would not comment on them "for reasons of confidentiality." Two vacancies have already been filled, and the company plans to replace the remaining resigned employees "in the near future. ""Metro Media says it has implemented a "modernization" that has resulted in investments "to improve the user experience [of] digital platforms, the development of [the] content offering and new professional opportunities [for] employees to contribute to the wind of change blowing through Metro." titre: Encore beaucoup de travail à faire avant la réouverture de l'unité d'obstétrique à La Sarre
texte: Center hospilatier de La Sarre, in Abitibi-Ouest Photo: artcad.qc.ca Six days before the reopening of the obstetrics unit in La Sarre, the Ministry of Health still has a lot of work to do. The 8 nurses who will come in relief in Abitibi-Ouest have finally been confirmed in the last few days. There will be four from Sainte-Justine, two from the Prénato clinic in Quebec City and two from CIUSSS de l'Ouest-de-l'Île-de-Montréal. The Ministry of Health is currently working on completing the work schedules. It will also be necessary to manage the comings and goings of the various nurses from outside the hospital and to find them accommodation. The first nurses are expected to arrive at the last minute, on April 14. The announcement of the reopening of the birth department at La Sarre had taken many people by surprise. The President and CEO, Yves Desjardins, had not even been informed of the situation. The head of the obstetrics department, Kim Beauregard-Lepage, is demanding that the department of medicine and surgery no longer be merged with the obstetrics department. Photo : Radio-Canada / Jean-Marc Belzile Sainte-Justine nurses surprised The national representative of the nursing staff for the CSN union at Sainte-Justine Hospital, Félix-Olivier Bonneville, also says he was very surprised at the time of the announcement, especially considering the shortage of nurses at Sainte-Justine. At this time, in April, there are a little more than 150 shifts that are more or less filled, that is to say, could people fill them with overtime, could we cut back a little to have a little less elective deliveries that would be planned in advance, so there is a whole mechanism that must be done that is not yet done, he says. Yes, I think that Minister McCann, when she made her exit, was a bit premeditated. Félix-Olivier Bonneville is in favour of reopening the obstetrics unit in La Sarre, but he believes that everything was done too quickly. We know that there are interested girls, we know that it is something that has aroused interest among the nurses of the birthing unit. When the release was made by the minister, many of those nurses were questioning how it will happen. There are some basic questions that are not yet answered," he says. For this second evening of information, a group of 13 people sat on the stage to present to the population concrete actions to try to correct the problem of overdraft in obstetrics. Photo: Radio-Canada / Lise Millette The president of the Federation of Medical Specialists, Diane Francoeur, deplores the lack of planning in hospitals. A situation that would be directly responsible, according to her, for the closure of obstetrics units in La Sarre in Abitibi-Témiscamingue and La Malbaie in Charlevoix. The Ministry of Health has stated that the nurses who will come to relieve La Sarre will be well trained and ready to work. The nurses who will come from Sainte-Justine, the Prénato clinic in Quebec City and the CIUSSS de l'Ouest-de-l'Île-de-Montréal will all have specialized training in obstetrics and newborn care. The Ministry of Health has also announced that additional measures will be put in place to ensure that the nurses who will relieve La Sarre will be well taken care of. Temporary housing will be provided and transportation services will be put in place to facilitate their travel. The Ministry of Health has also announced that it is working on measures to ensure that nurses who will be relocating to La Sarre will be well integrated into the medical team. Training sessions and workshops will be organized to allow them to better understand the Quebec health system and to adapt to their new environment. The Ministry of Health has also announced that it is working on measures to ensure that the nurses who will relieve La Sarre will be well integrated into the community. Social and cultural activities will be organized to allow them to get to know the region better and to integrate into it. The Ministry of Health has also announced that it is working to put in place measures to ensure that the nurses who will relieve La Sarre will be well supported. Psychological support and counselling services will be made available to them to help them better manage their stress and emotions. The Ministry of Health has also announced that it is working on measures to ensure that nurses who relieve La Sarre will be well compensated. Additional bonuses and benefits will be offered to allow them to better enjoy their stay in La Sarre. The Department of Health has also announced that it is working on measures to ensure that nurses who relieve La Sarre will be well protected. Additional security measures will be put in place to allow them to work safely. The Department of Health has also announced that it is working to ensure that nurses who will be relieving in La Sarre will be well informed. Regular newsletters and updates will be sent to nurses to help them understand the situation and make the right decisions.

titre: Des contrôles resserrés pour les clients de Desjardins à la Banque Nationale
texte: Have Desjardins customers become "toxic" following the massive leak of personal data? Photo: Radio-Canada / Ivanoh Demers The National Bank is wary of requests from Desjardins customers and is strengthening its security measures towards them, Radio-Canada has learned. According to a computer security expert, victims of the massive data theft should be prepared to undergo more stringent checks with banks and businesses. Have Desjardins customers become "toxic"? According to our information, the National Bank has recently taken increased security measures specifically targeting them. For example, opening an online bank account is no longer as easy as it is for customers of other financial institutions. The author of this article did the test, as he is one of the 2.9 million Desjardins members affected by the theft of personal data. When he identified himself as a Desjardins client, the online account opening process stopped and a message sent him to a BNC branch. However, he was able to open an account if he indicated that he belonged to a bank other than Desjardins. When we indicated that we were a customer on the Desjardins site, a message sent us to a branch. But by selecting another financial institution, the account could be opened online. Photo: Screenshot/Radio-Canada "I can confirm that we have increased our monitoring measures for the opening of online accounts, but there is no systematic refusal," says the senior director of public affairs at the National Bank, Marie-Pierre Jodoin. Some Desjardins members would still be able to open an account online, says the NBC. Which ones? The Bank refuses to go into detail about its security strategies, simply mentioning "cross-referencing". "I would do the same thing if I were in their shoes," explains François Daigle, an IT security expert at Okiok. He considers the measure taken by the National Bank with regard to Desjardins clients "normal, appropriate and prudent". According to the expert, Desjardins clients who were victims of data theft should be reassured: "It will reduce the risk of their identity being stolen. On the other hand, François Daigle expects that other banks and businesses will follow the example of the NBC and double-check that they are the real people. "We're going to want to verify their identity maybe more than others," he believes. "It's going to take longer, it's going to be more complicated. Those are, unfortunately, the consequences of identity theft." Desjardins customers should expect to be sent to branches more often or to go in person to certain businesses. According to François Daigle, the consequences of data theft are numerous and Desjardins customers should expect more thorough checks. "Banks and businesses are going to want to make sure that the person who shows up is who they say they are," he says. "They're going to want to verify the address, phone number and other information." So Desjardins customers should be prepared to provide more information and spend more time proving their identity. "Expect the account opening and purchase processes to take longer," says Daigle. "You have to be prepared to provide additional information and answer more specific questions." Desjardins customers should also expect their information to be verified more often. "Banks and businesses are going to want to make sure that the person who shows up is who they say they are," explains François Daigle. "They're going to want to verify the address, phone number and other information." So Desjardins customers should be prepared to provide more information and spend more time proving their identity. "Expect the account opening and purchase processes to take longer," says Daigle. "You have to be prepared to provide additional information and answer more specific questions." These additional security measures are necessary to protect Desjardins customers and their personal data. "Banks and businesses need to take steps to ensure that customer information is protected," says Daigle. "This is the only way to ensure that customers' personal data is not compromised." Desjardins customers should therefore expect that their information will be verified more often and that the account opening and purchase process will take longer.

titre: Louis Robert retrouve son emploi et les mois de salaire perdus
texte: Louis Robert was fired from the Ministry of Agriculture after 32 years of service. Photo: Radio-Canada / La semaine verte Victory on all fronts for the whistleblower fired by the Quebec Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (MAPAQ). Radio-Canada has learned that the agronomist will regain his job on August 6. He will even receive financial compensation for the damage he suffered. The employees of the Ministry of Agriculture office in Saint-Hyacinthe were informed by their superiors on Tuesday morning that their colleague Louis Robert had signed an out-of-court settlement with the government. According to our sources, the whistleblower will be reinstated in the same position he held, the payment of the six months of salary lost during his dismissal, as well as compensation for the stress caused. As part of the negotiations, Treasury Board even offered Louis Robert full retirement with three years left on his contract. But he refused, preferring to return to work. The out-of-court settlement ends the arbitration process and all grievances are dropped. Louis Robert did not wish to comment. In a press release, the Syndicat des professionnels du gouvernement du Québec "hopes that the government will have learned its lesson with the agronomist saga and that never again will an employee find himself in such a storm for having wanted to protect the public. For its part, MAPAQ welcomed Louis Robert's "return to work" and said it was "satisfied to be able to count on his expertise". "Mr. Robert and MAPAQ are determined to work in the same direction, that is, for the benefit of farmers in the Montérégie and Quebec," said Mélissa Lapointe, spokesperson for the Quebec Ministry of Agriculture. Louis Robert, who had more than 30 years of experience at MAPAQ, had denounced the interference of the private sector in public research on pesticides. On January 24, he was fired for having transmitted confidential documents to Radio-Canada. A few days later, the Québec Ombudsman announced the opening of an investigation. In her report, the ombudsman severely criticized the Department of Agriculture for not respecting the law and for not protecting the identity of the whistleblower. Louis Robert was welcomed back to work with open arms by his colleagues. "This is a victory for justice and for whistleblower protection," said a department employee. "We are pleased that Louis Robert was able to return to his job and that the government has recognized the harm he suffered." Louis Robert's return to his post was welcomed by whistleblower rights organizations. "This is a victory for whistleblower protection and justice," said Transparency International Canada Executive Director James Cohen. "It shows that the government is willing to recognize the courage and work of whistleblowers and protect them." Louis Robert's return to his post is also a victory for farmers in the Montérégie and Quebec. "We are pleased that Louis Robert has been able to return to his position and that the government has recognized the harm he suffered," said Marcel Groleau, president of the Union des producteurs agricoles. "We are confident that his expertise and commitment to protecting farmers will benefit everyone." Louis Robert's return to his position is an important step toward protecting whistleblowers and promoting transparency and integrity in the public sector. "We hope that this case will serve as a lesson and that the government will take steps to protect whistleblowers and encourage disclosure," said Quebec Whistleblowers Association President Jean-François Lépine. "We are pleased that Louis Robert was able to return to his job and that the government has recognized the harm he suffered."

titre: Dans les poches des électeurs, la clé du pouvoir | Élections Canada 2019
texte: Townhouses in the Toronto suburb of Burlington. Photo: CBC/Radio-Canada / Thomas Gerbet The cost of living is the issue of most concern to Canadians, according to surveys, especially families. That's what we found in suburban Toronto. Burlington has miles of row houses. It's unthinkable to live here without a car, in this suburb west of Toronto. And patience is required. During rush hour, it can take up to two hours to get to downtown Toronto. "You have to drive to get the kids to daycare, drive to work, drive, drive and drive," complains Judy, who puts gas in her car. At her eye level at the pump, Doug Ford's provincial government has placed stickers against the carbon tax introduced by Justin Trudeau's Liberals. The stickers show the cost of the carbon tax per liter (4.4 cents) and how it will rise to 11.1 cents per liter by 2022. There is no mention of the federal government's reimbursement to citizens. Everything is done to send the message that it will be expensive. We'll get $300, but the carbon tax will have cost me more than that," says Judy. Besides, what's the point of charging it and then giving the money back to everyone else. It wouldn't make sense. The ridings in the Toronto suburbs are very large and often vote as a block. Here, you can win or lose power. "The cost of living is very high, every day you feel like you're losing a little more to taxes or whatever." Does Trent, who has two cars, have trouble making ends meet? "I don't have any personal debt," he admits, "except for the car loan." If he wants more money in his pocket, it's in anticipation of retirement, he says, for which he has very little savings set aside. A few houses down the road, in front of his pickup truck and boat, John is railing against the Liberal government's record: "Trudeau promised to balance the budget in 2019 and he didn't. It's a total failure. It's a total failure." This Conservative voter also wants less taxes: "I'd rather have more money in my pocket to control my own destiny. I can manage that money better than the government. Real estate agent Audrey Bailey, who works in Burlington and Hamilton, says it takes at least $500,000 to $700,000 for a family to buy a home. Even 50 kilometers from Toronto. Young couples with no children and budgets under $500,000 are becoming very difficult to find," she says. Unfortunately, they have to keep renting. The problem is that renting is also very expensive. | Burlington voters are aware that their votes can have a significant impact on the outcome of the election. "I want my vote to count," says Judy. titre: Record d'utilisation du camion blindé du SPVM
texte: The device is used during high-risk interventions with suspects carrying firearms. The ballistic protection truck, purchased in 2013 by the SPVM. Photo: Radio-Canada / Dominic Brassard Purchased six years ago for $365,000 by the Service de police de la Ville de Montréal (SPVM), the ballistic protection truck has been used 13 times since May 2018, according to data obtained by Radio-Canada. The Thunder-1 truck is a metal monster: 17 tons, 285 horsepower. The machine, which can carry a dozen people, has the capacity to travel at a speed of 120 km/h. The vehicle is intended to serve as a shield for the Emergency Response Team (ERT) during high-risk operations, such as when an armed person is barricaded or hostages must be evacuated. The armored vehicle is equipped with 13 gun ports that allow police officers to fire outward or hand communication devices to barricaded individuals to negotiate. The SPVM has added a hydraulic ram to the truck to break down a door or a window from a distance of 3.5 meters. The police believe that this protection avoids the need to use lethal force and also allows them to protect citizens during operations. According to data obtained under the Public Agency Records Access Act, the armored truck was used a record eight times in 2018, including seven times between May and December. We retained only operational uses, excluding training and public displays of the vehicle. Between the start of 2019 and October 22, the armored truck was used five times. It's impossible to know when or why, because that information is confidential. It's also unclear whether the vehicle helped save any lives. Criticized at the time as a form of militarization, the police department justified its usefulness by planning to use it 10 to 15 times a year. However, for the past six years, the SPVM has never reached the threshold of use anticipated to justify the purchase. "The SPVM does not regret the purchase of this vehicle. Its relevance is not measured in the number of sorties, but rather in the fact that it can be essential in certain situations to ensure the safety of citizens and police officers. The SPVM has put in place strict procedures for the use of the armored truck. Only members of the Emergency Response Team (ERT) can use it and only when circumstances warrant. Police officers must assess the risk and determine if the truck is necessary to ensure the safety of citizens and police officers. The armoured truck is also used for high-risk interventions that do not require the use of firearms. For example, the vehicle can be used to evacuate hostages or to transport suspects to a safe location. The SPVM also has procedures in place to ensure that the armored truck is used safely and effectively. Police officers must undergo special training to learn how to operate the vehicle and use it properly. The SPVM also has procedures in place to ensure that the armoured truck is maintained and inspected regularly. Police officers must ensure that the vehicle is in good condition and ready to be used at all times. Despite the relatively low number of uses of the armoured truck, the SPVM believes that the vehicle is essential to ensure the safety of citizens and police officers. The SPVM believes that the armoured truck is a valuable tool that can be used to save lives and protect police officers and citizens during high-risk operations.

titre: Un bébé de deux ans meurt durant une intervention de la DPJ à Joliette
texte: Social services had underestimated the urgency of the family situation. The Sûreté du Québec's major crimes section opened an investigation. Photo: Radio-Canada / Félix B. Desfossés The child died suddenly of respiratory distress, while the interveners of the Directorate of Youth Protection (DPJ) were absent for a few moments from his home, Radio-Canada has learned. At 1:15 p.m. on Thursday, March 26, DPJ workers arrived at a residence in Joliette, but the parents were reluctant to let them in. After insisting, they discovered a scene of horror rarely seen, according to three sources familiar with the case. In the unsanitary dwelling, the four young children of the family had fungus on their faces and purulent skin. Obvious negligence on the part of the parents, but the worst was yet to come. At 2:00 p.m., the DPJ decided to proceed with the emergency placement of the children, a 6-year-old boy, a 2-year-old boy and two 6-month-old twin girls. The two workers left the residence for a few moments. They alerted the police, quickly found a foster family and went in search of a vehicle with infant seats to transport the children. When they returned to the home at 3:00 p.m., they were surprised to find an ambulance on the scene, in addition to the police. The two-year-old boy was unconscious and in respiratory distress. He died on arrival at the hospital from cardiopulmonary arrest. The situation of the family's children had been reported to the Lanaudière DPJ in January. The case was classified as "code 3", the lowest priority level. However, it requires an evaluation within twelve days. However, it took more than two months for the DPJ to evaluate it. The abundance of files would be the reason. According to our information, social services called the family for the first time a few days ago. An intervener noticed a lack of cooperation from the family on the phone and became concerned, which triggered the visit to the home on Thursday. The management of the CISSS de Lanaudière wishes its most sincere condolences to the family," wrote the spokesperson for the Centre intégré de santé et de services sociaux, Pascale Lamy, in an e-mail. Considering the rules of confidentiality that apply, we cannot give any information related to this situation. The Sûreté du Québec's major crimes section has opened an investigation. Interviews will be conducted, including with the family and the DPJ. Why didn't anyone stay at the scene between 2:00 and 3:00 pm? The death of the two-year-old child has caused a wave of indignation and sadness in the Joliette community. Neighbors and family members told Radio-Canada that they were aware of the family's plight and had reported their concerns to the DPJ. "We tried to help them, but we were not heard," said one neighbor. "It's very sad that this child had to die for someone to finally become aware of the situation." titre: Le cri du coeur de Véronique Hivon contre la mort sans dignité
texte: The MP is calling for a "minimum of humanity" because relatives are still unable to accompany their dying relative from COVID-19, despite the directive that allows it. The MP Véronique Hivon is known to the general public for her management of the "Dying with Dignity" file. Photo: Radio-Canada / Ivanoh Demers Véronique Hivon raises her voice against the government in an interview with Radio-Canada. The MP behind the Act respecting end-of-life care in Quebec notes that too many seniors still die alone and without dignity in CHSLDs. She is concerned about the mental health of loved ones. I can't believe that we are going to let more and more seniors die alone. This is the opposite of dignity," says Véronique Hivon, who is very affected by the situation. It is the opposite of the approach that we wanted to be so humane and proactive in Quebec. "In a society as advanced, as humane, as supportive as Quebec's, where so much work has been done on death with dignity, on accompanying the end of life, it seems to me that we owe that to the seniors who built Quebec. A directive dated March 23 (New Window) from the Quebec Ministry of Health allows visits to relatives at the end of life, including in CHSLDs. One person at a time is allowed, with a maximum of three family members in turn per 24-hour period. How is it that this is not applied when everything is supposed to be in place for this," she says. On April 8, Health Minister Danielle McCann reiterated the "watchword" for facilities to call and keep families informed of their loved ones' health. Families, we have not forgotten you," she said. On April 11, Premier François Legault even suggested hiring staff to dedicate to this communication task, recognizing a gap between the directive that is given and what is humanly possible to do in some places. The PQ member recognizes that the lack of staff complicates matters in this unprecedented crisis, but she wonders if sufficient efforts are being made: I can't believe that we are not imaginative and creative enough in Quebec to find ways. Véronique Hivon recommends using users' committees or residents' committees, which have been somewhat neglected since the beginning of the crisis, to liaise with families. Like Dr. Joanne Liu, she also suggests allowing family caregivers to return to residences, even those struggling with COVID-19. "It's no more risky for a family member to wear all the protective gear than it is for an inexperienced volunteer to come in and lend a hand and care for 20-30 residents." The MP cites the example of Montrealer Réal Migneault, whose presence at the side of his dying mother even managed to reverse her condition, before being barred from the CHSLD. Véronique Hivon believes that the government must take steps to ensure that the directives are applied and that loved ones can accompany their dying parents. "The government must put pressure on institutions to apply the directive and ensure that families can be present," she said. She also stressed that family caregivers are a valuable resource and should be allowed back into residences, even those struggling with COVID-19. "Family caregivers are people who know their loved ones well and can offer support and a caring presence. They are a valuable resource and should be allowed back into the residences," she said. Véronique Hivon also stressed that families must be kept informed about the health of their loved ones. "Families must be kept informed of the health of their loved ones and their condition. They must be informed of their rights and their possibilities of support," she said. She added that families must be treated with respect and dignity and their needs must be addressed. "Families must be treated with respect and dignity and their needs must be addressed. They must be informed and supported in their efforts," she said. Véronique Hivon concluded by saying that Quebec must show humanity and solidarity towards the seniors who built Quebec. "In a society as advanced, as humane, as supportive as Quebec's, where so much work has been done on death with dignity, on the accompaniment of the end of life, it seems to me that we owe this to the seniors who built Quebec," she said. She added that Quebec must show compassion and respect to families who are facing the loss of a loved one. "We must show compassion and respect to families who are facing the loss of a loved one. We need to give them the support and guidance they need," she concluded.

titre: Éclosions de COVID-19 à l'Hôpital Charles-Le Moyne de Longueuil | Coronavirus
texte: At least 37 patients have been infected with the coronavirus within the walls of the hospital. Admissions are suspended on the two affected units. Photo: The Canadian Press / Ryan Remiorz Another hospital has been added to the long list of those dealing with COVID-19 outbreaks. Radio-Canada has learned that the virus has spread outside the units reserved for patients with COVID-19 at Hôpital Charles-Le Moyne, located in Longueuil. Two units are affected and admissions are suspended until the situation recovers, confirmed the Centre intégré de santé et de services sociaux (CISSS) de la Montérégie-Centre. Surgeries can be performed as planned, says CISSS spokesperson Sara-Ève Tremblay. However, according to a medical source within the institution, several surgical rooms are not functioning and waiting lists are getting longer outside the emergency and semi-emergency departments. In order to obtain confirmation of these outbreaks, we had to contact the CISSS five times since Wednesday, May 6. The 37 infected patients were transferred to a unit reserved for patients infected with COVID-19 in the hospital. In addition, 32 positive employees have been screened and placed in isolation. Further testing is underway, says CISSS. "To contain the spread of the virus, infection prevention and control measures are being applied as in any other type of outbreak." On Tuesday evening, the Charles-Le Moyne emergency room was 116% occupied. A total of 17 patients had been waiting on a stretcher for more than 24 hours and 7 for more than 48 hours. In Longueuil, the other hospital, Pierre-Boucher, is also experiencing outbreaks, Radio-Canada reported on May 5. Like Pierre-Boucher, Charles-Le Moyne Hospital is designated by the Ministry of Health to receive patients with COVID-19, but like many other institutions, it has not been able to contain the virus in the hot units. In recent weeks, outbreaks have destabilized Maisonneuve-Rosemont Hospital, which has had to cancel surgeries and send patients elsewhere. The Ministry of Health has stated that infection prevention and control measures are being rigorously enforced in all facilities affected by COVID-19 outbreaks. Additional measures have been put in place to ensure the safety of patients and employees. Patients and employees are being screened for positive cases and isolated. Social distancing measures are also being implemented to limit the spread of the virus.
