titre: Certaines écoles rouvriront dès le 1er juin dans le Grand Montréal
texte: To give parents of children with disabilities a break, the Ministry of Education is allowing special schools to reopen. L'Étincelle elementary school welcomes autistic students. Photo: Radio-Canada / Conrad Fournier The return to school will be quicker than expected for hundreds of students in the Montreal Metropolitan Community (MMC) and the Joliette MRC. Teachers are concerned. Quebec announced on Thursday that specialized schools with regional and supra-regional mandates will be able to reopen on June 1, under certain conditions. The reopening concerns only particularly vulnerable clienteles. The goal is to meet the needs of students with disabilities or serious behavioural problems," said Bryan St-Louis, a spokesman for the ministry. With the deconfliction coming on May 25 in Greater Montreal, the government wants to make it easier for parents with special needs children who cannot stay home alone without supervision. However, the return to class will be optional, at the parents' choice. In Montreal, some schools will open in their entirety and others, which serve both disabled and non-disabled students, will open only for disabled students. "To be eligible to return to school, the student must not have symptoms associated with COVID-19 and must not have a precarious health condition that could be worsened by deconfinement." As they prepare to reopen, staff members are questioning the conditions under which classes will resume and the ability to maintain physical distance from some students. At Montreal's Joseph-Charbonneau School, which has 188 students, the majority of whom require wheelchair assistance, the school's governing board is concerned. It passed a motion on Thursday demanding additional guarantees before reopening, citing fears about the measures that will be put in place to safely accommodate the students. The reopening is "unpredictable," according to Marie Contant, a teacher at L'Étincelle school in Montreal. Students with severe autism will not be able to maintain physical distance, she says. "We have to hold their hands when we move around, we have to spoon-feed them, some of them have self-injurious behaviours and we have to stop them. There's spitting, biting, hitting, glasses being ripped off... But this will probably be masks and visors being ripped off." All of our school teams are mobilized to put in place a safe environment adapted to the reality of their environment," says Alain Perron, spokesperson for the Commission scolaire de Montréal (CSDM). | The safety measures put in place by the Ministry of Education are very strict. Students and staff must wear masks and visors, and classes will be divided into small groups to ensure physical separation. Students will also be required to wash their hands frequently and surfaces will be disinfected several times a day. Parents are encouraged to make their own arrangements for school transportation and to ensure that their children are healthy before sending them to school. Teachers are encouraged to adapt their teaching methods to fit the situation and to provide activities that meet safety measures. Specialized schools are also encouraged to provide distance support services for students who are unable to attend school. Schools are also encouraged to provide psychological support services to students and their families to help them manage the stress and anxiety associated with the situation. Teachers and school staff are also encouraged to participate in trainings to learn how to manage difficult situations and provide support to students and their families.

titre: Montée en flèche des enfants retirés de l’école depuis la rentrée au Québec | Coronavirus
texte: Thousands of parents concerned about outbreaks are asking to be home-schooled. The department is running out of resources. Marie-Isabelle Rochon reports Photo: Getty Images / pinstock Christine Desrochers has prepared the necessary documents. In the next few days, she will withdraw her son and daughter from their school in Sainte-Anne-des-Plaines for the entire school year, for fear of COVID-19 outbreaks. "I don't think they're safe. It really worries me and I'd rather keep them at home with me." Like them, an additional 3,340 students were pulled out of school within a month. That's an unprecedented number. These numbers don't even include absences based on a medical exemption, which the Department of Education doesn't yet tabulate. The data also does not include students in seclusion who will return to class later. At the beginning of the school year at the end of August, there were 8304 children in home schooling, which was already much higher than last year, but now there are 11,644 and the number is growing. Christine Desrochers deplores the large class sizes and the grouping of students at lunchtime and recess. The school is not doing enough, she says, while about 100 schools are affected by outbreaks across the province. Conversely, some parents feel their child's school is doing too much, as Marine Dumond, president of the Association québécoise pour l'éducation à domicile (AQED), has found. "There are also families who feel that the health measures put in place will not provide an optimal educational experience for their child this year, so they decide to go without the school environment with home schooling." In the 2019-2020 school year, 5964 children were reported to be home-schooled, half as many as today. The Department of Education wants to be reassuring, reminding us that 99% of the 1.3 million students still attend school. However, it no longer has enough staff to follow up with children at home and accompany parents. Given the increase in enrolment, additional resources are being added, the department says. Christine Desrochers is not worried about her ability to provide this instruction because of the many tools available on the Internet. | The Ministry of Education has put in place measures to help parents adapt to home schooling. Webinars are held to help them understand and adapt to the system. Digital tools are also available to make it easier for them. "We have put in place tools to help parents adjust to homeschooling. We offer webinars and digital tools to make it easier for them," the department says. Parents who choose to homeschool are encouraged to get organized and prepare ahead of time. "It is important to get organized and prepare ahead of time. It's also important to be prepared to adapt to changes and find solutions to problems that may arise," explains Christine Desrochers. Despite the challenges, parents who choose to homeschool are encouraged to persevere. "You have to be willing to adapt and find solutions to problems that may arise. You must also persevere and not give up," concludes Christine Desrochers.

titre: Protégez-Vous  ouvre une enquête sur un vol de données touchant ses abonnés
texte: The personal information of 380,000 current and former subscribers of the magazine is sold on the web. In January 2020, the magazine had published a special feature on personal data protection. Photo: Protégez-Vous The magazine Protégez-Vous opens an internal investigation after a massive theft of personal data of its current and former subscribers, Radio-Canada has learned. The email addresses of 380,000 people, present in two Protégez-Vous databases, have been sold on the web in exchange for bitcoins since December 7. We could see that the passwords are also provided, but they are encrypted. Fortunately for the subscribers and ex-subscribers, their credit card data is not part of the leak. The magazine was not aware of this security breach. Within minutes of being informed, management notified us that an internal investigation was underway. "Protect Yourself is triggering an internal investigation in line with its cybersecurity processes." In an excerpt from the list visible to all on a web forum, we can see email addresses with French-sounding names, an email address of a Protégez-Vous employee and an email address of an official from the Quebec Ministry of Agriculture. We contacted four people on this list. All of them are current or former subscribers to the magazine. Protégez-Vous currently has 97,000 subscribers, both in print and digital formats. According to the CEO of EVA Technologies, a cybersecurity specialist, Éric Parent, the people on this list are exposed to phishing attempts by e-mail. "After a breach like that, attackers will often use that list to send fake emails and try to impersonate Protect-You." The expert advises subscribers and former subscribers of the magazine to change their passwords on the magazine's site, but also to change all their similar passwords on other sites. It is not known if the data theft was caused by someone internally or by an outside attack that exploited a security breach. In January, the magazine Protégez-Vous published a large dossier on the protection of personal data. In the preamble of its articles, we could read: Your information is worth gold and someone, somewhere, will want to use it to get rich. The era of complacency is over, and Protect Yourself said it will take steps to strengthen the security of its data and that of its subscribers. "We're going to put additional measures in place to make sure this doesn't happen again," said the CEO of Protect-You. "We will also be working with cybersecurity experts to make sure our systems are up to date and secure." The magazine also said it will contact subscribers and ex-subscribers to inform them of the situation and offer advice on how to protect their data. "We will be contacting all subscribers and ex-subscribers to explain the situation and offer advice on how to protect their data," the CEO said. "We want to make sure our subscribers and ex-subscribers are informed and protected." The magazine also said it will work with the appropriate authorities to investigate the data theft and find the person or persons responsible. "We will work with the appropriate authorities to investigate the data theft and find the person or persons responsible," the CEO said. "We want to make sure that the people responsible for this data theft are held accountable for their actions." The magazine also said it will take steps to ensure its subscribers and ex-subscribers are protected. "We will take steps to ensure that our subscribers and ex-subscribers are protected," the CEO said. "We will put additional measures in place to ensure that our subscribers and ex-subscribers are protected from any form of data theft."

titre: Des masques au potentiel toxique distribués dans des écoles et des garderies du Québec | Coronavirus
texte: The grey and blue SNN200642 masks should no longer be used, warn Quebec City and Ottawa. SNN200642 masks have a grey side and a grey and blue side. Photo: Radio-Canada The SNN200642 masks from supplier Metallifer have a "potential for early lung toxicity," reads a directive sent Friday to the networks of Quebec's Ministry of Family, Education and Higher Education. In the document obtained by Radio-Canada, we learn that the notice follows the receipt of a warning from Health Canada on Thursday. Some daycare workers had been suspicious of these gray and blue masks for a while, because they felt they were swallowing cat hair when wearing them. "Health Canada has conducted a preliminary risk assessment that found a potential for early lung toxicity related to the inhalation of nanoformed graphene." According to a Health Canada fact sheet, early lung toxicity is characterized by lung infiltrates, fibrosis or both. This is a potential risk," the Quebec Ministry of Health and Social Services insists in a release, assuring that the government is acting proactively to avoid any possible danger and that the directive does not affect pediatric masks. The Quebec Ministry of Family specifies that the Education and Higher Education network is also concerned. It attached to its warning a notice written by Patrick Baillargeon, Director of Procurement of Laboratory and Medical Imaging Supplies. The document states: To date, Health Canada has not received data to support the safety and effectiveness of face masks containing nanoformed graphene. Therefore, based on the lack of evidence provided by the manufacturers...Health Canada considers the risks associated with these medical devices to be unacceptable. "If you have these types of masks in your inventory, we ask that you stop distributing them and store them in a safe place immediately." We also learn that these masks were distributed by Revenu Québec in the last few months. titre: Des milliers de doses de vaccin de Montréal envoyées dans les régions | Coronavirus
texte: New appointment slots will be reduced in the metropolis. Pfizer vaccines from Montreal will be sent to the regions. Photo: afp via getty images / Jean-François Monier The 3rd wave and the spike in cases in some regions are forcing the Quebec government to reroute tens of thousands of doses of vaccine intended for the island of Montreal to five regions. Initially, at least 15,000 doses would be withdrawn in Montreal, but this would not affect people who already have an appointment. However, some appointment slots will disappear for others. The news announced to health care facilities on the island of Montreal did not make anyone happy, as health care teams in the city are scrambling to vaccinate as many people as possible in several neighbourhoods that are experiencing numerous cases of COVID-19. We're not very happy, because many workers have not yet received their first dose," says a source, frustrated. The bitterness is palpable among management. We have to share what little there is," laments another source. But the surge in cases in some regions, in addition to the slowdown in the use of AstraZeneca's vaccine, leaves authorities with no choice. "The regions where it's more difficult, we're going to increase the vaccines, with a new distribution organization." Health Minister Christian Dubé explained that this decision comes after a public health request due to the increased presence of variants in these regions. Another reason mentioned by the Minister: to rebalance the advancement of vaccination where the appointment is not made to the same age groups everywhere. The Bas-Saint-Laurent and Outaouais regions are particularly behind. While 20% of the Montreal population has received a first dose of the vaccine, only 12% in the Lower St. Lawrence and 11% in the Outaouais have received it. In the Lower St. Lawrence, the Kamouraska region has 405 cases of COVID per 100,000 inhabitants, and this figure rises to 487 in the Rivière-du-Loup region. Health authorities have therefore decided to redirect doses of vaccine to five regions, including the Lower St. Lawrence and Outaouais regions. The 15,000 doses of Pfizer vaccine from Montreal will be sent to these regions to help fight the 3rd wave and reduce the number of cases of COVID-19. Health Minister Christian Dubé explained that this decision was made to rebalance the progress of vaccination and to meet public health demand. The regions that are most affected by the pandemic and have the most cases of COVID-19 will be the first to benefit from these additional doses. This decision was met with a mixture of relief and frustration. Mainland health teams are relieved that their efforts to vaccinate as many people as possible are being recognized, but they are frustrated that they will have to share the limited amount of vaccine allocated to them. Despite this decision, health authorities are aware that the situation is still very precarious and that it will take much more time and effort to vaccinate the population and end the pandemic.

titre: Gré à gré jusqu'en 2022 : « une ouverture aux dérapages », dit Dominique Anglade | Coronavirus
texte: The Liberal leader is concerned about the green light given to untendered health contracts for another 9 months. The leader of the Quebec Liberal Party, Dominique Anglade Photo: The Canadian Press / Jacques Boissinot The leader of the official opposition is asking the government for explanations and questioning the Auditor General, the day after the publication of a decree that authorizes the purchase of medical goods and services without calls for tenders until March 31, 2022. Why wasn't it adopted last week, when we were able to debate it in the National Assembly? The new decree allows the Government Procurement Centre to award contracts by mutual agreement, regardless of the amount, for a whole list of medical and office supplies. "There's an openness to slippage that's obvious and they're passing this five days after the end of the parliamentary session." Among the products that can be purchased without a bidding process are anesthesia and respiratory therapy accessories, angio-radiology supplies and orthopedic products. The government is concerned about service disruptions if this equipment runs out. Quebec justifies the need for the decree by the delay in resupplying health care managers during the pandemic. If there are supply issues, we want to know where they are," says Dominique Anglade, denouncing a lack of transparency while 145,000 Quebecers are waiting for surgery. "What is at risk in terms of stock-outs and supply? Where are the possible disruptions in service?" In an email to Radio-Canada, the Government Procurement Centre explains that it seeks to avoid significant risks in the supply of patient care services as well as turbulence for institutions. Dominique Anglade is surprised that the authorization needs to be stretched over nine more months. That's far too long," she says. The decree states that contracts should not be for more than 18 months and should not be renewable. In 18-month contracts, you can end up with five years' worth of inventory," says the Liberal leader. The Ministry of Health has over-purchased some personal protective equipment (PPE) during the pandemic and some of it may have expired without being used. Between March and December 2020, Quebec spent over $3 billion on medical supplies through untendered contracts. In the emergency, masks were paid seven times the normal price. Quebec is refusing to disclose details of its spending on COVID-19 and the commissioner of the Unité permanente anticorruption (UPAC) is looking into contracts signed on the sidelines of the pandemic. the Liberal leader is calling on the government to explain and account for its spending on the pandemic. "We need to ensure that spending is justified and that contracts are awarded fairly," she said. She also stressed that the government must be transparent and accountable in its spending and contracts. "We need to make sure that public funds are used responsibly and that contracts are awarded fairly," she added. She also stressed that the government must be vigilant in ensuring that contracts are awarded to companies that provide quality products and services. "We must ensure that contracts are awarded to companies that offer quality products and services and that are able to meet the needs of Quebecers," she said. She also stressed that the government must ensure that contracts are awarded to companies that respect the laws and regulations in force. "We must ensure that contracts are awarded to companies that respect the laws and regulations in force and that are able to provide quality products and services," she concluded."

titre: Sans statut autochtone, Suzy Kies démissionne du Parti libéral du Canada
texte: The self-proclaimed "keeper of aboriginal knowledge" left her position just before the leaders' debate so as not to interfere with Justin Trudeau's campaign. Suzy Kies was co-chair of the Liberal Party of Canada's Aboriginal Peoples' Commission. She is pictured here with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in 2018. Photo: Facebook/CPA Suzy Kies is no longer co-chair of the Liberal Party of Canada's Aboriginal Peoples' Commission. In a statement released to the media, she announced her resignation in the wake of the controversy over her false Aboriginal identity and the outcry over her involvement in the book-burning project in Ontario schools. I refuse [...] that my story be used to harm Justin Trudeau and our party," wrote Suzy Kies. Radio-Canada revealed on Wednesday that Suzy Kies is not Aboriginal. She does not have legal Indian status, she is not listed in the Abenaki band council records, which she claims, and she has no Aboriginal ancestors in seven generations, back to at least 1780. Despite this information, Suzy Kies says her family conducted genealogical research in the early 1990s. That research, she explains, confirmed that we were of Abenaki ancestry. It confirmed what my grandmother had always told us. The two Abenaki band councils of Odanak and Wôlinak reject Ms. Kies' membership in their communities. titre: Un comité de francisation aux Francos de Montréal, après une enquête de l’OQLF
texte: The Legault government was concerned about the use of English backstage and in the festival offices. L'Équipe Spectra, which manages the Francos de Montréal, owns the M Telus, one of the flagship venues in the Quartier des spectacles. Photo: L'Équipe Spectra No more having to work in English at the Francos de Montréal. L'Équipe Spectra has set up a francization committee to ensure that French is maintained as a working language within the company, Radio-Canada has learned. In June, the Quebec government had mandated the Office québécois de la langue française (OQLF) to verify that the law was respected within the organization of this festival dedicated to French-language song. The event had been embarrassed by the revelations of Radio-Canada on the increasing use of English in its backstage and office areas. Employees and collaborators of the festival, as well as former employees, had denounced the growing presence of English as an internal working language. They testified to meetings held in English, despite the presence of French speakers around the table, and to written or oral instructions sometimes in English only. Six months later, the OQLF completed its investigation, which led it to speak with the company's management, staff members, L'Équipe Spectra subcontractors and associations in the entertainment industry. The Agency concludes that the situation reported in the media was a one-time occurrence and notes that L'Équipe Spectra has taken steps to correct the situation. "In order to prevent a similar situation from recurring, the company has voluntarily set up a francization committee made up of members representing the workers and management. This committee is responsible for ensuring that French is maintained as a working language within the company. In June, the company was the subject of much criticism, particularly among politicians. Contacted by Radio-Canada, L'Équipe Spectra wrote us by e-mail: We stand by the OQLF's statement and [...] we have nothing more to add. Founded in 1977, L'Équipe Spectra manages several of Montreal's major festivals, such as the International Jazz Festival, the Francos and Montreal Highlights. It also owns several concert halls, including the M Telus, the former Métropolis. The Francization Committee set up by L'Équipe Spectra is made up of members representing employees and management. Its mission is to ensure that French is maintained as a working language within the company. The members of the committee are responsible for ensuring that meetings, written and oral instructions, as well as all other internal communications are conducted in French. The francization committee is also responsible for making employees and collaborators aware of the importance of the French language and promoting its use. It is responsible for putting in place measures to encourage the use of French and to ensure that employees and collaborators are comfortable working in this language. The francization committee is an important step towards the promotion and protection of the French language in Quebec. It is essential that companies and organizations committed to the promotion of French take concrete steps to ensure that French is maintained as the language of work. This will contribute to the preservation of the French language and the promotion of linguistic diversity in Quebec.
